Title: Artists across the globe raise awareness about COVID-19
Content:
Hygiene tips on a comic strip

Ways to stay less distracted while working from home

Visual arts and chat session to spread awareness about COVID-19

Government of India releases comic book to educate children

In the midst of these gloomy times, art has been a voice of reassurance for many. And artists around the world are finding different ways to create more awareness about hygiene as well as spread cheer and positivity among the young and old. We bring you a string of artworks that are both quirky and informative…US-based illustrator Nivya Kuriakose’s comic strip reflects on the current situation. “As an artist, I think, this is the least I could do to spread some awareness. So, I decided to present the basic tips to prevent the spreading of COVID-19 in a fun manner, which will attract people’s attention. So far, a lot of people have responded to it, saying it’s both useful and funny,” says NivyaThe work-from-home scenario amid the pandemic serves as the inspiration for Bengaluru-based illustrator Alicia Souza latest artworks. Interestingly, she has been working from home for almost a decade now. “There are so many people I know who are struggling to work from home amid the lockdown, because they are not used to this regime. Since I have been doing this for a while, over time I have developed habits that help you become less distracted and more productive. My latest illustration focuses on those easy-to-acquire habits,” explains Alicia.Artist-activist Baadal Nanjundaswamy, who is known for his pothole art, recently took to social media to spread awareness about COVID-19. “My art talks concentrates on the fact that the coronavirus recognises no border, and that it can affect anyone. As an artist, I feel, it is easier to spread awareness through visual art, since the message gets across more quickly and convincingly. It is one of the best ways to educate people, especially kids, who are more attracted to visuals.”Even the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has found a way to educate kids through comics. They have released a book, titled Kids, Vaayu & Corona. The narrative follows the life of a superhero, named Vaayu, who helps kids to understand what coronavirus is and how it can be kept away. In the book, Vaayu repeatedly tells youngsters not to panic and educates them about social distancing and maintaining hygiene. This book has been conceptualised and written by Dr Ravindra Khaiwal, Additional Professor of Environmental Health — PGIMER — Chandigarh, and Dr Suman Mor, Associate Professor and Chairperson, Department of Environment Studies, Panjab University, while the illustrations are by Sonali Verma and Shruti Govil from Panjab University.

Title: I’ve been in quarantine since I returned home, says Nidhi Subbaiah
Content: When Nidhi Subbaiah went to New York earlier this year, she was looking forward to enriching her craft by attending a few intensive courses, among others, and was all set to return home in time for the Ugadi celebrations. But then, the coronavirus pandemic took hold of the world, and all her plans went topsy-turvy. The actress was hopeful of sticking to her original travel plan, but had to make last minute changes when she heard of flight operations being suspended in India.“I was in New York on March 19, when I heard about restrictions on international flights landing in India from March 22. That meant that I just had one day to find a flight and return home before the ban. I frantically looked up flights and found two Air India flights with lots of seats available. But by the time I got to the payment page of the booking, there were only two seats left on one flight, while the other was no longer available. Luckily, I managed to get a seat,” she says.The rest of the day, adds Nidhi, was nothing short of a blur, as she went into a mad rush of packing and weighing bags. “At the airport, the Air India gate was packed, the line was pretty long, but fast moving. After 15 long hours and lots of controversy theories about how they won’t let people out of the Mumbai airport and how they’re being shipped to government quarantine facilities, all by a medical intern based out of Mumbai who is also a neighbour and made me write down the ‘nicer’ hospitals where I’d be more comfortable, I landed in Mumbai. Nervous and jetlagged, we got off the flight, not knowing what lay ahead,” says the actress.What happened next, took her by surprise. “Everyone was asked to queue up with their masks on. There was a separate queue for people with immediate connecting flights. A medical supervisor would check our temperature, following which we had to cross a barricade, form another queue, where in the most disciplined fashion, nurses were questioning each passenger if they, perhaps, had symptoms of the coronavirus. If none, they would let each out with a stamp on the left hand for mandatory 14-day home quarantine, which specified the date we could step out again, and another on the right hand that said HQ,” Nidhi explains.Before being allowed to proceed for check-in for her connecting flight, the actress, along with other passengers, were also counselled by a doctor about the importance of quarantine and isolation . “We were asked to keep our phones on at all times, as they would be making follow-up calls to check on us,” she says.Since returning home, Nidhi has isolated herself, considering that she lives with her mom, who is nearly 60 years old, and grandmother, who is in her 80s. “Thankfully, my room is on the first floor and has a separate entrance. Food is sent up on a tray and when I want to talk to my mother, we do so by maintaining six-feet distance from each other. I understand the importance of following rules at this time. And no, it’s not about what’s going to happen to you, it’s about what might happen to others because of you. This is our time to protect society and our loved ones and help the country fight this virus, by staying indoors. Stay in, stay safe,” she signs off.

Title: Mysuru artists put up unique installations about social distancing
Content:
This story is from March 27, 2020

Mysuru artists put up unique installations about social distancing

The artist duo urges people to stay at home to contain the spread of coronavirus

Yoganand says, “We had initially started the

Mysuru artists Yoganand L and Hari Prasad are leaving no stone unturned to educate common people about the need to stay at home to contain the spread of coronavirus . A day after Janata Curfew, it was business as usual in the heritage city, which prompted the artist duo to raise more awareness about social distancing . Equipped with masks and their specially-designed installations, both Yoganand and Hari visited several localities in the city — including Devaraja Market, Nanju Malige Circle, KR Circle and Devaraj Urs Road — appealing common masses to stay indoors.Yoganand says, “We had initially started the campaign on March 18. At that time, not many people were aware of extremity of this deadly virus. Even though the knowledge and awareness has increased now, many are still too stubborn to acknowledge the gravity of the situation, and that is why things are slowly going out of control every passing day. We want to tell people the urgent necessity to remain indoors.”

Title: #CoronaLockdown: Workouts keep Arun Vijay busy
Content: For a fitness-conscious person like Arun Vijay , this lockdown and self-quarantine is proving to be a good break. Here are a couple of things that keep the actor busy...Doing workouts at home is nothing new to me as whenever we have outdoor shoots, I work out in the hotel room or use the space outdoor. So, during this quarantine period, I am using my space on the terrace. I skip, do ab crunches, pull-ups/push-ups... then, there are dumbbells.Since I’ve always been shooting outdoors, I get very less time to spend with my family. My kids, too, are having online classes. So, I sit with them and help them out. I also play indoor games with my son and daughter. My son has also been playing a spa game with me, where he applies lotion and cream on my face. Well, it turned out to be successful.

Title: Nayanthara, Trisha & Nazriya ace latest fad
Content: We are always up for challenges. Be it to defeat the Coronavirus pandemic, or to ace the ones on social media. While new challenges keep surfacing online every other day, the one that’s piqued the curiosity of our celebs now is #GestureChallenge Though the challenge is at least three months old, it has gone viral only recently, thanks to several people — who are working from home because of Corona crisis — taking it up to break the monotony. From Hollywood stars to B-Town and K’wood celebs, and sports icons, everybody’s been attempting to get the challenge right.Closer home, Nazriya pulling off the gestures like a pro while her husband Fahadh Faasil looks on ‘cluelessly’, Nayanthara and Vignesh Shivan synchronising their movements (like the much-in-love couple that they are) and Trisha acing the challenge not once, but twice, have gone viral. So, are you guys ready to crack the #GestureChallenge?

Title: The world steps up to help the elderly during lockdown
Content: Counted among the most susceptible lot during the coronavirus outbreak, it is important that elderly people stay at home to ensure they are in the best of health. However, being by themselves, having to tackle household chores and, at the same time, keeping themselves engaged and entertained can be taxing for many. Let’s take a look at how people around the world are doing their bit to make sure that the older generation is cared for at this time…In Spain, military personnel were spotted helping an old woman who was struggling to carry a heavy bag of groceries back home. Meanwhile, in Yorkshire, people have been asked to hang red-coloured flags at their windows to indicate that they need help with essentials — shopping, medication or transport. Many are also using social media to reach out to senior citizens who need assistance. In Bengaluru, too, a group of volunteers in Whitefield is reaching out to the elderly and helping them as and when required.With outsiders refrained from visiting the elderly at a healthcare facility in Belgium, an AI firm has instead sent robots equipped with video-calling software to help them interact and stay connected with their near-and-dear ones during the lockdown.Games and other activities being organised at care homes is not unheard of, but people playing Hungry Hungry Hippos sitting in their wheelchairs at this nursing home in the UK makes for a heart-warming sight.At a facility in Japan, the elderly residents reportedly continued with their fitness sessions by following videos on the internet. In India, actor Rishi Kapoor, too, featured in a video keeping up with his workout session in a similar manner.Times are tough, but if you’ve got a goofy significant other by your side, anything can be handled. At least, that’s the mantra of this quirky elderly couple. Twitter user, @janeytrill, shared how her parents, who’d planned to head out on a cruise, turned their quarantine into an experience. They watched a video of the sea on TV, got into their bathrobes, sat back and relaxed, sipping on a glass of their favourite drink. Janey even commented later that the response has been so overwhelming that her parents want to work on a satirical follow-up video of them ‘arriving at the destination’.Physical presence means a lot, even if it is separated by a glass window. A youngster in the US was seen hanging out with his dad from outside the window of a care centre. An employee at the centre took a picture of them and shared on social media, captioning it: “My assisted living is on lockdown so he comes every day to see his dad and they talk through the phone, sweetest thing ever. (sic)”Similarly, in the Netherlands, people gathered outside a nursing home to sing for the elders. In other countries, people wished their aged neighbours on their birthday by singing for them, and on one occasion, placed a cake in front of their home.

Title: Parenting trends that may become popular in 2020
Content: While every parent wants to be the best parent for their children, it’s not easy balancing career and family, juggling responsibilities and managing the needs of children and self. However, today’s parents are more invested, conscious and savvy about their parenting choices and are taking cues from everyone — environmental activist Greta Thunberg to celebrity couple Harry and Meghan. Here’s a look at the parenting trends that may pick up momentum this year…Till recently, not many were aware of the possibilities of environment-friendly parenting, except for going for wooden toys. However, millennial parents have started substituting baby wipes and cloth, using home-made food instead of canned food products and replacing plastic toys with those made of wood and natural colour.This can be a fitting trend for 2020, with parents ready to set aside 20 minutes every day to sit with their children and talk to them about everything under the sun.A pronounced trend in the West, gender-neutral parenting has been on the rise in India. These parents are letting their boys and girls choose the type of toys they want — no more cars for boys and dolls for girls, as urban millennial parents want to break the norm that pink is for girls and blue is for boys. These young parents are also dividing the household chores among themselves to show that there are no gender-specific chores at home. They also choose to narrate stories of inspiring women to tell kids that there is no concept called the weaker sex.The old practice of sitting together and watching television is increasingly being replaced by family games. Many families are finding time to play traditional games and are also buying multi-player gaming equipment for a family bonding session.Harry and Meghan made headlines when they announced to the world that they will stop at two children to help save the planet. Now, many families are gung-ho about the idea— a conscious decision not to have more than two kids so that they refrain from creating a negative impact on earth.Harry and Meghan announced to the world that they will stop at two children to help save the planet. However, the Anti-Natalist movement is all about forcing people to volunteer to not have have kids at all. In a bizarre announcement, a 27-year-old Mumbai businessman, Raphael Samuel, said last year that he plans to sue his parents for giving birth to him without his consent.Though the first menstruation cycle of a girl has been celebrated in India since yore, the West is now trying to emulate the same. There is an increased interest in celebrating their daughter’s first period with red-themed food and drinks to remove the stigma associated with menstruation, and this is an idea that’s likely to become more popular in the UK.Greta Thunberg was noticed by the world when she went vocal about the environment. Many parents have now started encouraging their children to raise their voices about the causes they believe in. Instead of only listening to adults, these children are making sure that their voices are heard by all. No wonder, companies are looking to hire children as consultants and ambassadors to talk about climate change and environment.

Title: Mamta Mohandas: When I found fame, I didn't take it for granted
Content: While for the majority in the country, lockdown started on March 25, actress Mamta Mohandas has been in self-quarantine mode at her home in Kerala since March 17. The actress had travelled from Los Angeles (LA) to Kerala with a halt in Dubai to shoot a music video in the midst of the Covid-19 outbreak.When we catch up with her over a telephonic conversation, she is halfway through with painting her house – a “messy” project to keep her busy during the isolation. Mamta talks to us about her experience filming amid elaborate precautions, tips to make the most of the lockdown time, completing 15 years in the industry and about the much-anticipated Big B sequel, Bilal It wasn’t so bad when I left for Dubai, because my doctors in LA had asked if I wanted to travel at this time. I said as of now there’s no change because I spoke with (director) Amal (Neerad) and he said everything was going as per plan and Bilal's shoot would start on March 21. But the day after I landed in Dubai, everything seemed to have changed. Suddenly, there were talks about places getting locked down and flights getting cancelled.The music video’s director Sachin Ramdas and team had taken permission to shoot in several places and it was very difficult to pull that off. But we did. We had minimum crew. We were also shooting mostly in contained places; we did have outdoor shots but thankfully there weren’t many people at those locations. We avoided public locations such as those close to the Dubai Museum.I am kind of used to functioning when there are few people because where I am living now in LA, there aren’t a lot of people. It wasn’t a shock for me but for those in Dubai it was a big deal, not seeing people around and the roads being less busy.I have been through that phase of cancer multiple times and also had to be in isolation for 30 days through my bone marrow transplant process. Few people would have had to go through that and it teaches you too many things; I wouldn’t ever wish that on anybody. But the least the authorities are expecting from people right now is to take some sort of responsibility, for themselves and those around them. I don’t understand why it is hard for people to stay indoors and find constructive ways to spend time.These are questions I have even asked my mother. She is cleaning all the time and it gets to her so much that she keeps telling others, she cleaned this and that. That is her way of venting all her frustration. I think you need to find a way of giving life to all that energy inside you. There are so many beautiful things that you can do by yourself at home.When I come to Kerala, people always ask me why is it that I find it easier to be in LA than here where I have all the attention and everything I need. It’s because of the chaos in the environment, and it gets into your system as well. As much as we speak about things like yoga and resilience, we haven’t really incorporated that into our lives. This is the right time for it. This is the universe’s way of telling us that it’s time for the entire world to come to a pause.Also, something bad is happening on one side that we have no control over. What we can do is practise washing hands with soap and using sanitisers. Also, to be active you don’t have to go outside or to a gym; all it requires is some self-motivation.It’s a non-film project, so that’s great. Its music director Sachin Warrier approached me, asking if I could lend my voice to the song. I am always happy to sing. A lot of people ask me why I don’t sing. I feel it’s because not many have taken the liberty to approach me for songs. Also, I don’t think it’s right to take up all the offers, I have to be careful about where I go and sing and with whom I record. Singing is something I do purely out of love, and I told Sachin this. I also said that I want to take complete ownership of the project and that they don’t have to picturise it on anyone else but me. We then got a Bollywood team back us and they helped us make the project much bigger.I am a little private about the things that I absolutely love to do. I sing at home for everybody, I sing for myself and even shoot videos of myself singing but I might have posted only 5% of what I have shot. It’s the same with writing. I somehow feel that internalising those experiences makes it way more meaningful for me than putting it out there. That’s probably why you don’t see much of my music. My parents always tell me that everything has a life. Even as an actor, you have a shelf-life in terms of how long you can put yourself out there, but music will be there with you till you die. So, I guess that sort of keeps me complacent.I think perseverance and consistency. There’s also no point in doing a job without self-respect. That’s something you need to maintain in the industry and that promises you longevity. I am a little shy to say this, but my career has never been just mine alone. I have always had my parents fully involved in my activities. I am an only child and so, they do the filtration process for me and keep in touch with everybody. People in the industry say that if Mamta has to know something, her family has to know it too. That has often been the case; I have had my health issues and those times it is my mother that people would end up talking to because I am inaccessible. So, until I bloom again, she’s in the forefront. That has helped me get stronger over time. I didn’t find fame overnight. I don’t think my first few films were even successful. I just maintained the fame, tending to it carefully and not taking it for granted.The script itself had what it took for me to understand Rithika’s character. The film’s co-director and scriptwriter Akhil Paul had also taken a lot of interest to ensure that the character reached me. Apart from that I had the complete script with me and had two months of prep time before the shoot. Taking that long break in 2019 also helped and I was ready for the next big character. There is a way of portraying a Malayali female cop as a rough and tough person. I didn’t want that because a woman is a woman in her position. She is someone else at home and someone else at work. I wanted to maintain that balance.I am thoroughly excited. Big B was Amal’s first film and I am sure once we start shooting we are all going to go back to crazy nostalgia. It’s going to be an experience for us to relish at location. We are all looking forward to it and are excited about the new addition to the cast in Bilal. After all it’s a franchise movie, so Rimi is going to be Rimi, just a few notches better, matured and a little more part of the Kurishingal family. She’s one of them now, rather than being looked at asan outsider.

Title: Here is how Chennai’s college students are dealing with lockdown
Content:
Finishing things which I never had the time for

— Varsha Sriram, final-year journalism student

Looking up ideas to beat boredom

— Sahana Swaminathan, CA student

It took a global pandemic to get us some time off

— Yagna Saravanan, final-year media student

I am editing hundreds of photos that I have clicked

— Sri Loganathan, second-year media student

I have picked up gardening to kill time

— Girish Athreya, first-year architecture student

As the world fights an uphill battle from their homes during this tumultuous time of the Coronavirus pandemic, daily routines have gone out the window. With the country currently under lockdown for the next 19 days, educational institutions, including colleges, have been shut indefinitely. While classes have moved online, calls for social distancing has upended college life and camaraderie. The students, however, who have a half-glass-full philosophy, march on. We caught up with a few, who gave us a rundown on their days.I’ve been home for over a week now and to be honest, I’ve lost my mind. But because I’m in my final year, and we have our final submissions going on, I’ve gotten time to sit down and finish my work properly. The quarantine has made me finish things I never had time for. I’m finally ticking off the movie and book list that I’ve been putting off for a while. Films like Contagion and Pandemic keep things relatable and real. My friends and I have started playing a lot of online games together, like Psych and Quiz Up. We video call each other every day through this app called House party, where we play games and even snack together. Since my dance classes and my cross fit spaces are shut, I am trying to work out at home a little bit.I have never been this idle for the longest time. So, this lockdown period has been really hard. I have been looking up useful ideas to beat this boredom and ended up finding a couple of chores to keep myself busy. I began allocating a lot of time for music and art. Since I am not much of a reader, I binge watch shows including Grey’s Anatomy and Rizzoli and Isles. Apart from learning to paint on canvas, I’m also trying my hand at photography along with my brother.Apart from final-year assignments and submissions, I rely on Instagram and streaming platforms to keep myself busy. Shows like Grey’s Anatomy and Fleabag are keeping me hooked. I’ve also been trying to be more social these days. Whenever someone posts something about the quarantine period, and I reckon they have an interesting take on something, I make sure to hit them up and ask them about the same — something I usually don’t do. While this does come at a bad time given that submissions and exams are right around the corner (especially for final-year students), I think this does reflect a lot upon the education system. This is the first time in many months we’ve had a breather. Basically, it took a global pandemic to get us some time off.Since I am a photographer, I am using this time to edit and collate hundreds of photos that I have clicked. While it is a bit unfortunate that I cannot venture out and click pictures, something that is almost second nature to me, I am trying to look at the positives. Usually, when we look at YouTube videos to learn new things, we hardly pay attention, thanks to hundred distractions. But due to the lockdown, I have come to understand the value of my privilege. So, I am using this time to learn new techniques. My current read is Agni Siragugal. I would normally read around five pages a day. But now I am finishing more than 35 pages a day. This lockdown is really putting things into perspective.This lockdown has had no effect on my classes. It has just shifted from physical classrooms to online classrooms. That is the only difference. On the positive side, I am able to pay even more attention from the comfort of my house. As an architecture student, we have site sheets and plans to submit as part of our assignments. While it is quite tiresome to depict complex site plans digitally, we are slowly trying to get the hang of it. As far as my hobbies go, I have picked up gardening to kill time. I have also dug into Kalki’s five-volume series Ponniyin Selvan. That should keep me busy for quite some time.

Title: Bollywood Quarantined: Arjun Kapoor shares his movie list, Richa Chadha cooks food, Kunal Kemmu plays guitar, Preity Zinta gets a 'champi', Mouni Roy makes a dessert
Content: As India is currently under lockdown to combat the Coronavirus Bollywood celebs have been sharing pictures and videos of what they are doing during the quarantine period. From playing the guitar, sweeping the floor and washing utensils to getting a hair 'champi', celebs are keeping fans updated about their lockdown activities. Arjun Kapoor took to his Instagram to share a video of a list of movies he is going to watching during the lockdown. Earlier in the day, he posted a video of him wearing a mask. Check out the videos here:Richa Chadha shared a post where we can see her cooking at her home. In the caption, she revealed that she shared the video to prove that she can cook!Well, Huma Qureshi made her dad proud by making dinner for him. In the caption, she stated that cooking is in her genes. And from the video, the food looked delicious! Mouni Roy also tried something new as she made a dessert with the help of her friend. The caption revealed that the dessert is called Tiramasu. Check out the video here: Dino Morea who is a fitness enthusiast shared that he didn't workout today as it was a rest day. The actor cleaned his house instead and felt that it was quite therapeutic. Watch it over here: Daisy Shah did some chopped some 'Bhindi' and 'Tamatar' for her meal. She captioned the post, "Moving on from bhindi to tamatar. #selfisolation कुछ भी करो बस घर पर रहो."Kunal Kemmu decided to play the guitar and sing songs of Ranbir Kapoor from the film 'Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani' and 'Ae Dil Hai Mushkil'. And his fans loved it!Preity Zinta shared a video of herself getting a 'champi' (massage) on her Instagram. She captioned the post, "जै माता दी 🤩🙏 Champi once again 👍Making the most of home quarantine 😘❤️🤗 #Day15 #stayhome #staysafe #jaimatadi #ma #champi #navratri 🎥 #mrgoodenough #patiparmeshwar ❤️ #Ting"Meanwhile, COVID-19 has brought the world to a standstill. As there is no cure for the disease, staying at home is the only way left to combat it and avoid the infection.

Title: #CoronaLockdown: Actors happy that they are back with their families in Delhi
Content: At a time when a nationwide lockdown has been announced for three weeks to contain the spread of Covid-19, there are many who feel lucky to be with their families. Among those are also a few TV actors who managed to fly from Mumbai to their hometown Delhi soon after their shoots got suspended (March 19 to 31). "To be trapped alone in a home in Mumbai would have been a terrible feeling," say these actors, who are using this time to bond with their families. For some, this is the longest time they have got to spend with their families in years.On March 15, when it was announced that the shoots will be cancelled, the first thing Karan Vohra did was to book his tickets to Delhi. "That was the time when situation had started getting bad in Mumbai and I knew that if I don't get out of the city right then, I would be stuck. Even though planning a travel was a risk, I decided to take the last (Mumbai-Delhi) flight on March 16 and came to Delhi. The flight that I took was almost empty and it was quite scary to see the situation at the airport," says Karan. He adds, "Being with family right now is such a relief. Ever since I started acting, I never really got to spend quality time with my family. So I am making the best use of this time."It's been over a week now that Mohit Malhotra has been at his Delhi home with his mother. More than anything, he says, it was important for him to be in Delhi to take care of her. "I have been reading so much about coronavirus and precautions that we all should be taking. I didn't want my mother to be alone at such a time. If I would have stayed in Mumbai, I would have only thought about her, so it’s better that I came home to be with her," says Mohit, who has been using this time at home for learning cooking. "I always wanted to learn my mom's recipes, but there was never enough time. Though we are bound to be at home because we are facing a pandemic, I am glad that I am getting to do things that I wanted to do. Chilling at home with my mother is a good experience, too. I have been reading a lot and there are so many movies I have to watch," he adds. Krishna Mukherjee had to come to Delhi to attend an event on March 18. Keeping in mind the growing number of coronavirus cases in the country, she decided to stay back at her sister’s place in Gurgaon. Now that the lockdown has been announced, she will be here for the next three weeks. "I did my dance course from Delhi and stayed here for three years, but in the last six years, I have only come to Delhi for a day or two," she says. She has plenty on her hands to remain busy. "There are no house helps coming now. So my sister and I get up early in the morning and do cooking and cleaning. There's so much work to be done," she says. Arjit Taneja had planned a vacation in the US with his parents from March 17, but due to travel restrictions and considering the spread of coronavirus worldwide, he cancelled his vacation five days before the trip. "After I cancelled my holidays, it was announced that shoots will also be suspended. Social distancing was advised and I thought that if I had to just stay at home in Mumbai and self-isolate, I would go crazy. So, I decided to come home to Delhi and it was no less than an ordeal to get a flight from Mumbai to Delhi on March 17. I spent almost four hours at the Mumbai airport. The flight that I had booked initially was cancelled and the other flight, which I managed to take finally was two hours late," says Arjit, who has been at home for the last one week, He hasn't stepped out at all. He adds, "I spend time with my dog. Since I am home, I am eating a lot and to burn those extra calories, I workout on my terrace. I moved to Mumbai in 2013 and since then, this is the longest time I have got to spend at home."

Title: Imran Khan: Lucknowites witness a rib-tickling play by actor-director Imran Khan
Content: Zara Muskuraiye Aap Lucknow Mein Hai, a humourous play, was staged in the city at Uttar Pradesh Urdu Akademi . The play was based on three hilarious comedies by great writers Munshi Premchand , Anton Chekhov and Saadat Hasan Manto Stills from one of the plays (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)The three plays staged were based on Munshi Premchand’s Ek Rasiya Sampadak, Manto’s Ullu ka Pattha and English writer Anton Chekhov’s Father and Son. Actor and director Imran Khan portrayed the stories in a quirky and contemporary way, making them more humourous. The background score of the play had several Bollywood numbers and shayari being played in the background. The auditorium was filled to its capacity with theatre lovers coming in large numbers to watch the production. The full of fun play kept the audience glued to their seats as they laughed uncontrollably.(L) Abdul Waheed (R) Nighat Khan (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Imran said, “We have been travelling all over India for this play. It is hilarious and we have received much applause for it so far. It has been my privilege to bring it to Lucknow and stage it for the discerning audience here.”— Yashi AgarwalSatya Singh Human and Gaurav Prakash (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Shabina (R) Zafar Nabi and Farida Yasmin (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Title: From cooking to gardening: Parents in UP look for unique ways to keep kids busy during lockdown
Content:
SOME HOME SCIENCE FOR MY KID

(L) Aarav is learning meditation from his parents (R) Devaagyh is learning fireless cooking (BCCL)

DON’T UNDERESTIMATE THE POWER OF YOGA

Hema Bhatia with her son Prajit Bhatia (BCCL)

KIDS’ WALL OF FAME

STRIKING THE RIGHT CHORDS

(L) Meenakshi Srivastava with her daughter Amaya (R) Shiv is learning yoga and meditation (BCCL)

ON A CLASSICAL NOTE

SOME MYTHOLOGY LESSONS FOR THIS KID

With the whole nation coming to a standstill because of the Coronavirus scare, parents are facing a tough time keeping their kids engaged within the four walls of the house. While some are giving cooking classes to their kids, others are resorting to gardening. Parents in cities across the state shared with us some unique ideas to keep the kids engrossed during this lockdown period.Lucknowite Ishna Agarwal Potdar, who has a son aged nine-years has made it a point to keep her son engrossed in productive activities during the time of this lockdown. She says, “It’s very difficult to engage kids these days. They can’t be allowed to watch television shows or cartoons all the time or be given other gadgets to play with. So I’m teaching Vardaan (her son) to sew buttons, ironing small clothes and do other small chores around the house. He’s also learning gardening from his grandmother and his father is teaching him how to wash the car.” Adding further Ishna says, “I’m glad that he wakes up in the morning everyday and does yoga along with his grandmother.”Hema Bhatia, a businesswoman from Kanpur, is teaching cooking to her 10-year-old son Prajit. “I initially started with teaching him how to make tea and some salad. Now that he has learnt to cut salad, I have taught him to make different types of sandwiches. What makes me happy is that Prajit has also shown a lot interest in cooking,” she says.(L) Aarav is learning meditation from his parents (R) Devaagyh is learning fireless cooking (BCCL)Shubhi Tiwari from Lucknow, a homemaker in the city with a seven-year-old son Shivraj, says, “Normally we people whine about scarcity of time or the fact that we aren’t getting to spend quality time with our families. Now that we’re following the lockdown, everyone is actually getting to complete the list of things which we always wanted to do but never found the time for. I’m teaching my son origami these days. Along with this, he does aerobics and yoga with my husband and me every morning. I’m teaching him how to make tea and since the new school session will start soon, he’s also learning how to put covers on the books.”Even for Prayagraj’s Sameeksha Singh , a research scholar, managing her two and a half year old son Aarav is something she doesn’t have to worry about. “My son had joined a play school recently, so after the lockdown the play school has sent some very interesting assignments to be completed by the kids.The students are supposed to do basic yoga asanas like pranayam etc, for which they have sent website links and we in turn have to make a videos of the activity and send to the school. The other activity includes talking to the grandparents making a video call, colouring, etc. So it is quite fun doing all this”, she says.Hema Bhatia with her son Prajit Bhatia (BCCL)Isha Gupta, a research scholar from Banaras, says that apart from my daughter Apramiti, who is four-years-old , my sister in law‘s sons, Atharva and Aarav, both below 10-years, are currently staying with us, so to keep the kids engaged in such a scenario is tough. So I came up with a novel idea and asked them to use one of the walls of the toy room as a canvas. So the kids are painting away to glory. In just few days the wall is covered with their creativity. At the same time we are also asking the kids to help us in household chores, especially cooking. The other night when my daughter felt hungry, I told her to make a French toast and I must say, she did a splendid job. The kids are also being encouraged to tidy their room and clean around the house, with the household staff being on leave, this is also making them appreciate the contribution of the staff,” she says.Kajal Gautam, a home maker from Banaras, who has twins, Saksham and Samriddh, both 10-years old, says, “I try that my kids are not glued to the TV or engaged on their phone all the time. So when their schools got closed, I dug out their guitar, which was lying unused for sometime. Now I make sure that they practice for sometime on the instrument. In case they get stuck on some note, they make a video call to their teacher to clear out things. I also join and sing along, whenever possible.”(L) Meenakshi Srivastava with her daughter Amaya (R) Shiv is learning yoga and meditation (BCCL)Kanpurite Meenakshi Srivastava is also making efforts to keep her four-year old daughter Amaya entertained and busy during the lockdown period. “Amaya has a lot of interest in dancing and I am utilising this time to teach her classical dance. Both Amaya and I first watch some videos of classical dance and then we try copying the dance moves. Earlier, Amaya used to mostly dance on Bollywood numbers but now she is grooming herself in classical dance and she is really enjoying this change,” shares Meenakshi.Rashi Dixit Ahuja, a Lucknowite, is making use of the time by giving her kids lessons in Hindu mythology. “Kids are full of energy at this age. So for keeping them engaged not one activity is enough. So apart from giving my six-year old son some lessons in gardening and fireless cooking, every day, both my husband and I also read out lessons from the Ramayana and the Mahabharat turn by turn. I don’t think he would have otherwise got these lessons from us had it not been for the lockdown. But now after getting tired doing gardening and cooking, he relaxes hearing some good mythological stories from us,” she shares.— With inputs from Yashi Agarwal

Title: #CoronaLockdown: Actors happy that they are back with their families in Delhi
Content: At a time when a nationwide lockdown has been announced for three weeks to contain the spread of Covid-19, there are many who feel lucky to be with their families. Among those are also a few TV actors who managed to fly from Mumbai to their hometown Delhi soon after their shoots got suspended (March 19 to 31). "To be trapped alone in a home in Mumbai would have been a terrible feeling," say these actors, who are using this time to bond with their families. For some, this is the longest time they have got to spend with their families in years.On March 15, when it was announced that the shoots will be cancelled, the first thing Karan Vohra did was to book his tickets to Delhi. "That was the time when situation had started getting bad in Mumbai and I knew that if I don't get out of the city right then, I would be stuck. Even though planning a travel was a risk, I decided to take the last (Mumbai-Delhi) flight on March 16 and came to Delhi. The flight that I took was almost empty and it was quite scary to see the situation at the airport," says Karan. He adds, "Being with family right now is such a relief. Ever since I started acting, I never really got to spend quality time with my family. So I am making the best use of this time."It's been over a week now that Mohit Malhotra has been at his Delhi home with his mother. More than anything, he says, it was important for him to be in Delhi to take care of her. "I have been reading so much about coronavirus and precautions that we all should be taking. I didn't want my mother to be alone at such a time. If I would have stayed in Mumbai, I would have only thought about her, so it’s better that I came home to be with her," says Mohit, who has been using this time at home for learning cooking. "I always wanted to learn my mom's recipes, but there was never enough time. Though we are bound to be at home because we are facing a pandemic, I am glad that I am getting to do things that I wanted to do. Chilling at home with my mother is a good experience, too. I have been reading a lot and there are so many movies I have to watch," he adds.Krishna Mukherjee had to come to Delhi to attend an event on March 18. Keeping in mind the growing number of coronavirus cases in the country, she decided to stay back at her sister’s place in Gurgaon. Now that the lockdown has been announced, she will be here for the next three weeks. "I did my dance course from Delhi and stayed here for three years, but in the last six years, I have only come to Delhi for a day or two," she says. She has plenty on her hands to remain busy. "There are no house helps coming now. So my sister and I get up early in the morning and do cooking and cleaning. There's so much work to be done," she says.Arjit Taneja had planned a vacation in the US with his parents from March 17, but due to travel restrictions and considering the spread of coronavirus worldwide, he cancelled his vacation five days before the trip. "After I cancelled my holidays, it was announced that shoots will also be suspended. Social distancing was advised and I thought that if I had to just stay at home in Mumbai and self-isolate, I would go crazy. So, I decided to come home to Delhi and it was no less than an ordeal to get a flight from Mumbai to Delhi on March 17. I spent almost four hours at the Mumbai airport. The flight that I had booked initially was cancelled and the other flight, which I managed to take finally was two hours late," says Arjit, who has been at home for the last one week, He hasn't stepped out at all. He adds, "I spend time with my dog. Since I am home, I am eating a lot and to burn those extra calories, I workout on my terrace. I moved to Mumbai in 2013 and since then, this is the longest time I have got to spend at home."

If I would have stayed in Mumbai, I would have only thought about her, so it’s better that I came home to be with her," says Mohit, who has been using this time at home for learning cooking. "I always wanted to learn my mom's recipes, but there was never enough time. Though we are bound to be at home because we are facing a pandemic, I am glad that I am getting to do things that I wanted to do. Chilling at home with my mother is a good experience, too. I have been reading a lot and there are so many movies I have to watch," he adds.Krishna Mukherjee had to come to Delhi to attend an event on March 18. Keeping in mind the growing number of coronavirus cases in the country, she decided to stay back at her sister’s place in Gurgaon. Now that the lockdown has been announced, she will be here for the next three weeks. "I did my dance course from Delhi and stayed here for three years, but in the last six years, I have only come to Delhi for a day or two," she says. She has plenty on her hands to remain busy. "There are no house helps coming now. So my sister and I get up early in the morning and do cooking and cleaning. There's so much work to be done," she says.Arjit Taneja had planned a vacation in the US with his parents from March 17, but due to travel restrictions and considering the spread of coronavirus worldwide, he cancelled his vacation five days before the trip. "After I cancelled my holidays, it was announced that shoots will also be suspended. Social distancing was advised and I thought that if I had to just stay at home in Mumbai and self-isolate, I would go crazy. So, I decided to come home to Delhi and it was no less than an ordeal to get a flight from Mumbai to Delhi on March 17. I spent almost four hours at the Mumbai airport. The flight that I had booked initially was cancelled and the other flight, which I managed to take finally was two hours late," says Arjit, who has been at home for the last one week, He hasn't stepped out at all. He adds, "I spend time with my dog. Since I am home, I am eating a lot and to burn those extra calories, I workout on my terrace. I moved to Mumbai in 2013 and since then, this is the longest time I have got to spend at home."

Title: Imran Khan: Lucknowites witness a rib-tickling play by actor-director Imran Khan
Content: Zara Muskuraiye Aap Lucknow Mein Hai, a humourous play, was staged in the city at Uttar Pradesh Urdu Akademi . The play was based on three hilarious comedies by great writers Munshi Premchand , Anton Chekhov and Saadat Hasan Manto Stills from one of the plays (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)The three plays staged were based on Munshi Premchand’s Ek Rasiya Sampadak, Manto’s Ullu ka Pattha and English writer Anton Chekhov’s Father and Son. Actor and director Imran Khan portrayed the stories in a quirky and contemporary way, making them more humourous. The background score of the play had several Bollywood numbers and shayari being played in the background. The auditorium was filled to its capacity with theatre lovers coming in large numbers to watch the production. The full of fun play kept the audience glued to their seats as they laughed uncontrollably.(L) Abdul Waheed (R) Nighat Khan (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Imran said, “We have been travelling all over India for this play. It is hilarious and we have received much applause for it so far. It has been my privilege to bring it to Lucknow and stage it for the discerning audience here.”— Yashi AgarwalSatya Singh Human and Gaurav Prakash (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Shabina (R) Zafar Nabi and Farida Yasmin (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Title: Ruslaan Mumtaz: Everything went smoothly and we are proud parents now
Content: Actor Ruslaan Mumtaz and his wife Nirali became proud parents of a baby boy, yesterday. While the actor is ecstatic about the birth of his bundle of joy, he cannot forget the long hours of anxiety preceding it.Ruslaan told BT, “It was a normal delivery and the baby was born at 4 am on Thursday. Around 9 pm on Wednesday, Nirali went into labour and all of us panicked because we had to rush from our Juhu home to the hospital, which is located at Marine Lines. Due to social distancing, we didn’t take any of our family members with us. We did not see a single person on the road and it was quite eerie. I was scared that we might be stopped by the police, but luckily, nothing happened and we reached the hospital in half an hour. Nirali’s father, who is a radiologist at the hospital, was already waiting for us when we reached. The hospital was also empty, with only the staff members present. Thankfully, everything went smooth and we are parents to a lovely baby boy.”He added, “We will be in the hospital for two days. Due to the lockdown, my parents and other family members will not be able to see the baby. We had finalised a nanny, but now, due to the lockdown, we are planning to do everything on our own. The hospital staff was very efficient, but I was extremely worried about how we are going to manage it.”The actor is happy that he was home when his wife needed him the most. He said, “I was shooting for a film in Karjat when the lockdown happened, and I returned home on March 13. Otherwise, Nirali would have had to call me from Karjat when she went into labour. My mom (actress Anjana Mumtaz ) is at home to help, but I want to be a hands-on father. I was feeling bad that I could not be with Nirali in her last month of pregnancy, but now that I am at home, I will make the most of it. We plan to watch online videos to learn more about handling a newborn.”In an earlier interview, Ruslaan had said that Nirali and he had decided on names for a baby girl. He said, “Now, we will have to sit down and think of a good name for the baby. I had many names ready for a girl, but not a boy.”

Title: GALLANTRY AWARDS, UNIT CITATIONS AND SURYA TROPHIES AWARDED IN A SOLEMN CEREMONY HELD AT BAREILLY
Content:
Central Command Investiture Ceremony 2020 was conducted under the aegis of Headquarter Uttar Bharat Area at Kargil Hall, Bareilly Cantonment in a five-day event, where Lieutenant General IS Ghuman, PVSM , AVSM , General Officer Commanding-in-Chief, Central Command presided over the ceremony and felicitated 16 officers and 10 other ranks from all over India with gallantry and distinguished service awards, in the presence of serving Army personnel and special invitees including the families of the awardees. These officers and other ranks have been felicitated for various acts of gallantry in the face of enemy as well as exceptional devotion to duty and service to the nation.

The awards presented included Fifteen Sena Medals (Gallantry). Amongst all the most prominent was the gallant act of Lance Havildar Vijay Kumar of 23rd Battalion, The Parachute Regiment, who kept the highest tradition of the Armed Forces and made the supreme sacrifice while fighting terrorists in Jammu & Kashmir. For his gallant action and exceptional courage, he was awarded with Sena Medal (Gallantry) which was received by his wife Smt Suman Devi in the solemn ceremony.

Other gallant men who were awarded with highest ‘Sena Medal-Gallantry’ by Central Command for their war operations, exceptional duty and their journey of observing death so closely, while finally emerging out as real and true heroes, for their sense of duty, sheer determination and love for their country were Major Ritesh Sangwan , 14 Rashtriya Rifles (Garhwal Rifles); Major Yogesh Pandey, The Corps of Engineer/9 th Batallion the Rashtriya Rifles; Major Soham Bhattacharjee , The Corps of Engineer/ First Batallion The Rashtriya Rifles; ) Major Shakti Singh, 23rd Battalion The Parachute Regiment; Major Ravi Kumar , The Bihar Regiment/ 47th Batallion The Rashtriya Rifles; Havaldar Bhupendra Singh , 23rd Batallion The Parachute Regiment; Havaldar Nagendra Singh Rawat , 6th Batallion The Garhwal Rifles; Lance Havaldar Sandeep Kumar , 23rd Batallion The Parachute Regiment; Lance Havildar Vijay Kumar , 23rd Batallion The Parachute Regiment (Prosthmous); Naik Daljeet Singh , 10th Batallion The Jammu and Kashmir Light Infantry; Lance Naik Sombir , 23rd Batallion The Parachute Regiment; Sepoy Sushil Singh Kalakoti , The Kumaon Regiment/ 50th Batallion The Rashtriya Rifles; Rifleman Preetam Singh , 6th Batallion The Garhwal Rifles; Paratrooper Ashutosh Singh , The Garhwal Rifles / 4 Vikas (Special group), and Paratrooper Gurwinder Singh, The Parachute Regiment / 31st Batallion The Rashtriya Rifles.

Army Commander also bestowed “Central Command Unit Citation” to 12 units for their meritorious and outstanding performance. The Army Commander while speaking at the ceremony congratulated all the awardees and recipients of unit citations and exhorted all ranks to emulate the awardees and give their best in all spheres to make sure the Indian Army’s flag flying high at all times.

Title: Regulatory recall of defective vehicles to attract penalty for manufacturers
Content:
NEW DELHI: Mandatory recall of defective vehicles or components will not only cost the manufacturers or importers as they will have to rectify or replace them, they will also face a risk of paying up to Rs 1 crore fine, according to a draft notification issued by the road transport ministry.

For example, recall of six lakh plus two-wheelers or one-lakh plus four wheelers will attract the maximum penalty of Rs 1 crore, as per the draft norms. If the manufacturer or importer identifies the defect and starts voluntary recall process, it won’t face any penalty.

Though the trigger point for regulatory recall is yet to be defined, sources said there will be two parameters. For high end or less manufactured or imported vehicles, complaints or reports of defects in "certain number of vehicles" will be the trigger point to initiate mandatory recall process.

For popular models where the number of vehicles produced is very high complaints equivalent to 10-12% of production would trigger authorities to initiate recall policy.

The ministry, in the draft norm, has defined the detailed process for investigation into complaints, designating authority who can order recall based on investigation report and suo motu as well. However, there will enough checks and balances including giving enough time to the manufacturer or importer to respond before any penal action or mandatory recall is ordered.

“Necessary precautions have been taken to ensure that rivals or competitors among industries can’t use mass compliant trick to target each other. All those lodging complaints will have to provide several details. The entire process will be online for greater transparency,” said an official.

The proposed norms also specify how the authorities and testing agencies would ensure that the manufacturers and importers of vehicle models or components are adhering to compliance of production (COP), which means the products are as per the approved prototype.

Title: Khichdi becomes the star of #lockdown kitchens
Content: They say, when life gives you lemons, make lemonade. But what are you supposed to do when you’re locked down for weeks on end with bare minimum kitchen essentials to survive through a global pandemic? We say, make khichdi. After all, when cooking has become a necessity for even the uninitiated, what can possibly be a better bet than the companion for all seasons — fasting or feasting. Its versatile nature, high nutritional value and bare-minimum ingredients make the humble comfort food a one-stop dish to keep Indians across the length and breadth of the country united in this hour of acute crisis. So, at a time when many are grappling to stock up on basic food items to keep their kitchens running while several others are making the most of their self-isolation days cooking up a storm in the kitchen with #khichdi flooding oursocial media timelines, let’s understand why this one-pot meal is our saviour.The word khichdi often conjures up images of a rather simple dish made of rice and dal. But its journey is far more complex. While rice and lentil remain the basic ingredients for this versatile dish, almost every part of the country has a unique way of cooking it and those variations make it all the more interesting. From the spicy bisi bele bath in Karnataka and the quintessential Bengali khichuri to the Haryanvi khichdi with pearl millets and the comforting Gujarati khichdi served with kadhi — this wholesome dish is your go-to option when pantry stocks are limited but you are in no mood to compromise on taste as well as nutrients.Pongal: This variation of khichdi is popular in the southern states of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka. It’s made using moong or toor dal and rice or millet. There’s a sweet version as well.Khichuri: Usually prepared using Gobindobhog rice and moong dal, khichuri is often served with dollops of ghee in Bengal. During monsoon, it is accompanied by ilish maachh bhaja, making the dish nothing short of a delicacy.Bisi bele bath: A favourite in Karnataka, it is said to have originated in the Mysore Palace and Vellore Fort. This hot and spicy rice-lentil preparation goes well with boondi, potato chips and chutney.Adahengu khechidi: This ginger-asafoetida version is popular in Odisha and also served at the famous Jagannath Temple in Puri.Vaghareli khichdi: This popular Gujarati variant is served with kadhi.Khichdi is considered to be a healthy dish as the main ingredients — lentil and rice — offer protein and carbohydrates. “Khichdi is a great option if you are looking to maintain a balanced diet. Pulses have amino acids and rice gives you carbs. Also, it is easy on the tummy since the dish is low on spices. But that is applicable only for the vegetarian variation. The non-vegetarian options are heavier,” says dietician Sohinee Seal.According to Mumbai-based food consultant Rushina Munshaw Ghildiyal, having a dal-rice meal once a day is important. “This is a staple food for Indians since ancient times. I suggest adding a handful of veggies in your khichdi. I am making khichdi every three-four days. Also, this quick and nutritious meal fits the budget. It is the easiest meal to jazz up with pickle, papad and so on,” she says.“What makes khichdi this popular is the wide availability of rice and dal all over the country,” says Kolkata-based chef Sambit Banik, adding, “Areas that yield less rice replace it with millet, jowar, bajra or dalia.” Health-conscious millennials swear by khichdi made of oats to avoid gluten. “And these are just the basics. In case you want to add meat in it, make khichra. When it comes to being imaginative, sky is the limit with this dish,” he exclaims. Tanu Mehra, a Bengaluru-based home chef, sais, "For me, khichdi is like going back to basics. Not only does it require limited pantry resources, it also saves time, fuel and energy. This one-bowl meal has all the nutrients your body needs."If you’re bored of having the same khichdi over and over again, it’s time to add some twist. According to chef Ritabrata Biswas, you can give this traditional Indian recipe an Italian touch and turn it into risotto. “Since we all are judiciously using the ingredients at hand, make do with what you have. Get some aromatic short-grain rice like Gobindobhog. Put mustard oil in a pressure cooker, add kalonji (nigella seeds) and dry red chilli. Then add rice. Stir for a while before adding water — one ladle at a time to get the risotto texture. Once the rice is almost cooked, add pre-boiled urad dal to it. Season it well. You may want to add a bit of cheese or butter on top,” the chef explains.The British kedgeree — a rice dish cooked with flaked fish, parsley, hard-boiled eggs, curry powder, butter or cream and raisins — is thought to have its origin in khichdi. It is widely believed that the dish was brought to the UK by British colonials returning from India, who had enjoyed it here and introduced it as a breakfast dish in the UK in Victorian times, part of the then fashionable Anglo-Indian cuisine.One serving of khichdi (approx 225 gm) cooked with 40 gm raw rice, 35 gm pulses and a dollop of ghee will have:485 calories15 gm protein12.5 gm fatLast year, Kareena Kapoor Khan had revealed that khichdi is her comfort food and she likes to have it frequently.On the occasion of Gudi Padwa on Wednesday, Bollywood filmmaker Ashwiny Iyer Tiwari took to her Insta profile to share this pic of sabudana khichdi along with a detailed post explaining how ‘#stayathome has made me realise the warmth of ingredients’. Lately, celebrity chefs too have been sharing innovative khichdi recipes online

While there is no scientific evidence that the coronavirus was first transmitted from a bat to a person who might have consumed the animal, actor Emraan Hashmi made such a case in his latest tweet with mock conviction."And all this because some person thousands of miles away wanted to have a freakish culinary experience like eating a BAT," tweeted Emraan Hashmi, venting ire on someone in the faraway Chinese city of Wuhan who might have consumed an infected bat to contract COVID-19, and then pass it on to others, thereby planting the seed of the ongoing global pandemic.Meanwhile, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has declared a 21-day national lockdown to stem the spread of the virus.On the work front, he will be next seen in the film 'Chehre' co-starring megastar Amitabh Bachchan

Title: Coronavirus package India: Cash transfers, free foodgrains for poor in Rs 1.7 lakh crore corona package
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: The government on Thursday announced a Rs 1.7 lakh crore package focused on emergency cash transfers into bank accounts of the poor, along with providing free foodgrains, pulses and cooking gas for three months in a bid to cushion them from the impact of the coronavirus lockdown and economic disruption caused by the disease.Announcing the relief measures, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman , however, did not touch on loan concessions or support for the corporate sector and middle class, saying other concerns would be “considered separately”. It is expected that more measures aimed at helping business could be on the anvil. Two days ago, an extension in compliance deadlines relating to GST and income tax filings had been announced.The elements of Thursday's announcement, such as free grains, is a departure from the government’s usual stand against handouts but is seen as a response to an unprecedented crisis caused by the Covid-19 spread on the Indian and global economy and the displacement caused by the ongoing 21-day national lock down. “We have first tried to reach the poorest of the poor so that they don’t have to worry about how to feed their families,” the minister said, adding that as things develop the government will come back with more steps.With most elements of the package in place for three months, the government seems to expect that the coronavirus crisis will stabilise by end-June. Recognising the contribution of medical professionals in the current crisis, there will be a special insurance scheme for doctors, nurses, other health workers, safai staff and Asha workers dealing with coronavirus cases with a Rs 50 lakh cover in case they meet with an accident.Earlier, the government limited the first exercise to easing compliance burden for individuals and companies, while waiving some of the fees that banks charge. The current package adds up to around 0.76% of the GDP estimate for the next financial year.

Title: Rate of rise in positive cases ‘relatively stabilising’: Govt
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: The government said on Thursday that the rate of increase in positive cases of Covid-19 has “relatively stabilised” in the last few days even as it stressed that there was no room for complacency and alertness had to be maintained with determined implementation of a national lockdown.The health ministry reported 43 new cases and four additional deaths in the last 24 hours, taking the number of confirmed cases to 649 so far, of which 593 are active cases and 42 were cured and discharged, whereas one case was migrated. Total deaths due to Covid-19 now stand at 13.“Though the number of cases is increasing, we are seeing a relatively stable trend in the rate at which cases are increasing or a little bit of reduction in the rate of increase,” joint health secretary Lav Agarwal said. He added that the country was “fully geared up” to fight the virus.In an indication that the Centre continues to view the threat as grave, health minister Harsh Vardhan held a detailed review with state counterparts in the afternoon that lasted more than two and a half hours. The discussion centred on states with high numbers, with others gleaning tips on how to prevent and combat such situations.The discussion drilled down to preparedness of hospital facilities and the efficacy of the contact tracing and quarantine exercise. At the government briefing, Agarwal emphasised it was too early to read a clear trend, requiring the government as well as citizens to maintain alertness and full adherence of the lockdown.Besides, compliance of guidelines and protocols issued by the government for social distancing and other measures will help maintain the trend and overcome the problem, he said. The government also said that there was no “hard evidence” of coronavirus pandemic having reached the community transmission stage in India and added that India continued to be in stage 2 of localised transmission.

Title: Heat may slow coronavirus but early summer unlikely
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: Many Indians have been praying for an early onset of peak summer this year in the light of some studies that have shown that transmission of Covid-19 infections may slow down in high heat. That hope may be dashed, with met department forecasts showing that the chances of summer setting in early are low.Temperatures across most of India are likely to remain below normal at least over the next two weeks, the India Meteorological Department ’s extended range forecast reveals. The forecast, which gives weekly outlooks for the next 28 days, shows that the probability of the mercury hitting 40°C, even in central India, are low till the second week of April.Summer arrives earlier in south and central India than the north because these regions are closer to the equator. “Several parts of north and central India rainfall are likely to get rain over the next two-three days under the influence of very active back-to-back western disturbances (WDs). Again, next week, some rain is expected in north India, particularly over the Himalayas ,” said Mrutyunjay Mohapatra, head of IMD.Mohapatra added that temperatures aren’t expected to rise significantly over most parts of India over the next two weeks or so. A recent analysis by scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology had shown that coronavirus infections may transmit at the slower rate in places where the weather is hot. The study is not definitive, nor has it been peer reviewed.In general, the high summer period in India sees the least number of virus infections.

Title: Day 2 of lockdown: Truckers abandon vehicles, delivery boys fret about safety
Content: NEW DELHI: Two days into a 21-day lockdown, India’s hugely disrupted supply chain for essential commodities struggled to get going in the face of a fresh set of challenges — truckers abandoning vehicles on highways, manufacturers running out of inventory and delivery agents of e-tailers refusing to venture out for fear of police harassment — even as state governments and local authorities appeared to remove some of the roadblocks that had stalled the distribution network on the first day.Transporters’ associations and members of the Agriculture Produce Market Committee said the Centre's decision to exempt goods trucks from highway toll had made little difference because drivers and helpers had started abandoning stranded vehicles in anticipation of a prolonged logjam.With trucks unable to reach their destinations, wholesale markets have been hit by a shortage of agricultural produce. “Drivers have started abandoning trucks and hiking back home, even if these places are 200-300km from where they are. We request the Centre to urgently ask the states, particularly collectors, to supply food and water to our stranded drivers,” Bal Malkit Singh, chairman of the All India Motor Transport Congress, said.“We are also under lockdown, otherwise we’d be making arrangements for our drivers.” The All India Transport Welfare Association estimates that about 30 lakh trucks are stuck on highways. In the FMCG sector, Britannia CEO Varun Berry flagged the risk of the packaged food industry run ning out of stocks in a week to 10 days if the supply chain wasn’t normalised immediately.“The food industry supply chain is disaggregated and dependent on interstate movement of goods. Due to the nature of the materials, inventories across the chain are low. If even one link in the supply chain is broken, the country could run out of stocks of packaged food in the next 710 days,” he said.Many staples have already vanished from the shelves of supermarkets and local kirana stores. The movement of raw materials has been curtailed too, forcing firms like Britannia, Parle and Unibic to cut production. Britannia CEO Varun Berry’s remarks have been one of the strongest by an FMCG firm. Parle had expressed concerns, and Metro Cash & Carry India had said it was unable to open its wholesale stores because of police threatening its employees.Biscuit maker Unibic, whose sole factory on the outskirts of Bengaluru has been shut since Sunday, has been facing problems in transporting raw material such as palm oil, flavours and cashew nuts for its cookies. In Assam and some other states, many migrant vegetable vendors have returned home as it is unprofitable to set up shop when there's a severe shortage of produce and no capital to buy what's available. Prem Chandra Shah, a wholesale vendor in Guwahati, returned to Bihar on Thursday.“First there was disruption due to anti-CAA/NRC protests and now due to coronavirus . Too many losses in a short span of time,” he said. V R Soundarajan, president of the Koyambedu Wholesale Traders' Association in Chennai, told TOI that about 350 trucks arrive from Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Kerala on a normal day. “Today, only 150 trucks came; everywhere we are hearing stories of vehicles being stopped at state entry points. About Rs 1.2 crore worth of flowers from Karnataka were dumped today on the Bengaluru-Chennai highway With vegetables, we can't even quantify the loss,” he said. The Centre is setting up acontrol room and coordinating with states for entry of vehicles, sources said.A taskforce has been set up to work with state governments on faster issuance of passes inside city limits, and for speedy entry of vehicles through inter-state borders. For e-comm players like Amazon, Flipkart, BigBasket, Grofers, Swiggy and Zomato, getting curfew passes to resume operations is no longer the only challenge. While the police authorities in metros like Delhi, Mumbai and Bengaluru have assured them of curfew passes, these companies are now facing issues in taking new orders and fulfilling the existing backlog. (Contributions by Rachel Chitra, Digbijay Mishra, Madhav Chanchani, Avik Das in Bengaluru & Pankhuri Yadav & Paras Singh in Delhi)

Title: Coronavirus curfew on bad air: Pollution levels decrease in Varanasi
Content: VARANASI: After nationwide lockdown, the city registered a dip in air pollution on Thursday. Reason: No communting and industrial activities led to better air quality.At a time when the novel coronavirus has wrecked a havoc on human health and lives across the globe, the efforts to check its spread has brought a positive impact on environment particularly after the lockdown.“We can notice a significant improvement in air quality not only in Varanasi but other places too due to the imposition of lockdown in the country. The vehicular exhausts and industrial pollutants, which are the major source of air pollution, have been stopped. Obviously, it resulted in improvement of air quality, which is good to human health to fight against the coronavirus,” said noted environment scientist of Banaras Hindu University Prof BD Tripathi The data of the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) suggests that the air quality in most of the cities, which used to breath in bad air, has witnessed a significant improvement. Varanasi, which had witnessed 378 Air Quality Index (AQI) in very poor category in the beginning of January, recorded 135 AQI (moderate) on Thursday. A day after Janta Curfew the city’s AQI was 99 (satisfactory) on March 23.More or less similar was the condition in other cities including Kanpur and Lucknow, which were in the categories of ‘good’ and ‘satisfactory’ respectively. Kanpur’s AQI was 50, while Lucknow recorded 91 AQI. Out of 102 cities in CPCB’s AQI Bulletin only two cities -Muzaffarpur and Guwahati had ‘very poor’ air with AQI 216 and 214 respectively. While 22 cities were in ‘Good’ category, 14 were in ‘moderate’ and 64 cities were in ‘satisfactory’ categories. Mandideep was the cleanest with 29 AQI in the country.The ‘Good’ AQI (0-50) has minimal on health, ‘Satisfactory’ (51-100) category suggests minor breathing discomfort to sensitive people, ‘Moderate’ (101-200) causes breathing discomfort to the people with lungs, asthma and heart diseases. The ‘Poor’ AQI (201-300) makes breathing discomfort to most people on prolonged exposure, while ‘Very Poor’ (301-400) AQI causes respiratory illness on prolonged exposure. The ‘Severe’ (401-500) category AQI affects health people and seriously impacts those with existing diseases.Prof Tripathi said that such a situation came after the restriction on public and private transport, including autorickshaws, taxis, and all inter-district and inter-State transport buses, railways and air service.

Title: Tharus barricade villages around Valmiki Tiger Reserve
Content: BAGAHA: People belonging to Tharu tribes residing in around 50 villages located in and around Bihar ’s lone tiger reserve, Valmiki Tiger Reserve in West Champaran , have set an example in the lockdown period.To prevent the curb of Covid-19 virus, they have blocked the entry and exit routes of their villages. The villages in Tharuhat area in Bagaha- II block of West Champaran district including Daruyabari, Santpur, Sohariya, Devataha, Mahuyawa Kataharawa, Sonagarhwa, Mahadeva, Bharchhi, Jarar, Malakauli Narayanpur, Khajuria, Majhauya Narayangarh and Bakuli among others have cordoned the entrance route to their villages by putting up nets and bushes. Entry and exit from the villages are allowed only in emergency cases.Tharu Welfare Federation president Deep Narayan Prasad said, “The resolution to voluntarily cordon off the village was taken unanimously by the tribals to prevent spread of Covid-19 and ensure everyone’s safety.”Meanwhile, Bagaha SP Rajiv Ranjan appreciated the decision of the tribals and asked other villagers in the district to follow the same to curb the spread of Covid-19.

Title: Bihar hospitals to dispose corona biomedical waste through CBWTF
Content: PATNA: The Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) has issued advisory to hospitals and pathological units of the state to follow the new guidelines for disposal of biomedical waste generated from the isolation wards and quarantine zones made for Covid-19 suspects and confirmed patients.The hospitals engaged for the test and treatment have been asked to strictly collect and dispose the wastes from these wards under the common biomedical waste treatment facility(CBWTF) available in Patna Muzaffarpur and Gaya, BSPCB chairman A K Ghosh said.The advisory was circulated through emails to both government and private hospitals linked with the BSPCB.Ghosh said as the biomedical wastes from isolation and quarantine wards were extremely hazardous, these would be collected in dedicated yellow coloured bags. The containers and trolleys used for their handling and carrying would prominently be marked with the labels of ‘Covid-19’ and these should be regularly cleaned and disinfected by sodium hypochlorite solution.The hospitals concerned were directed to share information regarding setting up of isolation wards, sample collection centres and designated labs to the BSPCB so that the latter could monitor their system for disposal of Covid-19 biomedical waste, he said.

Title: ‘No scarcity of food, water for Patna zoo inmates’
Content: PATNA: Amid the 21-day nationwide lockdown to contain the spread of Covid-19 , the district administration is ensuring that the inmates of the Sanjay Gandhi Biological Park, commonly known as the Patna zoo , get food, water and health care facilities on time.Environment, forest and climate change department principal secretary Dipak Kumar Singh told this newspaper on Thursday that the home ministry on Wednesday issued fresh guidelines covering additional people and services, who would be exempted from the lockdown.“Staff and workers, who look after zoos, nurseries, wildlife, fire fighting in forests, watering plantations, patrolling and their necessary transport movement, are also exempted from the purview of the lockdown now,” Singh said and added, “We have more than five crore plants in our nurseries and if no one looks after them for three weeks, they will be destroyed.”Face masks have been provided to the 60 zoo staff are working in three different shifts to take care of the animals. Zoo director Amit Kumar said, “We have a deep freezer to store fish that come in bulk from Andhra Pradesh. The district administration is also supplying fresh items like beef, mutton, chicken, fruits and vegetables for the zoo inmates.”In 1979, the state government had declared the zoo as an ‘essential service’ under the Bihar Essential Services Maintenance Act.“Under this Act, the zoo staff are granted leave on the basis of duty rosters. In fact, only the Patna and Delhi zoos have been notified as essential services,” Amit said.This is the second time that the zoo has been shut for visitors for such a long time. Earlier, it was closed for 49 days from December 25, 2018 to February 11, 2019.Meanwhile, the zoo staff are carrying out proper sanitization of the premises regularly. They said the animals were relaxed and enjoying the peaceful environment with no visitors around.

Title: Covid-19: Bajaj pledges Rs 100 crore, Godrej Rs 50 crore
Content: MUMBAI: The Bajaj Group has committed Rs 100 crore to India’s ongoing fight against the coronavirus disease. The funds will be used to upgrade “key” healthcare infrastructure, provide basic essentials to the needy and to support economic aid programme in rural areas. “Working with the government and our network of 200-plus NGO partners, we will ensure these resources reach those who need it the most,” said Bajaj Group chairman Rahul Bajaj.The Godrej Group has earmarked Rs 50 crore for community support and relief initiatives. “This is an initial outlay and we hope to supplement it over time,” said Godrej & Boyce chairman Jamshyd Godrej in an e-mail to employees.Bajaj, the vehicle maker-to-financial services provider, is the fourth enterprise to set aside Rs 100 crore to combat the outbreak in the country. Earlier, Vedanta, Axis Bank and Hindustan Unilever pledged Rs 100 crore each for public healthcare and other initiatives.The Bajaj Group will use the funds to upgrade ICUs at government hospitals, procure medical devices such as ventilators (which are in huge demand currently), enhance testing capacities and to set up isolation facilities. The healthcare infrastructure support will be mainly in Pune, where the group is headquartered, and in nearby areas.
