Sources said a group of five youths who were marching from Madhya Pradesh’s Gwalior towards their native place were made to crawl and jump by a constable at Nawada crossing of Budaun district on Wednesday morning for allegedly violating the lockdown. In the viral video, two persons could be seen crawling while carrying their bags on their back and a constable who was armed with two lathis could be heard telling them to jump. Three more youths crawling at some distance could be seen in the video.

“A group of youths who are in their 20s came from Gwalior and were humiliated by a constable on duty. The youths who were migrant workers were walking towards Bareilly city,” said a police official.

Budaun SSP Ashok Kumar Tripathi said, “The incident occurred at Nawada crossing, which connects five roads, under Civil Lines police station of Budaun. An under-training constable, who is also under probation, posted at Civil Lines police station did it. Apart from this constable, a few senior constables and sub-inspectors were also on duty there and were checking other vehicles at Nawada. When these senior cops learnt about the constable’s act, they scolded and stopped him and removed him from duty.”

He added, “Being police chief of Budaun district, I feel sorry and am ashamed because such an act should not have been done. The SP (city) will probe the matter and action will be taken accordingly.”

Like these group of youths, many migrant workers, mostly daily-wage labourers, are forced to walk hundreds of kilometres to their native villages after nationwide lockdown. Most of them are walking on an empty stomach in the heat. On Thursday, 17 migrant workers who covered a distance of over 300 kilometres on foot from Ghaziabad and reached Shahjahanpur beating hunger and restrictions laid down by police. However, their journey is still long as they have to cover a distance of nearly 400 kilometres to reach their hometown in Basti.

Vijay Kumar Gautam, 23, who started marching on Tuesday, told TOI, “After our factory got closed following lockdown, we had no food and no medical facility near our premises. It is better to fight against the pandemic disease with our family members rather than living alone and dying of hunger.”

He added, “During our journey, we receive mixed treatment from police as we were welcomed with batons at someplace while we were offered bananas and biscuits at a few locations.”

Another worker Rajesh Kumar said, “We didn’t get much help on way here as a a few people thought we might be infected with novel coronavirus because we came from Ghaziabad.”

Later on Thursday afternoon, this group entered the border of Lakhimpur Kheri district where police provided them lunch and ensured their medical check-up with the support of medical teams.

Lakhimpur Kheri CMO Manoj Agarwal said, “We have screened all the migrant workers and no suspected case was found so far. We are screening all the labourers who have recently reached to make sure that no one is carrying the symptoms of the pandemic.”

Title: Inter-state goods movement off to a crawl
Content:
Hyderabad: After the nationwide lockdown brought inter-state movement of goods to a grinding halt, Thursday saw an easing of movement of trucks carrying essential goods into the state.

“Till yesterday, we had several complaints from our members across the country about their goods being stuck at borders of various states, but today the movement seems to have eased up a bit. We have been working with the government on the issue,” FICCI national president Sangita Reddy told TOI.

But transporters complained about long queues of trucks stuck outside the state’s borders at checkposts due to lack of clearance by local authorities. The Hyderabad Goods Transport Association (HGTA) has also written to the Telangana government seeking resolution of the issue at the earliest.

“There are about 150-200 trucks each stuck outside Telangana’s borders. The orders passed by the central and state government are not reaching the staff at checkposts. Police are stopping vehicles and in panic many drivers have abandoned vehicles at checkposts. Others are still stranded without food or water at checkposts,” HGTA president Sandip Guppta said.

However, Additional DGP (Law & Order) Jitender said all vehicles from neighbouring states carrying essential goods are being allowed into Telangana without any hassle. “Union cabinet secretary also held a meeting with state governments and gave directions to allow free movement of transport vehicles,” Jitender said.

Title: No symptom, man in Kerala tests positive for coronavirus
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A 45-year-old man who had come from Dubai but showed no symptoms has tested positive for Covid-19 in Pathanamthitta. This has created a cause for concern for the district administration and health authorities.A totally asymptomatic person in home quarantine in Adoor tested Covid-19 positive on Wednesday. Following this, there has been a demand for testing samples of all people under observation in the district.“This person had never developed any symptoms, including fever or cough. But his samples were taken since there were widespread complaints that he was defying quarantine guidelines and was moving around. It was a surprise when he tested positive,” said district collector P B Nooh.This has proved that a person can become Covid-19 positive even if he has no symptoms. At present, there are 7,361 people under home quarantine in the district, said the district collector.In this case, the Adoor native who reached the state capital from Dubai via Bengaluru had visited many places in his hometown. The district administration has released the route map of this person to identify all who came in contact with him.The demand for testing of samples of all people under home quarantine has gained momentum. “No two patients are alike. Different people carry different kinds of dynamics. Hence, we cannot always claim that everyone will carry the same kind of symptoms. In this case, there might have been some mild symptoms or he might have taken some drug for fever. All these might have suppressed the symptoms,” said Dr Amar Fettle, state nodal officer, infectious disease.The health authorities have taken random samples from people under home quarantine in the district and have sent for testing. A few of the results have tested negative. Hence, there is no need for concern at present, said district health authorities.

Title: 'Fresh ready reckoner rates once Maharashtra is free of Covid-19'
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat on Thursday said publication of this year’s Ready Reckoner (RR) rates has been postponed in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak in the state.

“Revenue department officials are busy with their health department counterparts tackling the coronavirus crisis. The Ready Reckoner rates will be published only after the state is free of Covid-19,” Thorat told TOI.

“The revenue department had almost finalised the Ready Reckoner rates. It needed a fortnight more to wrap up the procedure. The existing Ready Reckoner rates will continue till the new structure is announced,” he added.

The Ready Reckoner rates, which are prices of a residential property, land or commercial property for a given area, are published on March 31 every year and implemented from April 1. All calculations related to real estate, such as stamp duty, registration, premiums and tax collection, are based on the Ready Reckoner rates.

Referring to the developers’ request to the government to not increase this year’s Ready Reckoner rates, the minister said the rates would be rationalized.

“This is likely in areas with high rates,” Thorat said, though he refused to divulge more details.

A senior official in the revenue department said though the rates have never been brought down in the past, the state government was working towards rationalization of the prices. In the last two years of the previous BJP-Shiv Sena government, there was no hike in the Ready Reckoner rates. The last time the Ready Reckoner rates were hiked in Maharashtra was in 2017-18.

Property registrations at 27 offices in the city and Pimpri Chinchwad have already been stopped as a part of the social distancing strategy to check the spread of coronavirus. Realtors have written to the state government about the overall slump in the sector and also how the Covid-19 outbreak has affected real estate sector.

Thorat has, in the meantime, told the district collectors to ensure that agriculture work was not affected during the lockdown period.

“Harvesting machinery have reached the state from Punjab. There should be adequate fuel supply for the functioning of the machines. The administration has to ensure that movement of vehicles with essential goods remains hassle-free,” he said.

Title: Rajasthan excise staff to donate 5-day salary
Content: KOTA: Around 25,000 employees of the state affiliated with Rajasthan Aabkari Seva Sangh have decided to donate five days’ salary to Chief Minister’s Covid-19 Fund.Appreciating the measures taken by the state government to prevent the spread of Covid-19 and to extend relief to the needy in times of emergency, the president of the Sangh and assistant excise officer, Kota, Parmanand Patidar said the members of the Sangh have decided to contribute five days’ salary from the monthly pay to the CM’s fund. He has written a letter to the chief minister in this regard on Thursday and requested him to accept the contribution from the Sangh, Patidar said and added that around 25,000 employees affiliated to the Sangh would contribute.

Title: Sagar medical college gets Covid-19 lab, kits & training awaited
Content: BHOPAL: Much needed COVID-19 testing laboratory was set up at Bundelkhand Medical College (BMC) in Sagar district on Thursday, said Sagar collector Preeti Maithil Nayak . It is one of the first centres outside Bhopal, Gwalior, Indore and Jabalpur to get the COVID-19 testing facility. So far all samples sent for testing of COVID-19 suspects from the district to other centres in MP have been negative, she added.“We have set up the bio-safety extraction equipment; the equipment for PCR testing for COVID-19 has also been installed. After training and receiving kits, COVID-19 testing will begin here,” said BMC’s associate professor and COVID-19 nodal officer (testing), Dr Sumit Rawat.The machine, ‘Bio rad real time PCR’ can test up to 90 samples per day, said Rawat. BMC is a full-fledged tertiary medical college in Sagar district; it was established in 2008. The college imparts the degrees of MBBS and PG courses. Nursing and para-medical courses are also offered here. Of the 700 beds in the hospital, 360 beds would be for COVID-19 facility. Gynaecology , paediatrics, surgery and other departments and their patients have shifted to district hospital.It is one of 157 DHR/ICMR laboratories for helping in sample collection for COVID -19. MGM Indore lab began testing this week. Sagar laboratory has also been added to the centres to test for COVID-19.

Title: 11 approvals granted for units at GIFT city
Content:
Ahmedabad:As many as 11 entities on Thursday received approval to set up units in the special economic zone (SEZ) at Gujarat International Finance-Tec City (GIFT City), Gandhinagar.

Interestingly, the GIFT SEZ development commissioner granted the approvals through teleconferencing as the applicants could not remain physically due to the nationwide lockdown .

“Today through teleconferencing we could approve 11 new units in GIFT SEZ and have put in place a new process for the approval of units,” said A K Choudhary, development commissioner, GIFT SEZ The majority of companies that got getting approvals operate in the IT and ITES sector. They include names like Azura Technologies, Ajmera Infotech, Applie Infosol, Shrine Technologies, Silent Infotech and Omega Cyber World.

“We at GIFT are always ready to provide solutions to businesses so that in difficult times they get support for new units in GIFT City and ensure business continuity for operating units,” said Tapan Ray, MD and Group CEO, GIFT City.

With tax breaks on setting up SEZ units set to end on March 31, there was a rush of IT and IT-enabled services companies to set up base in GIFT City’s multi-services SEZ, which also houses an International Financial Services Centre (IFSC).

On March 16, total 17 companies got approval to establish units in the GIFT SEZ, which was already home to 180 units.

GIFT SEZ is one of the fastest growing services SEZs in India, having total exports of services worth around Rs 3,740 crore as on February this fiscal.

The SEZ also houses international exchanges of BSE and NSE, a global delivery centre of Bank of America, units of 13 major banks, 17 insurance entities and other services exporters.

Title: South Central Railway keeps freight trains running to transport essential commodities amid crisis
Content:
Representative Image

AURANGABAD: While all passenger trains have been stopped in the wake of the fight against the spread of Covid-19, freight train services are being run by Indian Railways to transport essential commodities in order to meet the needs of the nation, an official release said.

Commodities being transported by the zone include coal for various thermal plants to ensure uninterrupted power supply in the region, petroleum products, grain and milk.

“The South Central Railway (SCR) has been at the forefront of the endeavor and the zone has run over 200 freight carrying trains every day till Tuesday and the operations will continue,” chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh, said.

“Despite the lockdown, SCR keeps the wheels moving. It has been possible on account of the commitment and duty mindedness of the workforce of the SCR deployed at various goods sheds, stations and control offices besides on field duties,” SCR authorities said.

Indian Railways has slashed the demurrage and wharfage rates for goods and parcels to half of the prescribed rates till the lockdown. The free time for loading/unloading of wagons and free time for removal of consignment from railway premises has been increased to double of the prescribed free time till the lockdown.

On the sidelines, continuous cleaning activity and sterilization of passenger coaches, railway stations and other premises is also being undertaken by the railway staff.

“Close coordination is being maintained with the state governments so that rates of essential commodities are handled smoothly without delay, amid various restrictions imposed in the wake of COVID-19,” SCR officials said, adding that extensive coordination between various departments is enabling the zone to ensure that the workforce handling various tasks, report and perform their duties with a strong motto to serve the national interest in difficult times.

Title: UT adviser’s suggestion tweet bombarded with complaints
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: UT adviser Manoj Parida on Thursday took to Twitter to ask the city residents about improvements required in services rendered by the administration in the wake of 21-day lockdown. He wrote, “Hi Chandigarh, any improvement in service? Bad news can be given in polite words too.”

Soon thereafter, complaints started pouring in.

Navdeep Sharma from Dhanas wrote, “No improvement in Dhanas (Milk Colony). I am still waiting for vegetables and announcements for their delivery through police van or other medium.”

The DIG traffic replied, “For peripheral areas, special teams have been constituted. They are loading supplies. Delivery will be done in a short while.”

A resident of Sector 28, Anubhav wrote, “Vendor for Sector 28 is unresponsive. Not able to procure milk, vegetables and ration. It leaves us with no choice except going out of the house, which I don’t want to! Please help.”

The residents also raised the issue of limited stock available with vendors. “Although the lockdown is a good idea, there is a shortage of vegetables with the vendors and no fruits are available, eg vendor for Sector 35 has only limited supply of potatoes, onions and taro root (arbi). Also, he is not able to distribute properly,” wrote Nishant Alhawat .

Sanjeev of Sector 56 said, “No vegetable and essential item supply in Sector 56 since imposition of the curfew. I have to collect medicines for my parents from CGHS dispensary in Sector 45, but not able to do so.”

A resident of Sector 41, Nikhil, said there was no improvement in his area as he got only two packets of milk after standing for an hour in queue.

From Butrela village Pradeep Chaudhary wrote, “Please provide multiple vendors for Buterla village as in one building almost 31 families are living on rent. A single vendor cannot serve the purpose.”

While describing the situation of Sector 40C, Abhishek Vashishta said, “Bus stopped at one place and remained there for over an hour while people stood in lines without maintaining distance.”

On soaring prices, city resident Amit Garg said, “Black marketing is going on, vegetable vendors are selling at soaring prices. Those delivering groceries are asking for a minimum Rs 2,000 bill. This is absolute chaos. My suggestion would be to give curfew passes to all grocery stores else it will become a nightmare.”

Title: Vasco vendor held for hiking vegetable rates
Content:
Representative image

VASCO: A vegetable vendor who hiked prices was arrested on Thursday after a video showing him indulging in the malpractice went viral.

On Thursday, though vendors were warned against opening shops, Nagaraj Uppar, 23, from Magor Hill, was found selling onions and potatoes at Vasco market at Rs 100 per kg.

Title: Elderlies, students dial control room for grocery deliveries, cooked food
Content:
Dehradun: The Dehradun district administration has started a helpline for senior citizens and students to help them with essentials like food and groceries during the ongoing lockdown.

District magistrate Ashish Kumar Srivastava said that they are publicising the numbers of the control rooms along with the contacts of the nodal officers who can be contacted by senior citizens, students and anyone in need of help regarding supply of daily necessities.

For senior citizens, the designated nodal officer is Ganesh Kandwal who can be reached at 9412052143 whereas for students, the nodal officer is Sonia Pant who can be contacted at 9411228683.

The helpline service began on Thursday and was soon flooded with calls .

Talking to TOI, Ganesh Kandwal, designated officer for the senior citizen helpline, said, “ We are trying our best to send to people who are calling ration and groceries through our teams that are working in several parts of the city. Students, too, are facing difficultly in moving out and getting food. We are also helping them."

The official claimed that some senior citizens are also in distress, due to their health condition and want to have food cooked with particular ingredients only.

In addition, people involved in the work of providing of items specified in the list of necessary goods like medicines are also being issued passes for which a specific number of police control room has been issued.

Officials added that bookings for home delivery can also be made on the website https://dehradun.gov.in.

The deliveries will be made at the doorstep of residents till 6 pm.

Meanwhile, for regular and hassle-free supply of goods to the people, the district administration along with Dehradun police have identified 670 shops under 18 police circles for providing the supplies of daily need products.

Apart from the administration, some social organisations have also joined in to provide essential goods and food items to the daily wagers and others who are in need of help.

City-based NGO Waste Warriors for instance is providing hand wash and ration to daily wagers and sanitation workers of the municipal corporation.

Title: Supply of grocery improves in Jaipur
Content: JAIPUR: Majority of the grocery stores in Jaipur that had been complaining of curtailed supply were a bit satisfied with the improvement in supply on Thursday.All the retailers across the city were getting a refill of their stock. On the contrary, they had only a few customers as they said that customers have already bought their stock of grocery for at least two months. However, due to curtailed supply, the prices of vegetables witnessed a rise of 30%.TOI on Thursday visited various markets in the city to know the status of supply and procurement at grocery shops. “We have got a pass issued for the movement our vehicles across the city by police,” said a wholesale dealer involved in supplying of wheat flour at Chandpole Bazaar.The retail shopkeepers said they have ample supply, but there has been an increase in the prices of goods by the wholesale dealers. “There is a minor rise in prices of pulses, refined oil and wheat flour. However, we have now got enough quantity to cater to the needs of the customers for at least one week,” said Sunil Goyal, a retail grocery store owner in Khatipura.However, grocery stores had less footfall compared to the earlier panic buying. “It appears that the customers have bought enough stuff. Apparently many of them have got grocery for the next two months, which is the reason why we have fewer customers,” said Bharat Agarwal, a grocery store owner in Vaishali Nagar.Meanwhile, the prices of vegetables have witnessed a rise of 30% due to curtailed supply from other states including Andhra Pradesh, Himachal Pradesh, Punjab and Haryana. “Things will improve when we start getting vegetables from other states too. Presently, a few vehicles from other states are arriving,” said Pappu Lal Prajapat, president of Fal Sabzi Thok Vyapar Mahasangh.

Title: People hesitant about booking train tickets even after April 14
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A looming haze on rail services after the lockdown has left people in two minds about booking or re-booking tickets for dates post April 14.

Private firm employee Kumaresh Prasad cancelled trip to his hometown in Patna this week amid lockdown and is now confused about booking the tickets for later dates. “I had booked two-way tickets on the Pune-Danapur Express to travel on March 18 and 30. However, in the wake of the lockdown, I am not sure about booking tickets for later dates. I believe staying at home is the best option for now,” he said.

Though the Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) website states that people could book tickets for dates after April 14, Railways officials were not sure if train services would resume completely after the 21-day lockdown period. “We don’t have any information on whether the lockdown will end on April 14 or be extended,” an official from the Pune rail division said.

The IRCTC said people need not cancel their e-tickets as full refunds would be generated. The Pune rail authorities requested people to not rush to cancel tickets purchased from the counters as refunds would be issued till June 21.

“We had planned a trip to Shimla in May and had booked tickets accordingly. We have decided not to book tickets even if the lockdown ends,” Koregaon Park resident Shridhar Adkar said.

Sources in the IRCTC told TOI that future bookings were expected to be on the lower side. “After the coronavirus scare is over, no one will immediately get into their regular routine. Travel will take a back seat unless it is urgent,” a source said.

Title: Delhi News: Keep stores with essentials open 24x7: Delhi government
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi government has urged establishments dealing in essential goods and services to function 24x7 to ensure steady supplies during the national lockdown . After a meeting at the lieutenant governor’s office with officials on Thursday, the state government decided to allow e-commerce platforms to deliver essential supplies, including food, pharmaceuticals and medical devices, to homes.The government has started issuing colour-coded e-passes to allow easy movement for those engaged in essential services. The 1031 helpline number for electronic passes was heavily congested on Thursday. The government, therefore, created an online platform, epass.jantasamvad.org/epass/init/, for the purpose. Former Delhi University teacher and football commentator Novy Kapadia, 67, who lives in Naraina Vihar, was among those who couldn’t get through on 1031. “I called over 10 times and also tried the online platform, but didn’t succeed in getting a response. My medical helper needs to travel from Wazirpur to my house every day and needs an e-pass,” the ailing Kapadia said.The number of total lines available on the helpline has been increased to 30. Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, mindful that even this wouldn’t be enough, said, “We have requested police to allow essential service providers without e-passes to proceed while the government works to provide the passes to such people."At a press conference with LG Anil Baijal, the CM instructed the SDMs and area ACPs to ensure shops selling medicines, milk, vegetables, groceries and other essential items were kept open. “We have also asked these officials to ensure that the factories manufacturing essential goods are kept operational,” Kejriwal said.Delhi government announced that there would be no restrictions on movement for e-commerce platforms providing essential services. “The company ID cards of their delivery executives will be accepted as proof and they will be permitted to travel,” the CM said. The LG has directed the district magistrates and DCPs to facilitate e-commerce operations.Kerjriwal also said that doctors and medical workers involved in managing Covid-19 cases will regularly undergo screening. The number of testing centres in Delhi has been increased. The mohalla clinics will continue to provide healthcare services in neighbourhoods too. Referring to a doctor at one of the clinics testing corona positive along with his wife and daughter, the CM said, “While it is a sad incident, the rumour that because of this every mohalla clinic will be closed is completely false information. We will ensure each mohalla clinic is fully functional at this challenging time.”He continued, “The central government, Delhi government, police and the residents of Delhi are working together to combat this pandemic. Most of the people are following the instructions and staying indoor, but we have seen cases of violations of the lockdown orders. I again request every Delhi resident to observe the lockdown order.”

Title: Over 300 vans to deliver food at your doorstep in Varanasi
Content: VARANASI: On the second day of lockdown, district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma on Thursday flagged off the delivery vans from Pahadiya and Visheshwarganj mandis to deliver essential commodities to the public.As many as 325 four-wheelers and 412 delivery men have been engaged for home delivery of essential goods.Besides, 50 individuals and organisations have also been engaged to supply food packets to people trapped in the city after lockdown.The DM made an appeal to office bearers of vyapar mandal to cooperate regarding the supply of essential commodities. He along with SSP Prabhakar Chowdhary also inspected the Sigra vegetable market.He also instructed officials to arrange shelters and food for those trapped at different places in the city.The DM appealed to people to support lockdown by following guidelines and government instructions and social distancing completely to prevent the spread of corona virus. He also warned against action on the violation of prohibitory orders.For the convenience of public several control rooms have been created, which include Corona control room (0542- 2508077, 8114001673, 911981954), food supply/integrated control room (0542- 2508585, 9415064193), Police control room (112/7311150648, 0542- 2414150), CCR 9454401645, and DCR (9454417477).More than 40 cases of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) have been reported in Uttar Pradesh , prompting the Centre to announce a 21-day lockdown.

Title: Online delivery services to resume as cos get permission to deliver essentials
Content: Hyderabad: Inundated with complaints about local police imposing restrictions on the movement of delivery staff of online food and grocery players, the Director General of Police M Mahendar Reddy issued instructions to all the three commissionerates in Hyderabad to facilitate the movement of such delivery staff to ensure uninterrupted distribution of essential commodities.“All the officers of Hyderabad police, Cyberabad police, Rachakonda police, have been directed that following online delivery services Grofers, Milkbasket, BigBasket, Zomato, Swiggy, Spencers etc.. shall be allowed to operate their services from 6am to 6pm only,” the DGP said in a late Wednesday night tweet.Through a series of tweets on Thursday, he also urged online delivery companies to follow certain rules for proper identification of goods transport vehicles and delivery staff to facilitate hassle-free movement. Post lockdown, deliveries by online delivery companies were disrupted after they suspended operations due to restrictions on the movement of their delivery staff.Telangana industries & IT principal secretary Jayesh Ranjan said all the online food and grocery services providers have been granted permission on Thursday.“All the food and grocery delivery players have been given approvals so now they have to set their house in order. BigBasket was given permission on Wednesday and it resumed services with milk deliveries on Thursday. All the others like Flipkart, Grofers and Amazon got approvals through the day today,” Ranjan said.According to Ranjan, the state government has received 35,000 applications for passes from 11 categories that have been identified, including milk, vegetables, meat and fish, LPG, petroleum and newspapers, where there is some kind of supply involved. The process of issuing passes has already begun and will continue till Friday afternoon, Ranjan said.

Title: Jaipur: MLAs can sanction up to Rs 5 lakh from their fund
Content:
Sachin Pilot, Deputy chief minister

JAIPUR: Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot on Thursday said that legislators will now be able to sanction up to Rs 5 lakh from MLA-LAD fund for purchase of equipment required for investigation and examination of coronavirus-infected patients and other necessary items.

He said with this amount, equipment like infra-red thermometer, personal protective equipment for medical workers, thermal imaging scanners, corona test kits, ICU ventilators, masks, sanitisers and other items, can be purchased.

Earlier, the MLAs could sanction Rs 1 lakh each in their respective assembly constituencies for free distribution of masks and sanitisers.

Title: Take it or leave it: Some cash in on hard times
Content:
People practise social distancing

NEW DELHI: Amid erratic supply of items in the hour of crisis, several retail stores and vendors are selling the essential commodities at inflated rates. People, who are forced to buy these items at double the prices or even more, are complaining that the vendors are cashing in on the lockdown. TOI takes a look at the situation across the city.

“As no delivery services were available, I had to step out of the house to get some vegetables on Wednesday. All supermarkets were closed, and with great difficulty I was able to locate one greengrocer in the entire Acharya Niketan market. Potato that I bought at Rs 20 per kg a few days ago was available for Rs 50 per kg,” said 25-year-old Isha Banerji, a resident of Mayur Vihar Phase I.

“I had gone to buy vegetables and foodgrains. The store did not have long queues, but I was shocked to see that the prices of the items had been doubled. When I asked him about it, he chose to ignore the question. Whoever objected to the inflated rates, he told them that they could either buy the item at the revised price or leave it. We could afford it, but what about those who can’t,” questioned Jyoti Yadav, a resident of Janakpuri B Block.

The poor are in for trouble as many are not able to pay for basic items like pulse and rice. The problem is severe in west, east, south and southeast areas where several people shared instances where they were charged double the usual price of the item.

Rohan Sharma, a resident of Alaknanda, said, “A pack of 20 cigarettes is for Rs 300 on a regular day. Now, they are being sold for Rs 400 at some places. The local vendors are closed because of the lockdown, so it's only available with a few departmental stores.”

Title: Mapusa, Candolim take cue from Panaji, to start grocery delivery
Content:
SALIGAO: In a move that will bring relief to Mapusa residents, the municipality has decided to commence a grocery home delivery service within its jurisdiction in the wake of the 21-day nationwide lockdown.

Mapusa Municipal Council has divided the town into five zones, each of which has been designated a vendor who will undertake deliveries from Friday. It has urged residents to place orders for essential groceries between 9am and 11am, and tender exact change. Deliveries will be done the same day, at no extra cost.

Residents living in complexes should collect the items at the entrance of their buildings, the municipality said.

Candolim panchayat has draw up plans for commencing home delivery service which will begin from Saturday. Villagers can place orders from 9am to 5pm, and there will no delivery charges.

Title: Liquor fee deposit date extended
Content:
Jaipur: The excise department on Thursday extended the date for deposit of licence fees for 2020-21 keeping in mind the prevailing difficulties brought on by the spread of coronavirus.

The retail liquor shop applicants who had been selected through a lottery system were supposed to deposit the fees on March 27. But the department has extended the date to March 31.When asked if there is a chance to open the shops even for a limited time, a senior official said that the only concern is that they don’t want crowds to gather. He said that a couple of states, like Kerala and Punjab have classified liquor as essential item that means it is available there, but Rajasthan has not taken a decision on that. “It is the government which needs to decide, but we are clear that we cannot allow crowds at liquor shops,” said the official.

There is fear that absence of genuine liquor may push people, especially in rural areas, to produce country liquor illegally. “We also have that in mind. Any unregulated illegal production and consumption is not without risks. We are keeping a vigil on that,” said the official.

Title: Closure of district borders, lockdown reduce migration
Content:
Kolhapur: The Centre’s decision to implement 21-day lockdown and the Maharashtra government’s move to seal the borders of all districts has brought down the number of people returning to their native villages in western Maharashtra.

Statistics available with health departments of Satara, Sangli, Kolhapur and Solapur indicates that the number of people, who arrived in their jurisdiction, is on a decline as compared to last week.

The government has made it mandatory for all those moving towards their native villages to register their names with local authorities. In addition, village-level committees have also been instructed to keep a watch on the movements of guests.

Officials involved in this exercise said that stoppage of public transport, including ST buses and railways, had indicated to people that they had to stay put wherever they were. Screening at all entry points and police action has curbed temporary migration.

In many villages, people have blocked the roads by putting up barricades or boards, sending strong message that guests were unwanted in the village. Such incidents, even though not welcome, have had impact, said the officials.

Administration, however, is concerned as it is a tough task to monitor the movement of thousands of people, who have shifted to their native places. In Kolhapur district alone, more than 41,000 people have registered themselves. All of them were taken to the nearest primary health center and those with symptoms were further admitted to hospital.

People coming from outside Kolhapur district have been asked to stay in home quarantine for 14 days even if they do not show any symptoms of COVID-19. Health teams were putting stamp of home quarantine on their hands so that they can be easily identified to ensure social distancing. In 89 villages of Gadhinglaj taluka of Kolhapur district, 5,671 people have been registered till Wednesday night. Kagal, 30 km away from Kolhapur and close to Karnataka border, as many as 3,500 people have been identified in the category. Around 3,000 people in Shirol taluka have registered their names with local authorities.

In Mahabaleshwar, district administration has set up a separate cell considering large number of people coming for medical checkup. Many people from Jawli and Wai are settled in either Mumbai or Pune for employment and majority of them have returned.

Solapur municipal corporation has started a facility under which guests can fill their online information. Kolhapur municipal corporation has also started an app for the convenience of such people.

In Panhala, an offence has been registered against a man and his son for defying home quarantine order. They were found moving in a village. Ratnagiri police traced a couple, who was asked to be in home quarantine in Mumbai, but came down to Ratnagiri. The couple has been kept in isolation in Ratnagiri.

Title: Covid-19 grabs away popular Kerala fest - Thrissur Pooram
Content: Thrissur: The nationwide lockdown has created a shadow over Thrissur Pooram too.The preparation meeting of Thrissur Pooram which was scheduled on April 1 was again postponed in the wake of nationwide lockdown.The outbreak of Covid-19 will affect the Pooram too, said officials. The Thiruvampadi and Paramekkavu devaswom officials are plannig to conduct the the fest only as a ritual.Thiruvambady devaswom president P Chandrasekaran said, “In the present situation, there is less chance to conduct the pooram.” Paramekkavu devaswom secretary G Rajesh said, “Currently, we have stopped all pooram-based preparations. During pooram we need 65 sets of umbrellas for the Kudamattam ceremony.. However, we have stopped making it."“The two -month-long pooram exhibition too has been cancelled," he said.Cochin devaswom board president A B Mohanan said, “In the wake of nationwide lock-down, all the temple festivals under the devaswom board have been canalled with immediate effect. Earlier, we decided to conduct Peruvanam and Arattupuzha poorams as rituals. But now we decided to cancel them completely.”The cancellation of Pooram has also hit vendors in the town. “With the start of the Pooram season, we will usually get huge business. The pandemic has destroyed our hopes,” said Lathif, who runs a hotel in Thrissur.

Title: Virus couldn’t stop this mall guard from helping people
Content: Jaipur: This mall in Jhotwara is one of the biggest in the city. But for the last five days, this shopping arcade has been wearing a deserted look.The mall, which on any other day is abuzz with hundreds of visitors, now has a handful of people who are looking to stock up essentials from the super market, the only store which is open.Helping visitors load their items into their cars is Abdul Rahim, a 25-year-old guard . Most of the visitors thank him, not just for helping them but also continuing his service when the entire country is in a lockdown The strength of guards at the mall has been brought down to less than half. “I had a choice. My employer had asked me if I would like to stay home, but that would have meant a pay-cut. Moreover, somebody has to do this job. As far as I am physically fit, I would not want to sit back,” says Abdul, who admits that being the only earning member in a family of five, pay-cut was not something he could afford.“I have two sisters and elderly parents to take care of. But seeing people, particularly the elderly, queue up and struggle for essentials, I am glad I am here and can help them in whatever small way I can. It feels nice when people actually compliment for my service,” he said.Helping customers is not part of his duty, but Abdul likes doing that. When TOI was interacting with him, Abdul spotted an elderly couple with a trolley full of grocery items. He rushes towards them to help. “Itna saman hai, gaadi main rakhva ke aata hun (Lots of goods, let me help load it in the vehicle),” he said. The elderly couple was grateful for his help.For the first three days of the lockdown in the state, Abdul walked 10 km from his home to reach the mall. “I did not have a vehicle pass then, so I had to walk in the mornings and again at night after a 12-hour duty. Cops had stopped me on a few occasions, but seeing my uniform and I-card they let me go.” he said.Adjusting his mask, he added, “People are scared and puzzled. They will spend their time at home provided they get basic things including grocery, milk and vegetables. As the grocery stores are open and my employer needs me here, there is no way I will stay away from duty.”Abdul always wears a mask and makes it a point to wash his hands several times a day. “I make it a point not to shake hands with anybody. After duty hours, I wash my hands and feet with soap before entering and head straight for a bath. Even dinner comes after that,” he said.

Title: Shutters up at Goa horticulture kiosks on Monday
Content: PANAJI: Horticulture outlets which have been shut since March 22 will restart on Monday. “People will not be permitted to enter the outlets. The vendors will have to do home delivery of the groceries within their jurisdiction,” said Goa State Horticulture Corporation Limited (GSHCL) managing director, Sandeep Faldesai.GSHCL is yet to work out the modalities for the service. For now, the corporation is in touch with its suppliers from Karnataka, which is also under lockdown. The corporation mainly depends on suppliers from Belagavi, besides a few farmers from Nashik and Solapur in Maharashtra.With borders sealed as a precautionary measure against coronavirus , the entry of only essential commodities is being permitted into Goa.“We have asked Belagavi suppliers to resume supplies as soon as possible. But owing to the lockdown, they must seek permission from their collector,” Faldesai said.

Title: No gathering at mosques for Friday prayers
Content: JAIPUR: Abiding Centre’s and state government’s guidelines, Imams across the state have appealed to Muslims to hold their Friday prayers at their homes and appealed them not to come to mosques in the wake of Covid-19.Pahadganj mosque Imam Syed Mohammad Qadri said, “Message has been sent to the people in the area that they should pray at their homes and should not come to mosques for prayers till the situation improves. Only three-four persons will come and pray in mosques on Friday. It is haappening for the first time in my life, but if we have to defeat the disease, we have to take such measures.”The country is under lockdown and the state government has imposed Section 144 of CrPC. “Following guidelines of the Centre and state government, we are not allowing more than four people in the mosques during the prayers. The same is applicable for Friday prayers. We know that the disease spreads in community gatherings, so not more than four people will be allowed in mosques for Friday prayers,” said Hafiz Mohammad Ibrahhim, Imam Jama Masjid, Sikar.

Title: Around 15 complaints received on helpline
Content:
Kolhapur: The WhatsApp helpline numbers released by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has received around 15 complaints by Thursday afternoon, said Mallinath Kalshetty, the commissioner of Kolhapur Municipal Corporation.

According to the commissioner, the nature of complaints were mostly concerns about the people who have returned from Mumbai and Pune, their medical inspection, and disinfection of the areas they lived.

“We had deployed our fire brigade and health department officials to carry out the disinfection work, while the ones who have returned from Mumbai and Pune were screened. Health department officials visited the areas and found nothing But it does help in calming down the citizens in the vicinity. With the availability of the staff and easy distribution of the work, whenever a complaint is raised on the WhatsApp number, we aim to resolve them at the earliest,” he said.

He said that they will streamline the nature of complaints and for that, a system will be formed.

Currently, two officials are monitoring the complaints on the respective numbers, which are shared with us on priority and then action is initiated.

The civic administration has launched two WhatsApp numbers for the citizens to report their inconvenience or demand for civic service.

The KMC officials said that the complaints made to these numbers will directly reach the civic chief Mallinath Kalshetty who will then ask respective officers to resolve them at earliest. The numbers are 9766532010 and 9766532016.

Title: Vadodara isolation wards get ventilators, dialysis machines
Content:
A patient undergoing dialysis at GMERS, Gotri

Vadodara: The much-needed ventilators started arriving at the GMERS Medical College and Hospital, Gotri. The isolation wards at the GMERS, Gotri and the SSG Hospital have also been equipped with dialysis facilities now.

The dialysis unit at GMERS, Gotri was brought, installed and made functional by the early hours on Thursday. A patient who had tested positive for COVID-19 was admitted at the hospital and became the first patient to undergo dialysis.

Sources said that the patient had come in close contact with a doctor actively involved in public life too. The doctor was also tested for the novel coronavirus and the tests were negative. The patient had undergone dialysis at a private facility in the city and three persons who had come in close contact with him had to be quarantined.

Five ventilators have arrived at the isolation facility at GMERS, Gotri and 10 others had been identified and were to reach the hospital. The officials are trying to ensure that 50 more ventilators reach the hospital soon.

So far 42 persons have been kept at the quarantine centre on Ajwa road. These include 32 from Vadodara municipal limits and 10 from outside the city.

Title: State proposes rapid test but ICMR not keen
Content:
Kochi: Kerala government has requested Indian Council of Medical Research ( ICMR ) to grant permission to conduct rapid test to check if there is community spread in the state.

However, ICMR has reservations about permitting rapid test as even a Covid-19 infected person in the initial stage may test negative. Besides, there may also be lots of false positives. “In the rapid blood test, the results come positive much later and it remains positive for many weeks. So we have not yet started it,” said Dr Balram Bhargava, director general, ICMR. At the moment, the reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) tests are done.

Rapid test, on the other hand, is a surveillance test and is not for diagnosis of Covid-19. And Kerala government has been consistent in its argument that such a test is essential for epidemiological study of the disease spread in the community. They plan to test common persons who have recovered from bout of respiratory infection.

Kerala has started community screening using PCR tests but government officials admit that it is not possible to do large number of PCR tests. “Since ICMR has not yet permitted us to do rapid test, the state government through Rajiv Gandhi Biotechnology Centre, Thiruvananthapuram, has already started tests in the community,” said Kerala state planning board member Dr B Eqbal.

Indian Medical Association (IMA) has also been requesting that rapid test should be made available pan-India as the disease has been declared a pandemic. “Since the entire globe is affected, it is better to identify the hot spots and community spread at the earliest so that focused aggressive measures can be taken in that particular region to prevent further spread,” said former IMA president Dr VG Pradeep Kumar.

“Rapid test is far easier to do and doesn’t need technical expertise. Also, the cost involved is much lesser. For rapid test you require blood and for PCR secretion is required. Large number of tests can be done using the rapid test method,” said Healthcare expert Dr K P Aravindan.

Meanwhile, as the number of people in quarantine increases in the state, there is excess burden on the approved testing labs with a government official admitting that often the waiting time for test results now is 3 to 4 days. Despite the increasing burden, the state government is not too keen on granting permission for private labs to test for Covid-19.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Jaipur: 2 patients develop lung ailments, doctors say condition okay
Content: JAIPUR: Radiological test reports of two of the patients admitted to Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital for Covid-19 treatment have shown bilateral lung infiltrates. These patients are facing difficulties in maintaining normal oxygen saturation level. While other 38 patients do not have such complaints so far, the 69-year-old Covid-19 positive Italian tourist, who died of cardiac arrest last week, had pre-existing lung ailments.According to doctors, virus has infiltrated into the lungs of the two patients and caused hazy lung opacity.One of the two patients is a doctor who was rushed from Bhilwara where he was finding it difficult to maintain oxygen saturation. When his condition deteriorated, he was admitted to SMS Hospital two days ago. However, doctors claimed that his condition is improving. “In radiological investigation, it is found that he has patches on his lungs due to lung infiltrate,” a senior SMS Hospital doctor said. He is also living with diabetes and taking insulin.Another patient, who was also brought from Bhilwara and was working as a nurse in the same hospital where 17 persons contracted Covid-19 infection, has also reported bilateral lung infiltrates. He is also finding it difficult to maintain normal oxygen saturation levels. However, he does not have any co-morbidity such as diabetes or hypertension, which may help him in recovery, the doctors said, who are keeping a close eye on the patients.However, doctors claimed that the condition of the two patients is improving.However, SMS Hospital additional superintendent Dr Ajit Singh said, “No patient is on ventilator support.”Apart from antiretroviral therapy, the doctors are providing them antibiotics for helping them overcome from pneumonia. They are also providing them combination of two drugs— lopinavir-ritonavir, which are useful in treatment of HIV, and hydroxychloroquine, a common anti-malaria drug.However, there are other patients who are either asymptomatic or they have mild symptoms such as fever and cough.A core group of doctors for treatment of patients headed by SMS Medical College principal and controller Dr Sudhir Bhandari is regularly monitoring the health of the patients and taking appropriate decisions on line of treatment of Covid-19 patients. However, health experts claimed that bilateral lung infiltrates situation comes at least 7 to 10 days after the infection.“Initial symptoms of Covid-19 is fever and then cough and after six-seven days, some patients develop lung infiltrate,” said Dr Virendra Singh, pulmonology expert and former superintendent, SMS Hospital.

Title: Lockdown in India: With no transport, migrants make the long march home
Content: A new humanitarian crisis may be unfolding in the country. Tens of thousands of desperate people, mainly migrant labourers reduced to joblessness by the lockdown and with little or no money or food, have been streaming out of India’s major cities for the past few days, trying to walk hundreds of kilometres to reach their homes in small towns and villages.These tides of men, women and children, driven by the uncompromising arithmetic of survival and fear of contracting the coronavirus , pose a new challenge to the government’s all-out attempts to contain the spread of the disease. “Some 26,000 people have reached Ratanpur, on the Gujarat-Rajasthan border , in the past two-three days. Our teams are first listing them before medical teams screen them. Those who have been advised quarantine are stamped and then transported to their villages on buses arranged by the administration,” according to Dungarpur collector Kanaram.There are thousands leaving the Delhi-NCR, trudging down the Yamuna Expressway and the expressway to Meerut. Raj Kumar is one: he has set out for home with just Rs 1,000 in hand. But home is Chhapra in Bihar , 1,050 km away. And he has a toddler in his arms while his wife walks beside him. He is hoping he could hitch a ride, or several, home. Police checkposts on the outskirts of Jaipur are coming across people walking back to their villages. TOI visits the Jaipur-Agra highway and finds hundreds walking on the road, carrying bags.“My village is 110 km from Jaipur. I have no option but to go back. The police stopped us at a few places but, when convinced that we had no other choice, they let us carry on,” says Kishan Mahawar a daily-wage labourer.The scale of migration was so large that it frightened senior officers at the Jaipur police commissionerate when told by subordinates that hundreds of workers were walking towards Transport Nagar. “A migration is on… We have spoken to many of them who said they are left without any money. Yesterday we helped some of them reach their villages,” said Jaipur commissioner Anand Srivastav. On the Gujarat-Rajasthan border, patwaris were preparing lists of the arriving population according to the areas to which they belong and medical teams of 20 doctors and 40 nurses have been working day and night screening them. Most of them do not have money and had not eaten properly, Kanaram, the collector, said, adding though it was a large number of people, they were adhering to the social distancing protocol “as far as possible”.“Around 16,000 had reached till Wednesday and some 12,000 were reported to have reached in seven hours on Thursday, between 6 am and 1 pm. A large number is expected in the next two days,” Kanaram said, adding that 50 buses had been arranged by the district administration to transport these people to their homes. In Maharashtra, a man walked 135km, from Nagpur to Sindewahi, and was stop ped by the police about 25km from his village.Separately, police in the state’s Pandharkawda district prevented a tragedy when they intercepted five container vehicles stuffed with over 350 migrant labourers from Telangana. All belonged to Jodhpur. Yavatmal SP M Rajkumar said since the vehicles had not entered Maharashtra, the police had sent them back. But the labourers, forced out of their places of residence by their employers in Telangana, decided to walk on to their homes 1,500 km away.In UP, over 160 daily-wage earners travelling from Delhi and its surroundings in three vehicles, including a water tanker, were stopped by police. After medical examinations determined they were not suffering from Covid-19, they were sent on to their villages in Bahraich, Kaiserganj and Huzooprur. In Hyderabad, about a dozen labourers from a slum had set out on a journey of about 600km, to a village in Visakhapatnam.By Thursday they had walked and hitched rides to Kodada, on the Telangana-Andhra Pradesh border. Gujarat was no different. Thousands left Ahmedabad for their homes in MP, Rajasthan and UP, while police tempted them to stay back with promises of shelter and food. Ravindra Yadav, a woodworker in a furniture factory, had Rs 12 in his pocket for the road home to Barabanki, UP. “It is our only hope as our employer told us to leave as there would no work nor salary,” Yadav said.

Title: Grocers get nod to open in Sanguem, Quepem
Content:
Representative image

QUEPEM: The administration in Sanguem and Quepem has issued permissions to various grocery shops, fair price shops and milk outlets to commence home delivery of essential items to consumers.

Sanguem deputy collector S Ajay Gavde told TOI that he has issued 15 permissions to fair price and grocery shops and two to milk outlets. This will cover the entire taluka of Sanguem, including municipal area and all panchayat areas.

He said volunteers have been identified with the help of Sanguem MLA Prasad Gaonkar. Each team of volunteers will be given vehicles to facilitate door-to-door delivery, free of cost.

Garbage collectors roped in by the Sanguem municipality have been tasked with taking lists of essentials from each household while they are on their door-to-door garbage collection rounds. These lists will then be given to the respective grocery stores, Gavde said.

In Quepem, residents queued up outside the town’s Sahakar Bhandar outlet to get essentials after deputy collector Rohit Kadam issued permission to keep the store open through the day. Kadam also issued passes to around eight volunteers for home delivery services.

Quepem mamlatdar Ramesh Gaonkar requested customers to maintain a metre’s distance from one another while waiting in queue outside Sahakar Bhandar. The volunteers took down each customer’s list and instructed them to return home, assuring free delivery by evening.

Title: Temples shut, devotees stay indoors on Day 1 of Navaratra
Content:
A closed temple on Wednesday

Kanpur: It was for the first time in the lives of hundreds of devotees that they could not offer ‘Navaratra’ prayers at prominent temples as all religious places remained shut in view of 21-day national lockdown which became effective from Wednesday.

Closed gates left people disappointed when they reached temples to worship on the auspicious occasion.

Devotees reached Kali Mathiya temple, Durga temple and Baradevi temple and offered prayers from outside. Others stayed back in support of lockdown and prayed to the deity to save people from coronavirus.

Chander, a city resident, said: “This is for the first time in my life I am witnessing a complete shutdown where even temples are closed. I performed puja from my home with limited means and prayed that the country gets rid of the disease at the earliest.”

Title: Helping cops keep people at a safe distance in Hyderabad
Content: HYDERABAD: Kishore Kumar Mamidi started his day at 6am on Thursday going from street to street convincing people to maintain social distance. Kishore is among 36 volunteers who are helping police regulate movement in wake of the lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic. Kishore is a software engineer working from home. “Since my shift is from 2pm to 11pm, I volunteer between 6am and 1pm,” he said and added that since he lives with a joint family, he has a bath outside the house when he gets back and does not go anywhere near family members without a mask.The Cyberabad police has recently started working with volunteers on several fronts including checking travel permits, helping raise awareness and ensuring distance is maintained among people at public spaces. “Today (Thursday), two cops came with me as I made my rounds in Attapur, Hyderguda and Upparpally. Our focus has been on supermarkets, banks and medical stores where people are still gathering in large numbers,” said Kishore, who is volunteering with the Rajendranagar police station. The 30-year-old said that while people were being cautious, several preventive measures were being forgotten.“For instance, supermarkets are providing hand sanitisers inside but that serves no purpose when people are ignoring the 6-ft demarcations outside and no temperature checks are being done,” Kishore said. He added that he had called up the managements of several stores and ensured demarcations were followed outside as well. According to Kishore, ATMs and medical shops were problem areas where people have been seen falling over each other to get service.Doing a similar job is another software professional, Teja Alimilli, who has been volunteering with the Miyapur PS. “Besides identifying crowded areas and ensuring preventive steps are being taken, we are also ensuring limits are maintained on purchases. Only people with permission are being allowed to buy in bulk,’ he said. Another local, Hareesh Jayini, too has been volunteering but with the Kukatpally police. He has been manning the checkpost at Usha Mullapudi junction. “We are checking permits for people travelling across this junction to ensure no one is on the roads unnecessarily. Tomorrow (Friday), a vehicle with speakers will be assigned to us. We will be making announcements along with Kukatpally PS personnel about implementing social distancing. After that, we will go back and inspect whether businesses have implemented social distancing or not,” he said.Getting volunteers together are Sai Teja and Ramanjeet Singh who have been pivotal in organising the effort. “We are handling the back-end work, noting down the complaints that come in and creating a database to help the cops address them,” said Singh, an IT professional. “We hope to ease cops’ burden. Even before the crisis broke out, I was volunteering with the cops to man traffic. Now I will double my efforts,” Teja said. Among the many complaints are issues regarding lodging at hostels, hoarding and concerns over travel permissions, the duo said.Stating that the volunteers were helping them monitor areas during the lockdown, Cyberabad DCP traffic Vijay Kumar said: “We cannot oversee every nook and corner and this is where civil society volunteers make a huge difference.” The DCP said Teja and Ramanjeet were helping source food for the needy.

Title: Rs 28 lakh fund to procure protective gear for cops
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: State government sanctioned a budget of Rs 28 lakh to procure protective gear for over 5,000 policemen roped in to enforce the 21-day lockdown in Prayagraj district , in the wake of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic.The funds would be used to purchase safety gear like masks and hand sanitisers for the policemen deployed in the district.The allocated funds would cover policemen performing duties at over 200 static points in the district.SSP (Prayagraj) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “Around 5,000 policemen have been assigned duties at different static points during the lockdown period. The sanctioned budget would be used to buy masks and sanitisers for policemen on duty.”He added that the department had already distributed masks among 4,600 policemen, and rest would get them soon.These policemen will also trained in about the correct way of using masks and sanitisers so that they could shield them from the spread of the virus.The SSP said the cops have been asked to follow certain dos and don’ts while performing their duties during the lockdown.A team of senior police officials will be checking cleanliness of barracks, police lines and toilets at Reserve Police Lines.The department would be coordinating with health officials and Prayagraj Municipal Corporation to get the premises of Reserve Police Lines sanitised.Pankaj also asked those policemen who were on leave and away from the Prayagraj to stay where they were.Policemen on duty have been directed to take citizens who might be ill to hospitals along with health department officials.The district police authorities have already ordered masks, sanitisers and special suits from units in Kanpur and other districts. A team of cops were also preparing sanitisers at the Reserve Police Lines’ premises for daily use.

Title: Day 2 of Covid-19 lockdown: 52 booked for flouting rules
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: Day 2 of the nationwide lockdown enforced to check the spread of Covind-19 ended with 52 persons being booked for violating rules mandated for the period in Prayagraj on Thursday.Police caught a number of citizens in Old City and trans-Yamuna areas sitting outside their homes and wandering on streets.Ten FIRs were lodged with police stations at Ghurpur, Khiri, Dhoomanganj Mutthiganj , Jhunsi, Baharia, Naini and Manda under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code . The section deals with violations of section 144 of Criminal Procedure Code.Like the day before, streets wore a deserted look as local residents stayed indoors following the announcement of the lockdown. Shops selling essential commodities like medicines and groceries were open from 7am to 6pm.Police appealed to citizens to practise social distancing and ensured that shops selling essential commodities and pharmacies remain open from 7am to 6 pm.Police also urged citizens to use the Dial 112 helpline to complain any trader found blackmarketing essential commodities.Besides, a Covid-19 helpline (0532-2641577\78 and 7458825340) and a helpline for getting essential commodities (0532-2266098\99) have also been lunched.SSP (Prayagraj) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “Police have roped in more than 200 vehicles within the city limits to ferry essential commodities so that the citizens do not have any problems. Police have also demaracted areas for citizens queuing up outside shops selling essential commodities and pharmacies so that they stand at least a metre apart.”The SSP also said police took stern action against those found sitting outside their homes in Mutthiganj, Kareli, Karelabagh, Khuldabad and other parts of the city.Police put up barricades on 183 crossings and intersections of the city to restrict traffic movement and challaned over 1,100 vehicles for defying lockdown rules on Thursday.Police also rushed two critically ill patients to different hospitals and arranged for meals for orphans and homeless poor living on roadsides in the city.Police only allowed those two-wheelers and cars to move around whose owners were on their way to buy essential items, that too after checking their ID cards.The police also waived traffic restrictions for heavy vehicles delivering essential commodities and medical professionals.On Thursday, three more special police teams were dispatched in trans-Ganga and trans-Yamuna areas of the city to check blackmarketing of essential commodities by traders. Policemen in civvies posed as regular customers and visited many shops in Old City markets like Mutthiganj, Kydganj, Khuldabad , Chowk and Dhoomanganj on Thursday. However, no cases of blackmarketing were reported.

Title: Fireworks industry workers seek urgent aid in tough times
Content:
Madurai: Employees working in cracker units reeling under the lockdown have urged the government to provide monetary assistance to them till the units resumed functioning.

The cracker industry at Sivakasi in Virudhunagar district employs nearly eight lakh workers directly and indirectly. R Pandi, a resident of O Sankaralingapuram village, said an employee would earn an average of Rs 350 to 400 per day by working in a cracker unit and the salary is disbursed every weekend.

“Since all units are closed, the employees would have received the salary for working during the last week with which they would be able to manage their family expenses for nearly 10 days. As the units would be closed for the next 21 days, we will start facing difficulties after 10 days,” noted Pandi.

He said when the employees are in need of money, they used to request for advance salary, but they are not sure they would get it now. Another employee, K Sundaram from Maraneri, said the rise in prices of essential commodities will affect them severely. To make matters worse, they are all forced to stock up essential commodities. Hence the government should provide them monetary assistance, he said.

The district secretary of Fireworks and Matches Workers Association affiliated to CITU, M Mahalakshmi, said they will meet the owners and submit representation to the district administration to protect the livelihood of the employees during the lockdown period. The president of Tamil Nadu Fireworks and Amorces Manufacturers Association P Ganesan said that though the fireworks industry would come to a standstill during the lockdown period, instructions have been given to the members of the association to take care of the welfare of their employees by proving monetary support.

Title: Rs 1.6 crore allotted to govt hosp from MPLADS funds
Content: Madurai: To treat patients admitted in Kanyakumari and Tirunelveli districts, Rs 1.6 crore has been sanctioned by MPs A Vijayakumar and S Gnanathiraviam from their Members of Parliament Local Area Development Scheme ( MPLADS ) towards preparedness to treat Covid-19.On Thursday, Vijayakumar inspected Covid-19 preparedness and facilities at the Kanyakumari government medical college hospital and handed over the letter allotting Rs 1 crore from MPLADS to hospital dean R Suganthy.“They are running short of ventilators and other equipment. We have placed the ordered for 10 ventilators and expect it to be despatched from Chennai on Friday,” the MP said, adding that he will allot more funds based on the requirements.Other equipment for which he has allotted the funds include O2 flow meter, 10 RO plants, 50 multipara monitors, 10 ECG machines, portable digital x-ray and USG machines and mammogram.In Tirunelveli district, MP Gnanathiraviam handed over the allotment letter for Rs 60 lakh to collector Shilpa Prabhakar Satish . It includes Rs 20 lakh for Tirunelveli government medical college hospital to screen and treat Covid-19 patients and Rs 40 lakh for the same purpose in other government hospitals in the district.

Title: No fresh cases in Kanpur, administration boosts efforts
Content: KANPUR: No fresh positive case of Covid-19 was reported on Wednesday even as 11 suspected cases of people with travel history were reported taking the total suspected cases to 827. Health officials said all 11 suspected patients have been home-quarantined.Eight patients completed their quarantine time on Wednesday taking the number of such people to 203. Authorities collected four samples on Wednesday and sent it for testing.Meanwhile, divisional commissioner Dr Sudhir M Bobde said the state government has sanctioned 28-day leave with wages for all registered labourers. The department has transferred Rs 1,000 in bank account of 5.30 lakh labourers. The district administration allowed provisional stores to open for home delivery. All stores will have to follow sanitation, maintain hygiene and social distancing. The DM has also asked chemists to ensure circles are painted outside their shops to ensure social distancing among consumers.Meanwhile, police checked 6,450 vehicles on Wednesday and challaned 1,798 of them. Cops seized as many as 76 vehicles when the owners could not show relevant papers and realized a fine of Rs 52,200.Police registered as many as 69 cases against lockdown violators.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Rajasthan:‘Ramganj youth mingled with over 200 people’
Content:
Security personnel gurad a deserted road in Ramganj on Thursday.

JAIPUR: Curfew has been imposed in Ramganj area of Walled City after a person tested positive for Covid-19 on Thursday.

“Curfew has been imposed in a 1km radius of the house where the person tested positive. Intense contact tracing in the area has started,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health).

Across the state, five persons tested positive for taking the total count to 43. While two persons contracted the disease in Bhilwara, one person each tested positive in Jhunjhunu, Jodhpur in addition to the Ramganj case.

The two who tested positive in Bhilwara are son and granddaughter of the 73-year-old Covid-19 person who died today (Thursday) after testing positive a few days ago, said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health).

The 35-year-old Ramganj resident had returned from Muscat in Oman. He first landed in Dubai at 10am on March 11. He reached Delhi on March 12 and boarded a Rajasthan State Road Transport Corporation bus from Dhaula Kuan to Jaipur. He got of the bus at Ghat Gate in the afternoon and hired a rickshaw to reach his home in Ramganj.

After a gap of 14 days, the health department is now finding it difficult to identify his co-passengers in the bus.

Health department officials claimed that he remained in home quarantine from March 12 to March 24. However, on March 24 he developed symptoms of Covid-19. He was rushed to Covid-19 OPD at the SMS Hospital , where his samples were taken for testing. “He has been tested positive for Covid-19,” said a health official.

While investigating further, the health department found 33 persons, who were in his direct contact, 22 among them are from his family and relatives. Sources in Ramganj say he had offered prayers at Rehmania mosque atleast three times as there are chances of him getting in touch with 200 persons.

In Jhunjhunu, a 45-year-old person tested positive. “He had returned from Dubai and landed here on March 21. He came to the district hospital complaining that he has fever. His samples were sent to laboratory for test and on Thursday he tested positive for the disease,” said Umar Deen Khan, Jhunjhunu district collector.

Khan said so far six persons have tested positive in Jhunjhunu and all of them have travel history.

Title: Make basic needs available in Delhi via public distribution system : BJP
Content: NEW DELHI: BJP on Thursday urged chief minister Arvind Kejriwal to strengthen its public distribution system to ensure that the poor get their quota of rice and wheat at the earliest.In a letter to Kejriwal, leader of Opposition in Delhi Assembly Ramvir Singh Bidhuri also suggested that essential commodities such as vegetables, fruits and kitchen staple be sold through public distribution system (PDS) to prevent their hoarding. He added that as a responsible opposition party, BJP was willing to give its full support to the Delhi government in dealing with the Covid-19 epidemic.Bidhuri said it was the poor strata of the society that was affected the most due to the lockdown and they should be provided with one-month ration at the earliest, to ensure there was no shortage of food.“There is a need to streamline the network of ration shops run under PDS and give comprehensive information to public about these shops and their timings so that people can procure their essential items,” Bidhuri said in the letter.He added that milk, vegetables and fruits should also be made available at ration shops. “The government should also run its mobile vans with essential commodities in different parts of the city,” the letter said.

Title: Meet your everyday heroes trying to quench your thirst
Content: Nagpur: Amid coronavirus scare across the city, there are many unsung heroes who are ensuring we stay indoors without any problem. They are the everyday heroes from Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and Orange City Water (OCW) who work hard to ensure scheduled water supply to Nagpurians.Ashwin from Nehru Nagar zone, who operates a valve from 4am to 12 noon at various places, said, “I ensure that I stay fit and fine so that I continue to play the vital role of supplying water to all Nagpurians.”“Our responsibilities have increased as compared to normal working days. Even our seniors also encourage field teams especially supervisors and valve men. Amid coronavirus scare, we started feeling proud that we are real field soldiers who are supplying drinking water at Nagpur’s every tap,” he said when TOI spotted him operating a valve by wearing safety gear like mask. He also carried a pass which mentioned that he is part of discharging essential services.“Valve men play a vital role in the water supply system. Their day starts at 4am and continues till midnight as they operate around 182 valves across the city for smooth water supply to every household,” said an OCW spokesperson.Likewise, Badal, a tanker driver from Wanjari Nagar ESR, said, “We feel proud as we supply water to slums wherein there are no taps. We have been provided masks and other safety gears. We visit people’s home during lockdown to supply water so that they stay indoors,” he said as NMC-OCW provides water in many non-network areas through tankers.The NMC-OCW pressed 293 tankers and all the drivers into service and similar number of helpers too have been provided with masks to stay safe while providing water through tankers.Similar precautions are also being taken by 150-odd plant operators deployed at five water treatment plants – Gorewada (Pench-I, II, III), Kanhan WTP and Godhni WTP with safety masks etc.Even NMC-OCW zonal teams deployed for maintenance and leakage repairing works are working or remainign alert in resolving no-water or polluted water complaints of consumers.OCW CEO Sanjoy Roy said, “We stayed at work to provide clean and safe drinking water at your taps. You stay at your home with family to keep the city and the nation safe.”Other heroes include those who monitor smooth functioning of main pipeline. They plug major leakages on pipeline and to clear technical snag at ESRs etc that develop during system operations, said the spokesperson. Even the NMC-OCW surveillance staff team who takes care of bulk water supply from field too remains on toes. The 100-odd security guards too are playing a vital role to keep all the premises safe and secure.In a bid to support social distancing as well as lockdown, it has already intensified online payment method. It has appealed to consumers to prefer online payment of water bills. “Next cycle bills will be delivered on an average basis (no meter reading) and we have also stopped disconnection drive of defaulters,” the official added.

Title: Panic buying subsides but supply bottlenecks remain
Content:
Nagpur: Covid-19 outbreak has made even bulk traders at the agriculture produce marketing committee’s (APMC) yard at Kalamna, from where the city gets it supply of grains, vegetables and fruits, apprehensive. They fear that the market yard, where people from different parts of the country congregate, makes them more susceptible to infection making many to join the lockdown.

Despite an assurance by the APMC secretary, traders in vegetables have downed their shutters till Monday. From Tuesday onwards, the business will continue only from 4am to 11am. The fruit traders at Kalamna have already declared a closure throughout the lockdown period and will be sticking to it, they say.

The impact could be seen down the line at the fruit and vegetable stalls across the city. The traders whom TOI came across said their stock of vegetables would not last beyond a day or two. There were carts laden with fruit, but the vendors said they were not getting any fresh supplies. Meanwhile e-tailers have also stopped supplies. Big Basket has sent a mail to its customers it may take a day or two to start supplies in Nagpur as the chain has been affected due to curfew and heavy demand.

“Kalamna market can turn out to be the most dangerous place. We have people coming from different parts of the country. anybody can be a carrier of the virus, This is why traders have preferred to keep away from the markets,” said Rajesh Chabrani, former director of APMC. Chabrani, a fruit trader, said his guild had decided to shut down also due to lack of demand due to the lockdown. He said there may be assurances that shops will remain open but traders under his association had decided to keep shut.

Even as grain traders are continuing their business, sources said there was a dearth of labourers for whom traders have approached the police to issue curfew passes.
