The resident deputy collector Ravindra Khazanchi told TOI supply of essential items in the city was normal on March 26. He said the collector had asked police not to stop workers engaged in unloading food items from going to work. Police said that 3,459 curfew passes were issued on March 24 and 4,157 on March 25 for persons engaged in providing essential services.

At grocery shops, some item or other were running out. The traders said there was a major shortage of branded food items. The stocks at our godowns in the city are fast getting depleted and there was no fresh supply, said representative of a multinational company.

The promoter of a major food processing industry based at Nagpur said, requesting anonymity, that even as milk and bread production was continuing, the company’s unit making packaged snacks had closed.

At Purushottam Stores near Ram Nagar Square, the shopkeeper said he had run out of wheat flour and sugar. The wholesalers may be having the stock but it cannot reach the retailers either due to transport being blocked or labourers not turning up due to the curfew.

Atul Denge of Durga General Stores, a kiosk at Bharat Nagar, said he was not getting fresh stock of bread and butter. Another storekeeper at Dharampeth said the supplies had only resumed on Tuesday.

Prabhakar Deshmukh, president of Nagpur Chillar Kirana Vyapari Sangh , said the panic demand had receded on Tuesday but the labourers were still not able to make it to the market. Even transportation of fresh supplies had been held up due to the curfew.

Manoj Rathore, a wheat trader from Sehore in Madhya Pradesh, said Maharashtra was a major market for traders in the state. However, consignments that started for Maharashtra had been held up midway.

Sources said this had led to shortage of wheat flour. The wheat from MP also goes to the flour mills here. Pawan Poddar, who has a flour mill in the city, said even if supplies from outside were not available there was enough grain in FCI godowns here to meet any exigency. The millers were ready to provide any service to the society.

Pratap Motwani, secretary of The Itwari Grain and Seeds Merchants Association, said they had taken up the matter with authorities and passes would be issued to workers engaged grain and other markets too. Motwani said he had written to the police commissioner that truckers should be given curfew passes on WhatsApp so that transportation was not held up.

Rajesh Jejani and other wholesale traders in sugar said there was enough supply of sugar in the market and retailers need not worry. This could be judged from the fact that rates had remained stable.

Sources in Big Bazaar said even as the chain had started door-to-door delivery throughout the country, mobility of staff has been affected with even logistics of perishable items sourced locally hit in parts of the country.

45 grocers to home deliver provisions

Forty-five grocery shop owners have agreed to home delivery of provisions to customers in the city to reduce crowding at their shops. This was decided in a meeting between municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe and shopkeepers.

A list of these shops along with their addresses and mobile number of owners is being circulated by Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) on WhatsApp. Mundhe has appealed to the citizens to take advantage of the facility and avoid going to grocery stores.

The announcement by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman to increase quantity of cereals at ration shops led to long queues at the shops near slums. Ambazari police dispersed people in Pandhrabodi. District civil supplies officer Chetan Tayade said written orders in this regard were yet to reach him.

Title: Goa: Parra locals barter goods as shops run out
Content:
Representative image

CALANGUTE: Plans by the Parra panchayat to have essential grocery items delivered to citizens have failed to take off as grocery shops that were to supply items have no stocks. To cope with the unprecedented crisis, many have started bartering with their neighbours and friends, parting with any excess items in exchange for immediate requirements that they don’t have at all.

Panchayat members said they’re making arrangements for home delivery of essential items by roping in grocery shop owners and providing their phone numbers to citizens. Citizens have to phone their order in and the items will be delivered by volunteers without people having to come out.

“The problem is that the grocery shops themselves don’t have any stocks. I’ve spoken to all the grocery shop owners in Parra and nobody has any stocks. The government needs to allow supply vehicles to enter Goa and distribute essential items to the distributors,” Parra sarpanch Delilah Lobo told TOI.

Title: 6 poachers held with civet cat, monitor lizard
Content:
Nagpur: Wildlife poachers seem to be taking advantage of the ongoing lockdown. Six of them were arrested for poaching a civet cat and a monitor lizard from Aamghat forest area under Butibori forest range.

The accused have been identified as Akash Jagtap, Ramnath Sawant, Sundarlal Shinde, Anil Shinde, Tanaji Jagtap amd Motiram Mandavkar, all residents of Makardhokda in Umred tehsil.

“The accused, who are into business of selling Ayurvedic jadi-booti (alternative medicine) had entered the forest under the pretext of collecting medicinal plants but killed a civet cat and captured a monitor lizard. The lizard was released in the forest,” said RFO LV Thokal.

Due to coronavirus pandemic, the accused were released on bail on March 25, but have been ordered by the court to remain present as and when directed. The criminals seem to be habitual offenders selling body parts to gullible customers as medicines of various ailments.

Title: Border chaos ends between AP-Telangana, students shifted to quarantine homes
Content: VIJAYAWADA: Bringing the chaos at the AP-Telangana inter-state border to an end, the Andhra Pradesh government on Thursday shifted the students and software engineers, who were stranded at the check-post at Garikapadu village in Krishna district, to quarantine homes in the state.Officials allowed only those who gave their consent to stay at the quarantine homes to enter the state. About 43 people including students and techies from Krishna and Guntur districts have been shifted to quarantine home set up at Triple IT campus in Nuzvid.About 38 residents of East Godavari have been moved to an engineering college at Rajahmundry and those from West Godavari to Eluru with police escort.Those who refused to go to isolation centres have been sent back to Hyderabad as the Telangana government had also initiated measures to reopen the PG hostels. A few people with valid medical records and medical emergencies have also been allowed to come into the state. No one has been allowed to go home straight as part of containment measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19.The situation at the check-post had turned volatile on Wednesday when scores of students and software engineers, who were suddenly evicted by managements of private PG hostels in Hyderabad, tried to rush back to their native places in AP.However, the officials at the inter-state border check post refused to give them entry citing lockdown rules and requested them to go back to Hyderabad. The situation worsened with the Hyderabad police hurriedly issuing NOCs to all those who wanted to leave the city without looking into the consequences on the highways.After students flooded social media with SOS tweets, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy held discussions with Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao and requested him not to shunt the students out of Hyderabad.Meanwhile, Jagan directed the officials to take all those coming into the state to quarantine homes and asked them not to allow them to go homes. Special chief secretary Dr KS Jawahar Reddy directed the police officials and district collectors in the border areas not to grant entry to anyone from other states from Thursday.Sources said that about 600 students who refused to join the quarantine homes in AP returned to Hyderabad in their vehicles in the early hours of Thursday. AP has also decided not to allow even students from Thursday. The officials clarified decision to grant the entry to the people stranded in the check-posts is only a one-time offer.Reports about similar troubles are coming from other border towns in Kurnool, Guntur, East Godavari districts and Orissa border in Srikakulam district. Several daily wagers who came to work in chilli fields in Guntur district from Nalgonda were stranded at Vadapalli border near Miryalaguda as the police from both the states refused to allow them to cross the border.

Title: 2,234 held for violating lockdown norms
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: With police continuing its strict measures , it seems Keralites have finally got the message. On day three, the number of people who were out on roads dipped significantly, compared to the first two days. As many as 2,234 persons were arrested in 2,098 cases on Thursday for violating lockdown norms and 1,447 vehicles were confiscated . With this, 5,710 cases have been registered in three days.

While Idukki (245) witnessed maximum number of cases on Thursday, the least was in Kasaragod (27). Alappuzha topped the list in terms of those arrested at 214, while the lowest number was in Wayanad (31).

In the capital, where the past two days had evoked lesser response, police took stricter measures like confiscating vehicles and registering cases. "We will confiscate vehicles and return them only after 21 days. For the purpose, we will use a ground if required," said commissioner Balram Kumar Upadhyay.

The police have also launched several security measures including asking all apartment complexes to maintain a register at the gate, in which the details of an inmate leaving the complex will have to enter his name, details of the vehicle and purpose, that will be checked by the beat police periodically.

If anyone is found moving around and his/her details are not found in the register, police have warned that not only the person, but also the office bearers of the apartment association will be booked.

Meanwhile, state police chief Loknath Behera instructed all policemen not to stop vehicles carrying transporting soaps, sanitizers, gloves that are essential for fighting the disease. Vehicles, which are transporting employees of organizations manufacturing such products, will be allowed to travel from their homes to their office after obtaining police clearance. Behera specifically instructed not to disrupt the movement of those persons engaged in the cleaning process and waste management. This will be applicable to such workers in the private sector as well. He said that those working in such sectors are part of essential services.

All policemen, engaged in vehicle checking, should mandatorily wear masks and gloves. The responsibility of ensuring that all personnel are obeying instructions will be on respective district police chiefs, he added.

Behera also instructed that not every vehicle should be checked for documents leading to a long chain of vehicles waiting on the road. Instead of concentrating on one or two junctions, police should split and concentrate on several places, he said.

Title: Prayagraj clueless about government’s delivery plan
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: Amid the nationwide lockdown, the door to door delivery system of essential commodities doesn’t seem to be functioning smoothly in the city.

A number of citizens claimed that they had no idea how the doorstrep delivery works, and were still visiting grocery stores and vegetable markets.

The district authorities, however, claimed that provisional stores have been permitted for home delivery.

Mutthiganj resident Ravi Kumar Kesarwani told TOI, “When we dialled the helpline number for supply of essential commodities, the ration officers at the control room asked us to visit the nearby market or call a store to deliver the supply.”

Civil Lines resident Vinay Mehrotra said, “It will be a relief if prominent stores start door-to-door delivery during the lockdown period. Amidst police deployment in all areas of the city, I made my way to the vegetable and grocery shops with much difficulty.”

SP Marg resident Pankaj Mehrotra said, “When I called on the helpline number, officials asked us to visit the nearest market, and claimed that there was no dearth of essential commodities.”

Title: Delhi: Delivery boys of e-commerce firms may get ID cards
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi Police is likely to release a list of e-commerce companies that will be allowed to provide their services during the lockdown.Earlier, it had issued an order on Thursday asking the cops on ground to exempt the delivery boys of courier companies and fashion retail e-commerce stores as well. The order was, however, withdrawn later. Sources say that a revised copy of the order will be issued soon.A senior police officer said that the e-commerce companies supplying essential items have been asked to issue identity cards to their delivery persons. A delivery person will also have to carry a list of items to be delivered which must not include non-essential goods. “Delivery persons coming from outside the state will be issued curfew passes that they need to produce at the police pickets for the next 21 days,” he added.Another senior police officer said that the initial order also had names of some of the companies providing fashion goods. “A fresh order is being drafted with only the names of e-commerce companies that sell essential goods,” the officer added.An order has also been issued to allow goods vehicles with fresh stock to reach the warehouses of the e-commerce companies.Police have already issued an order directing the traffic cops, picket staffers and PCR teams to allow persons and vehicles engaged in essential services to operate in Delhi.Meanwhile, police have also set up a platform on WhatsApp for e-commerce websites to solve their issues.

Title: Man, 24, in isolation camp ‘escapes’ to meet girlfriend, brought back by cops
Content:
Madurai: A 24-year-old Dubai returnee , who was sent for isolation at the Chinna Udaippu camp near the Madurai airport , escaped from there to be with his girlfriend on Wednesday night . However, cops traced him to a village near Sivaganga and brought him back . A case was registered against the youth, said police.

The man was identified as Vijay, 24, from Keelapoongudi village in Sivaganga district . He reached Madurai airport via Delhi airport recently and was found to have symptoms consistent with Covid-19. He was isolated in the camp along with eight others, police said.

As he was found missing, health officials went into panic mode on Wednesday evening. Based on a complaint from the health officials, the Avaniyapuram police traced him using his mobile number to a village near Sivaganga.

Inquiries revealed that he had gone to meet his girlfriend. As the girl’s family were against their relationship, she escaped from her house and the two met at a place. Just when they were planning to get married at a temple, the police picked him up and the girl was sent back to her family, police said.

After the incident, the kidnap complaint filed by the girl’s family was withdrawn. Police sources said that health officials from Sivaganga district have asked the family members to keep the girl in isolation for a few days.

Title: 3 +ve cases take family’s total to 12, Islampur under watch
Content:
Kolhapur: One family now has 12 confirmed coronavirus patients. While 11 of live in Sangli, one is a resident of Pethwadgaon in Kolhapur.

In Sangli district’s Islampur village, four of a family had first tested positive for the viral infection on March 23. They had returned from Haj in Saudi Arabia. By March 25, five more family members had tested positive for Covid-19. Just a day later, on March 26, three others were confirmed to have the coronavirus infection, taking the total to 12.

Sangli district collector Abhijeet Chaudhary told TOI on Thursday that three new cases have been confirmed. He said their throat swab samples were sent to the Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) on March 25. Chaudhary also confirmed that one of the relatives is from Kolhapur district’s Pethwadgaon — she had come to Sangli to meet her relatives. All positive patients are being treated at Miraj civil hospital.

Sangli district civil surgeon Sanjay Salunkhe said, “We have already sent 11 more swab samples of close contacts and relatives, who might have come in contact with the positive patients, to NIV. The results are likely to be in by Friday, March 27.” He added that another team has been sent to the Islampur, around 42 km from Sangli, to collect 23 more swab samples of the close contacts who are still quarantined at home.

“Depending on the results, these close contacts will either be shifted to the institutional quarantine facility or will be allowed to stay under home-quarantine,” he said.

He said that with 12 cases emerging in the same family, Islampur is being put under strict monitoring. “We have contained the area. The medical teams are surveying the place, looking for the patients showing any symptom. As a precautionary measure, residents of around 500 homes have already been told to adhere to strict home-quarantine rules,” he said.

Few screening points have also been established in the Islampur to limit the entry and exit of citizens.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Andhra Pradesh government identifies 27,000 foreign returnees in 2nd round of survey
Content: VIJAYAWADA: The on-going second round of the household survey in Andhra Pradesh has identified 27,015 foreign returnees as of Thursday. As per official data, 26,934 people have been placed under home isolation and 81 people have been put in isolation wards in hospitals. Nearly 15,000 people were identified in the first round of the household survey which concluded a few days ago.Health officials say that they have managed to track all the returnees who were missed in the first round owing to the efforts of volunteers, village secretaries, ANMs and Asha workers at the field level.In a few cities, officials have been pasting notices on doors of foreign returnees asking them to home quarantine. Field-level staff has been mandated to report on the status of home isolation of foreign returnees twice a day.The modus operandi is that among foreign returnees, those exhibiting symptoms of infection are directly admitted to isolation wards in a special ambulance. Those asymptomatic have been issued notices for home quarantine for 28 days.Tracing foreign returnees has become a crucial part of containing the spread of Covid-19. Andhra Pradesh had 11 registered cases on Wednesday, of which 8 have foreign travel history and one is a close relative of another patient. The one other patient is said to have acquired the infection while staying at a religious place in New Delhi.Authorities are also tracking close contacts of foreign returnees to carry out tests and send them to isolation wards. Officials are also gathering details of the complete itinerary of these foreign returnees— from their arrival in India to how they reached home, details of the cab driver, meetings with friends, relatives and other social gatherings.Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Monday heaped praise on the volunteer and secretary system which managed to track foreign returnees.

Title: Goa police told not to stop buying, selling of essential items
Content: PANAJI: Inspector general of police Jaspal Singh on Thursday directed police not to stop those working in essential services, and also not to stop people going out to buy milk or medicine.On Wednesday, the first day of the 21-day lockdown, Goa police arrested 54 persons across the state for violating the curfew orders passed by district collectors. On Thursday, Singh met police officers to review the law and order situation in the state. He told police not to stop milk vendors from supplying milk.Police said that out of the 54 cases booked under Section 188 (Violation of order promulgated by government), 43 are in North Goa and 11 in South Goa.Police have been registering cases against those moving around villages and cities without the permission of authorities. Police have also booked cases against shopkeepers for keeping their stores open. Drivers, too, have been booked for transporting furniture. In some instances, cops have resorted to lathi charge.Singh asked police personnel to take legal action against citizens not abiding by the curfew even after repeated advice.

Title: Goverment to offer dedicated treatment for coronavirus at four hospitals
Content: VIJAYAWADA: In a move towards strengthening the infrastructure in its fight against the Covid-19 pandemic, the state government has decided to convert a few teaching hospitals in Andhra Pradesh as dedicated Covid-19 treatment facilities besides augmenting the quarantine facilities across the state. The four colleges/hospitals identified for these facilities are Siddhartha Medical College, Vijayawada (located in the premises of government general hospital); government general hospital , Nellore; Visakha Institute of Medical Sciences , Visakhapatnam; and Sri Venkateswara Medical College (Ruia Hosptial), Tirupati. The state government has already identified nearly 18,000 beds at district and constituency headquarters for quarantine facility.Regular patients receiving medical care at these four hospitals/colleges will be diverted to nearby hospitals. The dedicated Covid-19 medical facilities will work 24x7 besides suspending all the regular outpatient, emergency and inpatient services. About 3,000 beds in these four facilities, including 470 ICU beds with ventilators and 2,500 beds for advanced critical care, will be used only for the treatment of Covid-19.As per the discharge policy of the ministry of health and family welfare, the persons tested positive for Covid-19 should be hospitalised till two successive samples test negative..Special chief secretary, health, medical and family welfare department, KS Jawahar Reddy requested all retired professors, associate professors, assistant professors, medical officers, staff nurses and paramedical staff to voluntarily come forward to work in a facility closest to them. “They can choose the teaching hospitals, the state-level Covid-19 hospitals being set up in Visakhapatnam, Nellore, Vijayawada and Tirupati, or the district level Covid-19 hospital-attached private medical colleges. Salary will be compensated as per GO No 27 released in 2018. Those interested may contact the district collectors of the convened district,” he said.

Title: Lockdown no bar, Allahabad University ready for new admission season
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: Allahabad University authorities began the process for admissions for the next academic session (2020-21), despite being shut till April 14 during the lockdown announced to arrest the coronavirus contagion.

Candidates have been invited fill up online application forms for applying to various undergraduate and postgraduate courses. The last date for filling up forms is April 25.

AU director (admissions) Prashant Agarwal said, “The fee which has to be submitted along with the application for admission in AU or any of its constituent colleges is Rs 800 for general category students and Rs 400 for other backward category and SC/ST students. The application fee for professional courses is Rs 1,600 for general category and OBC students and, Rs 800 for SC/ST applicants.”

The director said that AU started with the process on time to avoid any delay in admissions.

University sources said that given the current lockdown, AU could extend the last date to fill up application forms by 10-15 days so that students are not at any disadvantage.

Title: 'Coronavirus lockdown violators to be named and shamed'
Content:
Residents in Bhatkal receive essential commodities on Thursday.

KARWAR: Those defying the Covid-19 lockdown orders in Uttara Kannada will get stamped in their hands with indelible. The names of second-time offenders will be announced near their residences in the public announcement system. In case of third office, the photographs of violators will be uploaded to the district administration’s official website.

Deputy commissioner Harish Kumar K said on Thursday that some people are unable to understand the gravity of the situation. “It is high time we took stern action against such people. It would be more effective if we create a social pressure by making public the names of violators,” said Kumar.

He said the district administration is trying hard to provide basic amenities to every doorstep. “By Friday, it will be streamlined,” he said.

Currently, traders are supplying essential commodities under the administration’s supervision.

Title: SDMC plans to set up isolation wards in hotels
Content: NEW DELHI: Everyone hopes that the 21-day lockdown will be able to halt the spread of the novel coronavirus across the country, but the municipal corporations in Delhi are trying to stay ready for any eventuality.If the number of Covid-19 cases keeps growing, South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) is looking at refurbishing hotels and schools into quarantine homes for people who have come in contact with a patient or are showing flu-like symptoms. The decision was taken in an SDMC meeting called on Wednesday to review its preparedness and discuss necessary steps, said a senior official.“If other places get filled, we can turn to hotel and schools buildings as their structures already have isolated rooms,” the official said. “Under the emergency provision of the epidemic Act, the administration is empowered to take any step required for public health,” he added.All district health officers (DHOs) of the four zones have been directed to immediately start preparing a list of all hotels, motels and guesthouses, the number of rooms available, and the contact person for each facility. “The database will ensure quick decision-making” he said. The officers have been asked to file their response on data collection in two days.Delhi government has already turned to a few hotels at Aerocity to arrange paid quarantine facilities for people coming from affected countries.East Delhi Municipal Corporation, on the other hand, decided on Thursday to intensify its drive to spray disinfectants at heavy-footfall areas using sprinklers. The decision was taken after lieutenant governor Anil Baijal directed the civic agencies to sprinkle disinfectants on busy routes and public areas.Two mist-spraying machines were used on lower surfaces on selected routes. “A mixture of water and sodium hypochlorite was sprayed from a maximum height of 1 metre to kill the virus at bus terminals, Ghazipur Murga Mandi, Mother Dairy intersection, around GTB Hospital, Brijpuri Main Road, Dilshad Garden and border areas,” an official said.The solution stays active for two hours and is not poisonous for human beings, he added. Staff have been asked to spray it in a horizontal direction through machines for long-lasting impact.Despite the 21-day lockdown, people are often coming to mandis, ATMs and markets in large numbers for essential work and EDMC is trying to minimise chances of infection at these places on a daily basis, the official said. More routes and places will be covered and the number of machines will be increased if necessary.North Delhi Municipal Corporation is also carrying out drives to sanitise areas around quarantined houses by spraying disinfectants.SDMC’s medical health official, B K Hazarika, said Delhi government had issued a fresh set of guidelines regarding home-quarantined people on Thursday. The authorities have been to “make announcements near the homes of suspected patients to ensure that they don’t venture out. So far, about 4,000 people have been covered in south Delhi”, an official said.The civic body also plans to involve RWAs to make people aware and enforce home-isolation rules.

Title: Stalin endorses PM’s message on lockdown word for word, urges people to follow it
Content: Chennai: DMK president M K Stalin , in a video released on Wednesday evening, said he welcomes each and every word of Prime Minister Narendra Modi on the 21-day lockdown and the measures being taken by the government to fight the virus outbreak. He said people must strictly follow what the Prime Minister has said.Stalin said though Tamil culture has “taught us to be together,” at present, what is needed is social distancing. People should maintain some distance even within families, said. He thanked doctors, nurses, sanitary workers and journalists and compared them to Army personnel guarding the borders.“At present, several people have been affected by Covid-19 . Some have died. More than 20 people are affected in Tamil Nadu. We must follow what Prime Minister said a few days ago on the 21-day lockdown as there is no other alternative to prevent this virus from spreading,” said Stalin.Getting into finer details, Stalin urged people to use handkerchief or tissue paper while sneezing and coughing. One should immediately wash the hands with soap. “Use sanitizer regularly. Housewives must be careful while working in kitchen after using hand sanitizer as it contains alcohol,” said Stalin.Similarly, no one should take medicine without doctor’s prescription, he urged. People with Covid-19 symptoms should seek doctor’s help, he said, adding that self-medication could be dangerous.

Title: Three home quarantine violators booked in Vadodara
Content:
Ramiz Salim was booked for argument with health team

Vadodara: A couple staying in the old city area was booked by the police for fleeing home quarantine on Friday. The police said that they could not find Deepak Patel, 40 and his wife Bhavika, who were asked to stay under home quarantine, in their home in Kalupura area and was later seen in their provision shop near their home.

Upon questioning the cops learnt that the couple had opened the shop in the morning and had dealt with many customers. “The couple’s daughter had returned from Latvia in Europe on March 14 and so the entire family was asked to stay in quarantine. But the couple flouted the orders and hence were booked under Epidemic Diseases Act for spreading infection endangering other people's lives,” said S K Desai, police sub-inspector, city police station.

Another man in Savli too was also booked for fleeing from home quarantine on Friday. Chirag Patel, 28 was booked at Savli police station as he fled from his home during the two-week home quarantine period. The police said that Patel, a resident of Kamalpura village, had returned to India from Nepal and was screened at New Delhi airport. On reaching Vadodara he was asked to remain in home quarantine.

But on March 24, he went to Nadiad to his brother-in-law’s home. The health department informed police about it following which a case was registered at Savli police station on Thursday.

“The man has been put under quarantine at government centre in Nadiad now as he violated the instructions,” a police official said.

An offence was registered against Ramiz Salim (26) a resident of Kalol in Panchmahal after he entered into arguments with a health team and did not follow home quarantine instructions. Ramiz, who had returned from Georgia was advised home quarantine.

When a health team visited him on March 22, Ramiz was asked to stay inside his house wearing a mask and answer the health team’s queries. Instead, he came out of his house without a mask and also started to argue when the team asked him his family’s details. The team recorded a video of the entire incident and then registered an offence against Ramiz.

Title: Healthcare professionals too face police excesses
Content:
Kannur: The police action in the name of enforcing the lockdown has gone out of control in many places of Kasaragod and even health professionals were not spared. Some vegetable traders and dairy farmers alleged that the police excesses have crossed all limits.

According to Dr Aravind Ashok, the police thrashed him with a baton when he stepped out of his Vidyanagar home to buy child food for his one-year-old son around 11am before going for duty at Primary Health Centre in Badiadka.

Incidentally, he is in charge of the isolation ward there, where six Covid-19 cases are under observation.

This is not an isolated case and the police excess has affected the morale of the health and medical workers. Some nurses and other paramedical professionals too were not spared.

A pharmacist had to face the fury of the police on two occasions on Thursday, and only after district police chief PS Sabu made a strong intervention he was released.

The police excesses have gone beyond limit in some places and this should be condemned, said Kerala Government Medical Officers’ Association (KGMOA).

The development has upset a section of the police officers in the district. “We have given clear instruction to the police that there should not be any excess but despite this some issues have come to our notice and we are looking into it,” said the district police chief. “Anyhow, we will make sure that there are no untoward acts on the part of the police, and we are seriously looking into it.”

Title: Delhi: Ration shops likely to stay open seven days from Monday
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: With the daily distribution of wheat, rice and sugar at fair price shops likely to begin from March 30, the food and civil supplies department on Thursday asked ration dealers to make adequate arrangements to avoid crowding.

Following a review meeting, food and civil supplies minister Imran Hussain said the distribution should be carried out smoothly without any inconvenience to the beneficiaries. He also asked 2,000-odd fair price shops across the city to stay open seven days a week in public interest.

In the wake of the novel coronavirus spread, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal last week enhanced the monthly quota of ration by one and a half times and made it free for about 72 lakh beneficiaries — 18 lakh families — for April.

Issuing a slew of directives, Hussain told the dealers to observe necessary precautions to ensure their own safety as well as that of the beneficiaries while distributing ration items. “They should ensure that beneficiaries don’t make rush at shops. The beneficiaries should be informed in advance that sufficient stocks are available and they should come later in case of crowding,” the minister said.

In case of queues, beneficiaries will have to maintain one-meter distance and they must also be encouraged to use masks and hand sanitisers. One civil defence volunteer will be deployed at each shop to assist the dealer while senior officers will ensure proper distribution.

Expecting a huge rush, the ration dealers early this week asked the government to make arrangements to ensure social distancing at their shops. In a letter, they requested the food and civil supplies department to devise a mechanism so that the beneficiaries do not have to sign the register.

The minister also asked legal metrology department officials to ensure availability of masks and hand sanitisers in market and take strict action against those overcharging or hoarding these items.

Title: Gandhi hospital likely to treat only Covid-19 cases in Telangana
Content: HYDERABAD: The government has decided to convert Gandhi Hospital into a full-fledged facility to treat only novel coronavirus patients if the number of Covid-19 positive cases see a spurt. Health minister Eatala Rajender on Thursday asked health department officials to make the necessary arrangements in Gandhi Hospital and directed the director of medical education to shift all the departments to Osmania General Hospital by this month-end.As many as 45 people had tested positive for the coronavirus in Telangana and nine of them had contracted the virus through others. In the wake of rise in the number of positive cases, he asked the officials to come up with a list of requirement for additional equipment and manpower at Gandhi Hospital.“Elective surgeries have already stopped at Gandhi and patients are referred to OGH. Shifting of other departments from Gandhi to OGH should be completed by March-end. King Koti hospital should also be kept ready to treat coronavirus patients,” Rajender said.A committee has been constituted headed by Kaloji Health University vice-chancellor Karunakar Reddy to utilise the services of private hospitals and private medical colleges. “If the number of patients keep rising, we would first need personal protection kits, ventilators and other equipment.” He directed MD of Telangana State Medical Infrastructure Development Corporation Chandrasekhar Reddy to place orders for the equipment immediately.He asked health and police officials to send surveillance teams mainly to monitor people under home quarantine. “No leaves will be given to PHC staff and Asha workers. Food and transportation should be provided to them,” he said.

Title: Municipal chief warns traders against inflating prices
Content:
Kolhapur: Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti on Thursday informed that they have not received any complaint regarding price inflation of vegetables and essential commodities.

He added that if anyone is found to be indulged in such activities, they will face strict action.

The rate of vegetable fluctuate on a daily basis and depending on the availability of the produce, the prices keep changing. Hence, the district administration has to verify reports on price rise, black marketing and hoarding.

“During these testing times we will not tolerate any action like unnecessary price rise or hoarding of essential commodities," Desai said.

Kalshetti said that on the grocery front, he visited a few grocery shops in the city and advised them to collect list of groceries from buyers and deliver it directly to their homes.

“Social distancing is the need of the hour. Hence, we have moved the vegetable market to different spots across the city. The places are marked keeping in the social distancing norm,” he said, adding that the ward committee is working towards facilitating easy supply of the essential commodities in different wards and are coordinating with the local corporators.

Title: Goa University postpones all exams until further orders
Content: PANAJI: Goa University (GU) controller of examinations in an order issued on Thursday said that all exams stand postponed until further notice. The order further states that the dates will be announced at least 14 days before the exam commences.“As approved by the vice-chancellor and in view of the ongoing shutdown of educational institutions in Goa due to the prevailing Covid-19 situation in the country, I am directed to inform you that all examinations of Goa University, scheduled as per the existing academic terms for 2019-20, stand postponed until further notice,” the order, issued to all GU deans, head of departments and affiliated colleges, states.Opposition leader Digambar Kamat tweeted that is was a “welcome decision by @GoaUniversity”.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Unruly scenes continue at other checkposts
Content:
GUNTUR: Even as the officials resolved the chaotic situation at inter-state border at Garikapadu of Krishna district, tension continued at Vadapalli bridge (Guntur-Nalgonda) and Putlur toll plaza (Mahabubnagar-Kurnool) as hundreds of students and employees got stuck at the check-posts.

They have been appealing to the officials of both the states to allow them to home. AP DGP Gautam Sawang made it clear that there is no question of allowing people from other states into the state.

“The very purpose of lockdown to fight Covid-19 would be defeated if thousands of people are allowed to cross the borders and move here and there,” said Sawang.

The police manning the inter-state check-posts have, however, refused to grant them passage to either side making it clear that no one would be allowed to cross the states in the wake of the complete lockdown.

Students and software engineers, who were evicted from the paying guest hostels in Hyderabad, took the Miryalaguda-Dachepalle route to enter the state after getting reports about heavy traffic jam on the national highway near Girikapadu in Krishna district.

To their shock, massive police force was found at the bridge. Police had blocked the entry of vehicles from Telangana three days ago.

A similar situation was seen at Putlur toll plaza where students from both the states were stranded. While students of Telangana undergoing coaching for bank examinations in Nandyal of Kurnool district wanted to reach their native places after the hostels were closed, the students and techies from Hyderabad wanted to reach home in Rayalaseema districts. A good number of women devotees returning from Srikalahasthi in Chittoor district to Hyderabad were also stuck up at the toll plaza as the police refused to go ahead.

Title: Woman kills self after fight with hubby over kids not studying
Content:
Nagpur: A domestic quarrel arising out of lockdown circumstances led a woman to commit suicide at her home on Wednesday. Seema Shahu, 35, hanged herself from the ceiling fan at her Bajrang Nagar home using a nylon rope, after a fight with her husband over studies of their children .

According to police, Seema, who worked as atailor, was living with her husband and two children, aged 13 and 9. The children used to be home all day as their school and tuitions are closed due to lockdown. She was troubled that they spent the day playing and used urged them to study as she wanted them to be government employees.

On Tuesday Seema as usual asked them to study but they were not listening to her. As she continued to chide them for not studying, her husband asked her to stop and let the kids play as they were stuck in the house. This started a quarrel between Seema and her husband Ashok.

On Tuesday night, the children went to bed after dinner but the couple did not eat anything.

Cops said Seema was very disturbed by the fight with her husband. Sometime in the night she hanged herself. The incident came to light on Wednesday morning when Ashok saw her hanging and raised an alarm. Neighbours rushed to his house and also informed Kalamna police who too reached the spot.

Cops sent Seema’s body to Mayo hospital after conducting spot panchanama . The post-mortem was conducted on Wednesday and body was handed over to her relatives who performed her last rites. Kalamna police have registered a case of accidental death in the matter.

Title: Allahabad HC: Lawyers can take up urgent cases after email
Content:
Allahabad high court

PRAYAGRAJ: In view of the closure of Allahabad High Court and its Lucknow judicature till further orders in view of threat of coronavirus, the high court administration on Thursday launched two e-mail addresses where lawyers can make a request for taking up their cases on the ground of urgency. One website is available for the lawyers practiCing at Allahabad high court and another for those who are practising at its Lucknow judicature. In the notification issued on Thursday, registrar general Ajay Kumar Srivastava made it clear that mentioning of imminently emergent and urgent cases will no longer be entertained on mobile numbers, which were provided earlier. Henceforth, mentioning of imminently emergent and urgent cases of Allahabad High Court will be made on urgentlisting_allahabad@allahabadhighcourt.in only. Likewise, for the matters pertaining to Lucknow Bench, the mentioning of imminently emergent and urgent case can be made on urgentlisting_lucknow@allahabadhighcourt.in only. Earlier, through a notification dated March 23, the high court administration had provided some mobile number of its officers of registry for mentioning of imminently emergent and urgent cases. However, through the present notification, a modification has been made and mentioning can be made only through the above-mentioned e-mail addresses.

Title: Indian Railways mulls plan to turn coaches into isolation wards
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: Indian Railways (IR) is mulling a plan to convert train coaches into isolation wards to pitch in with the action plan being readied to fight the novel coronavirus pandemic in the country.Railways is trying to convert a coach at the coaching depot in New Delhi on a trial basis after consulting medical professionals.“A sleeper coach of a train is being converted and improvised into an isolation wards for patients suffering from Covid-19. Such a plan can help us be well-prepared to meet any emergency,” said North Central Railway (NCR) general manager Rajiv Chaudhry.Besides, all railway divisions have identified a ward or building for setting up isolation beds for Covid-19 patients.Likewise, Indian Railways Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) is working out a plan to serve meals in different parts of the country and hospitals, if the need so arises.Chief public relations officer (CPRO) of NCR Ajeet Kumar Singh said, “NCR has taken necessary steps to ensure operational safety to mitigate any possibility of disruption in goods trains.”In big yards, where maintenance requires concentration of staff, speed of goods trains has been reduced to 15kmph to sustain required operation and maintenance with social distancing, he informed.Similarly, NCR is considering an extension of the mandatory Paramedical Medical Examination (PME) of safety category and running staff to boost its medical facilities.“NCR is also imparting training to its paramedical staff on for Covid-19 related procedures, especially ventilators. Videos available on Union ministry of health & family welfare’s website are being used to train staff,” said Chaudhry.

Title: During lockdown, donate blood from home
Content: Nagpur: In a unique initiative which kicked off in city on Thursday, blood donation drive was done without donors leaving their house. CREDAI Nagpur Metro and NGO Round Table India (RTI) are arranging for ambulance and medical staff to reach donor homes and collect blood.Since the lockdown has restricted willing blood donors’ movement, this initiative by the two organizations will ensure that blood banks remain fully stocked.Gaurav Agrawala, secretary of CREDAI Nagpur Metro, said, “While the focus naturally remains on Covid-19, we need to have ample blood stock. We wanted to help in facilitating collection of blood from donors so no shortage arises in view of the ongoing scenario.”After meeting with the authorities, the two organizations used their resources and tied up with blood banks and arranged for logistics to get the plan rolling. “On the first day we had seven donors till 4PM, the number might increase later. For Thursday, we have booking for around 50 donors,” said Agrawala.The are planning to tie up with housing societies where at one place they could get dozens of potential donors.Sharad Agarawal of RTI said, “During such times it is important valuable stock of blood is available with the authorities. And health officials have confirmed there is no fear of getting coronavirus infection from blood transfusion. Since it is perfectly safe and also crucial requirement, we decided to facilitate the same.”Huzefa Hussain was one of the first donors today and said that it was a gratifying experience. “People need not be worried at all about donating blood because coronavirus has nothing to do with it. As long as you maintain basic hygiene, cover up with a mask, it’s all fine. I hope more people join in this cause as it will help keep our blood banks full,” said Hussain.Speaking to TOI, GSK Blood Bank’s managing director Dr Ashish Khandelwal who collected the blood at Hussain’s residence, said, “We collected blood in staggered manner. All the social distancing norms were strictly adhered to. We plan to collect more blood in days to come, but it will be in very limited numbers.”As of now, at least three donors are required if one wishes to avail this service.Those willing to donate just need to call on 9890039000, 9823111700 or 9823233633 and make a booking for donation.

Title: Permission to sell essentials till 1 pm bears positive result, crowd ebbs
Content: VIJAYAWADA: With the district administration and Vijayawada Municipal Corporation stepping in, people started adhering to social distancing while waiting in queues to buy vegetables and other essential commodities on Thursday.Many were seen waiting in queues at rythu bazaars following social distancing. Makeshift vegetable markets arranged by the district administration across city received a positive response. All stores and markets selling essential commodities remained open till 1 pm.With the lockdown announced by the state government on Sunday, markets selling essential commodities remained crowded. Officials who initially failed to control the crowds had started marking 1 sq metre boxes with chalk powder at vegetable markets.Officials deployed special forces at vegetable markets and ensured that there was no crowd at a single stall. Agriculture marketing officials made efforts to maintain huge stocks of vegetables at markets. Makeshift markets arranged at Punnami Ghat, MK Baid School and Potti Sriramulu College helped reduce crowds.Minister Velampalli Srinivas and Vijayawada central legislator Malladi Vishnuvardhan inspected vegetable markets and interacted with the buyers and stall owners. Most buyers expressed satisfaction over the arrangements made. Stallholders requested the government to arrange tents.“We are fighting the coronavirus which is creating terror across the globe. People should stop panic buying as it increased the risk of spreading coronavirus. Permitting stores selling essential commodities to operate until 1 pm has given positive results,” the minister said.Officials deployed special forces at vegetable markets and ensured that there was no crowd at a single stall. Agriculture marketing officials made efforts to maintain stocks

Title: Vijayawada: Police high-handedness to the fore in many areas
Content:
Police punish commuters for breaching lockdown in Vijayawada

VIJAYAWADA: As the second day of national lockdown progressed, pictures and videos emerged of people being assaulted by police for violating lockdown across Vijayawada and Krishna district police units on Thursday.

One of the videos shot by a local youth showed Nunna police personnel in Vijayawada caning youngsters loitering around the streets. The cops then forced them to do sit-ups on the road for violating the national curfew.

Tension prevailed in Hanuman Junction in Krishna district after the police lathi-charged and thrashed journalists on their duties. Infuriated, they sat in front of the road condemning ‘police brutality’. Supporting their protest, the state journalist union too demanded action against the cops. Responding to the incident, Information and Public Relations (I&PR) minister Perni Nani assured that they would be suspending Eluru DSP who was present in the premises and requested the journalists to stop their protests.

Another video showed an electricity board employee identified as G Madhava Raj claiming that he was beaten up by the cops at Gollapudi while returning home after repairing a transformer. He threatened to boycott work if they are ill-treated.

Title: Corp to set up community kitchen at 5 zones
Content:
Kochi: In an effort to ensure that no person in the city is facing difficulties in getting meals, Kochi Corporation will set up community kitchen at five zones in the local body’s limits . In the initial stage, cooked meals will be given to the poor families free of cost at noon. The local body authorities also plan to extend the services and deliver food to all those who demand.

The plan is to start the kitchens at Mattancherry town hall, Palluruthy town hall, Ernakulam town hall, Vyttila and Edappally from Friday. “We plan to procure rice from Supplyco, groceries from Consumerfed and vegetables from Horticorp. We have held discussions with the officials with these agencies. We expect that Supplyco may give rice free of cost, and vegetables and grocery may get at bulk purchase rates,” mayor Soumini Jain said. “We have given Rs 10,000 each to health inspectors as mobilisation funds. So, they can procure rice and other items required immediately without waiting for the arrangement which we plan in association with Supplyco, Consumerfed and Horticorp. Noon meals will be provided to poor and needy in each area. Division councillors and health inspectors should decide the beneficiaries,” the mayor said. “Initially, the food supply will be limited to destitute, elderly and those who live an isolated life in their homes,” she said.

The corporation will make arrangements for delivering the meals to the beneficiaries. Besides the councillors’ service, NGOs also would be roped in for delivering the food. There are also plans to deploy delivery boys if needed. “We expect that at least 1,000 meals will have to be prepared at each zone. Chairpersons of standing committees have been entrusted with the responsibility of managing each zone,” Jain said.

In Edappally area, the kitchen will be set up at zonal office of the corporation at Anjumana. “There is already a canteen in the zonal office. If we require more space, we may explore other options,” said M B Muraleedharan, councillor from Vennala division who is one of the councillors to manage the operations of the kitchen at Edappally. “We have contacted the office-bearers of NSS Karayogam hall in the area. If we have to cook more food, we will shift to there. In the initial stage, the meals will be delivered to the poor and needy only and it will be free of cost. If demand arises, we will deliver food to others as well. Then, we will charge Rs 20 per meal given to such persons. They will also have to pay Rs 5 as delivery charge,” Muraleedharan said.

Kudumbashree also will be helping the local body authorities in setting up community kitchens. “As per the government’s decision, it is up to the local bodies to set up community kitchen. But, we will provide support to the civic bodies, if required,” an official with Kudumbashree said.

Meanwhile, Kerala Hotel and Restaurant Association leaders have offered to handover their hotels for preparing meals for community Kitchen.

Corporation authorities started spraying disinfectant on major roads on Thursday. The corporation authorities have hired three vehicles equipped with high-power spraying machines for it. They plan to disinfect all the major roads and public places within a week.

Title: Make that social call digitally, say experts
Content:
Kochi: Social distancing can cause distress to most people who are happy being in touch with fellow-beings. With ‘stay at home’ or ‘work from home’ being enforced, psychiatrists say that people will have a tough time dealing with staying indoors and no socializing .

When TOI spoke to psychiatrists on how people can deal with this, the common advice was to stay in digital communication with people. “This distancing can cause distress to socially-inclined people. When enforced as a public health measure, one needs to accept it. Like in a crisis, there is a need to develop resilience to this loss of face-to-face contact with people in social and job situations,” said Dr C J John, a renowned psychiatrist.

He said that there are two sections of people staying at home — one is with family and other without family. “When you are working from home and the family is with you, the family needs to give you a private space for work and also distract them during their free-time. In a way, one should say that they are better off and more blessed,” he added.

One of the most disturbing aspects is the situation of people who are alone at home because the offices have requested them to be on standby. “Living amidst an information overload alone can be a problem. Processing information is also important. Better rely on official sources only. The option for digital connectivity can be effectively used here too. It’s important to share feelings with someone when there is a perception that things are going out of control. Social distancing should never be transformed to loneliness,” Dr John said.

The cornerstone for psychological health is physical health, said Dr U Vivek, a city-based psychiatrist. “Don’t neglect physical activity. Exercise for half an hour. It is a must and can be done indoors along with a nutritious and balanced diet. Make sure you get an undisturbed sleep of 6-8 hours. This is a prerequisite for psychological well-being.”

This is the time to teach and make your young ones understand that discipline matters. “When the government, as an authority, tells you to stay inside for keeping the rest of the society safe, you have to respect that. And when you do it properly, you are passing on a very important lesson to the younger ones in your home,” said Thrissur-based psychiatrist Dr Shailaja Ramkumar.

She said that this is the best time to make those communications in the family. “If you have elderly, let the children spend time with them. Couples can sit and spend time talking or doing all the pending work which has been postponed due to busy schedules.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Ordinance to clear budget for 1st quarter
Content:
Y S Jaganmohan Reddy, CM Andhra Pradesh

AMARAVATI: The state cabinet chaired by chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy will meet at the secretariat on Friday. The cabinet will give its nod for the ordinance to clear the budget for first quarter of the next fiscal. Jagan has decided to go for the ordinance route to clear the budget in the wake of the health emergency following the outbreak of Covid-19.

Initially, the CM wanted to conduct the assembly session and clear the vote-on-account for the first quarter of the fiscal. The situation changed after Prime Minister declared a nation-wide lockdown till April 14. Secretariat Employees’ Association president K Venkatramireddy also urged the CM to suspend the assembly session and opt for the ordinance route to clear the budget. He cited a previous instance when the government secured permission for the budget through ordinance.

Subsequently, the CM held discussions with the ministers, senior officials and advocate general S Sriram. Taking their views into consideration, the CM decided to bring an ordinance to clear the budget till June 30.

Sources said that senior officials have advised that cabinet too could be deferred by taking the signatures of available ministers on the file as there was no sufficient space in the cabinet meeting hall to maintain the social distancing.

However, the CM decided to convene the cabinet meeting and directed the officials to shift the venue of the meeting to the spacious conference hall in the first floor of the block-I in the secretariat instead of regular cabinet meeting hall.

Sources said that the finance department had almost drafted the annual budget thinking that the budget session would commence in the last week of March. As per sources, the finance department had reportedly put the budget outlay at Rs 1.95 lakh crore. The government approved the previous budget with Rs 2.27 lakh crore.

Apart from clearing the budget, the cabinet would also review the measures being taken to combat Covid-19 in the state.

Title: Patients’ plight: Discharged, but forced to stay at KGMU-Lucknow
Content:
Patients are staying in the corridors of KGMU

LUCKNOW: Hundreds of people, whose kin were undergoing treatment in the King George ’s Medical University (KGMU) and now have been discharged, are facing a tough time these days. Because of the lockdown they are not able to return to their homes in other districts and are forced to stay under sheds or 'rain baseras' outside KGMU wards.

They are not only facing problems in getting essential supplies, but are also living under constant fear of catching infections.

Because of the curb on inter-city movement, most of the people are unable to return to their homes in other cities. Private ambulances or taxi drivers are available to drop them to their destinations, but they are demanding hefty amounts. Usually people of weak financial background visit KGMU for treatment from different cities. In most of suh cases only an attendant stays with the patient during the treatment, while rest of the family takes refuge in open space outside wards or 'rain baseras'. For food and other essential items they are fully dependent on vendors outside the KGMU campus.

However, after the lockdown most of the nearby eateries are closed and these people are finding it difficult to get raw material for cooking food. A reality check by TOI found scores of people outside the Trauma Centre, Gandhi ward and Shatabdi Hospital, following no social distancing norm.

Nibhi Devi (24), who had severe infection in her legs due to the diabetic foot, had come to KGMU trauma centre on March 18 after being referred by doctors at her native place in Gopalganj , Bihar. She was operated upon recenlty and was discharged on Sunday.

But as no public transport was available due to restrictions, she along with her husband was forced to take shelter under a shed outside Trauma Centre.

KGMU chief medical superintendent Prof SN Sankhwar said that he is aware of the problem and will inform district administration about it.

Title: Man walks 135km from Nagpur to reach home in Sindewahi
Content:
Narendra Shelke (left) was rescued by Sindewahi police some 25km from his village in Saoli teshil of Chandrapu... Read More

CHANDRAPUR: A person working at Ahmednagar had to walk for over 135 kilometres from Nagpur to reach his home in Saoli teshil of Chandrapur district following the travel ban due to coronavirus scare. He was rescued by Sindewahi police some 25km from his village.

Narendra Shelke is resident of village Jambh in Saoli teshil and works as a labourer at a sugar factory in Ahmednagar. The 7-day lockdown announced by chief minister Uddhav Thackeray from Tuesday caught all the labourers off guard. Being desperate, the labourers from Nagpur along with Shelke took a private vehicle immediately and started for Nagpur on Tuesday morning. However, by that time PM Modi had announced national lockdown. As their taxi reached Nagpur on Tuesday night, entire nation went into complete lockdown.

PSI Gopichand Nerkar, who rescued Shelke in Sindewahi, informed that labourers from Nagpur went to their home and taxi returned to Ahmednagar. Shelke was left stranded in Nagpur. Having failed to find any help and nobody to give him a lift, Shelke decided to walk back home during wee hours of Wednesday.

He took Nagpur-Nagbhid road and started walking towards his destination. He was intercepted by police in Umred. The cops helped him get lift in a truck but it took him for just a few kms and again he was dropped, PSI Nerkar quoting Shelke informed.

Shelke again began to walk on foot towards his destination and reached Sindewahi tehsil headquarter still 25km away from his village by late in the night. He had travelled over 135km on foot by the time cops stopped him at Shivaji Chowk in Sindewahi. As an exhausted Shelke narrated his woe, police took him to local rural hospital and brought him some food from their home, said PSO, Sindewahi Nishikant Ramteke.

He stated Shelke survived on just water for two days after starting from Ahmednagar. As soon as he recovered his strength, police took help of local NGO and arranged his transport to village Jambh in Saoli teshil, Ramteke said.

Sindewahi police informed the local authorities in Saoli about Shelke’s arrival and he was put into home quarantine immediately after arrival at his village, Ramteke said. Shelke himself could not be contacted.

Title: ‘Lockdown Bird Challenge’ amid Covid-19 crisis
Content: Aurangabad: While the country is under lockdown to contain the spread of Covid-19, an expert group — Bird Count India — has come up with an initiative to turn the situation into a positive contribution by recording the winged creatures around homes.Known for supporting, listing and monitoring of birds in a scientific manner, the group has announced ‘ Lockdown Bird Challenge ’ from Friday till the restrictions are lifted.“Do you see bird species you haven’t recorded before? Which species are found where in your city? What is the behaviour of the birds you see? You can contribute to answering these questions and more through the Lockdown Birding Challenge,” a release said.As part of the initiative, amateurs, as well as experts, are expected to look for birds for 15 minutes, standing at the same place during different time slots such as 4 am-6 am (optional), 6 am -9 am (at least one list), 4 am to 7 pm (at least one list), 7 pm-10 pm (optional).The purpose of the pre-dawn and the night lists are to document early-rising birds and nocturnal species respectively.The lists of bird spotted can be uploaded on eBird platform (ebird.org/india). The eBird mobile app is one of the easiest ways to upload sightings.“As with our other birding challenges, all those who manage to meet the target will be named on our website, and one among them will be chosen at random to receive a small gift in appreciation. Participants must ensure that they adhere to all instructions by central and local authorities while birding,” organisers said.

Title: ‘Angels’ were always with me, day and night’
Content: When I reached the Medical College Hospital in Kalamassery on March 20, I was praying hard for my test to be negative. I gave my samples and was sent home to self-quarantine. But unfortunately, after a day, I was tested positive for Covid-19 and was moved to the isolation facility on March 22.The first few days were tiresome since I was put on strong medications. Once I started regaining my strength I tried to get to know about the ‘angels’ who were taking care of me. They were always around, wrapped in body suits, day and night, to ensure that we are well taken care of. And people outside have no idea about the things they go through. Everyone has been busy complaining about how hard it was to spend 21 days at home, but they are not aware about the fact that many of these healthcare workers have not been able be with their family as well.When Covid-19 struck the UK, my parents tried their best to get me back home. Authorities were imposing travel restrictions and I knew I had to reach India before March 18. I managed to book a flight to Chennai via Dubai on March 16. I had developed a sore throat by then. From Dubai airport I booked a flight to Kochi but by the time I reached Chennai, I had only half an hour left to catch the Kochi flight. The long line for immigration clearance made things even more horrible. I got clearance but unfortunately by the time I reached the gate, my flight had taken off. I was panicking, and my health had deteriorated completely.But I was determined not to lose hope and booked a morning flight to Kochi. I was forced to spend 10 hours at the airport. There was panic in the eyes of everyone I saw there. And I had to make sure that I did not fall asleep in the airport or be near others as I was worried about getting infected with coronavirus. My body had given up on me, my head was pounding and I experienced a burning sensation in my head. Those 10 hours felt like 10 days. I somehow managed to kill time and it was time for me to board the next flight. Landing in Kochi made my heart pound for some reason and my eyes welled up. Finally, I was home.While they were screening me for coronavirus at the airport, I made sure that I informed the authorities about my complete travel history and provided them with all my flight details. I was asked to self-quarantine for 14 days. Coming out of the airport I saw my dad waiting for me and I wanted to hug him, but I did not.My dad had shifted my mom to our uncle’s house and he was fully prepared for the next 14 days of home quarantine . We were doing fine until I started getting chills and my temperature kept fluctuating. We informed Disha (the 24X7 helpline) and doctors about the situation and I was asked to go to the facility at Kalamassery. It has been a stressful week since. But now, I am feeling better and hope I will recover soon.(The writer is a student who returned from the UK. Name withheld on request)

Title: Hyderabad: Sale of homes drops 50%, experts say coronavirus a reason for slowdown
Content: HYDERABAD: The city witnessed at 50% drop in sale of homes between January and March in 2020, with only 2,680 residential properties sold during this period. In 2019, the first quarter sales stood at 5,400 units, show data compiled by Anarock Property Consultants. Among other factors, experts attributed this slowdown to the Covid-19 outbreak and the subsequent lockdown , which, they said, has led to a drop in site visits, impacted the sentiment of buyers and pushed them into a “cash conservation mode”.“Given the ongoing global healthcare calamity, housing sales and new project launches across India’s top seven cities decreased both on yearly and quarterly basis. As expected, monthly data trends reveal that March –when most advisories and lockdown were imposed - saw a decline in both new launches and housing sales against the preceding two months,” said Anuj Puri, chairman, Anarock, adding, “The government has taken an inarguably necessary hard-line stance to curtail the spread of the virus. The lockdowns have stalled construction activity and will lead to project delays in the future.””As per the report, new launches in Hyderabad dipped by 11% during the first three months of 2020. The city saw 3,380 (approx.) launches during this period. “While Ugadi is a usually the time for new project launches, this year many builders refrained from it. But, I still think it is too soon to gauge the impact of Covid-19 on the realty sector. It has only been a week since work has stopped,” said R Suresh Kumar, senior vice president (business operations), Prestige Group. He added, “There were other factors, including logistical issues, that led to a slowdown of the sector. It isn’t the health crisis alone.”Stating that the situation would be clearer only by the end of April, industry insiders said that the commercial sector too would be affected, with companies being more cautious with finances.

Title: Lockdown leaves truckers stranded on highways
Content:
Nagpur: The ongoing lockdown has also left many truckers stranded at the highways. On the roads leading to the city, truckers who came with loaded vehicles are not able to take them further to their destinations. Those who have unloaded their cargohere, are also stuck.

For nearly a week, the trucks have become home to their drivers and helpers who are managing with the rations they carried. As cash is running out, even ATMSsin the outer areas are dry, said the drivers along the Nagpur Amravati highway. The dhabas have also closed.

“One of our vehicles was supposed to reach a consignment of medicines to Lupin’s warehouse at Kalmeshwar but now the truck cannot move further. There are some empty trucks of our company too which cannot return,” said Balkrishna Pandey, who was resting with other drivers in one of the vehicles.

“Food has not been a problem so far as we carry rations along. To start fires, we use diesel from vehicles. We are buying supplies from shops in nearby areas but are running short of cash. We hope to get some help from the company’s office soon,” said Pandey who hopes the lockdown would not go beyond 21 days. “Even the police are offering help, but we have been able to manage so far,” he said.

Pandey and other drivers had come from Mumbai and are working for a Gujarat based transport company.

Manikchand Tiwari, a native of Allahabad, said he could not find cash in ATMs close by and has run out of money. “There is no money left and I cannot find cash in ATMs too. The wait seems endless,” he said.

Nanhe Soni, a worker who applies grease in the trucks, is jobless these days but says he can manage. “I am on fast due to Navratri,” he says. A little ahead Afsar and Salman said they were helped by locals yesterday.

Kukku Marwah, president of Nagpur Truckers Unity, said, “there is a longer queue at the Pardi Naka. Members of our association had gone there to distribute food but the police stopped us a kilometre away and allowed only one driver at a time driver to pick up the meals from a distance. We have not reached out to them again.”

Meanwhile, Pandey and others are happy they can recharge their mobile phones at nearby shops and talk to their family members. “We have charging equipment with us too,” he said.

Title: GMCH docs did not test woman who had no foreign travel history
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has confirmed that the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) authorities has refused to test a suspected Covid-19 woman after she told them that she didn’t have any foreign travel history.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe along with the collector Ravindra Thakare were directed by the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court on Monday, to verify the claims made in a media report which was submitted by petitioner’s counsel Ram Heda while hearing a PIL (No10/2020) by businessman Subhash Zanwar on Monday.

The petitioner had prayed for a slew of directives, including activation of the disaster recovery task force for every district to respond to the threats emerging due to deadly virus.

Highly reliable sources from the corporation told TOI that the woman was taken in the NMC vehicle to the GMCH after being referred by her family doctor. But, the GMCH authorities didn’t entertain her after she denied any contact with any foreign nationals or having visited abroad ever.

Raising concern over a media report, Heda had pointed out that the woman from Hindustan Colony, who was suffering from cough, cold and was running high fever, had visited the GMCH for coronavirus testing, on advice of her family doctor.

“At this stage, we can’t make any comment about the genuineness of the report. But, we can certainly say that this report raises a serious concern over the safety of all those persons who have happened to come in contact with any of such patients since last few days and who were likely to come in their contact in days to come,” a division bench comprising justices Sunil Shukre and Avinash Gharote said.

The bench added that it would be therefore, necessary for the collector and commissioner to get this report verified for its correctness. “If it’s found upon verification that the report is correct, the authorities would have to take necessary steps in the matter. Needless to say, verification report shall be placed before this court,” the judges said, before adjourning the hearing till April 7.

They asked the petitioner’s counsel to hand over the media report copy to additional government pleader Deepak Thakare and NMC counsel Sudhir Puranik.

Earlier, the court expressed satisfaction over steps taken by the civic body and district administration for containing spread of the deadly disease and effectively treating the confirmed patients. “However, some concerns still remain there. We’re of the view that they need to be addressed effectively and as quickly as possible,” the judges said.

Title: CBSE says crisis ‘golden opportunity’ to learn something new
Content: Nagpur: In a lengthy letter to all stakeholders, released only in Hindi for unknown reasons, CBSE has called the current crisis a golden opportunity for all as it offered ample time for teachers, parents and students to upgrade and re-focus on real purpose of education.Board secretary Anurag Tripathi talked about education system in advanced countries and said the content in books and topics being taught at schools were the same, yet there was a difference. Tripathi said in India we focused on teaching while they focused on learning. Since learning outcome was what the education system of advanced countries gravitated towards, it reflected on the final product as well.In the letter, part a moral booster and part a guideline on how to spend the time ahead, Tripathi wrote parents could think of utilizing the time to provide emotional support to children, playing with them and they learning new skills by participating in simple chores. Teachers, he said, could make the most of this break by upgrading themselves. He suggested making learning videos, preparing lesson plans and going over new pedagogies.Even on a day-to-day basis, Tripathi shared some ideas on how one could make the most of the time available. He said first thing in the morning everyone should do was some exercises which include stretching of legs and hands, or Yoga. He then suggested children to help their family members in doing various chores. He encouraged children to help parents in kitchen too as it will ‘be an enjoyable experience’.He encouraged children to engage in things for which they might not have found the time during a routine academic day like painting, singing, reading storybooks etc.Tripathi urged the children to engage in role play and recreate scene of a courtroom, a press conference, a market and enact the part. He even suggested recording these scenes and improving upon them by reviewing them again and again.Parents and children have been asked to make full use of the digital content being released by CBSE and HRD ministry and ensure that this lockdown became an opportunity to learn at home.

Title: Money trickles into relief fund as netas pitch in for fight
Content:
CHENNAI: Money is trickling into the chief minister ’s public relief fund with MPs and MLAs across many parties donating one month’s salary to the fund to fight Covid-19 outbreak in the state. Tamil Nadu governor Banwarilal Purohit has decided to donate a month’s salary to the fund, said a Raj Bhavan press release.

Sources told TOI that 98 DMK MLAs are donating their one-month salary, totalling Rs 1.02 crore. DMK and Congress MPs have been instructed by the respective parties to donate their one-month salary (Rs 1 lakh each) towards the fund. A communication from AIADMK party office said all its MPs would contribute Rs 1 crore each for fighting corona virus from MP LAD funds . AIADMK MLAs would contribute Rs 25 lakh each from their constituency development fund. Moreover, all of them would contribute one month’s salary to the relief fund.

Most MPs are allocating a portion of their constituency development fund for procuring masks, thermal sensors, ventilators and protective gears for health department staff. PMK MP Anbumani Ramadoss has given Rs 3 crore and MDMK chief Vaiko and AIADMK MP O P Ravindranath Kumar have donated Rs 1 crore each.

Madurai MP Su Venkatesan, who has recommended to the district collector to release Rs 50 lakh from his MPLAD fund, said two days ago, the Centre had announced that all MPs were free to allocate money from their constituency development fund to upgrade hospital facility. “I held a meeting with doctors in Madurai Rajaji Government Hospital and learned of their urgent requirement of masks and protective gears,” said Venkatesan. Till now, MPLAD funds allocated to health sector could be used only for construction of hospitals and not for purchase of medical equipment.

DMK south Chennai MP Tamilachi Thangapandian said she had written to Chennai corporation commissioner to release Rs 1 crore from her fund for purchase of protective gear for medical personnel, testing kits, gloves, sanitizers and other required material.
