Dharmapuri MP S Senthilkumar has allocated Rs 1 crore for setting up an isolation ward in Dharmapuri Medical College and Rs 20 lakh for improving facilities at Mettur government hospital. Without adequate facilities, it takes several days to get test results for people being admitted to Dharmapuri medical college with Covid-19 symptoms, said Senthilkumar.

AIADMK Rajya Sabha MP A Vijayakumar and DMK Tirunelveli LS MP S Gnanathiraviam have allocated Rs 1.6 crore each.

Meanwhile, many MLAs are consulting the respective district collectors and corporation commissioners to assess the needs of various hospitals. “Based on the requirement I receive from corporation commissioner, I will release funds. We distributed masks and sanitizers in Saidapet hospital in the morning,” said Saidapet MLA M Subramanian.

(With inputs from M K Ananth in Madurai and V Senthil Kumaran in Salem)

Title: MP to start kitchen for all at KGMU-Lucknow
Content:
KGMU, Lucknow

LUCKNOW: In view of the scarcity of food, BJP Rajya Sabha member Sanjay Seth will soon start a community kitchen for the attendants of patients at KGMU. Seth said he would also donate Rs 50 lakh from his MP fund to Balrampur Hospital .

Seth said he had written to the district magistrate to transfer Rs 50 lakh from his development fund to the Balrampur Hospital for purchasing ventilators and dialysis units.

Seth said he would soon set up a community kitchen at KGMU for patients and their attendants.

“Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister Yogi Adityanath are doing an excellent job in containing the outbreak of the disease and I, as MP and in personal capacity, would do my best to assist them,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus in Kochi: Staff shortage hits waste collection
Content: KOCHI: At a time when communicable diseases like Covid-19 are spreading in the city, waste collection in Kochi corporation limits has been disrupted. The difficulties in travelling forced many workers engaged in waste collection to stay indoors, thereby affecting door-to-door collection of garbage in the city.According to the officials with the corporation, they have given instructions to their workers to turn up and ensure smooth collection of garbage. Most of the workers come from distant places such as Aroor, Kuthiyathodu and Vaikom. “We have made arrangements for picking the workers living within corporation limits. We can’t conduct trips to distance places for picking the labourers as we will have to spend an entire day for the purpose,” said Anu R, secretary, corporation. “Residents also will have to adjust with the situation for the time being,” she said.Though the residents call up the councillors in each area, they also are unable to do anything to solve the problem. “In our area, collection of waste has been affected for the past two-three days. Contingency workers and other workers who are engaged in waste collection don’t turn up,” said Vijayakumar, councillor from Devankulangara division. Councillors are exploring options to bring the labourers from distance places so that the waste collection can be removed. “In our division, plastic waste is being collected every Wednesday. But, today few workers reached and so, there were problems in collecting the waste. I called up many of the workers and promised them help in their transport. Some of them have agreed to come from Friday after we reminded them of the gravity of the situation,” he said. “Some of them are not coming as they are afraid of police checking while another group doesn’t have motorcycles. With all public transport facilities having come to a stop, many of them are left with no option to arrive in Kochi,” said Baiju Thottali councillor of Vytilla-Janata division.Councillor Shyamala S Prabhu, who represents Cherlai division of the corporation, also raised similar concerns. “Moreover, the corporation authorities have made some changes in the deployment of workers for the purpose. Though the authorities have decided to deploy workers selected through employment exchange also, they are yet to complete the formalities. This adds to the crisis,” Shyamala said. Officials with health department in the district raised concerns regarding the chances of communicable diseases spreading in the city. “We are already in the middle of a crisis following Covid-19 spread. If waste is not collected and treated, it will lead to other communicable diseases also spreading in the city,” an official with health department said.Corporation authorities are still unable to provide adequate safety gears to the workers engaged in waste collection. “They haven’t given us masks and other safety equipment. Indiscriminate disposal of used masks also poses health risk for us,” a worker engaged in waste collection said.

Title: Lala Lajpat Rai staff threatens strike as cops in Kanpur thrash contractual employee
Content:
KANPUR: Lala Lajpat Rai Hospital employees threatened to go on strike after a class IV contractual employee was beaten up allegedly by Unnao police on Thursday.

The incident occurred when the employee was on way to attend duty at the hospital. A probe has been ordered.

The contractual employee, identified as Sudarshan Nishad, a resident of Pony Road, Shuklaganj , Unnao, was on way to attend duty when he was manhandled by Unnao police on Thursday morning.

"As I was about to reach Old Ganga bridge from Shuklaganj side, some policemen stopped me from heading further and asked me to return home. I showed them my ID- card and told them that I work with the LLR, but they refused to listen to my pleas and started beating me with a baton. Somehow, I escaped from there and reached LLR and apprised my colleague about the incident," Sudarshan told media persons at LLR.

Angered by the incident, the class IV staff of the LLR created ruckus and threatened to go on strike.

They raised slogans demanding strict action against the policemen. They threatened to go on strike if such incidents happen in future.

Senior LLR authorities rushed to the spot and assured employees of prompt action into the manhandling of their colleague. They later alerted Unnao district authorities and police officials.

ASP Unnao Vinod Kumar Shukla told TOI that after coming to know about the incident, he reached the spot. "I have instructed policemen on duty to not to stop anyone with ID-card. We are looking into the incident. Guilty policemen will face action," he added.

Title: Leopard intrudes into house, rescued
Content: Chandrapur: Even as world is scared of coronavirus pandemic, the man-animal has conflict continued at its pace in Chandrapur district. In latest incident, a full grown leopard was rescued from a house , after three-hour long operation in Telimendha village under Nagbhid forest range on Wednesday night.Sources in forest department informed that a leopard intruded into the house of Lokmat Satibawne in Telimendha on Wednesday evening, when the family members had gone to their relatives house.Upon returned, they found that somebody was hiding under a cot. As they tried to remove the cot, they were shocked to find a leopard was hiding underneath it.They immediately rushed out of house and locked it from outside. Forest officials of Nagbhid range rushed to the spot on getting information and began rescue operation at around 9pm. The rescue continued for three hours. Rescue team kept the cage with bait at the door of the room where leopard was hiding. some time the wild cat entered the cage and was captured.Sources claimed that the village had lost power supply during evening hours. The leopard might have came to the village pursuing an animal. It could have got confused during in the dark and went into the house. Officials claimed that it was two and half year old female leopard. It was checked for physical fitness and was released back into the wild on Thursday morning.

Title: Coronavirus in Bihar: Bihar reports 3 new Covid cases, total figure up to 7
Content: PATNA: Three Covid-19 positive cases, including a 12-year-old boy, were reported from Bihar on Thursday, taking the total number of cases to seven.The state health department confirmed that the minor and a 35-year-old woman from Munger district have tested positive, while the third case, that of a 21-year-old man from Patna, was confirmed by Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences (RMRI), Patna, director Dr Pradeep Das.All three persons who have tested positive had come in contact with the 38-year-old Munger resident who had died on Saturday and was found to be positive for Covid-19 on Sunday.State nodal officer for Covid-19, Dr Ragini Mishra said, “The 12 year old boy, whose sample tested positive, is the deceased's nephew, while the 35-year-old woman is his neighbour.”State health department principal secretary Sanjay Kumar too confirmed the third coronavirus positive case. "He is a ward boy at a private hospital on Bypass Road in the city where the Munger deceased was taken. He has been kept in the isolation ward of NMCH. The child and the woman have been kept in Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College and Hospital in Bhagalpur," the principal secretary said.Apart from the deceased Munger resident, two more people had tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday, but sources said the samples of their close contacts have been found to be negative.The fourth positive case of a man who had returned to Patna from Gujarat was reported on Wednesday. He is currently in the isolation ward at NMCH, which has been declared as a dedicated Covid-19 hospital in the state.Samples of his 25 contacts have been collected and sent to RMRI, Patna. “The tests will take around eight hours for completion,” the RMRI director said on Thursday evening.As per official data shared by the state health society on Thursday evening, a total of 469 samples have been collected, of which six have tested positive (three each from Patna and Munger) and 415 were negative. Result of 45 samples are awaited, while three got rejected.So far, 1,456 passengers had been enrolled for observation, out of which 210 have completed their 14 days observation period.

Title: Bihar: Online weddings in the times of corona
Content: PATNA: Among the casualties of the Covid-19 outbreak and the consequent nationwide lockdown are weddings that were scheduled to be held this month in Bihar . Many families have cancelled the ceremonies, but there are some couples who have chosen to take the tech route for long-distance marriage via video-conferencing.This week saw three such ‘Nikahs’ in the state — sisters Nagma and Rahat Parveen of Begusarai and Sadiya Nasreen from Patna chose to exchange their wedding vows without ‘band, baja and baraat’ through an online ceremony in the presence of a small group of family members and relatives.Sadiya and her groom Danish Raza, a native of Ghaziabad in Uttar Pradesh were scheduled to have their ‘nikah’ (marriage) on March 23 at a community hall in in Patna’s Haroon Nagar. But when the lockdown came, it was clear that Danish and his family will not be able to come with ‘baraat’ to Patna. The couple then decided to go ahead with the online wedding with the consent of their parents and clerics.“The lockdown announcement came a day before the wedding. With the consent of elders and clerics, the marriage was solemnised. A big reception ceremony would be held after the things would get better,” said a close relative of Sadiya.Their wedding ritual video went viral on social media on March 24 in which the bride and groom in their wedding fineries were seen sitting in front of the screen. The cleric read some marriage sermons from the Hadees at the bride’s home in Haroon Nagar. When Sadiya and Danish said ‘Qubool Hai’ (I accept), both families congratulated each other. The couple then came closer to the television screen to formally see each other’s faces after getting hitched.After the rituals, both families held mini-celebrations at their homes.The sisters Naghma and Rahat had married in a similar online ceremony at their home in Begusarai’s Choti Baliya village on March 25 evening. Taking inspiration from Sadiya’s video-conferencing wedding, Wali Ahmed Querashi organised online weddings for his daughters on the same evening.Bride’s father Wali said, “In order to restrict the spread of Covid-19, they decided to organise their wedding with the help of internet. A small celebration was also held at home.”Nagma got married to Shamshad of Jitanpura in Nalanda district, while younger daughter Rahat wedded Shashnawaz Alam , son of Kaleem of Jagdishpur in Gaya.However, Maulana Shibli Qasmi , general secretary of Imarat- e- Shariah, which has its jurisdiction over Bihar, Jharkhand and Odisha, said, “If such video-conferencing marriages are happening, then we need to tell people that it is not the right way of solemnising the Nikah.”

Title: Nitish OKs Rs 100 crore for natives stuck in lockdown
Content:
PATNA: CM Nitish Kumar on Thursday released Rs100 crore from the CM Relief Fund (CMRF) for making food and stay arrangements for persons from Bihar who are trapped within or outside the state on account of the nationwide lockdown due to the coronavirus outbreak. The same care would also be extended to those people from outside who are trapped in Bihar.

“The government will make arrangements to provide food and stay facility to persons from Bihar who are trapped at Patna or in any other town in the state as well as in other states due to the lockdown,” the CM said. “Nobody will be allowed to become a problem,” he said.

The decision was taken at a high-level meeting attended by deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi, water resources department minister Sanjay Kumar Jha, chief secretary Deepak Kumar, DGP Gupteshwar Pandey and disaster management department (DMD) principal secretary Pratyaya Amrit.

This is the second bunch of the ameliorative steps that the CM has announced in the last couple of days. The sum was released to the disaster relief fund (DRF) under the state’s DMD with a direction to all the 38 districts to create their own DRF with the fund provided to the department.

The fund is meant to take care of the rickshaw-pullers, daily wage and construction workers who have been rendered jobless due to the lockdown. “The government is making the food and stay arrangements at its own level,” the CM said, adding that “social distancing” norms would be followed in all these activities.

The state’s resident commissioner at Delhi would coordinate with those states and the district administrations concerned to track the Biharis trapped and provide them food and stay facility. The governments of other states would also make suitable arrangements to address problems facing people from Bihar who are trapped there, the CM also said.

Title: Social distancing move in Vadodara ignored
Content:
There was a sudden rush at the market in Padra taluka as it was closed for 4 days

VADODARA: Vadodara civic body’s aim to create social distancing backfired with a bang on Thursday when the Polo Ground witnessed a massive rush of citizens jostling one another to get fresh veggies at Khanderao market prices.

The historic Khanderao Market – city’s largest vegetable market – located in Vadodara Municipal Corporation’s backyard - has traditionally been Barodians’ favourite place for farm-fresh greens at affordable prices. But looking at the lockdown, VMC decided to shift the vendors here to the Polo Ground on Thursday as Khanderao market is too congested.

But the decision proved costly as it defeated the entire purpose of lockdown with hundreds swarming at the sprawling ground near Kirti Stambh to buy veggies after word spread like wildfire across the city.

After vendors reached the Khanderao market premises at about 4.30am on Thursday, they were asked to shift their stalls to Polo Ground. “We were baffled as the authorities didn’t inform us in advance of the plan. A few policemen told us that we need to shift to the Polo Ground and so we did accordingly. But what ensued was total chaos,” said Jitu Kachhiya, who has been selling veggies in Khanderao for the past 45 years. Kachhiya questioned the justification of bunching all the vendors together at one place. “When the government is advising social distancing,I don’t understand why all of us had to be shifted to a single spot. What was seen at Polo Ground was exactly opposite of what we are being told to do,” Kachhiya alleged.

Another vegetable vendor, Priyank Kachhiya alleged that while Khanderao has a good parking space and many gates to enter, Polo Ground had only a single gate leading to overcrowding at one spot. \

Many vegetable vendors also claimed that the cops were intercepting them at different points in the city and questioning them.

Title: Away from home, Goans live in fear and loneliness
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Chicalim-resident Hombal Yadavendra, who works as manager for a private firm, has been travelling regularly to Mumbai for a company project since October 2019. Earlier this month too, he left as usual to Mumbai, promising his wife and young child that he would return on March 23.

But while he was still in Mumbai, first the nation-wide Janata Curfew was announced, he then saw all local bus and train transportation stop and later the 21-day lockdown was announced.

“I was preparing to leave the day after the Janata Curfew, which was a Monday. My wife and young child are by themselves in Chicalim. Thanks to the kindness of neighbours they are surviving. But in this time of difficulty where the entire neighborhood is suffering, for how long will people be able to help,” said the 41-year-old.

Hombal is now worried that if the lockdown period is extended, his wife and child may be staring at worse conditions. “I am more worried how they will manage in the current situation in Goa. In Mumbai, there are proper systems in place and all essentials can be purchased from 9am to 11am. But it is in Goa that my family is suffering,” he said.

Margao-resident Dattaraj Lotliker, 30, has been working as a marketing executive for some time now in Rajkot, Gujarat. “I had a window of opportunity to leave for home. But, from Rajkot, there are no direct flights to Goa. It is a 4-5 hour bus journey to Ahmedabad, to be able to take a flight. If I had gone ahead with the journey, I would have put the lives of a lot of people at risk back home. I did not want to do that,” said Lotliker, who now only has his guitar and a few kind neighbours for company.

“On the day of the Janata Curfew, I made a wholesome meal for myself and overate not realising that a longer lockdown will be declared. I don't even have a kitchen here, only an induction cooker. There is a supermarket open nearby where only the essentials are available. But since I don't have a fridge, I have to plan carefully what I eat. I have to consume whatever I cook quickly,” said Lotliker.

A 70-plus neighbour, whom he calls Dadi, and an 80-year-old bachelor are providing him solace during this tough time, said the marketing executive.

“I am surviving thanks to their kindness. They allow me to store things in their fridge and share food with me. Otherwise, I am only reduced to spending my days cooking meals and washing the utensils. I am someone who goes crazy about a workout but I cannot exercise either now. Because there is no nutritional food to eat after the workout,” said Lotliker.

The Covid-19 fear has griped not just the common man but government officials as well who have to continue reporting for duty.

They are apprehensive about leaving their families at home during the 21-day complete lockdown. Speaking to TOI, at least two officers with government jobs expressed fear and concern that when their families are unable to move outdoors, their presence at home was the need of the hour.

One of them said he has small children at home who need many things which he is unable to provide. “It’s easier when you are in a city, but for people in rural areas it’s difficult to get access to provisions,” he said.

The other officer has turned to religion for solace at a time like this. He was envious of those who get to work from home, unlike him. “We do not have holidays and our families long for our presence. I am aware that my subordinates too feel this way,” he said.

(With inputs from Albert Fernandes)

Title: Lucknow: Medicines’ home delivery from today
Content:
Representative image

People can now expect relief in supply of medicines with the district administration granting permission to 91 pharma suppliers in the city for home delivery of drugs from Friday. People will have to call these suppliers and provide them details of prescription as well as name of the hospital and doctor to place the order. The supplier will have to ensure that the medicines are delivered the same day.

According to the order issued by DM Abhishek Prakash , the administration has shortlisted suppliers who are competent of undertaking call-based home delivery service.

The list with name and phone numbers of the suppliers can be accessed by visiting social media accounts and official website of the district administration.

“It will help reducing overcrowding at medical stores, helping in the containment of Covid-19” said drug inspector Madhuri Singh .

Title: Over 1,000 in home quarantine, stamp ink coming off next day
Content:
Nagpur: Even as several reports came in of home quarantined persons not adhering to guidelines, the stamps on the hands of these persons have been coming off the next day itself.

The district administration has so far stamped over 1,000 flyers, who have been either sent home with the compulsory advice of self-isolation, or held back at MLA Hostel. To ensure the flyers are not venturing out of their homes, health officials had stamped their hands, with what was supposed to be indelible ink, and stay on for the 14-day isolation period.

Sub-divisional officer Shekhar Ghadge claimed that inedible ink — used during voting in elections — had been used in the stamps. When told the ink came off, he said he will have to cross check with doctors who have been stamping passengers for any such complaints.

District collector Ravindra Thakare didn’t answer TOI’s calls and messages.

One of the flyers, who landed at Nagpur last week, said he was stamped in Mumbai. “I have to stay in self isolation till April 4. But after I took a bath, the stamp came off. Now, there is no way anyone can realize that I have been advised home quarantine, though I wouldn’t be going out till that period ends,” the flyer said.

During this period, several complaints have come in of home quarantined people found out of their homes. A woman had also fled to UP while she had to stay in her Nagpur home.

The home quarantine stamp has proved effective in recent days as people have been easily able to identify those having travel history to affected nations.

TOI had reported how a Germany returned woman was identified and her neighbour called up the police to make her comply with the norms. Another woman has been booked by Sonegaon police for flouting home quarantine guidelines. The penal action invites imprisonment for several months.

Meanwhile, a couple of home quarantined flyers continue to risk the health of others.

A medical college employee told TOI that a woman who had travelled to Mumbai and had a stamp on her hand had directly entered the private hospital premises in Hingna area. “Now, the college gates have been locked and entry restricted. But the woman was not ready to listen when she was reminded about the stamp,” the employee said.

Currently, 138 have been quarantined at MLA Hostel. Total 1,123 passengers have landed in Nagpur since March 6 from different countries. Of these, 855 were allowed to go home but stay in self isolation. On Thursday, 47 of them completed the 14-day period.

Title: Together, we will win, Delhi CM tells global leaders
Content: NEW DELHI: Sharing Delhi’s experience in fighting the novel coronavirus pandemic, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said in a global meet of city leaders on Friday that taking a cue from several countries, his government had been aggressively pursuing the policy of identifying contacts of the Covid-19 patients and isolating them.“We are committed to learn and collaborate with leaders from across the world. Together, we will win,” Kejriwal said addressing the forum.The meet was organised through video-conferencing by an international body, C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group, to allow global city leaders share their lessons in the fight against the global pandemic. Among the 45 participants were Los Angeles mayor Eric Garcetti, Seoul’s Park Won-soon and Paris’ Anne Hidalgo.Kejriwal said that by learning from other cities, Delhi had managed to keep the count at 40 Covid-19 cases after the first patient was found 25 days ago. “However, we are not complacent. We wish to limit any further local transmission and will like to avoid entering the community transmission stage. Therefore, we have implemented a complete lockdown from March 23.”Admitting that the economic fallout of the move has disproportionately impacted the city’s poor, especially migrant workers, the CM said his government was taking various welfare steps to help common people during this period. The measures include increased social security pension for widows, senior citizens and specially abled and a sustenance allowance of Rs 5,000 for construction workers, he added.“Our approach has been that we cannot afford to lose a single life to Covid-19 or starvation. This is a crisis of unprecedented scale and we are committed to learn and collaborate with leaders from across the world,” Kejriwal reiterated.The chief minister later said many world leaders had appreciated the efforts being made by both Indian and Delhi governments to tackle the spread of the highly contagious virus.Over two lakh passengers from Covid-19-affected countries have been screened at Delhi airport and placed under surveillance till now. Currently, 12,973 passengers are under home quarantine while 6,250 have completed their 14-day isolation.

Title: Door-to-door delivery: Nodal officers in Kanpur to streamline supply, pick-ups arranged
Content:
Officials working at the Nagar Nigam control room and deserted city roads on Thursday

KANPUR: The district administration has taken a number of steps for smooth door-to-door delivery programme during the lockdown period which will conclude on April 14.

In a meeting on Wednesday evening, nodal officers were appointed to ensure the supply of various essential commodities.

The nodal officers will not only receive requests for items and ensure their supply, but also record reports of black marketing and will take action accordingly.

In another step, DM Dr Brahma Deo Ram Tiwari activated the command and control room located in Kanpur Municipal Corporation building.

The commonad & control room will work round the clock and ensure disposal of complaints on priority basis.

Nodal officers and assistant staff have been appointed and trained there.

Additional DM Virendra Pandey will be nodal officer of the control room and additional municipal commissioner will be his deputy.

The control room has a capacity of 20 lines, and therefore, it will only receive 20 calls at a time.

The administration has so far arranged as many as 450 e-rickshaws and pick-ups, and 1350 carts for door-to-door delivery.

The supply will also be done on foot and through provision stores.

The district administration has invited requests from provision stores interested in door-to-door delivery.

Vyapar Mandals have also been asked to make a list of traders willing to join hands in this crucial period.

A list of shopkeepers will be prepared area-wise and passed on to the concerned police station in charge, who will then ensure the supply of commodities.

The administration has also collaborated with adjacent district authorities to maintain proper supply line between districts.

For home delivery, the listed provision stores will distribute their contact numbers in their respective areas so that consumers can book required items.

The district authorities conceded that it would be a difficult task to deliver goods to the homes of 50 lakh citizens, and the execution of it will take some time.

Title: Kanpur: Decongest mandis, ensure social distancing, directs divisional commissioner
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: Divisional commissioner Sudhir M Bobde on Thursday asked officials to ensure proper supply of essential commodities . He directed them to negotiate with districts supplying milk, vegetables, wheat, meat, fish, etc, to Kanpur Nagar and restore inter-district vehicle movement.

Chairing a meet of senior district officers here on Thursday, the commissioner directed them to ensure that 87 retail and small mandis of the city should remain decongested. He suggested them to shift these mandis to nearby open place, parks or plots so that people could observe social distancing. He directed Kanpur Municipal Corporation to sanitize the place where over five persons assemble to purchase essential commodities.

Additional IG Jai Narayan singh, IG Mohit Agarwal, Dr Brahma deo Ram Tiwari, DIG Anant Dev, municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi and other district officials were present in the meeting held at divisional commissioner’s office.

The district administration allowed 'dhaba' of Deep Chauhan at Bhauti highway under Sachendi police station and Singh dhaba at Barra bypass to offer food to drivers and cleaners of vehicles involved in transporting edibles and essential commodities from mandis. Both the dhaba owners have been directed not to allow any other persons there.

Basant Agarwal, district civil supply officer, stated that the district administration was trying to streamline door-to-door delivery system. "We want to make it foolproof," he added. He said that, so far, 198 grocery shop owners and provison stores had uploaded their details in the door-to-door delivery system website.

The district administration has allowed people to purchase commodities of daily needs between 6 am and 11 am on Friday too. The district magistrate has appealed to people to maintain the social distancing.

At around 10 in the morning the police had started asking people to go inside their homes. To check the traffic on road the city police had installed as many as 595 barriers in the city.

The police on Thursday checked around 2965 vehicles plying on the road and realized fine to the tune of Rs 13500 from 680 vehicle owners. Apart from it the police also seized 35 vehicles. During the lockdown period roads were wearing a deserted look.

Labour department has stated that Rs 5,38,69,000 has been transferred to the account of 53869 labourers of six districts in Kanpur division. These districts are Kanpur Nagar, Kanpur Dehat, Etawah, Auraiya , Kannauj and Farrukhabad .

Title: Landlords evicting health workers: Telangana doctors
Content:
HYDERABAD: In a video conference that was organised with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday, Dr P Raghu Ram, president, The Association of Surgeons of India, brought to the fore the struggles of healthcare professionals in Telangana and how some of them were being discriminated against by their landlords.

Stating that several junior doctors in Warangal were being driven out of their homes, Dr Raghu Ram said, “It is very disturbing to see so many junior doctors being driven out of their homes by their landlords saying that these doctors are infected and dirty. The community must be very sensitive towards healthcare professionals at a time like this and we request you to issue a directive in this regard,” he said.

Dr Ram also stressed that the pay of healthcare workers must be protected during a crisis like this, when they are at the forefront of the war against the novel coronavirus. “Every hospital has a nodal officer and it should be his/her duty to empower healthcare professionals in the hospital. This exercise will enable these personnel to be better prepared when the time comes for them to perform,” he said.

The PM interacted with Dr Ram and a few other prominent healthcare professionals through video conferencing over Covid-19 and discussed matters relating to protection of healthcare workers, retaining and recruiting doctors among other issues.

Title: Retail chemists running out of stock as wholesale markets shut in Lucknow
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Wholesale markets of medicines in Aminabad and Chowk have been shut for five days due to shortage of workers and inadequate supply from manufacturers. As a result, retail chemist shops in the city are running out of stock.

Wholesalers said that while some employees are not coming out of fear, others are finding difficult to move out due to curbs. “Passes issued by the district administration for some of their employees will help in restarting the operation, but the larger issue is supply of medicines from manufacturers based in other states as well as from other parts of UP,” they said and added that authorities concerned have assured them of solving the problem at the earliest. TOI reality check found that retailers at many places have closed down their shops after their stock dried up. Some big retailers have a backup of 10-15 days but the high demand due to stockpiling by people is adding to the problem.

Ramesh Chandra, a distributor of medicines in Chowk, said that he has staff strength of 18 workers apart from daily wagers whom he deploys to pick up and drop consignments. But only four of them are coming to office. Similarly, Mohammed Nasir, wholesaler of surgical goods in medicine market in Aminabad, said, “Neither we are getting supply from outside nor our local brands are able to meet the rising demand.”

He said that he had placed an order to a company located in Transport Nagar on March 21, but the order is yet to be executed.

Most of the wholesalers said that they have informed senior district officers about the crisis and they have assured help at the earliest.

Title: To ensure supply, govt to procure wheat from FCI on behalf of flour mills
Content:
Dehradun: To ensure that there is no shortage of wheat flour during the lockdown in wake of Covid-19, the state government has decided to procure wheat from Food Corporation of India (FCI) depots. On behalf of the flour mills owners and on basis of their requirement, the state government - under the Open Market Sale Scheme - would procure the wheat from FCI depots and forward it to the flour mills. In a letter dated March 26, secretary Sushil Kumar has written that regional food controller of Kumaon and Garhwal, will procure the wheat from FCI depots in their respective regions and thereafter provide it to the flour mills operating within their jurisdiction areas. They have also been named the nodal officer for ensuring that the districts in their areas got the required share of flour.

The district supply officer of each district will collect the requirements of each flour mill and the list would be forwarded to the regional food controller, who will ensure that on basis of the decided rate, the initial amount is deposited in the FCI account. For the purpose, an account would be open in a nationalised bank. The district supply officers have been directed to immediately prepare the list of required wheat flour in their respective areas, so that there is no shortage in the future.

Title: Wardha begins spraying public places with disinfectant
Content: Nagpur: Wardha civic body has come up with a unique method to check the spread Covid-19 . It has started spraying disinfectant sodium hypochlorite using spraying vehicles used for agricultural purposes at all public places in the city to fight the virus.The spraying of the disinfectant across the town by the Wardha Municipal Council has also been praised by the citizens.Wardha collector Vivek Bhimanwar said, “We had received guidelines that spraying sodium hypochlorite helps in fighting the virus. We also discussed it with Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation officials who had also started the same drive for public places.”Wardha civic chief Pradip Jagtap told TOI all public places in city were being sprayed with the disinfectant. “Sodium hypochlorite is mostly used in hospitals for cleaning. It is a disinfectant. Currently a private company has given us three spraying vehicles as a courtesy. We are using them to spray the disinfectant at market places, bus stops, railway stations and other public places,” he said.“Wardha city has around 1.10 lakh citizens so public places are a priority. We will continue the drive for some time now. It is not yet clear how much disinfectant we will need to spray the whole city as we have just started,” added Jagtap.Currently Wardha has not seen any Covid-19 positive case but the extra precaution by the administration has been praised by the citizens.Shridhar Deshmukh, a businessman, said currently the administration was spraying disinfectant at public places but later zone wise spraying will also happen. “It is a good initiative by the administration as citizens are scared due to the outbreak,” he said.Pratik Saraf, another businessman, said, “The spraying will have a good impact on the health of citizens. As sanitization is very essential, spraying disinfectant will also help citizens remain fit during these times.”Meanwhile, videos and photos of the vehicle spraying disinfectant on roads of Wardha went viral on social media on Thursday. Some Nagpur citizens suggested that such spraying must happen in the city too.Leena Budhe, a civic activist, said, “It is high time NMC started spraying disinfectants and fogging in city. They must target areas where hygiene is not very good. Sanitization must be the top priority to fight coronavirus.”

Title: When humanity shines even through the gloom of Covid-19
Content:
opens its heart and hearth

IT professionals use soft kills for hard task

More on Covid-19

Out-of-work cooks rustle up meals for jobless

(With reports from Anuja Jaiswal & Arvind Chauhan, Prashant Jha, Uttara Verma, and Sandeep Rai)

Every day till April 14, shoe exporters in Agra will hand out 5,000 food packets to those who have lost their livelihoods because of the Covid-19 lockdown. “Many people spoke about it, the need to do something for those who have been left to fend for themselves. They are walking home, hungry, sometimes hundreds of km, without money. So we thought this is the least we could do,” said Puran Davar, a shoe exporter. The local administration and cops have pitched in. “Police officers are helping us distribute the food in slums and on highways, ensuring that social distancing norms are followed. The food is prepared in an automated kit chen following all hygiene norms,” Davar added.Realising that those forming backbone of the local economy are out of work, money and choices, a group of people in Nainital have vowed to do something about it. “We got in touch with grocery shop owners and asked them to put together essentials – rice, flour, pulses, milk powder, oil – in packs. Then we decided to make lists of families who need help,” said Rushir Sah, a restaurant owner.Nainital MLA Sanjeev Arya and municipal members spread out and spoke to people across the city about those in need. They identified 1,000 such families. “Some of them are from UP, some from Bihar West Bengal . There are many daily wagers from Nepal too. They have no food, no money and no way of getting home. We had to help them,” Rushir Sah, a restaurant owner said. Schools joined in. And the town’s hotel association. Till now, the initiative has received Rs 1.5 lakh in donations. “We need Rs 4 lakh for the first batch of essential items packs,” Sah said. The deliveries will begin in a day or two.Kishore Kumar Mamidi, a software engineer in Hyderabad, steps out at 6am, going street to street, trying to convince people to maintain “social distance”. The problem areas, he said, are ATM and medical shops. As the Covid-19 outbreak unfolded, Cyberabad Police started engaging volunteers. Kishore volunteers between 6am and 1pm. “When I get back I don’t go anywhere near a family member without a mask. Must practise what I preach,” the 30-year-old said. Another software professional Hareesh Jayini has been manning the checkpost at Usha Mullapadi junction. “We are checking permits to ensure no one is on the roads without a valid reason,” he said.Mohd Shakeel had not been getting any work for a few weeks. “Cooks like us, who work independently, have been out of work,” he said. But when he thought of the thousands of homeless on the streets of Meerut, he knew what he had to do. So he and six other cooks started a delivery van, distributing food to some 250 people a day. “Our one condition is that people must observe social distancing,” said one team member.

Title: One booked for spreading rumours in Kanpur
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: The city police have booked a man for spreading misinformation about the number of Covid-19 positive cases on social media. The man has been booked under IT Act.

The man was held from Barra Sabzi Mandi area of the city after he was found involved in spreading fake information about the number of Covid-19 positive cases. “We have regieterd a case against the man identified as Sanjay Shukla,” said inspector Barra Ranjit Rai adding that investigations are underway.

The Chakeri police, meanwhile, registered a case against the owners of Upper India Tannery for violation of lockdown and Section 144 CrPC after the tannery was found operating, on Wednesday.

A patrolling police team found around 18 to 20 labourers working at the tannery and took them under custody. They told the police that they were called by the tannery owner Yusuf and Mohd Saleh .

Incharge Chakeri police station Ram Kumar Gupta said that the police have registered a case of violation of section 144 cr PC against the tannery owners. tnn

Title: Covid-19: Fishing banned in Uttara Kannada
Content: KARWAR: The Uttara Kannada district administration has banned fishing, fish farming activities and sale of fish till further notice. The order by deputy director of fisheries department in Karwar stated that fishing activities lead to the congregation of people at one place which can spread Covid-19 or coronavirus . All traditional and mechanised boats should be anchored on the shores, the order read.Meanwhile, deputy commissioner Harish Kumar warned that the vehicle registration and driving licence of people will be cancelled if they are found unnecessarily moving around the city. He said the process of identifying such vehicles through CCTV footages has begun. “Even after repeated requests to stay at home, some people have made it a habit to move around. Such people will be strongly dealt with,” he said.No new positive cases of Covid-19 has emerged in the district after the lockdown. Two people who returned from the UAE had tested positive for Covid-19 in the district. The authorities are carrying out fumigation in the district.

Title: Ajmer police take action against blackmarketing
Content:
Representative Image

AJMER: City police came forward to help citizens against blackmarketing and hoarding of groceries in Ajmer during lockdown . Police maintained strict vigil on city’s roads as they booked over 2,000 bikers in the last two days. The district administration issued notice to every shop to display a price list according to the district supply department. On Thursday, action was taken against a shop in Chanderwardai on the complaint of charging more. The shop was sealed till further orders.

The district administration has been trying to streamline the delivery of goods in the district from the last two days. The district police came out hard against blackmarketing and hoarding of essentials after a voice message from Ajmer SP Kunwar Rashtradeep on Thursday morning. The SP said in his message that it was the duty of police to see that people don’t break the rules of lockdown and also to ensure that they get their share of essentials.

The message said, “Police must be humane and see that on every grocery shop there is a price list and people are getting all that is essential.”

Title: Fireworks industry workers seek urgent aid
Content:
Madurai: Employees working in cracker units reeling under the lockdown have urged the government to provide monetary assistance to them till the units resumed functioning.

The cracker industry at Sivakasi in Virudhunagar district employs nearly eight lakh workers directly and indirectly. R Pandi, a resident of O Sankaralingapuram village, said an employee would earn an average of Rs 350 to 400 per day by working in a cracker unit and the salary is disbursed every weekend.

“Since all units are closed, the employees would have received the salary for working during the last week with which they would be able to manage their family expenses for nearly 10 days. As the units would be closed for the next 21 days, we will start facing difficulties after 10 days,” noted Pandi.

He said when the employees are in need of money, they used to request for advance salary, but they are not sure they would get it now. Another employee, K Sundaram from Maraneri, said the rise in prices of essential commodities will affect them severely. To make matters worse, they are all forced to stock up essential commodities. Hence the government should provide them monetary assistance, he said.

Title: MP too struggles in corona testing
Content:
AIIMS director Dr Sarman Singh

Bhopal: Madhya Pradesh like other states in India is lagging in Covid-19 testing. Six days after Bhopal reported its first Covid case, the premier institute is still not able to test maximum possible 63 tests per day.

“Samples come in staggered manner, we have been able to test up to 36 samples in a day,” said AIIMS Bhopal director Dr Sarman Singh. He is one of India’s foremost experts in Clinical Microbiology and Molecular Medicine . Going by numbers the premier institute had about 160 kits, as on Thursday. ICMR provides these kits. A maximum of 63 samples can be run in three shifts at AIIMS Regional Virology Research and Diagnostic Laboratory (RVRDL). “We have made sufficient arrangements but no predictions can be made for the number of diseased, we might encounter,” said AIIMS Bhopal director, Dr Sarman Singh , here on Thursday.

ICMR Jabalpur can test 36 samples each day and similar are the numbers for testing facility at Indore and Gwalior , according to sources. TNN

Title: Lucknow: Tsunami of panic buying calls cripple door-to-door delivery mechanism
Content: LUCKNOW: A tsunami of panic buying calls on day one of the home delivery mechanism of essential items during lockdown led to chocked telephone lines, leaving thousands disappointed on Thursday. However, it also came as a big relief for hundreds struggling to buy groceries for several days. Officers said the situation will normalise in a few days.The 62 outlets of 13 giants permitted for home delivery were deluged by over 60,000 calls in a day, but they could meet only 20% of the orders placed during the first two hours of the opening. The volume of the calls was so high that thousands dialled for hours only to find numbers constantly engaged during the day.The establishments included outlets of two e-commerce giants, 54 branches of seven supermarkets and four app-based supermarkets. Besides, two online food delivery companies were authorised to collect orders from stores for home delivery. The workforce of all the 15 giants is over 8,000.Nishi Bajaj tried numbers of almost all the mega stores, app-based supermarkets and food delivery companies from her Jopling Road residence, but could not connect to a single one. “The telephone lines were either engaged or went unanswered, while app-based services rejected orders,” she said.The exercise left Saba Khan, a Indirnagar resident, exhausted by the end of the day. “My husband had to do all the household chores,” she said. Different Mega stores accepted orders with the minimum value of Rs 500 and Rs1000 and delivery within three-km radius, leaving many people disappointed. “Since lines of stores near my house were engaged, I tried outlets in other areas, but they too refused,” said Hemant Sharma of Gomtinagar.Mega stores’ staff were working in equally trying situation. “Calls started pouring in as soon as we opened at 9am and received over 200 orders by 11am, enough for our 20 delivery boys to execute in a day,” said an outlet manager in Aashiana.“Our staff on telephone duty could not sit idle even for a second. After our capacity was full and we requested people to call tomorrow,” said head of supermarket branch in Hazratganj.Employee of another retail giant in Kauthauta Crossing in Vibhutikhand said, "We booked orders for next three days in just two hours."An outlet in Aashiana, confused over the timing, started closing at 11am, but police intervened and clarified that closure timing is 11pm.Mahesh Singh, a resident of PGI, said that he placed order on e-commerce website and they said that they would deliver in a week.However, grocery shops were opened in most parts of the city. “The shop in my neighbourhood which was shut since March 21 opened today”, said Rashid in Mahanagar.ADM, Trans Gomti , Vishwa Bhushan said, "The pressure has started easing and the situation will be normal in next two to three days.”

Title: Three suspected cases escape from isolation ward in Kanpur
Content: KANPUR: Three suspected coronavirus patients escaped from the isolation wards of Lala Lajpat Rai hospital on Wednesday.The hospital authorities identified them as Atul Katiyar of Shiv Vihar area of Kalyanpur who had reportedly returned from South Africa, Saurabh Shukla of Sarsaul area of Maharajpur and Yogendra Singh Sengar of Auraiya."We have apprised district officials and police about the development. In case they will remain untraceable, we will lodge a case against them," said CMO Dr Ashok Kumar Shukla "The samples of Atul Katiyar and Saurabh were dispatched to Lucknow for laboratory test. Atul and Saurabh were admitted at IDH on Tuesday. Saurabh had a history of living with a Corona positive patient. Yogendra of Auraiya was admitted to IDH after he complained of suffering from cold and fever," said chief medical superintendent LLR Dr Anup Shukla.The three suspects left the hospital and to inspect the matter, I visited the hospital. I learned that the suspects left the ward. Initially, we thought they will return, but they didn't," he said. "Since it is a sensitive issue, we are coordinating with district authorities and police," said a health official.

Title: No jobs, no money... please, bring us home: Students stuck in Australia
Content:
Nagpur: The Indian students in various universities in Australia are stranded, facing not just fear of corona infection but also struggling for basics after losing their part-time jobs. Stuck due to corona lockdown, students are running short of money and demanding to be brought back to India.

On Thursday, TOI spoke to two such students pursuing masters in Project Management from Melbourne. Living in a rented apartment, the students first came to Melbourne early this year for further education.

It was around Holi (March 10) that the deadly coronavirus started spreading in Australia. “We booked the ticket back to India when we realized this situation is going to get serious as public places in Melbourne were shutting down. First universities, then cafes, restaurants, clubs and gyms, everything closed down,” said 23-year-old Sharad Rao.

Originally from Nagpur, Sharad and his friend Hiranya Bhagwat had booked an Air India flight to India for March 30. However, with the government banning all international flights, many students like them are desperate to return home.

While officials of Consulate General of India, Melbourne, did not reply to TOI’s queries, Rao and Bhagwat claimed there were around 1 lakh Indian students stranded across Australia.

With most of them not having jobs, they are struggling for basic needs. “I was working in the housekeeping department of a local hotel. I went to work only for two weeks as after that, the hotel stopped getting check ins and I was asked not to come,” said Sharad.

He added that like him, many Indian students lost their part-time jobs following the outbreak of the virus. “A few days after I came here, our university converted this semester online due to corona virus. The next week,the government closed down all cafes. Part time jobs are not available here and it is getting very difficult to survive,” said Hiranya.

Sharad added that looking at dollar rates, it was getting harder to manage each day. “Our monthly expenses easily go up to Rs 50,000. As students, we are not able to sustain here,” he said.

With the number of positive corona cases rising to over 2,800 in Australia, the students are feeling unsafe. “The number of positive cases here are increasing day-by-day. We want to come back to India before a complete lockdown happens here,” said Hiranya.

The students have appealed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and union external affairs minister S Jaishankar to bring them back. “The Indian high commission in Australia informed us that they have been talking to the government regarding our wish to come back. We request the government to act urgently before the situation gets worse here. We are living in constant fear as well as financial crunch,” said Sharad, who is unsure if he would be boarding the March 30 flight to India.

When contacted, the Air India officials based in Melbourne told TOI, “We are following the instructions issued by the Indian government and there will be no flights till April 14. Resumption of flight will be only known as we come closer to the date.”

However, back home, families of the students are demanding immediate rescue operation of their kids. Sharad’s mother Padma Rao has appealed to the government to evacuate all the Indian students stuck in Australia . “I fear that even if our country opens incoming international flights after April 14, the Australian government might have already locked down by then. Our children are away from home and it would get very difficult for them to survive for so long. I request the government to please bring them back home,” she said.

Title: Lens on those who came from outside in UP
Content: LUCKNOW: The UP government has started a massive exercise to identify people in both rural and urban areas who have returned home from abroad or from other states after their work places were shut down.Till Thursday, over 35,000 gram pradhans had got down to the task of compiling lists of such people and referring Covid-19 suspects to the chief medical officers of their respective districts.Secretary to the chief minister Alok Kumar-III said that by Thursday evening, over 35,000 gram pradhans had been contacted, while another 25,000 and all municipal councillors would be covered by Friday evening. Kumar is heading the CM helpline operations though which these calls are being made. His team, comprising special secretaries Avinash Kumar, Satyendra Singh and joint MD Jal Nigam Ramesh Ranjan is also tracking Covid-19 related calls on the helpline.“The plan is to identify all such people who have come from outside and have them quarantined for 14 days. In case someone displays symptoms of Covid , they will be referred to the CMO for testing. Those who have to be tracked are people coming from other countries and states, anyone who has been in touch with a Covid-19 positive person or someone over 60 years with breathing problems,” Kumar said.In the first round of calls, pradhans were told to compile lists of such persons and tell them not to leave their homes. In the second round, , the control room will check for compliance.Meanwhile, the CM helpline has been inundated with calls about the coronavirus . Kumar said that helpline numbers 112, 1076 and health department call centres were being linked.

Title: Delhi: Evacuation flight not allowed to take off from IGI Airport over dues
Content: NEW DELHI: An evacuation flight, supposed to fly back around 100 Europeans to Bulgaria, could not take off from Indira Gandhi International Airport on Thursday morning as statutory dues to Indian authorities had not been cleared.Budget carrier SpiceJet had taken a couple of Airbus A320s on lease from Bulgarian lessor BH Air. With the novel coronavirus pandemic grinding air travel to a halt, the cash-strapped private airline decided to return the aircraft to its European lessor.“Bulgaria had arranged to fly back some of its citizens from India on the aircraft on Thursday, boarding for which was also completed. The aircraft, however, had some statutory dues that needed to be cleared. A dispute arose between the lessor and SpiceJet over who would pay the dues. With the issue not being cleared, the aircraft was not allowed to take off on Thursday,” sources said.Attempts are, however, being made to resolve the issue so that the aircraft can take off with the citizens of the European country with whom India has very good ties, officials added.In a statement, SpiceJet said: “In view of the global outbreak of coronavirus, SpiceJet exercised its right under the agreement to early return the aircraft. At the time of return of the aircraft, there was a substantial amount that was to be returned to SpiceJet by BH Air before the aircraft could be Customs cleared. Incidentally, BH Air refused to pay, which led to non-clearance of aircraft and their operating crew by Customs. However, in order to ensure safe return of the BH Air crew to their home country, SpiceJet on its own has paid the due amount. We continue to engage with BH Air to get our amount refunded.”Comments from BH Air have been sought and are awaited.All Indian carriers are facing a serious financial crisis. Except for a few airlines that either have their own cash reserves (IndiGo) or are backed by strong groups (Tata, Wadia), others are facing a battle for survival.

Title: Essential item shops to be open till 1 pm today
Content:
Dehrdun: To avoid overcrowding at shops for essential items, the state government late on Thursday announced to keep these outlets open for six hours, from 7 am to 1 pm on Friday.

Vegetable and fruit cart vendors will also be allowed to operate in the day, a communique from the CM office said, adding that shops selling milk, vegetables and fruits will remain open for the entire day.

However, the movement of four wheelers is banned for the entire day. Only two wheelers can operate from 7 am to 1pm, the communique said. The CM also urged people to follow the lockdown strictly and maintain distance if they come out to purchase essential products.

Earlier in the day, the CM held a video conferencing session with all 13 district magistrates to review the Covid-19 situation in the state. He said just if required, a 500 bed pre-fabricated hospital dedicated for Corona patients can be made in Haldwani and Dehradun.

“The district magistrates have been told to identify 5 acre land in their respective jurisdiction area for the purpose,” Rawat said adding that arrangements have been made to provide the required wheat flour to people in the state.

The CM further added that there was no shortage of anything and the state was taking all required steps to tackle the situation.

Title: Papla gang member arrested
Content:
Representative Image

ALWAR: Bansur police on Thursday arrested Vinod Gujjar who masterminded the escape of criminal Vikram Gujjar alias Papala from Behrod police station after firing at cops with illegal weapons. Vinod was carrying a reward of Rs 10,000.

Police have so far arrested 26 gang members of Papla but the kingpin is still at large. Bansur police station has handed over the accused to SOG. Vidon was picked up from Naya Road area.

Title: Miscreants loot ambulance for masks, 1 held
Content:
Jaisalmer: Some unidentified miscreants waylaid an ambulance in a bid to loot masks and ultimately made away with the vehicle in Barmer’s Balotara on Wednesday afternoon.

One of the miscreants was arrested from Siner village under Samdari police station area. Driver Hanuman Jat in his complaint said that he was returning after admitting a delivery case referred to Nahta hospital in Balotra. Four miscreants, who were already waiting near Bhagat Singh Sabha Sthal, stopped the ambulance and asked for masks. When he refused, they beat him up and fled with the ambulance

. tnn

Title: Gujarat to procure 156 ventilators
Content: AHMEDABAD: State health and family welfare department officials said Gujarat is soon going to receive 156 ventilators for specialized hospitals for Covid-19 patients.Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary (health and family welfare), told mediapersons on Thursday evening that there is a severe shortage of ventilators globally due to the pandemic, but Gujarat has already ordered 156 ventilators for its hospitals and these will arrive soon. “We are keeping an eye on a development which may materialize by tomorrow – the CM has intervened to ensure availability of locally-produced world class ventilators. Final testing of the prototype will begin soon,” said Ravi.Ravi said that from Friday onwards, all new Covid patients in Gujarat will be admitted in the four major cities– Ahmedabad, Surat, Vadodara and Rajkot – at newly-converted facilities. Cumulatively, the four cities have 2,200 beds.As on Thursday evening, the total number of positive cases in Gujarat is 44. These include 15 in Ahmedabad, 8 in Vadodara, 7 in Surat, 7 in Gandhinagar, 5 in Rajkot, 1 in Kutch and 1 in Gandhinagar.On Thursday, the state health department launched its Covid-19 dashboard at gujcovid19.gujarat.gov.in . “Figures will be updated twice a day. We will also add more details over time,” said Ravi.In light of the deaths so far, Ravi appealed to senior citizens to be extra cautious and follow lockdown rules, not venture out, and maintain social distancing of at least 1 metre. “Even when you are home, try to maintain distance. If you suspect a condition with symptoms seen in Covid-19, inform the 104 fever helpline,” said Ravi.

Title: Delhi: Mosques deserted, Friday prayers at home
Content: NEW DELHI: For the first time in ages, the iconic Jama Masjid and its adjoining streets were deserted on Friday during the Jumah prayers . All mosques in the city were almost empty as people stayed back home in the wake of the novel coronavirus pandemic and lockdown in the country.The decision to stop congregation was announced by All India Muslim Personal Law Board AIMPLB ) on Twitter. “Due to novel coronavirus pandemic, Muslims are recommended to offer Zuhur at home instead of praying Jumah at mosques. Don’t come out for congregational prayers and stay at home to save lives. It is mandatory upon all to avoid causing harm to fellow citizens,” the tweet said.Many imams also asked their local area residents to avoid coming to mosques. Imam Bukhari, Shahi Imam of Jama Masjid, said, “We had earlier announced that we will keep the gates of the mosque shut. We broadcast on the speakers that since there are restrictions against mass gathering, people should stay home and pray. Even in remote areas of the country, hardly any namaaz took place.”AIMPLB said that mosques can continue to have prayers with a few people. “Don’t leave mosques abandoned. Four individuals should remain in mosques to establish the congregational prayers due to the Right of Masjid,” it tweeted.Responding to the call, only four people prayed in Jamia Millia Islamia’s mosque on Friday. “Only staff members were present. We made sure that no outsider came,” said a mosque member.The hashtag, #NoJumahInMasjid, trended on social media in support of the call. Abu Sufyan, an entrepreneur who resides near Turkman Gate, said, “We spread the word that people should avoid going out and threatening lives of their family members and others. Most in Old Delhi complied with it.”Mohammad Naeem, a librarian who lives in Pahari Imli in the Walled City, said smaller mosques were shut too. “We spread the word through WhatsApp and Facebook to comply with the directions issued by the government and the authorities,” he added. At Okhla Vihar, Mohammad Waseem, a mechanical engineer, decided not to go to the mosque which was right in front of his house.Around noon, instead of the azaan, the Jama Masjid in C-Block of East of Kailash made an announcement asking people to stay indoors.“Hukumat ki taraf se jo ailan hua hai us par poori tarah se amal karein. Apne gharon se na nikle aur namaaz apne gharon mein padhein kyunki jama hone ki wajah se bataya jaata hai ki virus zyada phailta hai. (Everyone should follow the government’s direction to stay indoors. Don’t step out of your homes and offer prayers at home as there are chances of spreading the virus in a large gathering),” the announcement stated.People were also asked to offer dua (invocation) to the almighty so that the “serious pandemic” is rid of soon.With Ramadan barely a month away, people at many mosques hoped the lockdown and the pandemic ended soon.

Title: Social distancing new norm for shopkeepers
Content:
White circles

Bhopal: With the country going into lockdown amid the fear of coronavirus, social distancing seems to have become the norm for shopkeepers in Bhopal.

Whether imposed by law enforcement officials or voluntarily followed, traders are making sure people to do not crowd at their stores on the second day of the nationwide lockdown.

In Katara Hills, for instance, shops on Thursday were opened as usual at around 8 in the morning. However, to avoid herding of people, shopkeepers are drawing their shutters down by afternoon. Those not wearing any protective mask — or even a simple handkerchief — are being told to get one or stay away from the shops. And of course, keeping a distance of at least one metre has become a necessity of sorts.

“We are making sure that not too many people rush to our stores because people seem to be panicking over availability of essentials. In such a situation, these white circle marked by the authorities are helping us,” said one shopkeeper in Katara Hills.

The white circles seem to be another common thing. On Thursday morning, police making rounds of their areas are making sure that these markings are drawn in front of every shop — to enforce a minimum of one metre distance between customers. Those not wearing masks are also asked to ensure they cover their faces.

In Bagmugaliya as well, grocery and medical stores followed the “one-metre rule” diligently. But, people were seen standing outside the designated circles marked by police.

However, for some shopkeepers social distancing seems to not be the only issue. In Bagmugaliya, police asked one vegetable vendor to move his shop at least 50 metres away from another hand cart right next to him.

“I understand that maintaining a safe distance is important at this time, but if we move our carts away from the usual spot people may not come. It is better that we shut shop for the day,” said the vendor, who did not wish to be named.

Jitendra Raghuvanshi, who owns a grocery shop in Katara Hills, said that availability of stocks is another issue. This, he said, is also the reason for many shops shutting down for the day early.

“You can see how people are buying most of their essentials in bulk. We are not sure how long this will last because none of our distributors have been able to deliver stuff over the last two days. The last time we got any stuff was before the janata curfew on March 22. I am not sure when we will get fresh delivery next. Once our stocks run out, we will have to shut down as well,” said Raghuvanshi, who kept his store open till 2pm.

Title: NMC begins survey of 27-30L population to trace Covid-19 suspects
Content: Nagpur: Probably for the first time in the state, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Thursday started a door-to-door containment drive across the city. Apart from suspected Covid-19 patients and those with severe acute respiratory illness, the drive will also take detailed information about high-risk patients.NMC had covered 64,436 houses with population of 2.64 lakh within 3km radius of the houses of the first four positive patients in Laxmi Nagar and Dharampeth zones between March 22 and 24. Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe said, “NMC will now cover entire city with houses of around 5.5-6 lakh and population of around 27-30 lakh under the drive. Teams will visit each and every house and take details of health condition of all family members. This will help us know whether there are any more suspected patients of Covid-19. Also, awareness will be spread among people about dos and don’ts in prevailing situation, method of washing hands, hygienic atmosphere, precautions during cough and cold etc. We will also take detailed information of high-risk patients. If needed in case of any situation, we will be able to isolate all these high-risk patients,” he said.NMC has formed 288 teams, which will also ask whether any family member has returned from abroad in last few days, or if they came in contact with positive patients. They will also monitor home quarantined people.NMC additional medical officer health Dr Bhavna Sonkusre said, “NMC teams will also collect detailed information of people suffering from diabetes, hyper tension, cancer, cardio vascular diseases etc. Also, details of persons above 60 years will be taken. People should cooperate and give complete and true information to the teams, which will help in controlling Covid-19,” she said.At the end of the drive, NMC will also be able to get exact data of high-risk patients with disease. It can help NMC plan various types of health related programmes.NMC assistant medical officer health Dr Praveen Gantawar said, “Drive will again cover 64,436 houses with population of 2.64 lakh within 3km radius of houses of first four positive patients in Laxmi Nagar and Dharampeth zones. This is as per guidelines of Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR). We will have to ensure no suspected patients have come up for 14 days, as this is the period for symptoms of Covid-19 to arise,” he said.The NMC teams have complained that a few houses refused to share details.Gantawar said, “Not a single house will be left out under the drive. We will send team of seniors to houses that refuse to share information. Appropriate measures as per Epidemic Act will be taken to cover each and every house,” he said.The drive will also cover all houses situated in 3km radius of the fifth positive patient.

Title: Mumbai News: Veggie prices soar, CM Uddhav Thackeray says key stores can stay open 24/7
Content: MUMBAI: Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray announced on Thursday that shops supplying essential commodities and medical stores will be permitted to remain open round-the-clock. The CM’s decision came as a huge relief to the common man on a day vegetable prices soared 50% on an average across the city and there were fewer items to choose from.Thackeray made the announcement a day after Prime Minister Narendra Modi declared a complete lockdown to tackle coronavirus.“In view of the lockdown, people are facing difficulties procuring essential commodities, groceries and medicines. Massive crowds are seen at most of these shops, which may adversely affect people’s health. Under such circumstances, it has been decided that these establishments be granted permission to carry out their businesses for 24 hours a day,’’ Thackeray said.At a meeting attended by chief secretary Ajoy Mehta and bureaucrats, Thackeray reviewed the state’s preparedness to fight the virus.The state government also appointed three senior IAS officers to ensure that essential supplies arrive uninterrupted. Principal secretary Anoop Kumar has been assigned to ensure smooth despatch of vegetables and fruit from APMCs. Principal secretary Mahesh Pathak will oversee supply of foodgrains to fair price shops and his peer Abha Shukla will monitor food supply to daily wage labourers rendered jobless.A senior bureaucrat said several citizens had brought to the CM’s notice difficulties faced in procuring essential commodities and medicines. The bureaucrat added now that permission is granted to keep shops open 24/7, it will be their responsibility to ensure safe distance between customers, and fumigation and cleanliness of the premises.Meanwhile, on Thursday, the situation in the markets remained precarious. Matunga’s K A Viswanathan said onion-potato sold for a shocking Rs 50 per kg and cabbage-cauliflower for Rs 100. In Andheri Lokhandwala, common vegetables cost at least Rs 100 a kilo, with Rs 120 for cluster bean and lady finger. Coriander was Rs 30-40 a bunch.Borivli residents invited greengrocers to enter housing complexes in tempos. A vendor said he had borrowed Rs 40,000 to buy vegetables to sell. Loaders have hiked charges from Rs 20 per box to Rs 50.Colaba MLA Rahul Narwekar asked police to take action against vendors who charge exorbitant prices.Long queues unfolded outside LPG outlets due to delayed delivery of cylinders in Colaba, Khar and Kalyan.Thane’s elderly complained of not receiving medicines on time as chemists stopped delivery. Even online platforms have deferred despatch.

Title: Delhi: 15 evacuation flights to and from IGI Airport since March 23
Content: NEW DELHI: Since the suspension of international flights from this Monday, Delhi airport has seen over 15 evacuation flights bringing Indians stranded back home from abroad and foreign countries taking their citizens from here. Since the ban, 280 Indians have come back to the country from Iran by Mahan Air.Lufthansa Group Austrian operated a Delhi-Vienna on Thursday and the parent airline will operate another evacuation flight to Frankfurt from the capital in the early hours of Friday.Among the flights taking foreigners back to their country, Aeroflot operated an aircraft to Moscow with 300 passengers, Japan Airlines with 197, Ukraine with 98, Lufthansa with 500, Air India took 300 Israelis to Tel Aviv and a flights each to Colombo and Sharjah with 140 flyers.An Indira Gandhi International Airport official said that they were working hard to ensure smooth operations at the airport. “All areas of the terminal are being sanitised regularly and the airport rescue and firefighting team personnel are always ready for any crisis,” the official said.The biggest aircraft used for evacuation was an Airbus A380 deployed by Lufthansa that flew out 500 German nationals to Frankfurt in the early hours of Wednesday.Before the restriction on international flights Air India brought back 563 Indians from Italy (Milan and Rome) on three flights, Mahan Air brought 234 from Tehran, Air India got 231 from Paris and 91 from Frankfurt. KLM saw 117 flyers from US and Canada via Amsterdam and a China Airlines saw 35.

Title: Power demand dips, discoms’ revenue hit in India
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: The demand for power in the country has taken a sharp dip of 20% following a nationwide lockdown. In a letter sent to the PMO on Thursday, the All India Power Engineers’ Federation (AIPEF) said that demand had crashed following a complete shutdown of industrial and commercial units and railways and would affect state power utilities/distribution companies as their major source of income was blocked.

According to the federation, power demand nationally has plunged from 1,54,045 MW daily to 1,21,937 MW. Likewise, supply has crashed from 3,565 million units (MU) per day to 2,975 MU.

AIPEF chairman Shailendra Dubey said consumers, too, cannot make payments to discoms as door-to-door billing had been suspended and online payments were also hit.

“There will not be any fund flow left to meet the monthly salary of power sector employees in the coming days,” the federation said in a statement.

Title: British woman tests -ve in Pushkar
Content:
Ajmer: A British woman suffering from cold and fever in Pushkar tested negative for Covid-19 on Thursday.

She had reached a hospital with coronavirus-type symptoms. A medical team swung into action and carried out tests in which she tested negative. Doctors asked the woman to quarantine herself in the hotel room for 10 days. Around 200 foreign tourists left Pushkar in the last four days through emergency flights from Delhi. Are around 250 foreign tourists are still stuck and are contacting their embassies to rescue them.

Pushkar has been completely closed. tnn

Title: Vadodara: 18 rail men stuck in yard sans food, water get help from Barodians
Content:
The four were stranded without food and water for two days

VADODARA: Around 18 railway staff members working in two trains were left to fend for themselves after passenger trains came to a halt on the midnight of March 22.

Soon after the announcement, a group, comprising coach attendants, housekeepers and air-conditioner mechanics in the Dehradun-Kochuveli Express and Sri Ganganagar-Kochuveli Express trains, got stuck in a yard near Vadodara railway station since the wee hours of Wednesday as these trains had already started journey from Kochuveli and had reached their destination stations. The trains, operated by Southern Railway , were returning with empty rakes to Kochuveli with these employees who did not even have any food or water stock with them.

Their miserable condition became public only after a video was shared by some relatives in Kerala. In the video, the staff members were heard speaking in Malayalam that they have not eaten food nor had drinking water for two days. They also mentioned that the toilets in the train too did not have water forcing them to live in unhygienic conditions. Diasporic Keralites living in city leant about it through their relatives in Kerala. Locals contacted railway officials and through intervention of divisional-level officers food and water could be provided to staff members.

“The trains were returning to Kochuveli and since these were point-to-point staff they were there in the train,” said western railway PRO Khemraj Meena. Point-to-point staff includes those employees who do not have fixed working hours. Their work starts when the train departs the origin station and continues till the train returns to the same station.

“As everything was closed down we contacted NGOs and ensured that the staff gets food,” he added. Members of Team MSU, Baroda Kerala Samajam and Samaj Seva Team and provided enough fruits, water bottles and snacks to the employees which can help them sustain during their entire journey. The two trains started their onward journeys later on Wednesday.

Title: Neuberg lab begins Covid-19 testing in Ahmedabad
Content: AHMEDABAD: After receiving approval from Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and Gujarat government, Neuberg Diagnostics Private Limited on Thursday announced the commencement of Covid-19 testing at its laboratory — Neuberg Supratech —in Ahmedabad.The laboratory chain startup has received ICMR approval to offer Covid-19 RT PCR tests through its four laboratories in India. Apart from Ahmedabad, itsother laboratories are located in Bengaluru, Chennai and Pune.“Neuberg Supratech Laboratory, Ahmedabad has started collecting COVID-19 samples at the lab as well as from home.
