Similarly, people from Karnataka are entering Telangana from remote villages in Jukkal mandal and Sopura village in Kamareddy district. On Maharashstra border, as Salura is closed for vehicular movement from other states, they are reaching from nearby villages. Some people from Sironcha in Maharashtra entered Chennur in Mancherial district on Wednesday and locals noticed them and informed the cops. But police said they cannot keep a watch on every village, especially in the remote areas. Police are finding it difficult to keep a watch on Maoist- affected districts like Warangal, Asifabad-Kumaram Bheem and Bhadradri-Kothagudem. The state government had closed borders of Maharashtra, Karnataka and AP on March 22, soon after news about a huge number of positive cases from Maharashtra spread like a wildfire. Following the Centre’s decision to lockdown the entire nation till April 14, movement of people, especially to neighouring AP, had increased since Wednesday. “It is true commuters are even ready to take the longest routes to reach AP by avoiding police checkposts. Traffic at Jangareddygudem in West Godavari and Tiruvur in Krishna district has increased in the last two days,” senior officials in the government said.

Title: Border opened at few places, to be shut from Friday
Content: Hyderabad: Telangana and Andhra Pradesh opened the borders at various places on Thursday and allowed people on either side to cross over.However, this was only a one-time move as after Thursday midnight, the border checkposts were closed and no person was allowed to cross over to the other side. With chaos prevailing at inter-state border at Garikapadu of Krishna , at Vadapalli bridge (Guntur-Nalgonda) and Putlur plaza (Mahbubnagar-Kurnool) as hundreds of students and employees stuck at the checkposts for last two days, Telangana minister G Jagadishwar Reddy said a decision was taken to allow the people of both states to cross.“This was the last chance for people to cross the borders during the lockdown period. Both Telangana and AP chief ministers had agreed on Thursday to allow people on humanitarian ground,” the minister, who visited the border checkpost at Vadapalli in the afternoon, said. However, he said all the people must undergo mandatory tests by the government and those suspected with coronavirus symptoms would be sent for quarantine immediately. The minister also announced that from Friday no person from AP would be allowed into Telangana during lockdown.Several hundreds of people, who reached the checkpost from Hyderabad on Wednesday night and Thursday morning, were stopped by officials of the AP government. The Guntur district administration and Gurajala revenue divisional officer said they would not permit people from Telangana during the lockdown period. Since there were several families and women who were stranded, police officials of the respective states brought the issue to the notice of their respective governments.Jagadishwar along with Miryalaguda MLA N Bhaskar Rao spoke to the people and said it was not the intention of the governments to put people to hardships. The minister informed the situation to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao who, in turn, spoke to his AP counterpart Jaganmohan Reddy and decided to allow them into AP.“Since none of you have undergone coronavirus tests, it is mandatory to undergo the test before going to your respective villages. This is a preventive measure, which is good for your family and village. I came to know that a three-year-old child was infected through her parents. That situation should not arise in both the states,” he said.

Title: B’luru lockdown hits techies from Telugu states badly
Content:
Hyderabad: The closing down of hostels and PG accommodation in Bengaluru has hit a large number of IT professionals and other workers from Telugu states. On Thursday, Bengaluru city police commissioner Bhaskar Rao said if PG and hostel owners ask inmates to leave, it would be illegal. “They must provide food too,” he said. The commissioner said if this was not done they would be prosecuted. “It’s loud and clear,” he said in a tweet.

A worker from Jagtial in Telangana employed with a pharmaceutical company told TOI from Bengaluru that he was forced to sleep on the road for last two nights. “Everyone in the PG accommodation where I was staying were forced to leave by the owners,” he said.

Prashanth (22), who has been working in Bengaluru for the last one year, said he was without food because of the lockdown. “I approached the local police who were passing by for help to send me to my hometown but they did not respond,” he said.

A resident of Siddipet, Bharath said both his sisters in Bengaluru were also facing a severe problem after they were evicted from their PG accommodation. While one of them is employed with a software company, another went there to join a company but the appointment order was cancelled because of the lockdown.

Both of them were staying in an area where there are several buildings from where PG accommodation is run. “Despite the orders of the police, the owners have evicted many people. My sisters wanted to return home but are stuck there because of the lockdown. We have no relatives in Bengaluru and they have nowhere to go,” Bharath said.

He has also tried to reach public representatives in Siddipet for help but has not been able to meet them. Bharath said he has been trying to meet finance minister T Harish Rao for help.

Title: Covid-19 suspect at UP govt hospital tweets to PMO, CM that patients told to drink water from toilet taps, no food
Content:
Meerut: Four Covid-19 suspects isolated at the quarantine ward of Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College (LLRMC) have tweeted to the PMO and the UP chief minister that they are being told to drink water from toilet taps. They have also said no food has been given to them in over 19 hours.

“The hospital staff asked us to fill our drinking water bottles from the toilets. Not just this, we were not provided with any breakfast on Thursday, and got food nearly 19 hours after we were given dinner on Wednesday,” claimed a 32-year-old Covid-19 suspect who works at a multinational hotel chain in Dubai.

A diabetic, he had approached the government hospital after developing symptoms akin to the contagious disease. According to experts, long gaps in meals may worsen the health condition of any diabetic patient.

The patient also tweeted to the Prime Minister Office (PMO) and to the UP’s chief minister seeking help from them.

“I am not sure if anyone is reading this, but I am suffering due to COVID-19. Meerut Medical College (doesn't) have proper infrastructure, no food or water (since) the last 20 hours here... help (sic),” read the tweet.

TOI could not access the hospital’s quarantine ward, but patients inside gave almost the same account when contacted on phone. They shared pictures and videos which corroborated the version shared by the patient on twitter.

Another patient, a 30-year-old from Hastinapur, said, “Drinking water is a major issue here. At a time when special care should be taken about anything we eat or drink, we are not even getting filtered water. We are being told to fill water from the washroom taps.”

When contacted, Dr RC Gupta, principal of LLRM Medical College, said, “We haven’t got any such complaint so far. However, now that the matter has been brought to our notice, we will look into it.”

Title: Telugu bodies unite to help UK stranded
Content:
Hyderabad: The 27 Telugu students in the United Kingdom, who had been left without accommodation following the end of an arrangement by the High Commission of India on March 25, can heave a sigh of relief as various Telugu associations have come forward to help. These associations have decided to bear the students’ boarding expenditure in another hotel. While the responsibility of seven students was taken up the Andhra Pradesh government, the others will be helped by the various Telugu bodies.

According to Gampa Venugopal of Telangana NRI Forum, all 27 students have been assured that expenditure for their food will be taken care of by the various Telugu associations which have made provisions to serve them lunch and dinner. The students have been informed that arrangements for their accommodation and food will continue till March 31. The students have been advised to make their own arrangements after that.

In addition to the 27 Telugu students, two students from Gujarat and one from Uttarakand are also being helped but only with food arrangements.

The students had been stranded in London as flights were cancelled. After spending two days at the HCI, they were moved to a hotel. The expenditure was met by Kuldeep Shekawath, a social worker and businessman. Many other Indian students who also found themselves in a similar situation have had to make arrangements for their stay in London.

While the responsibility of seven students was taken up by the Andhra Pradesh government, the others will be helped by the various Telugu bodies in the United Kingdom

Title: AMU teachers condemn massacre of Sikhs in Afghanistan
Content:
Agra: Aligarh Muslim University Teachers’ Association (AMUTA) on Thursday condemned the massacre of 25 Sikhs at a gurdwara in Afghanistan’s capital, Kabul. Eight people were injured in the attack. AMUTA has appealed to the government of Afghanistan to take stringent action against the culprits.

On behalf of teaching community and AMU fraternity, AMUTA extended condolences to the families of the deceased and assured them that the “entire AMU fraternity stands by them in this time of unbearable pain”.

While appreciating the efforts made to combat coronavirus, AMUTA also appealed to the President Ram Nath Kovid and Prime Minister Narebdra Modi to extend both financial and medical help to all those in need.

Title: Ready to deal with 100 patients a day: Kejriwal
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi government has got a standard-operating procedure (SOP) prepared to deal with all situations if the novel coronavirus outbreak reaches stage III and Covid-19 cases start pouring in.The SOP, prepared by a five-doctor team headed by Dr S K Sarin of Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences, has been submitted to chief minister Arvind Kejriwal . “The government is fully prepared to deal with up to 100 patients per day and is preparing for even 1,000 positive cases in future,” Kejriwal said on Friday.Staying prepared does not mean that the number of cases is likely to rise, the CM clarified. Urging people not to misinterpret it, he said, “The purpose of the 21-day lockdown by the Prime Minister is to contain the outbreak of the virus. But we are just avoiding taking a chance and preparing everything ahead.”Kejriwal also appealed to the people leaving Delhi to return from the border and stay back as his government was scaling up food distribution arrangements.Out of the 40 positive cases in Delhi, 30 have come from outside. “The situation is under control right now with a maximum daily increase of three-four cases. On some days, there are no new case. But the situation is deteriorating in countries like the US and the UK. If the same happens in India, are we ready for that?” the chief minister asked.The report of the team, set up by Kejriwal, was submitted on Thursday and includes a three-stage action plan. The first stage talks about the arrangements required if Delhi starts getting 100 new cases daily. The second and third stages deal with situations when the count reaches 500 and 1,000 new cases every day, respectively.The current healthcare system is enough to treat 100 new cases daily, said Kejriwal. “A detailed plan has been prepared to see how many isolation beds, ventilators, ICU beds, testing mechanism, ambulances, and medical staff including doctors and nurses,” are required to tackle all three stages, he added. The team has also mapped mechanisms on inclusion of private hospitals in case of a surge and on procuring essential resources.“We will start implementing these plans once the cases rise from 100 per day. We have a detailed plan to treat up to 1,000 new cases per day. But I hope we never reach that stage,” Kejriwal said.Through video-conferencing, lieutenant governor Anil Baijal and the chief minister also reviewed the lockdown situation and the condition of essential supplies.Around 8 lakh social welfare pension beneficiaries have received Rs 5,000 — double of the usual amount — for March and will get the same for April in the first week of next month, Kejriwal said. Electronic passes are also being issued for facilitating essential travel but the 1031 helpline number witnessed congestion on Friday too.

Title: Veggie vendors to occupy Ooty bus stand, municipal ground
Content:
Udhagamandalam: The main bus stand and a municipal ground in the town will be converted into vegetable and fruit markets during the 21-day lockdown period.

The closed Ooty municipal market houses over 1,300 grocery, vegetable and fruit shops.

“By splitting the vegetable shops in Uzhavar Sandhai and Ooty municipal markets, shops will be set up in open area in Shanthi Vijai ground (municipal) and Ooty main bus stand. This is to give required space to the customers to maintain social distancing,” collector J Innocent Divya told reporters in the town on Thursday.

“Shopkeepers are responsible for maintaining social distance of their customers. Otherwise, they will be asked to close their shops,” she said.

As far as villages in the district are concerned, pickup vans will supply vegetables and fruits to every village on regular intervals of time. In this connection, a meeting was held by the district administration with the wholesale vegetable vendors.

In connection with the seven samples from the district given for COVID-19 test, Divya said, “All the seven results are negative. However, two of them have symptoms and they are monitored in step-down wards.”

Stating that 91 cases have been booked till date against those under home quarantine for violating norms, Divya said, “If the home quarantined people continue to violate the prescribed norms, they will be arrested and remanded.”

With four fire-tenders, the exercise of disinfecting public places, temples, churches and mosques was started in the district on Thursday.

Agriculture activities are permitted in the hill district with limited workforce and maintaining social distance.

Bread and other bakery items are not available in the town since Wednesday. Clarifying that only tea stalls are closed, Nilgiris SP V Sasimohan said, “There is no restriction in selling bakery items. But customers should be attended across the counter, not inside the shop.”

Title: From Hyderabad to Vizag: 600km walkathon for Andhra Pradesh workers
Content:
There are about 300 people from Visakhapatnam in the same Banjara Hills basti. Few of their families had decid... Read More

HYDERABAD: Living cooped up in a shed for 21 days with no access to the outside world is scarier to a dozen-odd construction labourers from Visakhapatnam than travelling 600 km between states. Even the firmly closed borders between states does not bother them.

The labourers started their long journey from a basti in Hyderabad’s Banjara Hills area to Visakhapatnam the moment PM Narendra Modi announced the national lockdown on Tuesday. They reached Kodad on the Telangana-AP border on Thursday, walking and hitching rides on a handful of trucks that they came across.

Speaking to TOI over the phone, 26-year-old Vadla Shankar says that they have no other option but to walk as much as they can as they are left with no work and very little money to survive in Hyderabad. “Home would be a much safe option?” he asks.

“We began walking on Wednesday night at 10.30 pm, with each one of us having between Rs 1,000 and Rs 2,000 in cash,” said P Mahesh, another 21-year-old from the group adding: “It is very difficult to get food, but surviving 21 days of lockout on our own seemed even more difficult. We hope to reach our village soon.”

With great difficulty, the labourers had managed to get food at a local dhaba upon reaching Nalgonda district . They claim to have covered most of the distance by walking but with many having already exhausting their money, managing a truck to cover the remaining distance has become a difficult task .

Migrant labourers earn between Rs 700 and Rs 1,000 a day in Hyderabad. There are about 300 people from Visakhapatnam in the same Banjara Hills basti, some who have their families settled in Hyderabad decided to stay back.

The Telengana government reached out to them after a social activist alerted them on plight of migrant labourers unable to find work. “We tried to convince them to stay back, assured them food but we have to understand their psyche too,” said Sajaya Kakarla, social activist who had reached out to help them.

“Though the group belongs to a tribal community, the region they live in has not been declared a scheduled tribal area. Hence, they don’t get any benefits,” observed P S Ajay Kumar, another social activist who works with tribals in Andhra Pradesh . “Four of them carry mobiles but they have run out of charge and are unable to stay in touch with their families,” Ajay Kumar said.

A group of six had managed to reach Tuni in Andhra Pradesh which is over 400 kilometres from Hyderabad by Thursday afternoon. Locals there are said to have reached out to them to given them money and food .

Title: Andhra Pradesh News: Stone pelting at Wadapally as Andhra Pradesh cops cap entry
Content: HYDERABAD: A day after Andhra Pradesh police refused to allow the entry of thousands of people from Hyderabad near Suryapet district, some trying to gain entry into the neighbouring state through Wadapally resorted to stone pelting at policemen on Thursday night. This, after AP police imposed a cap of 150 persons to be allowed entry into the state.Nalgonda SP Ranganath told TOI that after the AP police resorted to lathicharge, many including women, were pushed back towards Telangana. As the situation became tense, the SP stepped in urged people, who intended to enter AP, not to resort to violence. It was learnt that at least five persons were injured while several vehicles damaged.“It is not advisable for you to gather in such large numbers. Who knows if they are carrying the virus. Please return to Hyderabad, I will facilitate your return travel and make sure you will not face any difficulty. If someone is not having any vehicle, I will help you out by arranging a bus,’’ Ranganath told those waiting to cross over. Most had left the place till last reports came in and had started their return to Hyderabad.Earlier in the day, chief ministers of both Telugu states had spoken to each other to resolve the issue and agreed on a one-time deal for people to cross over. However, due to the huge rush, the AP police had put a cap of 150 people to be allowed into the state.On Wednesday night too, high drama ensued in Suryapet with Telangana police having a hard time convincing motorists to return to Hyderabad after being refused entry into Andhra Pradesh by police officials in the neighbouring state. The motorists wanted to go back to their native places in AP. The situation remained relatively calm for most part of Thursday in Nalgonda and Suryapet until some resorted to violence in Wadapally.Tensions escalated on the night with the AP police refusing to accept no-objection-certificates issued by Hyderabad and Cyberabad police to those who wanted to return to their native places. “With great difficulty we managed to get the passes. It is unfair if after travelling for 200 kilometres, we are asked to return,” said K Sunil, a native of Guntur who works for a software company in Hyderabad.

Title: Delhi Police officer quarantined after daughter returns from abroad
Content: NEW DELHI: A Delhi Police officer is in isolation as his daughter fell ill a day after returning from abroad. Another constable posted in Rohini traffic circle was admitted to a hospital on Thursday after being down with fever for the last one week.“DCP West and his staff members are in isolation after the return of DCP’s daughter from abroad. There were no symptoms when she was screened at the airport. But since she was not feeling well, she was admitted to a hospital and her tests were conducted. The reports are awaited,” said a source.The blood sample of the constable has been collected, and the novel coronavirus report is expected in 48 hours.Meanwhile, Delhi Police Commissioner SN Shrivastava has asked 25 to 33 percent of the force to go in isolation on a rotation basis. Preference would be given to those who are above 50 years of age or have medical issues.The top cop also asked the officers to patiently deal with public.“...In view of the necessity for this lockdown, a part of Delhi Police personnel should remain in isolation, quarantine for a period of ten days by rotation. All police stations, offices of ACP’s, DCP’s and other higher offices are advised to send their 25-33 percent of staff posted in their office for isolation/ quarantine,” the order stated.A senior police officer said they have already started identifying the cops who have medical issues and are aged above 50 years.

Title: Workers return from Gujarat & Maharashtra, raise coronavirus scare
Content: UDAIPUR: Remote villages in migration prone Dungarpur and other districts in South Rajasthan are in the grip of mounting anxiety as migrant labourers begin to return home from Maharashtra and Gujarat areas affected by the coronavirus outbreak After the nation wide lockdown announced on March 22, these workers after being jobless walked back to their home state in herds. "Some 26 thousand people have reached Ratanpur on the Gujarat-Rajasthan border in past two-three days. Our teams are line listing them, they are being screened by the medical teams. Those who have been advised to be in quarantine are stamped and are being transported to their villages through buses arranged by the administration," Dungarpur collector Kanaram told TOI.According to the senior officer, some 30 counters have been put up at the check post where patwaris are preparing lists of arriving population categorically as per their areas. Medical teams of 20 doctors and 40 nurses have been working day and night in screening these people. Most of the people do not have money and had not eaten stomach full during their long walk back home. " It is indeed a large amount of people but we are trying to adhere to the social distancing protocol as far as possibleWe are providing them food, water and medicines too and ensuring that they follow the quarantine prescription even after reaching home" the collector said . Around 16 thousand had reached till Wednesday and some 12 thousand people were reported to have reached in 7 hours on Thursday between 6 am to 1 pm while a large number is still expected in two days. Fifty buses arranged by the district administration are making rounds to transport these people to their homes not only within the district but to Rajsamand,Banswara, Udaipur and Pratapgarh. Looking at the high inflow of workers , the government should.deploy additional medical teams and provide them with ample equipments to speed up the screening process. The large gathering of thousands of people in the area itself at this time may prove risky for all ,claimed activists . Meanwhile the police personnel, volunteers are arranging food packets at several towns and distributing to people walking back to their homes.

Title: Twin trouble for cultivators: Rain and virus wreak havoc in Rajasthan
Content:
Representative Image

JAISALMER: Farmers are faced with a double whammy, amidst the lockdown in the wake of coronavirus pandemic and the rough weather. In last two days, rain has damaged the crops which were ready for harvesting. Along with this, the labourers have gone to their villages due to which farmers are unable to get their crops harvested. There is heavy shortage of labourers due to which, loading and unloading of food items is also getting affected.

Truck drivers have gone to their homes and are not available to load trucks for transporting food items. In Jaisalmer’s Nachna, Mohangarh canal areas and other areas with tubewells, crops of wheat, jeera, mustard are ready to be harvested but farmers are not getting any labourers for it. And where the crops have been harvested, they are lying in the fields and not being gathered, for want of labourers.

According to the information, due to lockdown, all public transport is closed and labourers from the neighbouring places are not coming to the canal area and the labourers who were there, have gone to their villages due to which there is a shortage of labourers. A farmer said that due to rain for last two days, the worries of farmers have increased.

In Nachna on Wednesday, there was hailstorm as well and similarly in Barmer district also, there is information of damage caused to crops due to rain. The farmer said that untimely rain and hail have caused heavy damage to the crops. This is the time when farmers harvest the crops and sell in the market and earn money, but now the farmers have to face economic crisis. Earlier, locusts damaged the crops and now, the coronavirus and rain have wreaked havoc on them.

Barmer SND Jaisalmer district administration in a release said that those farmers who have insured their crops under PM Fasal Bima Yojana can inform the insurance company within 72 hours of the damage caused to crops lying in fields after harvest due to untimely rains. Many places in Barmer and Jaisalmer witnessed rains on Thursday and farmers have been requested to inform the agriculture department or insurance company within seven days about the damage to crops. There is also the added problem of distributing food items due to the shortage of labourers.

Title: SGCCI seeks deferment of gas, power bill payments
Content:
Surat: The Southern Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SGCCI) has urged the state government for deferment of power utility and gas bill payments of the domestic, commercial and industrial purposes for the month of March and April due to the prevailing lockdown situation owing to the outbreak of CVOID-19 in South Gujarat region.

The SGCCI has also made a representation to J N Singh, chairman of Gujarat Gas Ltd, to provide deferment from gas utility payments of industrial, commercial and residential purposes due to the lockdown in the state.

For both the utility payments, a request has been made to adjust the bills towards the usage of power and gas utilities during the months of March and April 2020 so that it can be collected post removal of the lockdown and declaration of normalization of condition and that it can be collected in nine equal monthly installments.

Title: Tackling disobedient crowds biggest challenge in containing corona spread, says Meerut zone ADG
Content:
Meerut: Despite a steady rise in the number of Covid-19 positive cases, policemen are having a tough time dealing with crowds loitering on the roads during the lockdown. According to additional director general of police (ADG-Meerut zone) Prashant Kumar, "Disciplining disobedient crowds is the biggest challenge in containing the spread of coronavirus."

Although Meerut zone, comprising eight densely populated districts of west UP, has only two confirmed cases — one each in Shamli and Baghpat — so far, western UP as a whole accounts for more than 70% of the total 42 positive coronavirus cases in the state, with Noida and Agra leading the chart.

"We are using all possible means, including continuously appealing to people through public address systems, patrolling, drawing social distance circles on roadsides and near shops for people to stand a meter apart from each other, issuing challans to stray vehicles, barricading, etc, but unless people understand the real danger, these measures turn futile," said ADG Kumar.

Unlike curfew, the lockdown has its own loopholes, too; there is a relaxation in the morning hours for the people to procure daily needs, but it is also the time when markets get crowded defeating the very purpose of social distancing and the lockdown.

"A large number of people still don't understand the gravity of the situation. A couple of car occupants got aggressive with cops when they were not allowed to enter the city limits. When the crossed their limits, I had to pull out my service pistol to force them to maintain at least two-meter distance," an inspector who wished not to be identified told TOI.

However, ADG Kumar says, "It's high time and we will have to be strict now, else all of us will regret."

Notably, in Saharanpur, drones have been deployed for aerial surveillance and identifying areas where people are venturing out of the roads.

"Despite prohibitory orders in place, many people are not adhering to the directions of staying at home. They cite one reason or another to stay out. We have deployed drones to enforce lockdown effectively and are taking strict measures against people caught by the aerial surveillance," said SSP Saharanpur Dinesh P.

Muzaffarnagar SSP Abhishek Yadav disclosed, " A total of 50 people have been booked on Thursday alone for defying the lockdown, while 10 were booked on Wednesday."

Title: Shamli sugar mill seeks nod to make alcohol-based disinfectant to sanitise 75 villages
Content:
Muzaffarnagar: A private sugar mill in Shamli district of Uttar Pradesh has sought permission from the local administration to develop an alcohol-based disinfectant which could be used for sanitising 75 villages in the district.

Senior administrative officials in the district have welcomed the proposal but are yet to give official sanction to the proposal.

According to sources, the proposal was made after a Dubai-returned man was found positive a couple of days ago in Kairana town of Shamli. The man was diagnosed as coronavirus positive on March 24 and sent to the isolation ward while whole area, where he resides, was sealed and sanitsed and Shamli district was locked down.

RB Khokahr, chief operating officer of the Doab sugar mill in Shamli, on Thursday sought permission to sanitize the area surrounding the mill in which as many as 75 villages fall besides Shamli city.

Speaking with TOI, Khokahr said, “We have started sanitising the houses and streets of the village from Thursday and we have also filed an application to produce hand sanitisers.” He said the mill had already purchased 90% of the raw material required for making good sanitisers and hoped the mill administration get would get permission within two days for mass production.

Already the mill management has appointed its 15 officials to oversee the whole procedure while mill's staff have been instructed to go to the villages and help sanitise them.

Shamli's administration has welcomed the sugar mill’s decision to help sanitise all the villages. Jasjeet Kaur, district magistrate of Shamli, said, “Sugarmill has come forward to sanitise villages voluntarily. It is a good step, We will provide identity cards to the mill employees so that they could visit the villages without any difficulty.”

Title: Hyderabad: Expecting mummy from UK quarantined
Content:
HYDERABAD: While the entire country is on lockdown to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus, not everyone seems to have got the memo of how serious the matter is. A woman who is nine months pregnant arrived in Hyderabad from London on March 16 and did not isolate herself for the mandatory 14-day period.

The house she is staying in at present in Kukatpally, has a nine-month-old infant and three-year-old toddler apart from a senior citizen. Since arriving in the city, the woman has been interacting with people freely. That is, until a few days ago when GHMC officials showed up at the doorstep of the Kukatpally house and asked her about her travel history. “We are hesitant to travel as far as Gandhi hospital to get tested. Moreover, since it’s a hospital, we don’t want to risk exposing her to the diseases there,” a family member said, adding that they have been put on isolation until March 30. “Since yesterday we have deployed 20 teams to check on foreign returnees,” GHMC deputy commission Prashanti Vangeepuram said.

Title: DGP’s warning to hostels is of little relief as students struggle to find food
Content: Hyderabad: The DGP’s order asking hostels and paying guest accommodations to allow students to stay back has brought little relief to many who are now struggling to find regular meals.Several students were seen standing in serpentine queues at various police stations seeking permission to go back to their home town. Some who managed to leave the city, found themselves stuck near the Andhra Pradesh border However, those who chose to stay back following the DGP’s order to hostels rue that they are finding it difficult to get regular meals due to closure of local tiffin centres and messes. “I used to have food at a local mess around the corner. But now that it is shut, finding food everyday is a real struggle as nearby hotels and delivery services too are shut,” said Pawan Yangala from Nellore who lives in a private hostel in Chikkadpally.Many students took to social media and reached out to minister KT Rama Rao for help. “We are nearly 80-90 students from Odisha stuck in SR Nagar, Hyderabad. We are suffering here last 3 days no food no facilities also we don’t have sufficient money please kindly give grant permission to us for which we can reach our home safely,” tweeted Shashikanta Rout.Some claimed that hostels were unwilling to offer food due to high prices of vegetables and unavailability of groceries. NGOs and Annapurna canteens came to the rescue of many.

Title: 4 more +ve cases in T, state tally rises to 45
Content: Hyderabad: A doctor, who had travelled to Tirupati for work, was among four persons who tested positive for Covid-19 on Thursday with the overall count for coronavirus cases rose to 45 in Telangana. The condition of the doctor and his physician wife, working in a private super-speciality hospital, is said to be stable.The 36-year-old female doctor, was in contact with her husband, who had travelled to SVIMS hospital in Tirupati to meet a friend on March 17 and returned the same evening by flight to Hyderabad. He went to work on March 20 at Yashoda hospital in Somajiguda, but left for home after an hour, as he was not feeling well.After staying at home for the next few days, he finally went to Gandhi hospital with his wife on March 24, where they both tested positive. “His father and two kids are under observation, while four others from the hospital have been quarantined at home,” said a health official.The third patient is a 49-year-old male resident of Qutbullapur, with a travel history to Delhi. He reported to Gandhi hospital on Wednesday after returning from Delhi by train to Secunderabad with fever and cold. “He had taken an auto home with his son, who has also been quarantined,” he added.The fourth patient also travelled to Delhi and came back with Covid-19 symptoms. “The 45-year-old patient is a resident of Buddhanagar, Secunderabad and is now stable at a designated hospital,” the official said. A health department official said patients have not be able to inform precisely if they had met anyone who had visited any foreign country.So far 1,319 samples have been tested in Telangana, of which 1,274 samples have tested negative.

Title: Agra shoe exporters provide food to migrant workers on long walk home
Content:
Agra: In an act of generosity, shoe exporters in Agra will distribute 5,000 packets of food every day among those who have lost their livelihoods such as daily wage labourers and construction workers due to the Covid-19 lockdown. On Thursday, many of the food packets were given to migrant workers who have started walking back to their native places as public transport remains suspended.

The distribution of food packets — sabzi or pulao — will carry on until April 14. The community has roped in the local administration and police to help with the distribution.

“Many good samaritans had come to us, expressing their desire to do something for the needy. So we decided to provide them food, especially to migrant workers who have been walking home hungry and without money,” said shoe exporter Puran Davar.

“Police officers are helping us distribute packets in slums and on the national highways and ensuring social distancing norms are followed.” He added, “The items are prepared in an automated kitchen with complete hygiene.”

ADG Agra zone, Ajay Anand, who gave out the packets to workers travelling to their native villages on Thursday, appealed to public to help those in need. “This is a good gesture and everyone should help.”

Several sweet-sellers and petha manufacturers have contacted police to share stocked items for distribution.

“Most of these food items have a short shelf-life so instead of wasting them, they should be distributed to the needy,” said a petha dealer, adding that he has around 2,000 kg of petha for distribution. He added that they have also sought permission to start a community kitchen.

Title: Teachers and parents call for en masse promotion of students in classes 1 to 9 in Telangana
Content: HYDERABAD: Amid growing concerns over the coronavirus pandemic, the demand for mass promotion without summative assessments of class 1 to 9 students studying in state board schools in Telangana has grown louder. The education department had declared holidays for all the schools from March 15. While the initial lockdown was declared until March 31 by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao , Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s recent announcement extending the lockdown to 21 days, till April 14, is likely to impact the academic schedule.As per the SSC board academic calendar 2019-20, summative assessment-2 (SA-2) for class 1 to 9 students was scheduled to be held from April 7 to April 16, followed by declaration of results and a parents-teachers meet on April 23, the last working day of the academic year. “Since schools will now resume classes only after April 14, we will be left with just 10 days to conduct SA-2. Government should focus on SSC exams which were postponed and promote class 1 to 9 students en masse,” said Srinivas Reddy, president of Telangana State Recognised School Managements Association Several states and union territories such as Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh and Puducherry have decided to promote all students of classes 1 to 9 without exams. On Thursday, the Andhra Pradesh government also issued an order declaring mass promotion of students from class 6 to 9. “When other states could take a decision to promote all the students, why can’t the Telangana government do the same?” questioned G Mahesh, a parent.When contacted by TOI, special chief secretary of education Chitra Ramchandram said: “We have not taken any decision regarding promotion of students of class 1 to 9 yet.” Meanwhile, the Union ministry of human resource development has written to Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) to work on an alternate academic calendar.

Title: Rajasthan: Jalore, Sirohi borders opened for labourers
Content:
JODHPUR: Rajasthani migrants, mostly from border districts of Sirohi and Jalore, have been appealed by the Rajasthan Migrants Association to stay where they are. The appeal has been issued in the wake of a massive influx of these migrants to their homes in these districts on account of lockdown in entire country.

It may be noted that a large population of the people from Sirohi and Jalore has been working in southern states including Gujrat and now, they now have been making their way back to their respective homes due to corona outbreak and suspension of works due to lockdown in thousands.

According to the member of the National Minority Commission, Sunil Singhi, these migrants have been asked to stay where they are.

“The Rajasthan Migrants Association has also been asked to help them, whosoever, contact them for help. They could also contact me for,” Singhi said.

Meanwhile, the district administrations of Jalore and Sirohi have now opened their borders for all these migrants who have been coming to Rajasthan and want to reach their homes.

“The borders were sealed till Wednesday but were opened on the orders of the state government in the evening. Since then about 1,500 persons have entered Rajasthan,” said SP (Jalore) Himmat Abhilash Tak.

He said that most of these persons have been coming on foot and were being allowed to enter Rajasthan only after screening and noting down their details like names, contact numbers and address.

MLA from Sirohi Sanyam Lodha has also tweeted to inform that the state government has also ordered to allow these migratory workers from Sirohi, Jalore and Pali, after conducting their screening on the border, which were ceased earlier.

But there is a threat also involved in this huge influx of the migratory workers, who have been coming all the way from Gujrat, Maharashtra and Karnataka mostly.

“Though, we have put up an extensive checking mechanism at the Abu Road and Mandar posts of Sirohi bordering Gujrat, but still some of these migratory workers entering Rajasthan from other routes in rural areas across 175km long border, could not be ruled out,” said Sirohi collector Bhagwati Prasad.

Two days back, 40 migratory workers from Gujarat, had been intercepted in Jodhpur at Paota circle and they had claimed that they had not been stopped anywhere. They, however, were let go only after screening and noting their details.

Prasad said that for such cases, the ward panch and panch of the villages of Sirohi have been asked to keep watch on every such person, who has returned home from other states, immediately.

Though, none of the districts have reported any positive case so far but the possibility cannot be ruled out in such a massive influx, if any positive enter the districts giving a miss to the eyes of the administration.

Title: Jr docs at Covid-19 facility seek enough safety gear, say they’re at risk
Content:
Agra: Hours after ninth resident of Agra was found Covid-19 positive and was shifted to the isolation facility of S N Medical College, the junior doctors’ association and other medical staff of the college raised demand for personal protection equipment, especially hazmat suits and N95 masks.

According to Dr Bhupendra Singh Chahar, president of junior doctors’ association, “Two teams comprising resident doctors, nursing assistants, ward boys and sanitary workers are simultaneously working at S N Medical College’s Covid-19 facility including one for screening at OPD and the other at the quarantine facility. However, the medical administration has provided personal protection equipment (PPE) only to the quarantine facility team, leaving the other team at OPD vulnerable.”

“In total, 32 PPE, especially hazmat suits, are required in 24 hours – 20 for the quarantine facility and 12 for OPD. But only 12 have been provided to the isolation facility team and none for OPD staff, who screen hundreds of patients every day,” said Dr Chahar.

Hazmat suit, also known as decontamination suit, is a piece of personal protective equipment that consists of an impermeable whole-body garment worn as protection against hazardous materials.

Dr. Chahar added, “We don’t understand when the state administration has provided sufficient funds to buy medical gear, why isn’t college administration buying it? After a lot of persuasion, the college administration provided us 300 N95 masks on Thursday, but our demand for PPE (hazmat suits) is yet to be met.”

College principal Dr G K Aneja refused to comment.

Chief medical officer Dr Mukesh Kumar Vats said, “We are following the government guidelines. There is really no need of PPE for OPD screening. However, on the doctors’ demand, we have given them 50 PPE (hazmat suits).”

Title: Food, masks distributed to homeless in Roorkee
Content:
Roorkee: Roorkee police, civic body and other volunteering groups distributed food , masks and sanitizers to homeless people on Thursday.

A team comprising SP (rural), circle officer (Roorkee) and other police officers visited slums to distribute the food. "We have prepared the food in our police station kitchen and distributed it to the needy with water bottles, masks and sanitisers," said Amarjeet Singh, in-charge of Civil Lines police station.

Meanwhile, a team of Roorkee Municipal Corporation led by mayor Gaurav Goel also distributed food across the city for homeless people.

Title: Police act tough, force grocery shops to shut
Content:
Coimbatore: Grocery shop owners in the city on Thursday said police personnel were forcing them to shut shops in many areas citing lockdown as a reason, despite the Centre and state announcing that all essential commodities would be available for people.

In some instances, they said, their employees were stopped on their way to shops from wholesale markets with goods. They said they needed clear-cut guidelines for their operation, as they were in a dilemma whether to open shops to ensure people get essential commodities, or close them as police force them to do.

In some areas in the city, such as Venkatapuram, police were seen threatening grocery shopkeepers to close by the evening. In some other areas, shops were open only for a couple of hours in the morning.

Representatives of grocery merchants’ associations, meanwhile, took up the issue with the district administration authorities.

G Irudayaraja, district president of Tamil Nadu Merchants’ Federation, said there were around 10,000 small provision and grocery shops in the city and that police were coercing many shop owners to down shutters. “The government says essential commodities would be available for people. But police are asking us to close shops,” he said.

Pointing out that they were dependent on other states for supply of goods such as dahl, masala and oil, Irudayaraja said, “Only if we get them from wholesale markets, we can sell them in retail. But cops have been beating our workers, who have been bringing stock.”

He said vegetable wholesale markets were open from 6am to 8am and that they were not able to procure stock in such a short time as the markets were crowded. “We want the state to extend the working time of wholesale markets.”

The merchants also urged the state to provide them with clear guidelines on how to function and issue them bonafide certificates so that they could travel to get goods without being harassed.

Meanwhile, collector K Rajamani said Uzhavar Santhais in R S Puram, Singanalur, Vadavalli, Sundarapuram, Sulur, Pollachi and Mettupalayam would function from Friday to ensure availability of vegetables to the residents. In addition, ad-hoc vegetable markets would be set up at Gandhipuram bus stand, Ukkadam bus stand and Mettupalayam Road bus stand, he said in the evening.

Rajamani said the vendors and buyers should maintain social distancing. Vendors should maintain a distance of 1.5m between each stall, while customers should maintain a distance of 1m from each other, he said and urged people not to crowd the facilities.

Title: Stuck Kerala youth sleep at Hyderabad school
Content:
The stranded youngsters from Kerala at a city school on Thursday

HYDERABAD: Eighteen youngsters from Kerala, who work as trainees in an agri products manufacturing company in Mumbai, are stuck in the city for the last one week due to the lockdown and subsequent suspension of transport services. As of now, the 18 persons with little money left are taking shelter in a school at Ferozguda near Balanagar.

Speaking about their ordeal, the stranded youngsters, who are aged between 19 and 25, said after the outbreak of Covid-19 in Mumbai, their employer informed them not to report for work till further orders and suggested they return to their native place.

Due to the non-availability of seats in direct flights and trains to Kerala, the youngsters decided to first come to Hyderabad en route and then board Sabari Express to reach Kerala.

The 18-member team reached Hyderabad last Saturday and they were supposed to leave Hyderabad on Sunday. However as Prime Minister Narendra Modi had already announced ‘janata curfew, all transport facilities came to a standstill.

Tey got in touch with Hyderabad-based Malayali organisations and contacted Telangana Planning Commission vice-chairman and former MP B Vinod Kumar, who inturn spoke to Cyberabad police and Ranga Reddy officials to make arrangements for their travel.

Title: AP, T not coordinating: Kishan
Content:
Hyderabad: Union Minister of State for Home G Kishan Reddy on Thursday said that lack of coordination between Telangana and Andhra Pradesh was causing problems at the borders of the states as many from AP staying in Telangana were trying to make their way back to their hometowns.

He said the state government should provide facilities for those who are from other areas.

He appealed to the people to stay back wherever they are as it is dangerous to travel at this point in time.

He said the union government had reached out to a few Telugus who were stranded in Varanasi.

He announced that each BJP worker would prepare five meal packets every day and supply to poor. He added that he had interacted with may district collectors in the Telugu states. “It is possible to check the spread of coronavirus if people cooperate and stay put at their homes during the lockdown period,” he said. With lockdown being declared across the country to stop the spread of coronavirus, several people have been stranded in different states as transport facilities have either been completely halted or reduced significantly.

Several districts in affected states have been completely shut off.

Title: Wedding in time of coronavirus
Content:
Bijnor: Desperate times call for desperate measures. With nationwide lockdown in progress, a groom–to-be decided to go ahead with his wedding minus “band, baja and baraat”. Instead of the horse that grooms traditionally ride on, he chose to drive his motorcycle to the bride’s house. His baraat comprised his father and two friends to witness the wedding. After getting married, he returned home with his bride without any fanfare.

The wedding took place in Bijnor's Jatan mohalla under Bijnor city police station area on Thursday.

Vikas Kumar, 22, from Naseerpur village under Kotwali Dehat police station area, was in high spirits ever since his marriage was fixed 18 months ago. He expected a big fat wedding but the outbreak of coronavirus put paid to his plans.

With the entire country locked down and people asked to maintain social distance and stay indoors, a grand wedding was out of question.

Not willing to put off his wedding, Vikas invited his closest friends and headed for the bride’s house along with his father and two friends on two bikes. Donning the groom’s outfit, Vikas also wore the protective mask before heading for the bride’s house.

Later, Vikas told TOI, “I have some plans to make my wedding memorable. But I had to content with a small family function. Most of my friends missed my wedding because of coronavirus and restrictions on movement and gatherings.”

The wedding rituals were performed in the presence of close family members. The bride’s neighbours also kept away from the wedding.

Title: Kolkata: Universities, colleges, too, turn to virtual teaching
Content:
KOLKATA: Bangabasi College professor Partha Ghosh was pleasantly surprised to find 85% attendance in his physics class on Wednesday morning. He felt the response was tremendous, given it was an online class.

With the nation shutting down to keep the novel coronavirus at bay, colleges and universities have shifted their classrooms to the virtual world to keep lessons going.

Teachers at Presidency University have started mailing assignments to students to work on them while the institutions remain shut till April 15. The university has also provided its students access to its digital library for reference work. Even the department of mass communication at Sister Nivedita University has been taking virtual classes. It is hard to hold students’ attention in person, but most seemed keen to engage during the online interaction, a professor at SNU said.

As the coronavirus pandemic shut down classes on campuses across the nation, students and faculty are sampling a taste of what could be the new normal in college life for weeks to come.

Professors and college authorities TOI spoke to said since it was not clear when classes would resume, they were trying to resort to different methods of online or remote teaching to make as much progress with the syllabus as possible. “University will be shut for at least the next four weeks but we are not sure if the situation will improve after that to allow us to hold normal in-person classes. Even as we stare at an uncertain future, we do not want to waste time as semester examinations are due in May. We are exploring several options, including emailing assignments to students and providing access to the digital library for reference work. If the shutdown continues, we may have to explore other options too,” said a senior official at Presidency University.

Most educators who work in traditional colleges and universities have very little training in online instruction but in the next few weeks, many teachers and students are likely to learn the effective ways of teaching and learning remotely. “We made a WhatsApp group of the students, where they were asked to join the virtual classroom. A meeting was scheduled over an app and the link was provided to students who logged in from their homes at the scheduled time. After a short lecture, assignments were give out. After completing them, students will submit them online. The entire cycle will be repeated every alternate day,” said Ghosh of Bangabasi College.

Colleges, which are rather particular about attendance, have decided to relax the rule. “Many students attend classes towards the end of a semester to achieve their attendance percentage so that they can sit for exams. In the current scene, we may have to allow some relaxations,” said the principal of a south Kolkata college.

Title: AR Rahman postpones North America tour due to coronavirus pandemic
Content:
There is nothing more important to me than sharing my music with my loyal fans throughout the world. Unfortunately,… https://t.co/xI3qgAc5p1 — A.R.Rahman (@arrahman) 1585233000000

I am postponing the May & June North American tour until next year. At that time we can come together to once again… https://t.co/w9CQ6132b8 — A.R.Rahman (@arrahman) 1585234104000

Music director AR Rahman on Thursday announced that he is postponing this year's music tour of North America due to the coronavirus pandemic.The 53-year-old composer took to Twitter to make the announcement to his fans.Referring to the importance of self-isolation to contain the spread of the virus, the musician tweeted: "There is nothing more important to me than sharing my music with my loyal fans throughout the world. Unfortunately, this is a moment when we should be in our homes with our families."The scheduled music event was supposed to be taking place in April and May. He also said that the tour will be postponed until next year and promised to update his fans in this regard."So with the health and welfare of you, my fans, my family & my band, I am postponing the April & May North American tour until next year. At that time we can come together to once again share our music and community. I will be sure to update you over time, and I am praying for everyone's health and safety. #ARRLive #NorthAmericaTour2020 ," he concluded.The push back of the tour joins the long list of festivals and concerts that have been postponed or cancelled due to the rapid spread of the coronavirus.

Title: Judges, lawyers, cops undergo screening
Content:
Coimbatore: A team of doctors screened judges , lawyers , cops and visitors at the combined court complex here on Thursday morning. People were asked to wash their hands before entering the court premises as a precautionary measure against Covid-19.

The team, deployed by the city corporation, checked the temperature of principal district judge R Sakthivel at the main entrance. “Those found with fever will be sent to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital for treatment,” said a doctor. People who entered the premises through the north gate were also screened.

Two lawyers, including a woman, who had flu symptoms, were sent to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital.

The district administration has also taken steps to prevent Covid-19 spread. It has set up a special control room at the collectorate. People can call up the control room by dialling toll free number 1077 to get information about Covid-19, collector K Rajamani said.

Title: Queries of residents to be answered correctly, in time
Content: NEW DELHI: Ever since the 21-day lockdown was announced, residents ’ welfare associations ( RWA ) from across the country have been inundated with queries from people.Right from questions around access to essential services like newspapers, milk and bread, to doubts on safety of senior citizens and whether residents can step out within the premises, RWAs have been proactive in ensuring that all such queries are answered correctly and in time.Not just this, many residents and RWAs have offered to take care of senior citizens who are alone or might need help with groceries, medicines and other essentials. Some have also been collecting funds to arrange for food and shelter for the needy.Amit Tyagi, COO of ApnaComplex (AC), a platform that manages many RWAs, said, “We have done multiple webinars with experts on pressing issues being faced by societies, like precautions, restrictions needed to reduce spread of the virus, waste management with minimum staff, etc.”During their interaction with managing committees in these webinars, residents told AC that there was a lot of contradicting information from various unverified sources, which strongly needed validation.To enable this, AC has tied up with The Times of India to gather queries from residents across housing societies and get them answered by verified sources. Raja Sekhar Kommu, ApnaComplex CEO, added that since they have a decade-long relationship with societies, many have sought their guidance in this crisis. TOI also looks forward to seeking answers to queries of our readers and ensuring that only credible, validated responses reach our readers so that they stay updated with the correct information during the lockdown.

Title: Cops cook food for beggars, locals extend help to needy
Content:
Dehradun: Police officials and good samaritans have taken the charge of helping the needy in the city during the lockdown due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

On Thursday, around 20 personnel of Government Railway Police (GRP) pooled in ration from their homes and cooked a meal for street dwellers. The policemen distributed the food among two dozen homeless people who were at a pavement near Dehradun railway station.

Dinesh Kumar, GRP in charge, told TOI, “The cops cooked rice and pulses and distributed the food among those who sleep at the bus stand next to the railway station. We had identified 10-12 people but more needy people came from nearby areas when we started distributing food. From Friday onwards, we will arrange big utensils so that we can prepare meal for more such people.”

Om Kumar, a labourer who migrated from Badaun but got stuck in Dehradun due to the lockdown, was among those who were served food by the GRP officials. “This was my second meal since Wednesday. I have been sleeping on the pavement next to the railway station since the nationwide lockdown has been announced,” Kumar told TOI.

Meanwhile, Dehradun Police reached out to almost 600 labourers and slum dwellers living on the banks of Rispana river and handed over packets of ration, masks and sanitisers.

Similar drives were conducted in Patel Nagar and Premnagar areas as well.

Policemen in other parts of the state also distributed ration, food packets, and water to slum-dwellers and people who have lost their livelihood following the lockdown. State residents from all walks of life are also extending their support in helping needy people. On the day, Dehradun residents Chetan Oberoi and Vijay Singh prepared 20 kg khichdi and drove around 7-8 kilometres to feed hungry people. Similarly, Jaina, a sweet shop owner in Dehradun, prepared meal for journalists and police officials.

Title: 40 undertrial juveniles released
Content:
Hyderabad: The novel coronavirus scare has left its imprint on juvenile homes as well. Taking no chances, the authorities have released 40 undertrial juveniles from various observation homes in Telangana.

A senior official said seven inmates, including two on Thursday, were released after the recent lockdown announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. “Before the lockdown, 33 juveniles were released. They were involved in theft, elopement and other cases filed under the POCSO Act. Most of them were in 15 and above age group,” said A Rajendra, assistant chief probation superintendent of juvenile homes.

The state has four observation homes where undertrial children in conflict with the law are lodged. Two such homes are in Hyderabad, while the other two are in Sangareddy and Karimnagar. Rajendra said all the homes had been sanitised. “After the lockdown, two new inmates were shifted and kept in a separate dormitory away from the existing inmates as a precautionary measure. Medical officers are monitoring their health,” said Rajendra.

Fiftyfour inmates are still in these four homes, an official said. The girls’ observation home is empty, while the boys’ home in Saidabad has 25 inmates. “Adequate sanitisers, gloves and masks are provided in all the homes,” said D Divya, commissioner, women and child welfare.

A few more are likely to be released in the coming days. Currently, the juvenile district board is looking at all the cases. “When the board receives an appeal for bail or release of the inmates, it will first review the case and accordingly grants release of the inmate,” said an official.

According to the women and child welfare department officials, 35 convicted juveniles are lodged at a special home in Gajularamaram.

Title: Public transport staff find quality time with family
Content:
Kota: The lockdown in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak has come as a blessing in disguise to some. The people employed with public transportation services — currently excluded from the list of emergency services — have found an unexpected opportunity to spend quality time with their families.

The public transport employees — who were accustomed to eight-hour shifts or overtimes, plying from one station to another by their assigned vehicles and would have to spend weekly holiday partially in pending official and homely engagements — are during the lockdown spending 24x7 at home with their families. “It is a happy time at home. It is for the first time in a career of 25 years that we are staying at home with the family for 24 hours without work or call from office. Otherwise, it was hardly possible for us to stay at home even at the time of Gujjar reservation agitation, when railway movement was halted,” said Rakesh Sinha, an Indian railways passenger train guard and added that he has been fasting for the Navratra and performing the daily pooja with his family.

“I don’t know how the 50 years of my life went by but now, it is pure happiness being in isolation with the family,” he further said.

The lockdown period has given him an opportunity to relive his childhood days when he would read portions of the Ramcharitra Manas during the nine days of Navratra, said B N Gupta, another senior official of India railways in Kota, adding that he has been reciting a portion of the holy book daily for two hours and been observing the Navratra fast.

Ashish Chaturvedi, deputy chief ticket inspector in Indian railways in Kota said, “I am enjoying my time home, also helping my wife with the chores.”

Title: Rajasthan: Three of a family killed as car falls into Chambal in Jhalawar district
Content:
Representative Image

KOTA: A young couple and their one-year-old child were killed on Wednesday night after their car fell into Chambal River from a bridge on Chaumahala-Mandsaur state highway under Gangdhar police station of Jhalawar district .

The bridge had sustained heavy damage in the last rainy season and was closed for traffic with barricades, but the family ventured through the damaged bridge and lost their lives, police said.

The deceased are Tufan Singh, 25, a resident of Neemuch district in Madhya Pradesh , his wife Seema Kanwar, 23, and their child.

The family was heading home in Neemuch after visiting a temple in Rajgarh district . Around 9pm, when the car was passing over the damaged bridge, it fell nearly 50-60 deep into the Chambal River, said Kalyan Singh, circle inspector, Gangdhar police station.

A few farmers working in nearby fields noticed the headlights of the car and informed police. There was about 5-6 feet water flowing in the river, he said.

Police handed over the bodies to the family members after postmortem on Thursday morning and lodged a case in this regard.

Title: DJB okays special powers for constant water supply in Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: With a total lockdown imposed and travel conditions restricted, ensuring uninterrupted water supply to the city of 20 million people has become a challenge. On Wednesday, Delhi Jal Board reviewed the developing situation and approved multiple proposals to ensure that water and sewage services remain unaffected over the next 21 days.The problem of essential services staff travelling from neighbouring states of UP and Haryana facing trouble from police was highlighted by zonal offices. DJB has contacted the local police and the district magistrates of satellite town to facilitate their travel. Orders have also been issued to replenish the stock of essential chemicals while delegation of emergency financial and administrative powers has been cleared.Raghav Chadha, the vice-chairman of DJB, chaired a review meeting on Wednesday, which was attended by all senior officers and officials of the board.A senior DJB official said that directions were given to officials to ensure that supply chain of essential chemicals and other items that are required to maintain the supply of clean drinking water remains uninterrupted.Chadha said that availability of essential staff has to be ensured at all times. “The issue of out-stationed employees, who are unable to report due to non-availability of inter-state conveyance and inter-state travel restrictions, was also raised in the meeting. DJB officials were directed to coordinate with local police and magistrates in the satellite towns to facilitate the travel of such employees,” an official informed.To ensure water tankers do not face trouble, its distribution was reviewed and instructions were given with regard to coordination with local police for unhindered movement of tankers, the official added.Maintenance and service during the lockdown period was also on the review agenda. “All workshops involved in providing necessary equipment and stocks for repair, maintenance necessary for the functioning of treatment plants and DJB network lines were asked to make appropriate provisions so that the supply chain is not affected,” the official explained.

Title: Coronavirus Update in West Bengal: First West Bengal private lab gets nod for coronavirus test
Content: KOLKATA: Apollo Gleneagles Hospitals Kolkata (AGHK) is all set to start testing Covid-19 samples soon. So far, the hospital’s laboratory is the only private laboratory in the state that that has got the nod from ICMR (Indian Council for Medical Research) to run a test on swab samples of Covid-19 suspected patients. The hospital is waiting for kits to arrive to take in samples.“We got the permission from ICMR to conduct the tests on Wednesday evening. We have ordered for the kits from Mylabs Science right after getting the green signal. We will start conducting tests within 24 hours of receiving the kits,” said Shyamasis Bandyopadhyay, director medical service at AGHK.Atleast five private bodies, including Peerless Hospital, Suraksha Hospital and Medica Hospital, had applied for this nod. Their results are awaited.With an increasing number of corona suspected patients and the ICMR extending the category of people whose swab samples have to be tested, pressure was mounting on ICMR-NICED and IPGMER, the only two facilities where samples from different hospitals in across the state are being tested.“There is the need to test more samples not only in West Bengal but across the country. But due to the existing infrastructure we were initially testing only the symptomatic patients. If private laboratories start conducting tests for those who can afford, it will put some load off government labs,” said a health department official.The central government a few days ago had decided to allow NABL accredited laboratories for real time PCR assay for RNA virus to conduct confirmatory test on swab samples of Covid-19 suspects. At least five private laboratories from Kolkata had applied for the registration with ICMR. So far only AGHK got the sanction.“Our chief consultant microbiologist will head the team that will run the laboratory,” said Bandyopadhyay.Only on Wednesday, the Bengal CM had rued that the central government had not given sanction to any private laboratory in the state. So far, ICMR has permitted 29 private labs across eight states in the country. For states like Maharashtra, where the Covid-19 count has crossed 100, nine private labs have been allowed to conduct tests. Smaller states like Delhi where the number of the infected has touched 35, four such private labs have been permitted.“Though the state government will start testing at three more labs attached with its hospitals, if the ICMR does not sanction more private labs to conduct the tests, it’s still going to be tough for the state,” said a senior health department official.The private labs have been allowed to use US FDA-approved kits. But the government has capped the charges for each test at Rs 4,500.Along with ICMR-NICED and IPGMER in the public sector, the laboratory at government run School of Tropical Medicine Kolkata will start taking in samples as 200 kits arrived for its facility on Thursday. Two more government facilities — Midnapore Medical College and North Bengal Medical College are, however, waiting for kits.

Title: Work suspended, labourers working on Char Dham road march towards villages on foot
Content: Dehradun: A group of 17 labourers working on the Char Dham All-Weather Road project near Mori block of Uttarkashi after being told by their contractor about the 21-day nationwide lockdown announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, were asked to go back to their homes as no construction activity would take place during the lockdown period.The news shocked them all. No transport, no food, and no shelter — they couldn’t understand what to do next. But as the saying goes, where there is will, there is a way. The group decided to walk all the way to their homes. It wasn’t an easy decision for them as they hailed from Saharanpur district of Uttar Pradesh which is a long way from Uttarkashi. But they had no other way out.With heavy bags on their shoulders, they began their journey but lack of eateries, fear of attack by wild animals, discharged mobile phones, lack of knowledge of directions, and the sheer distance made their trip a nightmare. “We drank water from springs but could find no eatery open. We slept by the roadside taking turns as the possibility of animal attack scared us. We asked for food from residents near Rishikesh but no one helped us,” Mukesh Kushwaha, one of the labourers who hails from Chhutmalpur village in Saharanpur, told TOI.On Thursday, the group somehow reached Dehradun. Severely exhausted from the journey, some of the labourers have decided to stay for some time in the capital city before restarting their trip. Others continued their journey. “Two members of the group would stay in Dehradun for some time as their legs have swelled up due to the trudge. The rest of us will continue our journey,” added Kushwaha.Another member of the group Naresh told TOI, “I contacted my ailing wife when we left the construction site in Uttarkashi but since then, I haven’t been able to talk to her as my phone has got discharged. I have no way to contact my family who must be worried about my whereabouts. I just hope we reach our homes soon.”

Title: Summons in all PMLA & FEMA cases deferred
Content:
Hyderabad: Following escalation in the coronavirus cases, the Enforcement Directorate has decided to not take summons issued to accused and witnesses in FEMA and PMLA cases by various courts till April 15.

Sources in ED told TOI that there are around 40 summons to accused and witnesses in PMLA and FEMA cases that are lined up till April 15. “We will not press on this, given the lockdown and curfew-like situation all over the country,” sources said.

ED, Hyderabad, is dealing with crucial cases of money laundering, including the multi-crore Heera gold scam. Sources said summons in Hyderabad and Visakhapatnam cases had been deferred unofficially.

Meanwhile, CBI has also deferred recording of statements of witnesses. A CBI source said, “Except major cases, we are not recording the statements of the witnesses. We are deferring them. While we continue to deal with court cases, searches and arrests have minimised.” The CBI website has not uploaded any FIR since March 21. Hyderabad and Visakhapatnam CBI offices have not issued any FIR in the last four days. Not just ED and CBI, other central agenies are also hit by the coronavirus. Director-general of GST Intelligence is working with skeletal staff at the Hyderabad office with a deputy director and two officers.

“As GST cases are time-bound unlike ED and CBI cases, we are not stopping issuance of notices. We are also attending to the court cases,” said a top CGST official. Most of the staff are working from home. The income-tax department has also stopped searches and there were no searches or surveys in the past few days.

Title: Plan for flu clinics at private hospitals to screen Covid suspects a non-starter for lack of protective gear
Content: Haridwar: It seems the state government’s plan to open flu clinics at private hospitals in Haridwar and other districts, for free treatment of flu patients, won’t take off. It was expected that besides treating flu patients, the clinics would screen suspected Covid cases and refer them to government hospitals, taking off part of the latter’s burden.However, doctors at private hospitals said the lack of personal protection equipment (PPE) and infra-red thermometers or thermal scanners are major reasons why the plan is a non-starter.Speaking to TOI, a member of Indian Medical Association (IMA) in Haridwar said, “Even N95 masks and sanitisers are not available to us at a reasonable price.”When asked if any flu clinics are working in Haridwar, chief medical officer Saroj Naithani said, “I have no information on it.” However, she confirmed that a letter to set up these clinics was sent to all 361 registered hospitals/clinics in a WhatsApp group of IMA, Haridwar.Regarding the argument that private hospitals were unwilling to set up flu clinics in their premises due to lack of availability of PPEs and thermal scanners, Dr Naithani said, “Doctors are expected to question patients about their travel history and symptoms. If they think there is something amiss, they can bring it to the notice of a government hospital. For this, they don’t require PPE or thermal scanners.”Meanwhile, reacting to the issue, IMA president Dinesh Singh said, “A number of physicians and paediatricians are providing consultation to patients, including those suffering from flu, in emergencies, as OPDs are closed at all hospitals/clinics due to the lockdown.He added that “none of the physicians who are looking at patients has so far come across any case of suspected Covid-19.”

Title: Bhilwara collector acquires 5 hosps, 1,500 hotel rooms to set up isolation facilities
Content:
Jaipur: With 19 persons already having tested positive for Covid-19 in Bhilwara, the district collector has acquired five private hospitals for expanding isolation facilities for corona patients. As of now, there are 50 persons in isolation — 35 in district hospital and 15 in the five acquired hospitals.

However, the district administration has also acquired 1,500 rooms of hotels across the city and currently 600 people are kept in quarantine facility developed in the hotels, Rajendra Bhatt, district collector, told TOI.

“The five private hospitals that have been acquired by the district administration are — Shrimati Kesar Bai Soni Hospital, Shri Siddhi Vinayak Hospital, Ramsnehi Hospital, Keshav Porwal Hospital and Arihant Hospital of Bhilwara,” said Bhatt. Bhatt said that they have increased number of isolation beds in the district hospital and now, they have 200 isolation beds in district hospital.

In Bhilwara, 19 persons have tested positive so far. “We have taken control of the five hospitals along with the doctors, nurses, hospital staff and equipment and its premises for Covid-19-related treatment, after district administration issued the orders,” said a senior health department official, posted in Bhilwara.

“Electricity, water and other necessities will be made available in the hospital by the state government, while the local bodies will ensure proper sanitation and cleanliness in the hospital,” said the district collector, Bhilwara, in the order. The order further said that when the government hands over the hospitals to the owners of the hospitals, it will be done only after completely disinfecting the hospitals.

In Bhilwara, so far 19 persons have already been found infected with the disease, while one 73-year-old person died of the disease on Thursday. Son and granddaughter of the 73-year-old man have also tested positive for Covid-19. TNN

Title: Kabul attack: Two victims were from Ludhiana
Content:
Pall of gloom had descended on the families after they had heard the news

LUDHIANA: Even as the news of deadly gurdwara attack in Kabul is yet to sink in, the families of two Ludhiana-based victims are worried about how they will get the bodies to India amid lockdown in the entire world.

Shankar Singh of Chawni Mohalla and Jeevan Singh of Karabara area in Ludhiana were among 23 killed in terrorist attack at a gurudwara in Afghanistan capital on Wednesday.

The families are in touch with the district administration and are completing documents to shifting the bodies to India.

Pall of gloom had descended on the families after they had heard the news.

“The brutal act was a murder of humanity and those who did it committed great injustice to us. Even as the family of Jeevan Singh is here, my sister-in-law Keemti Kaur (wife of Shankar Singh) is in Kabul. She is managing things there. She told me that she will get the body of her husband by 4 pm today and is getting paper work done for transferring of bodies to India in a special plane,” said Sunny Chawla , a dyeing unit owner and brother-in-law of Keemti Kaur.
