“I had called the deputy commissioner who assured us that after we get complete documents from there, he will give us the authority to get the bodies from Delhi and then two or three persons can travel in ambulance and get the bodies from Delhi airport,” he said.

Sikandar Singh, another relative of the deceased, said they will get the bodies cremated here only. He said his maternal uncles Sher Singh and Lota had miraculous escape in the terrorist attack and suffered only minor injuries.

Relative of Shankar Singh said he had gone to Kabul about nine years ago to run cloth business. He said he used to do service in the gurdwara daily for about one-and-a-half hours.

“My six nephews and nieces (children of Shankar) lived with their maternal grandmother Naveen Kaur in Chawni Mohalla even as Keemti would come to see them and stay for about month. My brother-in-law had come to Ludhiana about three years ago for his daughter’s marriage in Daresi and came again when she had a divorce as her in-laws didn’t treat her well. He used to tell me that he had visited his native place as he did want to face his daughter. Now, only his body will return to India now,” Sunny said. “He was the only earning member in the family.”

A relative of Jeevan Singh, whose family is inconsolable after hearing the shocking news of his death, said the victim had told them that he would return on Baisakhi and would get one of his two daughters married. Jeevan is survived by his wife, two daughters and a seven-year-old son.

The relatives said both Shankar and Jeevan were permanent residents of Afghanistan and had learned the local language as well.

Title: Delhi: Availability of essential goods eases on Day 3
Content: NEW DELHI: With more shops open and essential goods like milk, foodgrains, fruits and vegetables easily available in the markets on Friday, Delhi residents heaved a sigh of relief on the third day of the lockdown. Shopkeepers attributed it to more transporters using e-passes and relaxed norms.“Milk and grocery items were available at the normal rates in almost all the corner stores on Friday,” said Ritu Beniwal, a resident of Vasant Kunj Sector C-8.Sanjiv Rao from Malviya Nagar said that all the shops in his area had replenished their stocks. “We have shops in each block. Everything is under control and goods are easily available.Vegetable vendors have also started coming,” he added.Mahesh Tripathi, a resident of Najafgarh, said: “Initial two days were difficult, but the situation was back to normal on Friday with more shops open and street vendors seen inside the colonies.”Some RWAs are, meanwhile, coordinating with police to identify and punish shopkeepers who sell goods at hiked prices. “Such shops are being made to return the extra money to the customers who were fleeced earlier,” said SP Mudgil, a resident of Mayapuri Maya Vihar.Poonam Bharadwaj who lives near East Delhi ’s Maujpur main market, however, claimed that the situation has improved, but is not yet normal. “Prices have gone up and shopkeepers complain of not getting supplies from the wholesale dealers,” she added. “Police in plainclothes should keep checking prices of essential items at the shops . That may serve as a deterrent,” Mukesh Rastogi, a Laxmi Nagar resident, said.“Vendors were present near our colonies for almost three hours today, which came as a respite to many,” said Sargun Sethi, a resident of Shiv Nagar WZ Block.“The situation has changed a lot in the last 24 hours. Earlier, we used to be stopped several times by the cops, but on Friday, I went about my business without any hiccups,” asserted Arvind Kumar who works for an e-commerce food delivery service.Dilip, who works at a pharmacy and delivers medicines locally in Jangpura Extension, said: “My work was slightly affected for two days, but the new rules are likely to make our movement easier.”

Title: ‘Haridwar teeming with those who are stranded’
Content:
Dehradun: Amid the nationwide lockdown due to Covid-19 outbreak, officials of Haridwar forest division on Thursday distributed food and medicines to those who were left stranded.

The department officials said they had identified three main locations – Haridwar city, Shyampur range and Chidiyapur range, which shares border with Uttar Pradesh. Several stranded workers have approached the patrolling teams for help as they struggle to go to their home states. Most of them could be seen at railway station and bus stand, forest officials stated, adding that they also distributed face masks, hand sanitisers and fruits.

District forest officer (DFO) of Haridwar Akash Verma told TOI, “A lot of people are stranded in Haridwar. They don’t have much support. So, we have asked our patrolling team to feed these people. Not only that, we directed them to provide food for the stray dogs too. This is our own initiative and we appeal to the people to come forward and support the poor and the needy.”

“The district administration is constantly trying to move them to safer areas in the city. Haridwar has a large migrant population and all of them now need our support,” the DFO added.

Meanwhile, there were reports of overcharging and hoarding from some areas in the district with people alleging that fruits, vegetables and daily essentials like rice, wheat flour, cooking oil etc were being sold at more than normal prices in some areas.

Title: Shivraj cabinet expansion may get deferred till April 15 due to corona scare
Content:
Madhya Pradesh chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan

BHOPAL: The newly-formed cabinet expansion of the Shivraj Singh Chouhan-led BJP government may get delayed till April 15 due to the Covid-19 lockdown. The government, which was formed due to a split in Congress, might face a major challenge during the cabinet formation in a bid to manage the cards of keeping BJP loyalists together and also convincing the 22 MLAs from the Jyotiraditya Scindia faction.

“Covid-19 is the biggest challenge and priority before us. Cabinet may form within the next week or ten days,” said senior BJP leader Narottam Mishra.

The entire exercise is as challenging as the coronavirus outbreak, which if done smartly could lead to smooth functioning of the government.

Sources disclosed that Prime Minister Narendra Modi has asked all states to tackle Covid-19 as their first and foremost priority. His instructions to completely lockdown the country for a period of 21-days was also endorsed by former Union minister Scindia, who has a crucial role to play in the formation of the state cabinet.

“Requesting everyone to conform to the lockdown. Let’s break the chain of this deadly virus. This is the biggest challenge before us,” said Scindia, on a social media post on Thursday. He further tweeted, “I am aware of the problems caused to the public due to the coronavirus scare and lockdown. But, Modiji has appealed to maintain social distancing and that is why I am not able to come before you.”

Scindia loyalist MLAs have also asked the state government to ensure proper supply of essential items in their respective constituencies from where they will be contesting in the bypolls in the next six months. “The government must ensure proper supply of essential items in the constituencies so that the poor and needy get relief,” former health minister and MLA from Sanwer, Tulsi Silawat, told the media.

Interestingly, after Covid-19, the biggest attention of MLAs is towards the cabinet formation and how chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan convinces the BJP MLAs along with the 22 former legislators who joined the saffron party. Sources said, initially there was plan to adjust two leaders as deputy ministers (Tulsi Silawat and Narottam Mishra) and elevate 10 MLAs as cabinet ministers.

But, before the allotment of berths, both BJP and Scindia faction MLAs will have to decide on the distribution of assembly seats in different regions.

In the Gwalior-Chambal region, three heavyweights — Imrati Devi, Pradyuman Singh Tomar and Mahendra Singh Sisodia have kept their fingers crossed. They were ministers in the Congress government. But, new names have also emerged such as Adal Singh Kansana, who could challenge Narottam Mishra or Yashodhara Raje Scindia, who are already tipped to get a cabinet berth. BJP stalwarts Arvind Bhadoria, who trounced Congress leader Hemant Katare and played an important role in bringing the Scindia faction leaders is also seeking a berth in the cabinet. The total number can go up to 7 seats from the region.

Similarly, in Bundelkhand, BJP has five strong contenders. Among the rebels, Govind Singh Rajput is the only one minister from this region. But from BJP, Gopal Bhargava, Bhupendra Singh, former chief minister Uma Bharti’s nephew Rahul Lodhi, Harishankar Khatik and Brijendra Pratap Singh are strong claimants for cabinet berths. Except Lodhi, others had been in the cabinet in the previous Shivraj government.

In the Vindhya region, there are as many as seven leaders who can stake a claim in the cabinet. The only rebel is Bisahulal Singh, while BJP has a long list including Rajendra Shukla, Nagendra Singh, Narayan Tripathi, Girish Gautam, Sharadendu Tiwari, Kedarnath Shukla and Meena Singh. Rajendra Shukla, Nagendra Singh and Meena Singh have served as ministers before. Sharadendu’s claim is strong since he trounced Congress stalwart Ajay Singh Rahul.

In the Mahakaushal region, there are four names in the fray. Gaurishankar Bisen, Ajay Vishnoi, Sanjay Pathak and Jalam Singh Patel were ministers in previous Shivraj government. Pathak is a strong claimant since he played a major role in bringing the Congress rebels to BJP. Jalam Singh Patel is the brother of Union minister Prahlad Patel, who had also been inducted in the Shivraj ministry earlier.

In the Madhya Bharat region, BJP will have to adjust seven ministers, including Surendra Patwa, Vishwas Sarang, Rampal Singh and Kamal Patel — who had been cabinet ministers. Besides, Sitasharan Sharma is also a strong claimant for a cabinet berth. Two MLAs — Rameshwar Sharma and Vishnu Khatri are also strong contenders from Bhopal district, though Scindia confidant and former education minister in the Kamal Nath government — Prabhuram Chaudhary will definitely get a cabinet berth.

The Malwa-Nimar region, which was left unattended during the previous BJP regime due to internal differences among leaders, has as many as 10 contenders for cabinet posts.

Scindia confidant Tulsi Silawat is believed to be a frontrunner for the deputy CM’s post. MLAs Vijay Shah and Paras Jain will also stake their claims. Besides, Nina Verma, wife of former Union minister Vikram Verma , Kailash Vijayvargiya’s close confidant Ramesh Mendola, former Indore mayor Malini Gaur, Usha Thakur, Yashpal Singh Sisodia, Rajendra Pandey and Om Prakash Saklecha are some of the strong claimants.

Scindia supporters Hardeep Singh Dang and Rajvardhan Singh Dattigaon are also claimants. If all of them are considered, the new government will have more than 50 contenders for cabinet berths and selecting 30 among these is definitely going to be a hard nut to crack for chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan.

Title: Kolkata: Scant supply pushes up prices towards evening
Content:
KOLKATA: Irregular supply to city markets has led to a fluctuation in the prices of staples and vegetables. With stocks depleting fast, prices of commodities are soaring as the day is progressing. In the morning, prices of commodities cooled a bit with police easing the movement of goods vehicles. But the supply was less than the demand, induced by panic buying of consumers.

Most of the shops selling rice remained shut on Thursday as stocks dried up. Grocery stores across the city wore an empty look.Arun Ghosh of Annapurna Bhandar in Kidderpore said, “There was no point in keeping my store open as I am yet to replenish my stock.” Another shopowner from College Street market said: “Since there is no vehicle to ferry items from the wholesale markets and neighbouring districts, there is a scarcity. Suppliers said that lorry drivers are scared of the police. We opened our shops, but essentials are not available.”

Another issue plaguing the markets was the absence of workers. Ingredients like flour, oil, sugar and rice come from Burrabazar and Posta haats that are shut because of lack of workers. “Many of them have gone back to their homes in the districts. Others are not able to come as there are no trains and buses,” said Biswanath Agarwal, general secretary of the Posta Merchants’ Association.

The supply of perishable items improved a bit on Thursday. But prices spiked in the evening with the steady depletion of stock. Besides, there was very little supply of fish and chicken in the market.

Potato, which started selling at Rs 20 a kg, rose to Rs 30-Rs 35 in the evening. Most vegetable prices soared like this. However, there was some good news as well. Onions, potatoes and green vegetables were available in huge quantities. But police did not allow anybody to set up stalls outside the markets to sell the fresh produce.

Title: Police story: When protector turns provider
Content: NEW DELHI: It isn’t as if Delhi Police is only turning away people from the streets. Cops at Krishna Nagar, Sadar Bazar, Lodhi Road and Ambedkar Nagar have also opened up their police stations to host people who have no money for meals and distributed food to migrant workers returning to their hometowns.In south Delhi, policemen scanned the rain-shelters, JJ clusters and bus stops for people who have not eaten these past few days. “We also roped in NGOs, some residents’ welfare associations and market associations to locate such people,” said Atul Thakur, DCP (South). In Lodhi Colony, the cops ran into men who were determined to walk their way home in having lost their jobs. Police provided them with raw rations for their journey.Desperately hungry people made more than 50 calls on the police helpline, 011-23469526, on Thursday and on Friday. “We gathered the people at the police station and either fed them there or distributed food packets,” said Dinesh K Gupta, DCP (Shahdara), who handed out more than 6,000 food packets in Shahdara.In northwest Delhi, police have tied up with an ashram to distribute food to slum dwellers and workless daily-wagers. In southwest Delhi, they have committed to care for 250 homeless daily-wage labourers. “We will make sure they are fed till the lockdown ends,” said a police officer.On Friday afternoon, some cops detected a group of labourers camping at Wazirabad. They claimed to have come to Delhi from Bihar in search of jobs but were stuck now. “We assured them help and got them food and water and moved them to a safer place,” said an officer.Some officers, like inspector Deepak Malik posted at Maurya Enclave police station, have donated a month’s salary for the cause.Police have also formed a team to look at the distress of the elderly. “Most calls are from senior citizens who are unable to walk down to medical stores. We are informing the beat officers or alerting the nearest NGO to help them,” said an officer posted in south Delhi. On Thursday, a pregnant woman called for help. An all-women PCR team was diverted to her residence and she was hurried to the hospital for delivery.

Title: ‘Indore almost in Stage-3 of Covid-19 spread phase’
Content:
Stages of Spread

Stage-1,

Stage-2

Stage-3

Stage-4

Source: Pravin Jadia, officials of rapid response team of health dept

INDORE: It’s almost Stage-3 in Indore. The district made a sudden jump after nine positive cases of coronavirus through contact infection came to the fore in past three days. Indore reported nine positive cases in past two days and one death so far.CMHO Dr Praveen Jadia said, “Indore district has directly jumped to a stage somewhere between second and third stage. There are four stages of COVID-19 or coronavirus infection.”The health department had been screening international passengers since January 29. We have tested samples of any person found with symptoms, said Jadia. However, no person was tested positive for Stage-1. The positive cases only began appearing in district from Tuesday, said Jadia. There were many among the positive cases, who do not have any travel history and are unable to give details of contact history with any infected persons , added Jadia.Positive cases have travel history of countries affected with coronavirus infection. At this stage there is no spread of the disease locally.There is a local area of infected persons. At this stage, the infected persons usually are acquaintances, relatives or family members of person infected by travelling in an affected country.Fewer people are affected, source of virus is known and is therefore easier to perform contact tracing and contain spread via self-quarantiningIn this stage those who have not been exposed to an infected person or anyone, who has a travel history to affected countries are tested positive.In other words, people are unable to identify where they might have picked up the virus from. Unfortunately for Indore, there are a few cases similar to this stage.This stage is the worst, where it becomes an epidemic. It becomes impossible to control and contain the spread of infection. In this case, number of infected persons increases exponentially

Title: Nainital residents come together to help around 1,000 poor families
Content:
Nainital: Several residents of Nainital have come together to help around 1,000 poor families stuck in the town due to the country-wide lockdown.

The residents have decided to supply food items to all the families that are in need of help by creating food packets, which will include daily essentials and other food items. “We have contacted shopkeepers and asked them to pack essentials such as rice, flour, pulses, milk powder oils etc. in packets. We have also identified around 50 eminent people and activists to make lists of the families living across the town who will need help,” said Rushir Sah, a resident and owner of a restaurant.

The people who have been identified include Nainital MLA, nagar palika chairman, ward members among others. They have been asked to contact people living in their area and identify the families who need to be supplied food packets. “We have estimated that around a thousand such families live in Nainital. They have come from places such as neighbouring Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal while some of the daily wagers have also come from Nepal. They have no food and are also short of cash. Therefore, it is necessary that people with means should come together and help them,” Sah said.

The initiative has also gained support from many schools as well the hotel association of Nainital. Sah added that he has already received around Rs 1.5 lakh as donation to help the families stuck in Nainital.

"We need around Rs 4 lakh to supply the first batch of packets and I have already received around Rs 1.5 lakh. Meanwhile, people are also donating money to the people tasked with identification of poor families. Therefore, we think that the target will be achieved every easily," he said.

The residents have decided that they will start delivering the food packets to families within a day or two and the deliveries will be done during the three-hour window already provided by the administration.

Meanwhile, the Nainital district administration has said that it is the responsibility of the employers to provide food and assistance to poor families and daily wagers who were employed by them and are stuck in the area because of the lockdown. The administration, in a meeting late on Wednesday decided that the employers will be charged if any labourer dies of hunger.

Title: Small steps that docs, nurses take to keep Covid-19 at bay
Content: Coimbatore: The healthcare workers are exercising maximum precautions to ensure their safety and that of their family while working in the front line to handle both confirmed and suspected cases of Covid-19.Most doctors in private hospitals, especially general medicine doctors, pulmonologists and those attend emergency cases, had stopped wearing watches at work more than a week ago. They had also stopped taking their medical kits or any other equipment, including stethoscope, home. On Monday, many hospitals had cancelled all their elective surgeries, shut non-emergency departments and prepared rosters to ensure that only a third or fourth of their staff work at any given point, until the situation improved.Even as prime minister Narendra Modi again reminded that healthcare workers, including doctors and nurses, were at the forefront to handle Covid-19 patients, putting themselves at risk, he had in his latest address urged them to take all the necessary preventive measures to keep themselves and their families safe.Dr Dinesh Narasimhan, general medicine doctor at PSG Hospitals, said, “We neither wear watches nor carry any of our hospital things to our houses. When we exit the hospital, we wipe our hands with sanitizer and also surfaces of our mobile phones and spectacles. We also immediately remove our clothes and take a quick shower.”Many doctors have stopped carrying wallets and distributing visiting cards, besides appointing themselves the designated person to step out for groceries or medicines.Dr Krishnananda , chief operating officer of Royal Care Hospital, said in their advisory they had asked doctors to stop carrying purses. “We have advised our staff to remove clothes and soak them in soap water and take shower immediately after they reach home and not to touch anyone or anything else before that. We have also ensured that no one else at our households step out of the house, unless spouses or children are also doctors.”Other private hospitals like GKNM have already prepared a roster, by splitting doctors and staff into three teams, each of which would be incharge for a week.

Title: Covid-19: Govt mulls roping in 5th-year medical students, retired doctors to fight coronavirus
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: In urgent measures to ramp up medical capacity to tackle any sharp rise in Covid-19 cases, the government is considering facilitating fifth-year MBBS students and retired but practising doctors to help in managing patients, if necessary.The health ministry and the Board of Governors in Supersession of Medical Council of India (BoG-MCI) is looking at senior medical students being given provisional permit to practise and manage Covid-19 cases, sources said. The suggestions include allowing doctors in vital disciplines like anaesthesiology, pulmonology, cardiology and radiology who are waiting to appear for the final exam with a “Board Eligible” degree so that they assist in medi cal management.They could get “Board Certified” degree later after passing the exam. There are around 50,000 such specialist doctors who can play a key role in critical care if the number of hospitalisation cases increases in the coming weeks.The proposal also includes relaxing norms and giving temporary licence to those who have pursued medical education from foreign universities in Russia and China and are waiting to clear MCI’s eligibility test. Such doctors can be allowed to work in hospitals under senior doctors to tackle the current situation.Health minister Harsh Vardhan is understood to have asked Niti Aayog member V K Paul, who also heads the BoG-MCI, to review the proposal, sources in the ministry said. The proposal is crucial as it has the potential to address the shortage of doctors, mainly specialists in the country. Such doctors, along with nurses and paramedics, are absolutely essential to tackle any community spread of the disease.Though India’s strategy against Covid-19 is focused on breaking the chain of transmission, there are concerns over a rise in mortality and the need for ramped up infrastructure to tackle the menace. Around 17 states have started working at dedicated Covid -19 hospitals. Besides, the government has also earmarked beds for isolation and treatment of Covid-19 patients in both public and private hospitals.Currently, there are 119 public laboratories under the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) capable of conducting 12,000 Covid-19 tests every day.

Title: Israeli national arrested for farming marijuana on terrace in Jaipur
Content:
The Israeli national who was arrested for farming marijuana

JAIPUR: In its crackdown against illegal production and smuggling of narcotics, Jaipur police on Thursday arrested an Israeli national who was allegedly involved in farming of marijuana at the 15th floor situated terrace of a residential apartment at Bhankrota. The accused was sowing a good quality marijuana at an area of 2750 square feet on the terrace. Police have also seized 1080 plants of marijuana.

Various teams of Jaipur police commissionerate were constituted by the commissioner of police for its crackdown against narcotics in the city.

Amid the lockdown the police got a specific input that a man who appears to be foreign national is roaming around in the locality. Police in plain cloths was deployed to check the activities of the suspected men.

“Our team raided an apartment near Mahapura Mode under Bhankrota police station area and arrested the accused identified as Alon Molay a native of Israel. He was involved in organic farming of marijuana and we have seized nearly 1080 plants of marijuana from the terrace of the apartment,” said Ashok Gupta, additional commissioner of police (Crime) told TOI. He had also got automatic system where the plants were getting the heat from the tubelight even during night time.

Title: No sanitizers: ATMs hold risk for users
Content: Trichy: The residents who venture out to withdraw cash from ATMs are in a fix as majority of the ATMs in the city are not properly disinfected and do not have hand sanitizer despite strict instructions to banks Trichy district has around 445 banks, of which 123 nationalised banks and 62 private banks are located in Trichy city and the suburbs. Ever since the spread of Covid-19 in the state, the lead district bank and district management had instructed the bankers to facilitate hand sanitizers for customers at the banks and ATMs. However, a majority of the banks in the city have not implemented the instructions. Most of the nationalised and private bank ATMs in commercial streets including Thillai Nagar and Sastri Road did not have hand sanitizers. “During curfew, people will be in need of cash as grocery shops may not accept debit cards. While loading cash in ATMs, banks should place sanitizers,” S Vignesh, a city-based advocate, said. While the ATMs situated on the premises of the main bank branches had sanitizers a few days ago, but that did not continue, local people said.Customers at a few ATMs said that they are scared to touch the screen and keypads of ATM. In the absence of sanitizers, customers were seen using the withdrawal slips to cover their fingers while keying in the ATMs. “We already convened a meeting and have urged the bankers to facilitate sanitizers in the ATM cabins,” V Sathyanarayanan, the lead district bank manager, told TOI. The banks are functioning with 50% staff for four hours every day. Meanwhile, a section of private banks has asked the district administration to open only the main branches in the city if needed.

Title: Rajkot firm set to make ventilators
Content:
Meeting between district administration and manufacturers held in Rajkot on Tuesday

RAJKOT: A Rajkot-based company has taken up the task of manufacturing ventilators in bulk, looking at the massive demand in hospitals across the country where Covid-19 patients are being treated.

A meeting of various stakeholders was held at the Rajkot collector’s office two days ago under the leadership of Rahul Gupta, a special coordination officer appointed for coronavirus and former collector of Rajkot.

The need for hand sanitizers, personal protective equipment (PPE) kit, and ventilator has risen massively with the spread of the virus and hospitals nation-wide are reeling under the shortage of supply of these essential medical equipment. The meeting was called to explore the possibility of mass production of these medical equipment at local level.

According to sources, Jyoti CNC, a leading Rajkot-based company in CNC manufacturing machines in India, has shown willingness to manufacture ventilators. The company is one of the top manufactures of computerized numerical control (CNC) machining used to make various factory tools.

When contacted, chairman and managing director of the company, Prakramsinh Jadeja said, “We are not experts in producing ventilators but looking at the current demand in the country, we are planning to develop this equipment. We will take help of experts in the manufacture and design of the equipment. First we will start with five to 10 pieces, and if we are successful, we will go in for mass production.”

According to company officials, it is premature to talk about the cost of the equipment at this moment.

Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary, health & family welfare said, said that Jyoti CNC has agreed to manufacture 1,000 ventilators for the state government to rise up to any emergency challenge that Covid-19 may pose in the state.

“These ventilators will help state be equipped to treat critically ill coronavirus patients on a large scale,” said Ravi.

Title: 4,000 families in Karimnagar get essentials
Content: HYDERABAD: To prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus in Karimnagar which was visited by a group of Indonesians who tested positive for the virus, municipal corporation authorities in the town are providing essentials to families in the ‘red zone’ where the group had stayed.Giving strict instructions to nearly 4,000 identified families in three different localities, the Karimnagar municipal authorities have gone house to house and delivered parcels containing essentials. The authorities said these provisions would be enough for four days and they would be replenished later.Of the 11 Indonesians, nine had tested positive for Covid-19 when they were shifted to Gandhi Hospital in Secunderabad. A local person who hosted them had also tested positive. The Karimnagar district administration cordoned off the areas which the Indonesian group had visited and sprayed disinfectants at the collectorate premises, the municipal corporation, district hospital, bus stand, police commissionerate and rythu bazaar using fire engines and drones, according to the municipal corporation.The families in the ‘red zone’ have also been given the option of requesting for essentials like milk and medicines which the municipal staff will deliver at their doorstep.

Title: Kolkata: Dhapa crematorium furnaces reserved for Covid-19 victims
Content:
KOLKATA: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation on Thursday decided to reserve the crematorium at Dhapa for Covid-19 victims. This facility with two furnaces was set up in 1995 to cremate unclaimed bodies. The decision was taken to avoid a repeat of the 10-hour delay that authorities faced after stiff resistance from locals and Nimtala burning ghat staff in cremating the 57-year-old who had died of the disease.

The KMC health department indicated that the crematorium situated on the municipal solid waste dump ground complex was ideal for cremating Covid-19 victims as the neighbourhood is sparsely populated and there would be no objections. A source said the operator of the electric furnaces was on Thursday asked to ensure both the units were serviced and ready for operation. Usually, one furnace is operational and the other is on standby.

An official said the civic body’s electrical wing had agreed to hand over the crematorium to the health department for the next couple of months. “The health department will take a final call in case a Covid-19 patient has to be cremated,” he said. The civic body’s health department has also decided not to allow entry of more than three family members of a Covid-19 victim at the time of cremation, a KMC source said.

The state health department must prepare the KMC staffers at Dhapa to handle bodies. “They have to be trained on the standard precautions for hygiene, use of masks and gloves. The rules allow relatives to see the body for one last time by unzipping only the face end of the body bag. Only those religious rituals are allowed that do not require touching the body.

“No one is allowed to bath, kiss or hug the body. The cremation staff and family members should follow hand hygiene measures after the cremation. The ash does not pose any risk. Large gatherings at the crematorium should be avoided as a social distancing measure,” a health department official.

Title: Kolkata: Coughing woman stays put on bus, refuses test at ID
Content: KOLKATA: The ID hospital at Beliaghata witnessed high drama on Thursday morning as a woman, who had been coughing during a bus journey from Barakar to Esplanade, was driven straight to the hospital for a test. But she refused to get down from the bus.The woman stayed put inside the South Bengal State Transport Corporation bus for seven hours even though the hospital employees were wearing full protective gear and cops tried to convince her to get down and go in for a test. Later, she was taken to MR Bangur Hospital where her swab and blood samples were collected.The woman, who works in Lucknow, had come to Dhanbad. Since train services are suspended, she had taken a bus from Barakar to reach Kolkata. According to the driver of the bus, the woman had started coughing and sneezing immediately after she boarded the vehicle at Barakar. As soon as the bus reached Esplanade, the driver informed the police who asked him to drive the bus to the ID Hospital with the woman. The bus reached the hospital around 8.45am but the woman refused to get down.The hospital authorities sent a team of workers, who were dressed in protective suits and wearing masks, to get her off the vehicle. But the woman was adamant, claiming that she was fit and did not require tests. Women staffers tried to convince her that since she was a Covid-19 suspect, tests were mandatory.“Despite our efforts, she refused to budge. Other patients and staffers who had been streaming into the hospital were wary,” said an employee who boarded the bus to talk to the woman. The bus was parked at a far corner of the hospital premises. Disinfectants were sprayed on the bus as a precaution.

Title: Demand for assessment of agricultural damage
Content:
Aurangabad: As rains accompanied by gusty winds lashed parts of Marathwada, including Aurangabad district during the past 24 hours, farmers groups have raised the demand for assessment of agricultural damage.

Wheat, chickpea, maize along with sweet lime and mango trees have said to have taken a hit due to unseasonal showers.

As per official data, Aurangabad reported maximum 11 mm rainfall during past 24-hours, followed by Hingoli (7 mm) and Jalna (3 mm). Other districts from the region also reported showers but of lesser intensity.

Farmer activist Deepak Joshi said the latest rainfall was second such extreme event during the ongoing Rabi season of crops in a quick span of time.

“The unseasonal rain was associated with heavy winds which led to major crop damage. While the farming community is already bearing the brunt of dull market due to Covid-19, the latest natural calamity has further added to the woes of farmers,” he said.

Earlier, city and many parts of the district along with some areas of Marathwada, including Beed, Jalna and Latur district, had reported unseasonal rainfall by end of February.

Another farmer activist Jayaji Suryawanshi said that the latest showers have caused major damage to the farming community and the government must swing into action. “The government must order panchanamas in affected areas during previous and latest showers. The rabi crops and orchid farms have been devastated due to untimely rains and farmers must receive a helping hand from the government,” he said.

When contacted, divisional disaster management officer Ganesh Lokhande said that the details related to rainfall activity have been compiled and communicated with senior authorities.

Meanwhile, the city and the region as a whole reported by and large sunny skies despite official forecast of cloudy weather during second half of the day. The rainfall in the last 24-hours brought down the maximum temperature in Aurangabad to 32.3 degree celsius which was below normal by around 4.2 units. At 19.1 degree celsius, the minimum temperature was well in keeping with the normal range, official data showed.

Title: Collectors told not to stop trucksamid lockdown
Content:
Bhopal: Government has strictly directed all district collectors and superintendents of police not to stop trucks coming in and out of Madhya Pradesh or district bounders within the state.

The directives were to ensure that sufficient supply of essential goods continue in every part of state during the nationwide lockdown till April 14 to fight the coronavirus. There were complaints received in secretariat that district police and squads of transport departments were stopping trucks on the check posts and barriers giving a reason that not all trucks were carrying essential goods.

Taking serious note of the issue, chief secretary, Iqbal Singh Bains called the collectors and directed that trucks must not be stopped or else it may affect supply of essential services in several districts. The chief secretary also made it clear during the video conferencing with district collectors and SPs on Wednesday, but on again getting complaints, he further made it clear.

Soon after the chief secretary’s directives, the state transport commissioner, Madhu Kumar issued directives to transport department squads at all check posts and barriers for not stopping vehicles. The transport department also issued two mobile numbers of its officials on which vehicle owners can be contacted .

The vehicle owners have complained to government that checking drives to hassle them are on at the state and district borders. At few places including Jabalpur there was a long queue of trucks due to the checking drives. The government pointed that trucks should be stopped on the state borders for not having pass. Besides, on the check post and barriers of the transport department, government directed not to stop any vehicle at all at least not till the nationwide lockdown till April 14.

Title: Jaipur: No job and food as migration of daily wagers continues
Content: JAIPUR: Police checkposts on the outskirts of the city especially along Jaipur-Agra Highway, Jaipur-Sikar Highway and Jaipur-Ajmer Highway are coming across people walking back to their villages. These migrant workers in the absence of daily wages, food and Covid-19 fear have no hesitation in walking back to their native villages.All these workers have been asked by their families at Dudu, Phulera, Dausa, Hindaun City, Mahwa, Bharatpur and even Karauli to return home to better their chances to avoid Covid-19 infection.TOI visited Jaipur-Agra highway near Goner Road and found many walking on the road with their bags and luggage. “My village is nearly 110 km from Jaipur. I have no option left other than going back. At a few places police stopped us. However, when they were conveniced that we have no other option left, they did not resist,” said Kishan Mahawar, a daily wage labourer who was working at a construction site at Jagatpura prior to the lockdown.“On Wednesday night, we stopped a truck carrying vegetables and asked the driver to drop some five workers who were on their way to Kishangarh,” said Sultan Singh, a cop posted at Poorani Chungi.According to the labourers who preferred to walk back, their migration in inevitable in absence of daily wages, money, timely food and scare of corona virus.Such was the migration that on Wednesday night senior police officers of Jaipur police commissionerate were in panic while they were told by their suborgniates that hundreds of workers were walking towards Transport Nagar “The migration is on as these workers live in a small rented room in which eight to 10 people stay. We have spoken to many of them who said they neither have wages nor are left with any money. Yesterday, at a few places we helped them reach safely to their natives villages,” said police commissioner Anand Srivastav on Thursday.At Dausa, a few voluntary organisations arranged food and water for these workers. “Through social networking, we were informed by our people in Jaipur that some migrant workers are moving and will pass through Dasua, thus we have arranged for food and water for them,” said Harpal Singh, who owns a Dhaba near Bhandrez Mode on the national highway connecting Jaipur to Agra.Similar scenes are witnessed in Jodhpur, Barmer, Jaisalmer and Ajmer districts.

Title: Declare Covid-19 natural calamity: Hoteliers to PM, CM
Content: Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Hotels & Restaurants Association on Thursday demanded that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister Uddhav Thackeray should declare the pandemic coronavirus as natural calamity owing to the problems it has brought to the hotels and hospitality sector.In a communication sent to the Prime Minister and chief minister, association president Harpreet Singh Nirh said: "The Covid-19 outbreak has added to the revenue losses that we have been facing since quite a few years. We urge you to declare this pandemic as natural calamity."The association also listed many issues the they have already been experiencing owing to different reasons. "Drought, shutting of bars after a Supreme Court ruling, 8 major riot incidents, garbage issue and shutting down of Jet Airways in the past 2-3 years have been proving to be a deterrent for travelers from across the world. All these things have directly affected the hotel business," the letter said."By the time we could come out of this setback, we have landed in a much bigger and major crisis with the spread of this virus. This has not only impacted the flow of foreign and Indian tourists alike," it added.The association said that their members witnessed huge cancellations in rooms, events, marriages and banquet bookings. "The virus is even keeping the locals away from restaurants. Even after the scare is over hotel industry will still take a substantial time to be back in business," Nirh said."Fixed costs like staff salary, maintenance and electricity bills are highest in hotel industry compared to any other industry. Hotels require huge investments to set up and in the current scenario loan repayments will suffer. We won’t be able to survive with such high loan repayments along with other higher operating expenses and entire tourism infrastructure of the city will collapse," he added.The hoteliers have demanded relief in provident fund and Employee State Insurance Scheme contribution for at least one year. They have also sought 50% support for payment of staff salaries under MNREGA, waiver of profession tax for one year, as well as relief in income tax, GST, electricity bills and exemption of income tax on salaried class having income up to Rs 10 lakh per year.The association also urged the prime minister to "urgently look into the demand and sought immediate disbursement by departments concerned to assist in survival and keeping the infra of the tourism capital of Maharashtra alive".

Title: Telangana transport crisis biggest cause of concern for Doctors
Content: HYDERABAD: Of the emergency procedures allowed to be carried out at hospitals, delivering infants is among the most hectic given the sheer number of cases to be handled when doctors are hard pressed for time and overworked because of the crisis. Government hospital doctors would have assisted 99,000 deliveries from March 1 to April 31.As per estimates, an average of 1,500 procedures need to be undertaken per day. In 25 days of lockdown, Telangana is expected to see 37,500 childbirths in government hospitals.In addition there would be at least 20,000 deliveries in the same period in the private sector. “The total would be around 42,000, or even 50,000 if the tracking becomes more intense,” said an official on the condition of anonymity.The pregnant women are tracked by Women Welfare and Health Department through anganwadi workers. They are given iron supplements and other benefits under government schemes.Though the government has assured that emergency procedures would not be cancelled or deferred and chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao himself said authorities were tracking the number of women due for delivery, a major concern is transporting the women to hospitals when they experience labour pains. “Government provides Ammavodi vehicles for them, but at this time, it is a cause for concern on all fronts,”said KL Reddy, a farmer from Armoor, whose wife is scheduled to deliver on April 3.Doctors say expectant mothers will beunder severe stress given the situation. “Usually, mothers to be are under stress, in the current scenario they will be even more affected. They ring us up often and we tell them to stay come,”Dr Sandhya , a doctor said.

Title: Doc questions MMC’s online consultation circular
Content: Aurangabad: The Maharashtra Medical Council (MMC) has issued a circular allowing registered medical practitioners to give online consultations and prescriptions for a set of medical complaints in a particular scenario. However, a city-based doctor said that the circular is confusing and violates guidelines issued by the Government of India and Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR).In a circular dated March 23, the MMC refers to the current situation regarding Covid-19 , the possibility of community transmison and the circulars issued by the health ministry, Government of India and ICMR to avoid crowding of OPDs and avoiding venturing out of one’s residence. It allows registered medical practitioners (RMPs) to give telephonic consultations and send prescriptions online during the ongoing emergency phase.However, it states that the RMPs should provide the treatment only for minor ailments, routine follow-ups, and for patients whose medical histories are known to the RMPs. It restrains the RMPs from prescribing injectables or prescribing clinically suspected Covid-19 cases.According to Avinash Deshpande, an Aurangabad-based doctor, the circular is unnecessary because the state government has asked all private hospitals to keep their OPDs open. “Has the MMC received the government’s nod on this circular? It is not clear how the RMP will know that the patient is clinically suspected Covid-19 case. What is the legal definition of a minor ailment? When the court of law has disallowed online consultation, by what jurisdiction or power has the MMC overruled it?” Deshpande asked.Incidentally, on March 25, the board of directors of the Medical Council of India issued guidelines on use telemedicine by RMPs. It states that the professional judgment of an RMP should be the guiding principle for all telemedicine consultations.When asked about the circular, MMC president Shivkumar Utture said clear-cut guidelines on who can be given consultation, the type of ailments covered in telephonic consultation and the process of giving prescription to the patient is in black and white. “The idea behind the circular is that patients should not be crowding the OPDs of doctors’ clinics. In a usual OPD, it is not possible to follow the 3m distance rule,” Utture said. He added that most routine patients of the doctors are elderly and it is advised that they should stay indoors.Utture said the circular has been issued with the permission of the deputy director of health services and the Directorate of Medical Education and Research Maharashtra.Kuldeepsing Raul, the former president of Indian Medical Association (IMA), Aurangabad branch, said though it is not advisable to use telemedicine generally, the ongoing situation is an unprecedented scenario and that is why the exception has been made and IMA has also endorsed it.

Title: Trichy: Ban on liquor sale leaves alcoholics in deep distress
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: The ban imposed on sale of liquor during the three weeks of curfew over Covid-19 has forced alcohol dependents to look for ways to overcome their craving.

Curfew from Monday evening led to the closure of all Tasmac-run wine shops attached with bars as well as bars in restaurants across the state. As the ban has stopped alcohol availability for addicts as well as dependents, they have started experiencing withdrawal symptoms in the past three days.

“It is going to be a big issue. Three days of non-alcoholic state will lead to withdrawal symptoms such as pneumonia, violence and aggression. Our de-addiction centre has been witnessing such cases for the past few days,” said director of Athma Hospitals in Trichy and psychiatrist Dr K Ramakrishnan.

Stating that such people would turn violent and take extreme steps, Dr Ramakrishnan however said addicts can overcome this condition by keeping themselves under control for at least a week. However, the doctor was apprehensive that such people may procure liquor through illegal means or get hold of other substances like marijuana.

Quoting surveys, Dr Ramakrishnan said India had 27% of alcohol abuse or social drinkers and 5% of dependents. Those with withdrawal symptom would usually visit the general physician who will in turn refer them to the de-addiction centres. Due to Covid-19 scare, de-addiction centres are also screening patients with alcohol withdrawal symptoms before admitting them for treatment.

Consultant psychiatrist at Kauvery Hospitals in Chennai Dr Yamini Kannappan says that 5% to 10% of alcohol dependents can have a severe withdrawal called delirious tremens marked by complete shakiness and sometimes fits. “The severity of the alcohol withdrawal depends upon how long the person has been drinking and how much. The symptom will occur six hours after the last drink and will be worst at 24 hours to 72 hours,” said the doctor while insisting on the need for more de-addiction centres to tackle such cases that could present a second health crisis after Covid-19 outbreak.

Clinical psychologist D Randeep Rajkumar of Trichy says the reward system in the brain won’t work due to withdrawal of alcohol and it will only result in depression for them. “They will become irritated and angry. They cannot concentrate on anything; they will even break things,” he said.

The psychologist suggests such people consume raw vegetable like carrot, cabbage, gooseberry, bitter gourd soup etc since such things are rich in sour taste which will prevent the body from becoming dry. “If the level is maintained, they can get rid of the symptoms. Breathing exercise will help them get over tension and irritability,” said Randeep.

Dr Yamini also asked people taking alcohol to get rid of their anxiety triggered by social distancing, isolation, not meeting friends and being locked down for three weeks. “We should not take self-medication to relieve anxiety,” she said.

Title: No congregational prayers on Fri: Waqf Board to mosques
Content:
Hyderabad: Invoking the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, the Telangana Waqf Board on Thursday directed the managements of all mosques in the state to not hold congregational prayers on Friday .

The board, in an order, instructed its inspector-auditors to inform mosque managements across Telangana and ensure that no Friday prayers are held during the lockdown period to prevent spread of the coronavirus. It, however, said a group of only five people can offer prayers in each mosque to maintain sanctity.

The board’s chief executive officer, Mohammad Khasim, in the official order, also invoked the provisions of Shariah (Islamic jurisprudence) and the fatwa issued by leading Islamic deemed university Jamia Nizamia of Hyderabad on March 24 to enforce the directive. The order has instructed Muslims to offer prayers at home and not to gather in mosques for the Friday prayers. “Jamia Nizamia has issued a fatwa stating that despite high significance attached to Friday prayers in Islam, great importance is also given to the preservation of human life. Islam asks Muslims not to become a cause of harm to anyone. The vice-chancellor of Jamia Nizamia advised all the devout to offer namaz at home and not to gather in mosques even on Fridays,” the CEO said in the order.

The board order stated that keeping in mind the Shariah guidelines, Muslims have been advised to offer Friday prayers at home.

“As per the central and the state governments’ orders, a few people, not more than five, can gather in mosques and offer Friday prayers with a short sermon, so that mosques are not deprived of prayers,” the order stated.

The board, which controls mosques and other Muslim endowments in the state, maintained that its instructions should be strictly adhered to.

Waqf Board member and senior advocate Waheed Ahmed said in view of the current medical and health threat with respect to Covid-19 around the globe, it has become mandatory to follow the guidelines issued by WHO and other such organisations. “The same was advised by Prophet Muhammed 1450 years ago, to nullify plague. There are sayings of the prophet as recorded in Bukhari Shariff and Muslim Shariff, two great Islamic books, that instruct people to maintain quarantine. The prophet said that if you hear of a plague in a land, then do not go to it. If it happens in a land where you are, then do not travel out of it,” Ahmed told TOI.

Title: Goa CM Pramod Sawant relents, allows stores to open with distancing norms
Content: PANAJI: Relenting to public pressure that even saw a PIL being filed in the high court, chief minister Pramod Sawant on Thursday — day two of the national lockdown — permitted grocery stores, vegetable vendors and milk centres to open from Friday.Even as he allowed shops to stay open 24x7 if needed,Sawant warned people of the consequences and appealed to them to maintain social distancing and not roam around with their vehicles.The central government ordered lockdown will continue to be operational in toto, Sawant said.Goa police urged people not to bring their vehicles to shops as that would hinder forming of queues and social distancing norms. “Legal action will be taken for violating these directions under MV Act and relevant provisions of IPC. This would be strictly enforced and vehicles may be impounded if required,” Inspector General of Police Jaspal Singh said.He said that they “also expect public to maintain safe distance from one another while standing in queue”.“It pains me (to relax the lockdown) because I know what repercussions it can have on my people,” Sawant said, alerting the public that there are as many as 2,500 people who have come into Goa who are not cooperating with police and health authorities about home quarantining.“The government should not be held responsible if coronavirus starts spreading in Goa on a large scale as we wanted 100% lockdown to prevent people from coming in contact with each to curb the spread of the disease,” he said.Not only had the opposition lashed out at the state government for failing to put a system in place to provide essential commodities to people during the lockdown, but the pressure had mounted from citizens, too.After a citizen approached the high court over the issue, the advocate general assured the court that by Thursday evening all steps would be taken to ensure supply of essentials to the peopleThe petitioner, a high court advocate, said the state government has gone against central government guidelines by keeping grocery shops shut and had prayed that the state government comply with the central guidelines or put in place a system for essentials to reach the people.The chief minister said that his decision to open stores was because he received several complaints from the public about insufficient supply of essential commodities following the state announced total lockdown.Sawant said that though he and his government had started receiving flak on social media for strict measures put in place he was “ready to face criticism in the interest of the health of the people” and the decision to open shops was in deference to “people’s sentiments”.“Understanding peoples’ sentiments, the state government has taken a decision to open grocery shops, milk centres and vegetable vendors. Even shopkeepers can keep their stores open 24x7,” the chief minister said while appealing to people to cooperate with the police during the lockdown.Each person has to be responsible for his and his family’s health. “We cannot tell from where and whom coronavirus will be transmitted.”During the period March 22 to March 26 the state government has home quarantined nearly 1,500 persons, Sawant said. He requested those under home observation to refrain from venturing. “But it looks like they are moving around villages across Goa and interacting with people,” he said, a subtle warning to the populace to stay alert to contamination.Sawant said that persons who have been home quarantined had come to Goa from places where several positive cases have been reported.“After we contacted municipalities, local panch members and other authorities, we learnt that nearly 2,500 people who have come to Goa either from outside the state or the country have not been stamped as home quarantined. Police and medical officer have gone to their places, but they are not willing to cooperate with them and it is a serious issue,” Sawant said.Three positive cases were detected on Wednesday and more than 100 people have been quarantined at the facilities created by the government.“Being a touristic state, many people may even have travelled from Goa and there could be more positive cases. One of the patients we have found is asymptomatic, but he could be carrier of the coronavirus spreading it to others,” Sawant said, adding that this is why after understanding all of this he had called for a 100% lockdown.If we had to keep grocery story, milk and vegetable open then almost all of Goa would have taken to the streets, he said.He said that 35 closed contacts of the three positive cases have been placed at isolation centres already.“We are making all efforts to identify each and every persons who has come in contact with them and place them in isolation,” Sawant said.

Title: Big B wants Mum to follow KMC’s disinfection model
Content:
Kolkata: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation’s (KMC) efforts to clean the roads has drawn praise from none other than actor Amitabh Bachchan. In a retweeted video of KMC road-sweeping trucks rolling along Sarat Bose Road, Bachchan wrote: “Wow! This is fantastic…hello Mumbai. Can the authorities do this for us as well”.

The vehicles in the video were pressed into service by the KMC in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak. They are being used to clean and sweep roads and are also spraying disinfectants at a time when manual cleaning has turned difficult due to the lockdown.

The vehicles, called ‘sweeping-cum-washing trucks’ were first bought by the KMC from Germany a few years ago. Now, they are locally manufactured and procured by the KMC. They are fitted with a collecting bucket that collects the trash which is emptied in dump yards.

Some of these vehicles are also fitted with sprinklers that can spray both water and cleaning chemicals. Over the last two days, the KMC has used the trucks on 25-30 roads, including Harish Mukherjee Road, Sarat Bose Road, Chittaranjan Avenue, Alipore Road and JL Nehru Road.

Title: Private establishments proactively take steps to combat virus
Content: Aurangabad: While essential services such as food, ration, medicine, fuel, internet and mobile connectivity continues to be open amidst the lockdown, some private establishments are taking steps to ensure that people do not engage in overcrowding and practice hand hygiene.In Beed city, Agarwal medical store on Subhash Road witnessed heavy rush of patients seeking medicines and other medical supplies. However, after failing to manage the rush, the store owner decided to take a proactive measure. He drew boxes at one-metre gap in three rows for customers to stand while waiting in queue to purchase medicines.At Dyanradha Multistate Co-operative Society’s bank in Beed, visitors are provided with water, wash basin and soap to wash their hands before entering and after leaving the bank.In Aurangabad, all State Bank of India branches are keeping hand sanitisers at their entrance and the guard at the entrance sees to it that every visitor uses them. The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) head office and process industries which are given exemption from lockdown are equipped with thermal screening which checks the body temperature of employees or visitors entering the building.All petrol pumps owners in Aurangabad under the Petrol and Diesel Association have posted a printed copy of the lockdown order of state government outside their retail outlets. Aqueel Abbas, secretary of the association, said that people are being sensitised through social media and through boards put up at retail outlets that fuel supply being an essential service will not be stopped during the lockdown.Meanwhile, on Thursday, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey held a meeting with the district supply officer and industry representatives to discuss the unrestrained supply of essential commodities to city and their provision to the residents. Interestingly, the meeting held at his residence ‘Rayat’ saw chairs placed at one-metre gap to ensure social distancing.

Title: From bikers to barbers, 2,000 held for breaking lockdown in Kolkata
Content: KOLKATA: Cops swooped down on a group of 24 people chatting at a Kalighat locality on Wednesday. On seeing the police van, the crowd dispersed in every direction. Cops kept warning that no one should congregate anywhere during the lockdown . An hour later, the Kalighat police received the tip off that the group was back again. In the next one hour, police rounded up all of them.Kolkata Police has arrested 2,327 persons so far, including 1,874 in first 48 hours of lockdown. From people roaming with friends around Rabindra Sarobar to travelling from Behala and Mukundapur to catch up with friends at Jadavpur, police have found several instances of people violating the lockdown on flimsiest grounds. Most of the arrests involve groups of people.At Lords Crossing on Prince Anwar Shah Road, police rounded up several youths racing in bikes. Slightly ahead near Rabindra Sarobar, even the closed gates did not deter youths from walking inside. The Chhoto Lake in Lake Gardens turned out to be a major go-to zone for those getting “bored being stuck at home”. At CR Avenue-Kapalitola Lane crossing, several bikers were moving around in lanes until they came under the scanner of the police. At Dover Road, police arrested youths after their repeated attempts to displace them from a near a local shop failed.At Rajabagan in the Port area, two groups of people were arrested for standing on the road and quarrelling even before they had hurt each other. At East Rajapur in Survey Park, three shopkeepers, including a salon owner, were arrested for not downing shutters, despite cops’ warning. They were also charged under IPC 271 (disobedience to quarantine rules) in addition to IPC 188. A customer was arrested for allegedly taking part in the melee.At Survey Park, Sujoy Debnath, a sergeant of Purba Jadavpur Traffic Guard stopped a truck near Hiland Park crossing on Eastern Metropolitan Bypass and asked for a proof when he told him that he was ferrying goods for emergency services. When the driver failed, he was arrested. At Maninimohan Avenue, Bhowanipore police deflated tyres of bikes and cycles as the riders did not have a valid reason to be out on the road.

Title: Centre may extend interest subvention, loan repayment benefit to farmers
Content:
Trichy: In the wake of Covid-19, the department of agriculture, co-operation and farmers’ welfare, government of India is planning to extend the benefit of interest subvention and prompt repayment incentive to the farmers who would repay their crop loans promptly, in an effort to provide some relief to the farming community.

The ministry had earlier communicated to the nationalized banks about the stoppage of 7% agriculture jewel loans and revocation of interest subvention and prompt repayment incentive to the farmers. Banks were also advised not to sanction prompt repayment incentive to farmers, if the loans were availed after October 1, 2019. This apart, the rate of interest for jewel loan was also enhanced to 9.9% from 7%.

Farmers have demanded the government to revoke the order to allow them to avail agriculture jewel loan at 7% interest with prompt repayment incentive of 3%.

Earlier, farmers were given jewel loan for an interest rate of 7%. If anyone repaid the loan promptly within the stipulated period, they will get 3% prompt repayment incentive.

Meanwhile, considering the unprecedented situation prevailing in the country on account of increasing incidence of Covid-19 infection and consequent lockdown, the Union government is considering the possibility of extending the benefit of interest subvention and prompt repayment incentive to short term agriculture crop loans due between March 20, and June 30 this year, if the loans are repaid by June 30, official sources said.

The farming community in the delta region has welcomed the Union government’s decision on revoking the earlier order with regard to the extension of the benefit of interest subvention and incentive, said N Veerasekaran, state spokesperson of Bharatiya Kisan Sangam.

The entire loan amount availed by the farmers irrespective of co-operative or nationalized banks should be waived off, secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association Swamimalai S Vimalnathan said.

Title: Authorities order policemen to initiate legal action instead of canning
Content: Aurangabad: With innumerable videos depicting policemen thrashing those stepping out of their homes amidst lockdown , serious criticism has started pouring in from all quarters against the unwarranted use of force.Taking cognizance of the same, police authorities from different parts of the state have started issuing instructions to their subordinates to initiate legal action instead of canning people caught violating lockdown orders.In some cases, senior police officers have observed that canning and public shaming has even been done for the sake of recording video, clicking pictures and making them viral.Senior police officers have cited that this would result in unwanted friction between the commoners and police. “People, who have suddenly lost their livelihoods due to the lockdown, along with the ones unable to sense gravity of the crisis, are agitated with the restrictions. Using force against poor people or the ones stepping out for genuine reasons would divert public anger towards police and we don’t want it to happen,” said a police official.In Aurangabad city, commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad has issued directives asking the policemen to avoid using unwarranted force. Following the directives, deputy commissioner of police rank officers, during patrolling, were seen instructing the men at the static points not to assault people and instead opt for initiating legal action by registering offences and even arresting the trouble-makers.In Nanded, additional superintendent of police Dattaram Rathod has issued a written communication stating, ‘It has come to our notice that the commoners stepping out of their homes are being assaulted by the police and it is very serious.’Issuing an ultimatum, the officer warned, ‘If any video of policemen assaulting the commoners during the current lockdown goes viral, he/she will face disciplinary action.’Authorities from Aurangabad rural police led by Mokshada Patil, Beed police led by Harssh Poddar, Osmanabad police led by Raj Tilak Roushan, Jalna police led by S Chaitanya, Hingoli police led by Yogesh Kumar, Nanded Police led by Vijaykumar Magar and Latur police led by Rajendra Mane reiterated their stand that unwarranted force should not be used against the commoners.Instructions have been issued despite the fact that Beed policemen on duty were allegedly attacked in Raut Galli of Sirsala in Parli on Wednesday after the patrolling team asked the men sitting in open spaces to return home. In all, nine people have been booked in the incident that left two policemen injured.

Title: Hyderabad: NGO to give hygiene kits to daily wagers
Content:
HYDERABAD: NGO GiveIndia Hyderabad started a mission to support families impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic in India, which is likely to result in loss of livelihoods for a very large number of people, especially among the daily wage workers.

Under the mission, GiveIndia has launched two initiatives to help the disadvantaged and support families - to provide a safety net for the economic toll and to provide protection against the virus . While one will help daily wagers with food, the second, #IndiaAgainstCoronaVirus will provide hygiene kits to underprivileged families across India who do not have access to soaps, sanitisers and masks.

The initiative also aims at supporting people at the frontline of the fight against the virus, such as healthcare professionals, as well.

GiveIndia has raised over Rs 1.5 crore from over 6,000 donors in three days after it launched the campaign.

Title: Maharashtra: Sugar mills continue operations, concerns over cane cutters
Content: KOLHAPUR/AURANGABAD: Most sugar mills have shut for the crushing season but some continue to operate after the administration exempted them from the lockdown. However, many cane cutters have returned to their native villages in Beed and parts of Marathwada , those who are still in western Maharashtra are reluctant to work amid COVID 19 concerns.Arun Kakada, district deputy registrar, Kolhapur, said, “A total of 22 sugar mills were operating during this crushing season. Of these, 14 had completed cane crushing before the nationwide lockdown was announced. Now, eight mills are operating in the district.”“Of these, crushing of two major mills -- Jawahar cooperative sugar mill in Hatkanangle and Datta cooperative sugar mill from Shirol taluka -- will take around eight to ten days to be completed,” he said.He said that cane cutters are not willing to continue harvesting but the millers are doing their best to convince them. “They have sought permission from civic administration and police to move the cutters from one place to another for cane cutting. At some places, where the harvesters are not willing to take up cane cutting, the millers are exploring the option of using machines to cut cane in the fields,” he said.As the sugarcane harvesting season is nearing its end, the sugarcane harvesters from Beed and Ahmednagar districts returned. However, many of them are still in western Maharashtra. Beed district guardian minister Dhananjay Munde raised the issue of the cane cutters wanting to return to their villages with deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar.Munde told TOI that the lockdown had raised concern about the 2.75 harvesters still working in the fields. “I asked the deputy chief minister to intervene in the matter. We have clearly instructed the sugar factories which are running to ensure that they take care of the ration, health and security of these labourers,” Munde said.Munde said that a letter signed by the managing director of the sugar factory or the cane supply officer is being issued to these labourers. They can show this document to the police and at the toll naka and they will not be stopped.Beed district collector Rahul Rekhawar said these labourers will not face any problem entering the district or while going to their village. “Our village-level team is ready to receive them. The sarpanch, gram sevak and anganwadi workers alert the district administration. The teams deployed at local public health centre will examine the labourers when they reach the village. Their children are safe and their food and accommodation is taken care off,” he said.

Title: With 13 patients, Indore hotspot of state’s Covid-19 outbreak
Content:
Bhopal: Six more patients tested positive for Coronavirus in the state on Thursday, one of whom, an elderly Indorean, died. There were three other cases in Indore, and one each in Ujjain and Shivpuri districts.

Indore seems to be turning out to Madhya Pradesh’s Covid-19 hotspot with 13 cases detected in just two days – accounting for half of the state’s 26 cases.

Three of Indore’s new patients are from Ranipura – the locality where the 65-year-old who died on Thursday lived. Two of them are girls, aged 14 and 18 – making them the youngest Covid-19 patients in Madhya Pradesh. They have been admitted to MY Hospital.

The third, a 41-year-old man, is admitted to CHL Hospital. And the fourth patient, a 53-year-old, is from Limbodi area. “Both are men, who don’t have any travel or contact history. I am gathering details of the female patients,” said MGM Medical College PRO Dr Rahul Rokade.

The entire state is in lockdown and curfew is in force in five cities – Bhopal, Indore, Jabalpur, Gwalior and Ujjain.

The Shivpuri patient had arrived from Hyderabad recently and posted a video on social media, saying “he feels he has symptoms of Covid-19”. He urged officials to get him tested. The administration took note of the video and sent a team to check.

He was put in home quarantine and swab samples taken, which came back positive on Thursday.

He was immediately shifted to a hospital isolation ward where Shivpuri district’s first Coronavirus patient is also being treated. His family members have been put on home quarantine and are being observed.

In Gwalior, officials were shocked when railway officials informed them that around 590 people have boarded a goods train at Mathura and reached Gwalior railway station.

When the train did not stop, they started shouting and the Gwalior stationmaster got the train to stop.

“Majority of these people were from Bhind and Morena districts. They were daily labourers who got stranded. We ensured proper screening and also gave them food. The administration of their districts have made arrangements to take them home,” Gwalior division commissioner M B Ojha told TOI.

“Exodus from nearby districts both inwards and outwards is seen in great numbers, we are ensuring proper testing of each and every individual,” he added.

Officials of Bhind and Morena districts sent teams to take them home. “They are being brought back. Some buses are still en route to Morena. About 200 of the 590 people were from Morena,” collector Priyanka Das told TOI. She added, “This is an issue in the district, but local people are responding and informing about any such possible suspect patients.”

In Morena district, Congress MLA from Sabalgarh, Baijnath Kushwaha, his driver, gunman, and family members have been put in home isolation, though he doesn’t have any symptoms. He was at the press conference in Bhopal on March 20, which was attended by a journalist who has turned out to be Covid-positive.

Officials said the condition of the six patients in Jabalpur is stable.

Title: Coronavirus Deaths in Rajasthan: Rajasthan reports 1st coronavirus death, 5 new cases take total to 43
Content: JAIPUR/NEW DELHI: A 73-year-old man, a resident of Sabzi Mandi area of Bhilwara, succumbed to Covid-19 on Thursday and became the first vicitm of the virus in the state. He had undergone treatment at the ICU of the private hospital, which has become the epicentre of the virus outbreak in the state after reporting 19 positive cases, including the patient who died today.The death occurred on a day when five more persons -- two from Bhilwara, one each from Jaipur, Jodhpur and Jhunjhunu -- tested positive, taking the total number of infected cases to 43 from across the state.Curfew has been imposed in the Ramganj area on Thursday as the person who tested positive for the virus comes from this congested area of the Walled City. “Curfew has been imposed in the one-km radius of the house where the infected person stayed. Intense tracing of those he came into contact with has started,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health.The 35-year-old Ramganj resident had returned from Muscat in Oman. He first landed in Dubai at 10am on March 11. He reached Delhi on March 12 and took a Rajasthan State Road Transport Corporation bus from Dhaula Kuan to Jaipur.The Ramganj resident got down from the bus at Ghat Gate in the afternoon and hired a rickshaw to his home in Ramganj.Since there has been a gap of 14 days since his arrival, the health department is finding it difficult to identify the passengers who travelled with him and screen them. He has been found to have had direct contact with 33 people, with 22 of them being his family members and relatives. He also went to a nearby mosque for prayers.The two persons who tested positive from Bhilwara are the son and grand daughter of the 73-year-old who died today. A 45-year-old man from Jhunjhunu also tested positive on Thursday. He had returned from Dubai and landed at Jaipur airport on March 21.Meanwhile, the body of the Bhilwara man was consigned to flames as per the guidelines on precautions for handling bodies of Covid-19 persons. He was diagnosed with the disease on Wednesday. Though he was rushed to the district hospital on Thursday, he died while undergoing treatment.“He had diabetes and chronic kidney disease . He also suffered a stroke and was admitted to the hospital. This is the first death due to the disease,” said health minister Raghu Sharma.The patient was admitted to the private hospital on March 3 for treating his kidney disease and remained there till March 11. As his creatinine level was above normal, he had to undergo hemodialysis frequently. He also suffered stroke and went into a coma. Following the advise of doctors, he was brought back home on March 11.Nine days after he was discharged from the hospital, two doctors of the same private hospital tested positive for Covid-19 on March 20. The health department officials zeroed in on the deceased man while tracking patients who had come into contact with these doctors. They went to his home and collected his sample for test two days ago. On Wednesday, he tested positive. A health department official said that they took him to the district hospital, where he died.Health department officials said that since he already had co-morbidities such as diabetes, chronic kidney disease and had suffered a stroke, it was difficult to say that he had died of Covid-19.Earlier, an Italian tourist, who had recovered from coronavirus , had died later from heart attack at a private hospital in Jaipur. But authorities refused to attribute the death directly to the virus infection.

Title: Vendors get vegetables delivered at doorstep
Content:
Bhopal: Amid the lockdown across the city, some vendors have come out to keep going the essential supply of vegetables and make it available to people at their door-steps. In a novel way, some vendors along Ayodhya By-pass road used a carriage van and provided vegetables in the residential colonies.

It was a pleasant surprise for most residents, confined to their houses when vendors asked them for vegetables. They had adequate stock of potatoes, onions, okra, bitter gourd an bottle gourd, green chilies and coriander leaves.
