When asked, Rajaram who was accompanying the vendors at Vrindavan Nagar , Abhinav Homes and Comfort colonies said they thought since it was curfew and people are not allowed to go out of their homes, they decided to deliver vegetables to homes. The veggies are sourced from the nearby farms and are fresh, he said.

While doing so, they are also maintaining the call for social distancing and not allowing customers to crowd the vehicle and touch the vegetables. “It is an extraordinary situation, we are discouraging people from touching the veggies, instead we are picking them what they want,” he said.

Meanwhile, the lockdown was complete in Piplani, Sonagiri, Ayodhya Nagar and Ayodhya By-pass areas. Chemists and druggists were open in the morning and late evening hours and so were select grocery stores. Like in the last couple of days, there was no crowding at these stores.

The weekly vegetable market at Piplani was suspended while milk supply remained uninterrupted.

Title: Curfew violations down in city as cops tighten checks
Content:
Trichy: Stringent action including arrest and seizure of vehicles on the first day of the curfew on Wednesday has helped in bringing down violations as the roads looked deserted with minimum number of two-wheelers and cars moving around the city on Thursday.

Police personnel posted at all junctions found less number of people in the city as a police team near the central bus stand heaved a sigh of relief on Thursday saying they were exhausted of advising people to stay indoors.

In some parts of the city there was unwanted movement of people on bikes and cars. Such people were arrested and released on bail besides seizing their vehicles for disobedience to lawful order, negligent act likely to spread infectious disease, disobedience to quarantine under the Indian Penal Code, Epidemic Diseases Act and Tamil Nadu Public Health Act and Motor Vehicles Act.

Commissioner of police V Varadharaju said that people into medical, vegetable and groceries, municipal water supplies, public distribution system and milk profession were exempted from prosecution. “The violations have come down today compared to yesterday. We have imposed fine ranging from Rs 100 to Rs 500 against the violators from today,” he told TOI.

The situation was similar in Trichy rural, Ariyalur , Perambalur, Karur, Pudukottai , Thanjavur , Tiruvarur and Nagappattinam districts in the central region. As of 6pm on Thursday, 439 people were arrested in 384 cases and 265 vehicles including two four wheelers were seized from Trichy rural and the seven districts. On Wednesday, the police arrested 850 people in 651 cases and seized 459 vehicles including 20 four wheelers.

A case against a quarantined man in Perambalur was also one of the cases. “A quarantined man went out and returned home. So, he was also booked,” central zone IG A Amalraj told TOI this evening.

Title: Bhopal: Notices for quarantine misconstrued as +ve cases
Content: BHOPAL: A large number of Covid-19 notices – pasted outside the house of the people quarantined in different localities of Bhopal – are being misconstrued as positive cases of the coronavirus infection. Images of such notices are also being circulated on social media with posts like, “Dekho mere ghar ke paas corona positive case hai.”Senior lawyer Vineet Godha , has written a letter to the chief minister to take cognizance of the issue, which is adding to the woes of quarantined people. “There are over 2000 such notices. The language used in such notices should be changed as it is creating confusion,” he said. The lawyer said that his son and wife had returned from England on March 16.“Though my son had a little fever after his return, he is fully fit now. I had informed the administration about it and immediately quarantined both my wife and son. Instead of medically examining my son, I was asked by the administration to SMS my address. Ten days after his return and informing the administration, two persons approached me on March 24 and asked about their passport details. On March 25 night a notice of COVID-19 was pasted outside my home,” wrote Godha in his letter.The notice also mention that quarantine period will be from March 25 to March 15. In fact, almost all the notices pasted in Bhopal mention the same quarantine period, irrespective of people’s travel history .Godha said that there is nothing wrong in pasting notice, but it should not be misleading. “ When we contacted the administration on March 16, we wanted to tell them about the people who had visited him but it did not happen and defeated the very concern raised by the PM,” he said.Such notices can be seen in Arera colony, BHEL, Ayodhya bypass and Saket Nagar.The office of the district collector told TOI, “Yes all these are not COVID-19 cases, but we consider them as suspects. What if they turn out to be positive after a few days?” So far there are only two positive cases in Bhopal, the office of collector said.

Title: Residents fume as LPG, food and grocery supplies stay thin in Pune
Content:
(With inputs from Rujuta Parekh)

PUNE: Social media is abuzz with angry reactions from resident about limited food, grocery and LPG delivery since the 21-day lockdown was announced on Tuesday.“A gas agency in Hadapsar denied home delivery even after online booking and advance payment. We can’t go out. Delivery should be topmost priority for the agency. Please help. There is no food being cooked at home and kids are hungry,” a Pune resident tweeted on Thursday.Another Twitter user said Big Bazaar’s home delivery claims were a sham. When contacted, Big Bazaar cources refused to comment on the matter apart from reissuing a statement from the firm stating, “In light of the recent announcement, we are receiving an unprecedented number of requests for doorstep delivery. There could be delays due to the restrictions.”A Twitter user, while tagging the CM office, on Wednesday wrote, “Please start BigBasket and home delivery at Pune. I have met with an accident......Ankle is fractured since 23 days. I am staying indoors at my sister’s place, a senior citizen and a diabetic. We have not stored food and medicine. Can you help us.”When contacted by TOI, BigBasket had no comments to offer over its inability to restart operations in Pune. As for the LPG supply, a source from the All India LPG Distributors Federation, Maharashtra, attributed the problem to huge exodus of delivery boys, drivers and transport curbs. “We tried to resolve this issue by sticking ‘essential services’ tags on our vehicles and getting ID cards for delivery personnel. But deliveries have still not smoothed out,” the source said.A senior state official from the agriculture department facilitating all the essential services activities with the police said, ”We are talking to BigBasket and Amazon to sort out delivery issues. Online portals have logistical issues like shortage of manpower and problems cropping up from restrictions on movements. We are talking with the police to resolve such issues.”

Title: Coronavirus: Cardiac patients need to take extra care
Content: HYDERABAD: Amid the coronavirus outbreak, cardiologists say heart disease patients need to be extra careful.“Coronavirus attacks the heart muscles. This leads to fluctuating heart rate. Due to already weak heart muscles, pumping action is weak in heart patients. Symptoms of breathlessness should not be ignored at all,” said Dr Ravi Shankar, senior cardiologist.Patients with cardiovascular disease are not only at higher risk of contracting Covid-19 but also have worse prognosis. “Cardiac complications of Covid-19 are similar to SARS, MERS, and influenza. Given the increased risk of secondary bacterial infection with Covid-19, it is essential for cardiovascular patients to take pneumococcal vaccine, these patients should also be vaccinated against influenza in accordance with the guidelines of Centre for Disease Control (CDC),” said Dr E Babu, consultant interventional cardiologist.Stating that smokers are at a higher risk of getting lung and chest infections , experts say it is very important that people who smoke don’t do so in the presence of non-smokers. “People are mostly indoors these days and they might want to smoke in front of a family member, especially kids, and this puts them at higher risk of contracting the coronavirus,” said Dr A Srikanth, secretary, Indian Dental Association , Deccan Branch.

Title: Drone used to sanitize Thanjavur med college
Content:
The Government Medical College Hospital in Thanjavur has employed a drone to sanitize the hospital premises. The college dean , Kumutha Lingaraj , said that the aim was to keep the premises safe and prevent the spread of Covid-19.

“We used sodium hypochlorite solution to sanitize the premises. The drones spray the disinfectant on the hospital premises without leaving any spot”, the dean said.

Drones, originally designed to spray pesticides on agricultural land, are being used to spray disinfectants. “The drone are able to cover an 8-km radius at a stretch. We use the drone as it can easily cover the sprawling 200-acre medical college campus in a short span of time,” an official said.TNN

Title: Civic administration identifies spots for vegetable distribution, marks safe distance
Content:
Kolhapur: The civic administration, in order to avoid crowding in market areas, has identified places in different wards of the city to sell vegetables to the locals.

Every vendor will be made to sit at a safe distance from one another and markings have also been done for customers to stand in queue and buy vegetables. Superintendent of police Abhinav Deshmukh has announced that security will be provided for grocery and vegetable shops that will remain open for 24x7 till April 14.

Talking about the initiative taken by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC), civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti said, “We have set up as many as 33 vegetable stalls in the city at initial level and have ensured that all residents will have access to these shops. The local vendors have been roped in for the work. We have ensured that there is sufficient supply of vegetables to these stalls. We will increase the number of stalls in the next few days.”

Vinay Hasabnis, a resident of Rajarampuri said, “We thank the civic administration for setting up a vegetable market in our area where there was no crowd and people were following the rules of social distancing. I bought vegetables without any rush. Variety of vegetables were available in the market at reasonable rates. We had expected that the rates may rise due to sudden country-wide lockdown but that was not the case.”

Yuvraj Gaikwad, a vegetable vendor in Rankala bus stand area, said, “We are getting adequate supply of vegetables from the suppliers at the APMC. We have been shifted to a new place from the existing markets and the flow of customers continued throughout the day. So far, there is no shortage of vegetables.”

Guardian minister Satej Patil said, “We have asked the government agencies to gather information about the availability of cold storages in the district and if necessary we will acquire them. Vegetables can be stored in these cold storages and can be supplied to the customers as per requirement. This will help us in keeping the flow of vegetable supply in the market normal and put a check on price rise. We are also planning to make seating arrangements for farmers who are coming to the city to sell vegetables in Tapowan area. This will make their commute easy and people in that area will also get to buy fresh vegetables.”

Meanwhile, Deshmukh said that people are coming out of houses to buy vegetables and grocery as they fear these commodities will not be available to them due to lockdown.

“This was making the vegetable markets crowded. We have convinced the people that there will not be shortage of any essential commodity till the lockdown ends. To ensure that people get enough vegetables and grocery, we are ready to keep the markets open 24x7.”

Title: West Bengal: Probe sought into ‘lathicharge death’ in Howrah
Content:
Lal Swami

HOWRAH: Leaders of all political parties in Howrah have demanded probe into the death of a man who was allegedly killed after lathicharge at Sankrail on Wednesday. The victim was identified as Lal Swami, a resident of Rajgunj in Howrah’s Sankrail. His wife Annu alleged that her husband had stepped out of home to buy milk for their three kids.

“Around 7pm on Wednesday, cops resorted to lathicharge to disperse the crowds roaming on the road. My husband was hit with a police baton. He was taken to a nearby hospital where he was declared dead ,” said Annu.

Sankrail IC Madhusudhan Majumdar said, “He was ailing. We took action to send people back home, but there was no lathicharge.”

Title: Farm produce delivery at 67 PMC designated spots
Content:
The civic body has said the new system will start functioning in two days.

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has identified 67 locations across the city for delivery of vegetables during the ongoing lockdown.

A list of farmers’ groups has been drawn up to deliver vegetables at these places.

The civic body has said the new system will start functioning in two days. The civic body will upload the details of locations and farmers’ groups on its website for citizens.

Citizens are expected to register their demand for vegetables using the contact details of a farmers’ group attached to the nearest location for delivery.

Deputy commissioner Madhav Jagtap said, “The chart which will be available on the website, contains the location with the details of the ward where it is located, the name of a farmers’ group that will deliver the farm produce at that location and the contact details of the group. Any individual or housing society can register their demand with the farmers’ group.”

A proposal to introduce a system for doorstep delivery of vegetables was discussed in the last few days. The initiative is being executed by the PMC, the state agriculture department and the farmers’ groups.

A PMC official said most areas of the city are covered under the initiative. A ward-wise approach for delivery of vegetables will restrict citizens’ trips to Mahatma Phule Mandai and other places for vegetables.

The locations identified are familiar to the citizens of the area as most are places where the weekly farmer’s markets are hosted.

While deliveries are expected to take place at these locations, it will be up to the farmers’ groups and citizens to finalize how and where they will be picked up within the area. The farmers’ groups and residents can mutually decide the payments which can be processed online as per convenience or after the vegetables are delivered.

The PMC said it would not be responsible for the quality and prices of vegetables since the supply would come directly from farmers’ groups.

Title: Surat: Nine suspected patients of COVID-19 admitted in NCH
Content:
SMC officials said they were now getting suspected cases with no foreign travel history

SURAT: Two healthcare staffers of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC)-run SMIMER hospital and Mahavir Hospital and seven other people with suspected symptoms of COVID-19 were admitted in the isolation ward of New Civil Hospital (NCH) here on Thursday.

The healthcare staffers were a 24-year-old woman employee of SMIMER hospital and a 58-year-old male staffer of Mahavir Hospital.

A 65-year-old male from Variavi Bazaar in central zone, having travel history to Delhi; a 23-year-old male from Adajan, having travel history to Hyderabad; a 28-year-old male from Pandesara, with no travel history; a 54-year-old woman from Ghod Dod Road, with no travel history; a 60-year-old woman from Adajan, with travel history to Rajkot and Amreli; a 30-year-old woman from Bhatar, with travel history to Vadodara; and a 54-year-old woman from City Light, with travel history to Turkey, were among others to be admitted in the isolation ward of NCH.

Dr Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospitals), said, “Now, we are beginning to get suspected cases from people with no travel history to foreign countries too. Samples of all these new patients at NCH have been sent for laboratory tests. Their reports are expected to come soon.”

Meanwhile, SMC has decided to allow some malls and shops selling essential items to remain open for 24 hours in different locations of the city to avert crowding.

Municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani has chalked out a plan along with civic officials to ensure uninterrupted supplies to people after a meeting with retailers, mall owners and wholesellers on Thursday.

"This will help people to buy their groceries and other essential items with ease. There will be no long queues anywhere. We urge people to maintain social distancing and stay at home to protect themselves from COVID-19,” Pani said.

SMC officials said shops and malls will follow a system which will ensure that people maintain distance from each other. Also, local courier agencies have agreed to deliver vegetables from Agricultural Produce Market Committee (APMC) to residents in the city.

"From Thursday, we have allowed 180 vegetable vendors inside 216 housing societies in the city,” the municipal commissioner said.

Title: 24 cases registered in Bhopal for lockdown violation
Content:
Bhopal: City police on Thursday registered 24 cases at eight different city police stations, against people violating lockdown restrictions enforced in view of Covid-19 spread. In all, 53 cases have been registered since Sunday, March 22, after lockdown orders were issued by district collector.

The violators were booked under section 188, 269 and 270 of IPC along with section 51 of National Disaster Management Act. Kamla Nagar police booked two men, who were found loitering close to Upper Lake, near Van Vihar. Bajaria police registered two cases against two people loitering on roads near Habibia school and near Bhopal railway station without valid reason.

Habibganj police also registered two cases against two such people violating the lockdown order. Bairagarh police booked a hardware shop owner for opening his shop in lockdown. Similarly, Nishatpura police registered a case against a vendor for opening shop in Karond mandi . Berasia police booked a man for loitering near bus stand. Eintkheri police registered a case against a farmhouse owner for allegedly renting two rooms in which 30-35 labourer were residing in pathetic conditions.

DIG Irshad Wali said thanked people for supporting police by following lockdown restrictions. He appealed to people of the to follow social distancing for their own safety and asked them not to go out in crowded areas. He said that lockdown will be for long time, but it will save many lives. He asked people not to buy goods more than requirement and stay safe at home.

Box- Cops distribute food packets and masks to the needy

A group of daily wage labourers approached Awadhpuri police station and told the cops they didn’t have any food supply. Acting on information, CSP (Govindpura) Ankit Jaiswal and other policemen arranged for necessary food items and distributed them among the labourers. Similarly, a group of daily wage workers, who had come to city from Chhindwara for work, left for their native place on foot due to no work and scarcity of food stuff. Misrod police, however, arranged for their food. Many cops distributed food packets and masks to the needy in their respective jurisdiction.

Title: Cough, and your neighbours might tell on you
Content:
Coimbatore: Beware of stepping out with a cold or cough , your neighbour might just rat you out. Nearly 35% of calls that the newly-introduced 1077 helpline for Covid-19 related queries gets is from people who want to complain about their neighbours with either flu symptoms or a travel history not seeking medical help or flouting quarantine rules.

The team manning the helpline say they get at least 150 such calls a day. “The helpline is manned by three shifts, so that we are available 24x7. Each shift gets at least 50 calls from people who want to alert us about neighbours with either suspicious symptoms or travel history,” says a doctor manning the helpline. “They say their neighbor has a cold or cough, or just returned from abroad, but are not quarantining themselves. If someone has both a travel history and symptoms, they start panicking.”

A public health department official says most of such calls are from urban areas such as Peelamedu, Sowripalayam, Singanallur and Puliakulam. “Most of our callers are people who live in apartments. They get paranoid that their corridors, elevators and entryways are getting contaminated by neighbours who are not quarantining themselves. These areas have a lot of apartment clusters and the residents are well off and often travel across the country and abroad.”

The helpline handlers, however, welcome these complaint calls as while they have been able to trace international travellers, they have not been able to do so in the case of domestic travellers. “Almost 25% of these calls are genuine. Since we are now monitoring inter-state travellers with symptoms, these people are being helpful. And it is important that these people isolate or room quarantine themselves properly. We also stick the quarantine sticker and poster on their houses,” the official said.

Since the callers also provide contact numbers of suspected cases, it is easy for the helpline people to ascertain facts. If the person in question has a travel history and symptoms, the team will ensure checkup by a doctor from the nearest primary health centre. They will also arrange a 108 ambulance to take the suspect to ESI Hospital or government hospital, if required.

The helpline also gets many calls from people who want to either clarify their doubts on Covid-19 or get to know whether they should get tested if they were having some of the symptoms and what they could do to prevent getting further infected.

“We also get calls asking us how many more cases are reported in the district. Some call us to complain about lockdown related issues or conservancy workers who are out with symptoms. There are others who take up issues such as gas leak and water supply issues,” said another helpline team member.

He said they would also help with contact tracing of suspected cases and following up with people who are already under quarantine. “We will have a doctor and home guard visit the 20% who doesn’t respond to our calls.”

The helpline, which has two landlines and an android phone to make video calls to check on people who are already under quarantine, is expected to get two more landline phones this week.

Title: A week after testing COVID-19 positive, Idris Elba and wife Sabrina Dhowre are feeling okay
Content:
Hoping everyone is coping with this $@@!! Currently still quarantine.. Sab and I still feel ok so far with no chan… https://t.co/Vfh5V4uy0o — Idris Elba (@idriselba) 1585180310000

Actor Idris Elba , after a week of self-isolation post testing positive for the Coronavirus , took to social media on Thursday to give an update of his current condition.The 47-year-old star shared a post on his Twitter handle and wrote that he and his wife, Sabrina Dhowre , who too has tested positive after self-isolating with the actor, are still in quarantine."Hoping everyone is coping with this .. !!" he wrote alongside a picture of himself, wearing a beanie and a sweatshirt. "Currently still quarantine. Sab and I feel OK so far with no changes," he tweeted."Doctor told us that after quarantine we will be immune for a certain time since our antibodies fought this. At some point, we'd like to go home to London. Be safe," he concluded.Other celebrities that are currently battling with coronavirus are actor Aaron Tveit , television host Andy Cohen, Colton Underwood, actor Daniel Dae Kim, music producer Andrew Watt, actor Kristofer Hivju , and 'Oblivion' actor Olga Kurylenko Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson , who were earlier diagnosed with COVID-19, have been discharged from the hospital and are under quarantine.

Title: Habibganj station facelift halted
Content:
Revamp of Habibganj railway station may take another six months to get completed.

BHOPAL: Amid the coronavirus scare, the redevelopment work o the Habibganj station has been put on hold. Authorities said if the lockdown continues for next 15 days, the work will take an extra six months to get completed, as the construction company is not able to get raw material from outside the country for since January. Earlier, the construction company — Bansal Pathways Habibganj Private Ltd — was given a three-month extension of the deadline to complete redevelopment work.

The first deadline was December 31, 2019, but about 14% construction work was yet to be completed by that time. Railway officials had given the second deadline of March 31, 2020 which will be missed again.

Habibganj is the first railway station in the country to be redeveloped through public-private partnership mode under the station redevelopment programme of Indian Railways. IRSDC, a joint venture of IRCON and RLDA, is the nodal agency for undertaking development works at railway stations under the Ministry of Railways . The revenue realized from real estate development and commercial facilities at the station are being utilized for station redevelopment and maintenance.

Talking to TOI, joint GM of Indian Railway Station Development Corporation (IRSDC) Rajesh Mandloi said, “This is a critical situation work. Construction work has been affected severely as the company is not getting the required materials. Most of the material which is being used is to be imported from China, Singapore and such other countries which has been stopped since January due to the coronavirus scare” .

Mandloisaid, “I am not in a position to specify as to when te work will be completed. Work has been completely stopped due to the Cororna scare.”

Title: Pune: Medicines at your doorstep to stop people from wandering on roads
Content:
Policemen ramp up action, stop vehicles for investigation at various check-points

PUNE: Representatives of the pharmacists’ association on Thursday agreed to release a WhatsApp number for facilitating free door-step delivery of medicines to dissuade people from moving around with old prescriptions to justify their presence on the road.

Policemen enforcing the lock-down orders pointed out that vehicle users were showing them old medical prescriptions to be on the road.

Ambulances, water tankers, garbage trucks, government, army and goods vehicles were not stopped. People showing identity cards and their purpose were allowed to go.

Katraj resident Pramod Salunkhe showed a 2008 prescription at Adarsh Chowk in Kondhwa and argued with the police for stopping him. After he was let off, Salunkhe told TOI, “The police cannot question me about where I should purchase medicines from. It is my discretion.”

Kondhwa resident Saeed Mulla, carrying a 2017 prescription, told TOI at Jyoti Chowk checkpoint, “The prescription is old but the medicine is the same. I don’t feel it necessary to visit the doctor for getting a new prescription for purchasing the same medicine.”

The police, who stopped people at checkpoints at Dandekar bridge junction and Rajaram bridge on Sinhagad Road, near Alka Talkies in Deccan Gymkhana area and other places, wanted to know why nearby medical stores were not accessed and their necessity to travel to far-off places.

Joint commissioner of Pune police Ravindra Shisve told TOI, “A person in need of medicines can send his or her prescription along with the name and address to the WhatsApp number. The order so placed will be forwarded to the area distributor who will send a delivery boy to the person’s home for handing over the medicines free of charge.”

Shisve said the idea is to reduce unwanted rush at medical shops. “Senior citizens are not familiar with online apps for medicines. There is a lockdown and we are seeking a judicious balance between enforcement and facilitation. Fuel availability is being sorted out.”

The police higher-ups also met 15 representatives of online app-based food service and other online service providers such as Zomato, Swiggy and Big Basket about passes on conditions to delivery boys. “We need some time to study their movements and develop a technology for monitoring them before the passes are issued,” Shisve said.

These service providers must not fleece customers. They should sensitise their employees on maintaining cleanliness and hygiene and they should wear masks, use sanitisers and maintain social distance from their clients.

Shisve said, “We are working to ensure that each PMC ward has a vegetable outlet to reduce the rush at Market Yard in Gultekdi, Mandai and the PMC markets.”

Title: First Covid-19 positive case at Trichy; co-passengers being traced
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: A 24-year-old man who flew in from Dubai and was admitted to the isolation ward of Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital (MGMGH) here tested positive for Covid-19 on Thursday. Public health and preventive medicine department was in the process of identifying the co-passengers of the man, the first Covid-19 case recorded in Trichy.

The information was confirmed in a tweet from health minister Dr C Vijaya Baskar in the evening. “One new # COVID-19 positive case reported from Trichy. 24 Y Male, Dubai Return at # Trichy GH. Pt in isolation & stable,” it read.

MGMGH hospital administration said he was a native of Erode district and has been to Dubai looking for a job. A bachelor, he landed at Trichy airport in the early hours of March 22. The public health and preventive medicine department official said he had symptoms of cough and fever. Hence he was isolated at MGMGH the same day.

His swab sample was taken and sent to the viral research and diagnostic laboratory (VRDL) at government medical college hospital in Tiruvarur the next day. After testing his sample, the laboratory sought to repeat the test on March 24 and it was reconfirmed at the King institute of preventive medicine and research at Guindy in Chennai. He has been kept at the intensive care unit (ICU) of the isolation ward. Doctors said his health condition was stable.

As soon as the infection was diagnosed, public health and preventive medicine department swung into action to check the list of 85 passengers who were on board the flight with the man. “We have been checking the list of his co-passengers in order to reach out to them,” said an officer.

As on Thursday evening, five patients including him were being kept at the isolation ward. A day after shifting all the 600 patients from the six- storey superspecialty block at MGMGH, the hospital administration got fire and rescue service personnel in Trichy to conduct a mass cleaning of their campus. They sprayed disinfectants using their equipment.

Title: Here, they are on a mission to feed people under isolation
Content:
Members of the ‘Sruthi’ Kudumbashree unit at work in Parottukonam

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Sliced onions get sauteed to a golden brown tinge. Soon, Girija A steps in and a blend of powdered spices and masala is sprinkled over the softened onion slices. A few minutes later the dish takes the form of egg roast and a stack of spongy appam is readied for packing. This was the dinner for around 200 people in care homes who have been kept under isolation in the city on Thursday.

Girija and seven other women have been serving food to people brought to care homes from airport and other places since March 14. Their Kudumbasree unit ‘Sruthi’ based in Parottukonam is taking up such an initiative for the first time.

“We have collaborated with city corporation many times, but to provide food for people who are being observed for 14 days in camps is a special experience. Initially, many persons advised me not to take up this job, but I came forward and we take all precautions. Besides, these people need our support and care, they chose to remain under isolation to keep others safe,” said Girija, who has been running her team for 15 years.

She picks a menu as varied as possible. On Thursday, they served idli and sambar for breakfast followed by fried rice and chicken for lunch. On Tuesday, they served meals with fish curry and five other dishes. It is not just cooking, they have to make around 200 packets three times a day. They have barely slept for the past two weeks as breakfast needs to be readied by 6am.

“When we were told about giving food for these people, we understood that they came from different places and different backgrounds. It was not their fault that they have to stay in care homes for 14 days. We want to give them good food, because there is nothing else we can do for them. They stay away from their families in a care home and at least we can help them by giving them tasty food,” said Thankamani, another member of the team.

All of them are the sole breadwinners of their families. “These are difficult times for many people especially during this lockdown. We are grateful that we got a job to do and that too a noble one,” said Rose Mary. On the first few days, Girija and Rose Mary used to load the food packets in their Omni car and drove to each care home. Now, corporation vehicles arrive to pick the food. They also served food for the destitute, who were housed at Putharikandom on Wednesday.

From Friday onwards, they will also introduce snacks along with tea. “Till now we gave them biscuits in the evening. Now onwards we will introduce different kinds of snacks,” said Girija. Serving food three times a day along with tea for two weeks to nearly 200 people does take a toll on these women.

“We are used to working hard, if we become lazy in our work, those people would be hungry, so we would rather skip our sleep and prepare food for them,” said Thankamani.

On Thursday, the city corporation also launched the first community kitchen at Thycaud Model LP School.

Title: West Bengal: Supply hiccups remain, administration steps in
Content: KOLKATA: The state administration stepped in on Thursday to ease food supply chain bottlenecks but with consumers still making panic purchase, stocks flew off the retailers’ shelves, making replenishment difficult due to transportation difficulties during the lockdown. The demand-supply mismatch became all the more conspicuous in the evening when prices of all essential commodities spiked. In several places, shortage of milk and bread continued.The situation could improve on Friday with merchants in Posta assuring that they will open for business on Friday. Posta Merchants’ Association general secretary Biswanath Agarwal said all wholesale shops would function from Friday onwards to revive the supply chain.But the assurance of operations in subject to availability of workforce. Wholesalers said they cannot assort and package food items without labourers, most of whom have left for their homes in neighbouring states. Posta and Burrabazar provide essential edibles to not just entire Bengal but also the neighbouring states. Even a day’s closure can impact supply in these areas and result in price escalation.Retailers, on the other hand, said they were unable to ferry food items because mini-trucks were not available. Federation of Traders (West Bengal) general secretary Tarak Nath Trivedi said lack of small goods vehicles had impacted transportation from wholesale hubs to retail markets. “Most drivers are unwilling to operate fearing police coercion and arrest. Also, many drivers and helpers have left the city for their home because they don’t have a house here and no fixed place to eat,” said Trivedi.Though the CM warned of stern action against those who impeded movement of essential commodities, complaints continued to pour in. Food and civil supplies minister Jyotipriya Mallick said he had received a few complaints and spoken to police. “There are some issues like identity of vendors that we hope to resolve shortly. We received calls from traders in Koley market about trucks carrying essential materials from districts being stopped at Burdwan and Dankuni. We called up the district police officials and ensured that these vehicles reached Kolkata,” said DC (EB) Biswajit Ghosh.“In the absence of train services, vendors are hiring vehicles to bring vegetables to the markets, if they are forced to return, it would be very difficult to bring back the supplies again during the remaining lockdown period. Their loss will be mounting, factoring in the vehicle hiring charges,” said West Bengal Vendors’ Association president Kamal Dey The state government has put all kinds of food, e-grocers and their movement and transportation in the lockdown exempt list and has said these vendors need an authorisation from the local police or administration for unrestricted movement. Police had provided two phone numbers — 9432610446 and 9874903465 — for vendors to call up if they got stuck during their movement to and from wholesale and retail markets. Joint CP (headquarters) Subhankar Sinha Sarkar said they did not receive any calls from vendors throughout the day. Police said they were fast-tracking request for authorisation letters for those involved in medicine, groceries, vegetables, fruits or are animal products delivery.During the day, cops visited several markets. “We had sent our police teams across major markets and to grocery stores to collect reports. The flow of vegetables has increased and prices of vegetables have stabilized,” said an Enforcement Branch officer.(With inputs from Dwaipayan Ghosh)

Title: Panic buying leads to shortage of medicines in Hyderabad
Content:
HYDERABAD: Breakdown of the supply chain coupled with panic buying and hoarding of medicines has resulted in a shortage of a range of medicines right from the basic paracetamol and antibiotics to medicines for diabetes, heart disease and immunosuppressants.

Amid scarcity of these medicines, many of which might be as important for critically ill patients, as food for a normal person, experts suggest doorstep delivery of some medicines. “For instance, immunosuppressive medicine should be provided to all kidney transplant patients at the doorstep under the current circumstances. While people are not even able to buy the basic medicines, it is even more difficult to get supply of immunosuppressive medicines. For transplant patients not getting these medicines, the scenario would mean death. The government needs to provide these at the doorstep,” said Dr Bhagwan Reddy,

Meanwhile, patients are facing hardships to get basic medicines, especially when movement is restricted due to the total lockdown. “I have done rounds of all medical shops in the vicinity of my house to get medicines Eliquis and Oxramet. Like me, many heart disease patients were doing rounds of shops but were turned away and now with the lockdown, it is impossible to go to other areas to check for availability,” said a patient, Sunil Reddy .

Meanwhile drug suppliers say that although medicines are available in some parts of the city, distribution has not been possible to remote areas in the city, and even distributors are expecting a shortfall soon. “The available stock will last for 7-8 days and we are expecting a shortage after that if the distribution network between states remains cut off,” said Ramesh Chandragupta, president, Chemist and Druggist Association , Telangana.

Title: Bhilwara collector ‘takes over’ five private hospitals, ‘books’ 1,500 hotel rooms for Covid-19 care
Content: JAIPUR: After 19 persons tested positive for Covid-19 in Rajasthan’s Bhilwara, the collector has now “taken over” five private hospitals to scale up the number of isolation facilities for coronavirus patients in the district.As of now, 50 persons are in isolation — 35 in the district hospital and 15 in these five private hospitals.The district administration has also “booked” 1,500 rooms in hotels across the city. At the moment nearly 600 people are kept in these hotels, district collector Rajendra Bhatt , told TOI.The Covid situation in Bhilwara plunged into a crisis after the death of a 73-year-old person on Thursday and his son and granddaughter too testing positive for the infection. So far, 19 people in the district have been found infected with the virus. a huge team of 1,500 health workers and 2,400 police personnel undertaking the country’s largest screening exercise for the novel coronavirus after 13 cases of virus infection surfaced in Bhilwara, The magnitude of the task feels overwhelming. The textile town of 6 lakh people in Rajasthan is under curfew. Bhilwara’s borders have been sealed and the vast majority of the population is struggling for essential services.“The five private hospitals taken over by the district administration are — Shrimati Kesar Bai Soni Hospital, Shri Siddhi Vinayak Hospital, Ramsnehi Hospital, Keshav Porwal Hospital and Arihant Hospital of Bhilwara ,” Bhatt said.Bhatt also said that the number of isolation beds in the district hospital has been increased to 200.“We have taken control of the five hospitals along with their doctors, nurses, staff and equipment and the premises for Covid-19-related treatment after receiving orders from the district administration,” said a senior health department official, posted in Bhilwara.The order further said that the hospitals will be completely sanitized before they are handed over yo the owners.

Title: App for travel permission
Content:
Pune: The city police will launch a smartphone QR code-based application functioning round-the-clock to give permission to people to commute in emergency.

Joint commissioner of police Ravindra Shisve said, “People can download it and send travel requests to us.”

DCP (crime) Bachchan Singh said, “Some emergency requests will be automatically processed.” —Gitesh Shelke

Title: Lack of jobs, food haunts migrant labourers in Kolkata’s wholesale hub
Content:
Labourers plead for help at Burrabazar on Thursday

KOLKATA: Labourers, who form an important cog in the delivery chain of commodities, have gone jobless and don’t even have a place to eat as cops have shut down all eateries. The situation has turned so difficult for them that they are now starting to flee the city.

From assortment to packaging to delivery of items, this workforce — people from Bengal and the neighbouring states — drives the industry. These people work as drivers of goods vehicles, helpers and labourers in the wholesale hub during the day and sleep in their vehicles or on the pavement at night.

Many of them alleged that they were not finding any food to eat as cops have instructed small eateries to keep their places shut during the lockdown. A very big part of this workforce depends on small eateries that sell food at very low prices.

According to traders, many of them have started leaving the wholesale hubs to take refuge in the suburbs. “For the last two days, I have been roaming from one locality to another in search of food with police chasing us several times. We do not have homes here where we can purchase vegetables and prepare our food. ,” said Birju Paswan, who works as a helper in a goods vehicle, in Burrabazar.

On Thursday morning, TOI found close to 100 labourers almost on the verge of tears because they had run out of money and could not even go back home in Begusarai in Bihar. “We are wage labourers working in Posta, which are shut for the past two days. We have very little money left but no food is available. Cops are chasing us when we are going out to search for food. We just want to go back home now,” Pankaj Singh, one of the labourers.

Wholesalers said it was very difficult for them to keep the supply chain smooth in the absence of labourers. “We have to assort and package commodities like potatoes, onions, garlic, ginger, flour in sacks of 40-50kgs and we are talking about thousands of sacks here. It is not possible for us to do that. But we will try to do our best with the available workforce,” said Biswanath Agarwal, secretary of the Posta Merchants’ Association.

Owner of many eateries TOI spoke to said they had strict instructions from the police to not open their establishments.

Title: Kolkata: Panic booking, staff shortage hit LPG cylinder delivery
Content: KOLKATA: Several parts of the city saw long queues and empty cylinders stacked up outside LPG outlets on Wednesday and Thursday as the distributors were forced to ask customers to pick up their cylinders since they didn’t have enough manpower to deliver them to homes. The situation was further compounded by a surge in demand amidst the lockdown.Officials of LPG providers said there was no problem in supply but in almost all distribution centres, those who deliver them to doorsteps were not reporting to work owing to fear of contracting the disease.According to customers, trouble kicked off from the first day of lockdown as delivery persons found it difficult to reach the distribution centres. Entally resident Rajkumar Bhattacharya had to hire a rickshaw paying four times the actual fare to reach his LPG distributor at Padmapukur on Wednesday. “Usually, we make an online booking and the cylinder is delivered within 48 hours. When it wasn’t delivered within that time, I called up the distributor and he asked me to collect the cylinder as he did not have manpower,” said Bhattacharya.An elderly resident of New Town said he received a text message on Wednesday that read: “Due to Covid-19 epidemic spread worldwide, the LPG supply may be delayed due to non-availability of deliverymen. Kindly take self-delivery of filled LPG cylinder from our showroom/godown.”TOI on Thursday spotted 150 customers at a gas dealers’ showroom near Tobin Road where LPG cylinders were stacked up but the customers were asked to maintain 1m distance. “I have a full cylinder at home but the other cylinder I have is near empty. I came with the other cylinder to replace it with a new cylinder to ensure I don’t run out gas in case of emergency,” said Pranab Majumdar, a resident of Gopal Lal Thakur Road.LPG distributors, too, admitted to the manpower crunch. “There are around 80 distributors in Kolkata and most of them are working on a skeletal workforce. Few of them are arranging pickup and drop for the delivery people. But that is not enough. With complete restriction on trains and buses, the delivery personnel are not reporting to work and the dealers are forced to ask the customers to come and carry the cylinder home by themselves,” said Bijan Bihari Biswas, president of Indane Distributors’ Association (West Bengal).A senior official of Indian Oil Corporation (IOC) said the company was witnessing a 50% surge in demand. “ LPG demand has gone up from 2.3-2.4 lakh to 3.2 lakh per day,” said Arup Das, the deputy general manager of IOC. Das explained that those with double cylinder book for a new one when he or she starts using second cylinder for 3-4 days. In the changed scenario, most of the people are booking when even the first cylinder is still running.Bharat Gas Distributor Association state president Sukomal Sen agreed with Das. “There is a spurt in booking but there is no crisis in supply. We are facing problems of delivery boys as well,” he added.According to Das, to meet the rising demand for LPG, IOC has taken all steps to increase production by optimising operations and improving LPG yield in LPG producing units like FCC/Index.On Wednesday, a TMC-affiliated truck drivers association at the Budge Budge unit had refused to ply, leading to a temporary gap in supply. But state food minister Jyotipriya Mullick intervened and brought the situation under control and the supply resumed. “I asked told the agitating drivers that they cannot cut the supply line at any cost. The supply was resumed shortly after that,” Mullick told TOI.(With inputs from Udit Prasanna Mukherjee, Rohit Khanna, Krishnendu Bandyopadhyay and Subhojyoti Kanjilal)

Title: Mobile vegetable shops a boon for villages in districts
Content:
Trichy: M Mohamed Saleem, 46, who has been selling vegetables at the weekly markets in Trichy, has converted his mini truck into a mobile vegetable shop to cater to the needs of villages around Trichy and Pudukottai .

He says people in the city can take their motorcycles to the neighbourhoods to purchase vegetables from markets. But for many villagers, cities have become inaccessible in the absence of public transport.

Mohamed along with his wife purchases vegetables from Gandhi market and sell them in a few villages on the outskirts.

Mohamed is not alone in the business, there are many in the area who are running such mobile vegetable shops. “Villages do not have access to markets now,” said M Rajesh from Mullupatti near Avur. Such mobile vegetables shops are of good help, he said.

S Ramalingam, 45, owner of another mobile vegetable shop, said that they have been spreading awareness on Covid-19. “We will try to keep the price low, but the state government must ensure that supply of vegetables to markets is not affected, which may lead to price hike,” he said.

“Many villages are hesitant to venture out of their house fearing police action. Such mobile shops, in a way have reduced the number of people outdoors,” said T Ramakishanan from Thiruverumbur .

Title: St Joseph’s College supplies sanitizers to dist authorities
Content: Trichy: The district administration is ready to encourage institutions that come forward to prepare hand sanitizers to meet the increasing demand in the wake of the spread of Covid-19, said Trichy district collector S Sivarasu on Thursday.St Joseph’s College Trichy ( SJC ) was the first institution in the city to start in-house preparation of alcohol-based hand sanitizer with natural Aloe Vera to meet its campus needs.The escalating cost of hand-sanitizers has prompted the college to engage its chemistry department to prepare the solution with the available raw materials. It had also offered the district administration to make hand sanitizers if it can provide them the raw materials.On Wednesday, the college supplied about 65 litres of hand sanitizers in 300 bottles to the district administration. “We approached the district administration while extending our help towards preparing hand sanitizer for which the collector readily agreed. He also supplied 40 litres of ethanol, which is the primary raw material for making alcohol-based hand sanitiser,” said the principal.The collector said that the hand sanitisers received from SJC will be supplied to the health department officials. “Though there is no immediate need for hand sanitizers, we are stocking it for future use. We also appreciate other institutions as well, if they come forward to extend their support in preparing hand sanitizers,” he said.However, he insisted that hand sanitizers need not be used by general public on a regular basis and washing hands with soap is enough to keep them safe.

Title: These septuagenarians rise to the occasion, serve society
Content:
Coimbatore: Age-related health problems haven’t deterred 75-year-old Jayalakshmi and 77-year-old Rukmani from doing their bit to help the society handle Covid-19 scare. Over the past one week, the two septuagenarians from Karunya Nagar have stitched and distributed more than 200 cloth masks free of cost to healthcare workers in the area, braving joint pain and long-sightedness.

It all began around 10 days ago when the coordinators and managers of NGO SEESHA were discussing how they could provide their field volunteers with protective masks, since there was a virus scare. The NGO has around 24 volunteers, who have split into two teams to create awareness on hand washing techniques, sanitation and hygiene, garbage and health waste disposal in villages in and around Karunya Nagar.

Dr Samuel Thomas, one of the NGO’s coordinators, said, “We were discussing shortage of masks in the market and the difficulties involved in travelling all the way to Coimbatore city, which is 26km away, to just buy them. That was when Jayalakshmi, an inmate in our old age home said she could stitch the masks in their free time.”

Jayalakshmi, who has been an inmate of the home for the past six years, said she had been following the coronavirus situation on television for the past one month. “I picked up one of the plastic masks and surgical masks and tried to replicate them with three layers. Once I got the hang of it, I began stitching. I stitch for around five and half hours a day.” Jayalakshmi then trained another inmate, Rukmani, to stitch the masks.

The NGO, meanwhile, encouraged the two by buying them 200 metres of cotton cloth. “In the past one week, these two women haven’t complained of joint and back pain that they usually develop when they sit at a place for too long. Lack of adequate eye sight too hasn’t been a deterrent for them to stitch 200 three ply face masks, which we have distributed to our field volunteers, healthcare staff including doctors and nurses, forest department staff, and police, among others,” Dr Thomas said.

When TOI asked Jayalakshmi about the physical strains involved in the job, she said with a smile, “The fact that I am helping the community during this crisis takes away all my pains.”

The two are assisted by two tailoring teachers. They also get help from other inmates of the old age home who cut clothes, attach ropes to the masks, fold them and hot press them neatly to disinfect them.

Title: Telangana Lockdown: Cyber criminals have free run in Covid-19 lockdown
Content: HYDERABAD: India is under lockdown and the entire world is observing social distancing to arrest the spread of coronavirus . Save personnel from emergency services, none is permitted on the roads. With most people confined to their homes and probably hooked on to the Internet, cyber fraudsters are having a field day.On March 24, a 28-year-old Army personnnel, I Arun Kumar from Golconda, lodged a complaint with cyber crime police alleging that he was duped of over Rs 70,000 by a fraudster on an online classifieds platform.He claimed he saw an advertisement on e-classifides portal OLX about sale of a Mahindra Scorpio vehicle for Rs 1.9 lakh. Arun contacted the person who posted the advertisement and the latter introduced himself as Ajay Yadav, an IAF officer from Secunderabad. The army man made a deal with the fraudster to buy the Scorpio for Rs 1.7 lakh.On March 23, the fraudster sent vehicle documents along with transport receipt and asked Arun to transfer Rs 3,150 as initial payment towards service charges into his Paytm account. After transferring the amount, Arun received a phone call from a man claiming to be the delivery executive of the SUV. The delivery executive made Arun transfer Rs 69,000 into bank account of the accused to deliver the vehicle. As the vehicle did not reach his door despite paying the promised amount in advance, Arun realised that he was duped and lodged a police complaint.Similary, 32 year old private employee Ravi from Cherlapally lost Rs 1.1 lakh to cyber fraudsters on March 23. The culprits called Ravi, posing as Paytm Bank employee, and asked him to install ‘QuickSupport’ app and share the reference code. Subsequently, the fraudster made him do a Paytm transaction using SBI debit card and using those details obtained through remote access app, the accused siphoned off Rs 1.1 lakh from Ravi’s bank account.A 24-year-old doctor from Tolichowki approached police, claiming unidentified fraudsters, whom she met on Instagram, had duped her of Rs 80,000 by making her invest in a ponzi scheme . Likewise, a housewife from Jubilee Hills, S Laxmi, lost Rs 1.24 lakh, while a sales executive from Patherghatti, Obaid, reported that he was duped of Rs 75,000 by fraudsters posing as Paytm and Kotak Mahindra executives.Cyber crime cops of the three police commissionerates, on an average, recieve 90 to 100 complaints everyday. After the lockdown, they have been receiving about 30 complaints, including oral complaints pertaining to defamation in the name of coronavirus, from each commissionerate.“We have received some complaints claiming wrong information was being circulated on platforms like Facebook or WhatsApp about the complainant and their family members testing positive for Covid-19. We are ensuring that such posts and messages are taken down,” Rachakonda assistant commissioner of police (ACP), cyber crime, S Harinath said.

Title: Some fear cop action on streets, few try tricks too
Content:
Pune: Flour mill owner Sagar Karanjavane has kept his unit in Bavdhan closed fearing police action in the time of Covid-19.

“The man working in my mill was on Wednesday coming from Warje, when he was beaten up by some policemen. I will request police to issue passes for the flour mills,” he said.

The police said they were only stopping people loitering on the roads without any purpose.

A grocer on Paud Road accused the police of being harsh with his men. “The stock at the shop emptied because of panic buying on Wednesday night. My men were going to the market on Thursday, when the police beat up one of them,” he said.

A police officer at the Chandni Chowk checkpoint said some people did not understand the risk involved in moving now. He said, “We urge people to stay indoors. We take stern steps only when they do not agree to do so.”

Another officer said, “We stopped a man driving towards Deccan with his son. He said he was taking his son to a doctor. But he drove down the other side within a few minutes.”

Title: Ex-Cong corporator shot dead in Jabalpur
Content:
Jabalpur: A former Congress corporator was shot dead amid the coronavirus lockdown in Jabalpur city on Wednesday afternoon. Three bullets were pumped into the body of former corporator Dharmendra Sonkar.

The accused also fired bullets at his friend, identified as Ankit Gotiya, and he is admitted at a hospital and is undergoing treatment.

The incident took place at Bhantalaiya area under Hanuman Taal police station. It is suspected that enmity over an illegal gambling den led to the incident. Cops have arrested the accused, identified as Monu alias Reva Sonkar.

Additional SP Sanjeev Uike said, “Deceased Dharmendra Sonkar was sitting outside his house in Bhantalaiya area of the city and was talking with few people, when accused Monu reached the spot and opened fired. He fired at least 4 bullets targeting Dharmendra. His friend Ankit, who was also present there, tried to intervene, but the accused fired two bullets at him too”.

“Both were rushed to a nearby hospital where Dharmendra died during treatment, while Ankit is in a serious condition”, Uike added.

Sources said that the entire incident has been recorded on CCTV cameras fitted at the spot and the accused has also been arrested. Police said Monu is a habitual offender and is an accused in two other murder cases. There was a dispute related to the running of an illegal gambling den that has led to the incident.

Investigations are underway and additional forces have been deployed in the area to maintain the law and order situation, said sources.

Title: When things are closed but hearts are open: The other side of Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: Security guards, garbage collectors, domestic helps and street hawkers are among the people still working — with little support from those who have hunkered down against the novel coronavirus. However, some good Samaritans have emerged to take care of their needs.Some residents of south Delhi’s Chittaranjan Park offered meals to the security guards, while some in Aya Nagar bought flour and other essentials for the workless daily-wage earners in their area. Chitra Mukherjee of Abarjan Samiti in B Block, Chittaranjan Park, said, “We have to be considerate of the needs of people who continue to work risking their health.”Mukherjee’s group is also helping three garbage collectors who arrive every day despite the threat to their lives. There’s no place for them to have their meals because all shops are closed. “We have made a list of people who will give them breakfast and lunch in turn,” she said. “We have also spoken to other RWAs to start similar measures.”Sanjay Gupta, director of NGO Chetna, said members cannot move around to assist street children, so they have adopted an innovative way to keep in touch with them. “We observed that at least one of every five children had a mobile phone. We send messages or videos on TikTok and keep them abreast of the situation. Before the lockdown, we had distributed masks among them,” said Gupta.Gupta added that this effort to keep in touch was even more important for children living at the railway stations and near drains, where the living conditions were worse. Many of them don’t have families so monitoring them was vital to their welfare.Besides such groups, there are also individuals who are selflessly easing the pain of economic hardship of the impoverished. Ashok Randhawa , president of South Asian Forum for People Against Terror, said he had provided food to around 700 homeless people till Wednesday. “These are the people most vulnerable to catching the viral infection because they live in the open,” said Randhawa. “Some of them were fed by the local shops, but now with everything shut down these people weren’t getting food.”Randhawa and his son cook food in the morning and go to the Sai Baba temple on Lodhi Road and to Sarojini Nagar to feed the poor. “We wore masks and gloves and asked the people who gathered to stand at a distance from each other,” he added.Ved Pal Lohia of Aya Nagar too bought flour and other essential food stuff for the labourers in the locality who have been unable to return to their villages because there is no transport available. He said that he had also spread word in his neighbourhood about the initiative so more people could join the effort to help the daily-wage workers.

Title: Telangana bar council seeks Rs 10,000 for poor lawyers
Content:
Chalakani Venkat Yadav, member of the Telangana bar council

HYDERABAD: The legal fraternity is feeling the heat of coronavirus. Worried over the plight of junior lawyers and with courts not functioning, Telangana bar council has written letters to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to extend Rs 10,000 to each economically backward advocate to sustain his or her family.

“Continuous lockdown of trial courts and the high court will push 5,000 lawyers with less than ten years of experience towards a terrible situation. There are 33,500 lawyers registered with the state bar council and our study shows that 10,000 of them are poor. Of this, 5,000 are in dire straits who need immediate help from the state government during the lockdown period,” said Chalakani Venkat Yadav, member of the bar council and also the government’s welfare counsel in the high court.

He told newsmen on Thursday that since the government had already created a welfare fund, it could extend Rs 10,000 to each poor advocate.

Advocates going to attend court hearings in urgent matters should be allowed to reach courts without hassles, he said.

Title: NGO offers a plateful of hope to the hungry
Content:
Erode: Members of Atchayam Trust have been distributing free food to the destitutes in the city for the last two days.

They are preparing 500 packets each of sambar rice and curd rice a day, NGO founder Navin Kumar told TOI. “We rented vessels and bought grocery out of our own pockets. Before launching the drive, we obtained permission from Erode collector C Kathiravan . The collector issued identity cards for the members involved.”

Office bearers of the trust V Balaji, Balamurugan, Niresh, S Balaji, Hariharan and others carry the food in a van. “We go around the city and give the food packets to homeless people including alms seekers, ragpickers and people with learning disabilities,” Kumar said. “We will continue food distribution until April 14.”

The NGO members are also distributing food at Kumarapalayam and Pallipalayam in Namakkal district.

Title: Daily wagers in slums get a helping hand from police in Pune
Content:
The Dattawadi police explain to casual workers the need to stay put in their homes

PUNE: Janata Vasahat resident Yankappa Kumbhar (27) has not gone out to work in the past five days.

“I am worried. I used to earn Rs600-Rs700 daily by working as a crane operator, but have not earned a single paisa in the past few days. I am not sure how I am going to survive,” he said.

“We are using our groceries sparingly. I have saved money but that is not enough to sustain us for long,” said Kumbhar, a slum dweller.

Another resident, Ganesh Kawathe (40), said he works as ‘hamal’ (porter) at Market Yard. “I used to earn Rs350 per day but haven’t gone out to work for the last five days,” said Kawathe who lives in a small hutment with a family of five.

The Dattawadi police have come to the aid of casual workers in slums and is carrying out an extensive drive to convince them about the need to stay put in their homes.

Senior inspector Devidas Gheware of Dattawadi police said “Majority of the residents in the slum pockets of Janata Vasahat, Panmala, Ambil Odha-Dandekar bridge and Parvati Darshan are casual or daily wage workers. We called a meeting of ration, grocery and pharmacy shops on Wednesday and urged them to provide necessary goods and medicines to local residents on credit. After our request, the shop owners agreed to provide goods and medicines to the locals on credit. The local residents can pay the shop owners once they resume work,” he said.

Police have requested the shop owners to keep a record of the provisions on credit in detail and not fudge the records. “We have also warned them of stern action if they black market the grains or other essential commodities,” he said.

In last four days, the Dattawadi police have conducted awareness programmes for slum dwellers and asked them to be at home. Police have also urged the slum dwellers to observe social distancing and mark spaces outside the grocery shops and medicine shops. “Many women from the slum pockets work as maids or as hospital staffers and it is necessary for them to maintain a proper hygiene. We have arranged a counselling session for them,” he said.

Title: Bhopal: Home delivery off track due to flood of orders
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

BHOPAL: Lack of home delivery services due to the lockdown is forcing citizens to venture out of their homes to purchase essentials like groceries, milk, bathroom supplies and medicines.

While some local general stores and pharmacists have gone out of their way to ensure home delivery to customers, bigger online superstores, otherwise known for their home delivery services, have stopped the service even when the stores are open, forcing customers to go down to the store to buy necessary items.

The district administration has released a list of store managers for people to contact for home delivery, but most numbers are switched off.

Manoj Kumar, manager at a superstore in Katara Hills said, “We don’t have staff, so we are not providing home delivery services, but the store is open.”

When TOI tried to contact the numbers of store managers mentioned in the list, most of them were switched off, while others went unanswered, despite several attempts.

Online superstores have also stated displaying a message on their apps that they are non-operational due to restrictions imposed by local authorities and that they are working to resume their services.

District collector Tarun Pithode told TOI that the authorities are trying to get the functional numbers so that home delivery of groceries etc can start soon. He said people were still in panic mode, which is making things even more difficult.

“Superstores were flooded with orders because of which they couldn’t meet the demands. There was also the issue that some drivers were stopped by the police because of which they stopped the service. We are in touch with the online superstores to encourage them to resume services. We have also asked them to provide functional numbers so that people can contact them. Everything will be smoothed out in a day or two,” said Pithode.

Meanwhile, local stores and pharmacies have started delivering groceries, bathroom supplies and medicines to customers at their doorstep.

Vijay Shah, owner of a general store in Awadhpuri , said, “We have got passes for delivery staff so that people may not have to leave their homes at such a time. They have also been asked to maintain distance while delivering items and keep hands clean.”

Gurinder Malhotra, co-owner of a medical store, has started home delivery of medicines without any extra charges.

“In such a time of panic due to COVID-19, we have decided to deliver the medicines at the doorstep of the customers. We realise that there are senior citizens, diabetic patients and ill children who cannot do without their prescriptions, and are also afraid to leave their homes. This is a time to serve your people,” he said.

Title: City residents seek more elbow room in veggie markets
Content:
Trichy: Unlike the first day of curfew, several shops selling essential commodities like vegetables have told their customers to maintain social distance by drawing marks in front of their outlets. Since many prefer to go to street vegetable vendors, residents urged officials to ensure enough space in the markets to avoid crowding.

“We are ready to follow the Covid-19 protocol to maintain social distance. But in some shops, it is difficult to maintain the distance as the space available for customers to walk is very small that it would be very difficult to cross each other without rubbing shoulders”, S Chithra, a resident of Palayam Bazaar said.

Instead of entering the market area, it would be better to purchase from platform vendors as the risk would be very minimal, said K Parthiban of ESP Street. “Due to lack of infrastructure in the main city markets, consumers by and large prefer street vendors and a minimum number of consumers are seen buying vegetable in the markets”, he added.

The district administration has already closed down all Uzhavar Santhais, where a considerable number of people purchase their commodities. So all are forced to go to the vegetable markets which have no proper space to move around without touching others, said P Kathaperumal, a resident of Woraiyur .

When contacted, officials from agriculture marketing department said the situation went out of control on Monday and Tuesday morning. Hence, to avoid close contact, the district administration had ordered their

Title: 164 people arrested in Salem district
Content:
Salem: The Salem district police on Thursday arrested 164 people for violating norms of the 21-day curfew.

Despite imposition of section 144 of CrPC, residents and motorists were seen hitting the roads.

People thronging markets did not follow the social distancing while buying vegetables and groceries. One of the horticulture officials in the Hasthampatty Uzavar Shandy told TOI that the public were not standing in the specified circles. “They did not heed to us when we insisted them to follow the distance,” he said.

Similarly, many motorists especially bikers, went for jolly rides on deserted city roads and national highways. Salem city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar said bikers especially youths were not adhering to norms.

“We will act against repeat offenders severely,” he said.

However, some youths caught by the police were made to do 200 sit-ups.

On Wednesday night, the Dharmapuri district police resorted to lathi-charge at motorists when they assembled at a petrol bunk in large numbers. District SP P Rajan said he has directed all the petrol bunks to close in the district to control vehicle movements. “We have asked one petrol bunk to be kept opened in the town,” he said, added that, fuel will not be given if they failed to show identity cards.

Police registered 163 cases in the west zone on Thursday. “280 people were arrested, and 58 vehicles seized in the zone,” he said.

Of them, 164 were arrested in Salem district, 70 in Namakkal district and 25 in Krishnagiri district.

“The Dharmapuri district police arrested 18 people while Erode district arrested three,” the officer added.

Cases against them have been registered under sections188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) of the IPC.

Title: Indore’s first Covid-19 death takes state toll to two
Content: INDORE/BHOPAL: Indore’s first Covid-19 death was recorded on Thursday when a 65-year-old man succumbed to the infection, hours before he tested positive for the virus. The Madhya Pradesh death toll is now two, with a 65-year-old woman from Ujjain dying on Wednesday. Neither of them has a travel history.Six more patients tested positive for Coronavirus in the state on Thursday, four of them from Indore, including the one who died. Ujjain and Shivpuri had one patient each.Indore seems to be turning out to MP’s Covid-19 hotspot with 13 cases detected in just two days – accounting for half of the state’s 26 cases.Worryingly, on the same day, three Covid-19 suspects died in Indore and Ujjain. One of them later tested negative for Covid-19. The reports of the other two are awaited.Thursday’s victim, a resident of Ranipura area, was admitted to MY Hospital , where he died in the afternoon. His test reports came positive for Covid-19 in the evening, CMHO Pravin Jadia said.“This is the first death of a coronavirus patient in Indore. However, the man had a history of other co-morbid diseases,” he said, adding that the health department will send a team to his house. “His family will be isolated and their samples collected for tests,” the CMHO said.The area will also be fumigated and isolated as part of the newly introduced containment plan by the district administration. The district collector ordered isolation of 3km area around the house of people who have tested positive, and earmarked buffer zones of 5km radius.Earlier in the day, a 35-year-old Indorean, who was admitted to MY Hospital with cough and cold a few days ago, died. He tested negative for Covid-19.Two coronavirus suspects in Ujjain also died during the day. One was admitted to a hospital in Indore, and the other in Ujjain.One of them, a 60-year-old resident of Mohammadpura Bakhal area, was admitted to Madhav Nagar Hospital in Ujjain with cough and fever on Wednesday night and died on Thursday morning. Samples of his mucous and blood have been sent for tests.The other victim, a 47-year-old, worked in a soya factory and was referred to MRTB Hospital in Indore from Ujjain Civil Hospital on March 25. He died in the wee hours of Thursday.“Samples of his blood and mucus were collected for Covid-19 tests. The report is awaited,” said MGMMC PRO Dr Rahul Rokade. “When we asked him, he said he had not travelled abroad, nor to any other city before developing the symptoms,” Rokade said, adding that he had breathlessness, fever and cough. “He also didn't have any co-morbid conditions (like hypertension or asthma),” said Rokade.The patient was initially treated with antibiotics and other drugs but his condition kept deteriorating rapidly. He was put on ventilator but succumbed to the infection, said Rokade.

Title: Qazi booked for violation
Content: Bhopal: Talaiya police on Thursday registered a case against Imam, Moajjij and 27-28 others for allegedly offering Namaz at a Mosque in the area and violating government order.District collector Bhopal has issued prohibitory orders in view of Covid-19 and restricted gathering at religious establishments to avoid spread of coronavirus . Despite restrictions Imam and Moajjij of Zainab mosque in Islampura offered Namaz at the Mosque along with 27-28 others on Thursday. The violators have been booked under section 188, 269 and 270 of IPC. Police appealed people to follow lockdown restrictions and stop the spread of coronavirus. TNN

Title: Requirements & destination display must on vehicles
Content:
Pune: Vehicles carrying essential services must display prominently a list stating their goods and their destination to make it easier for the police authorities, district collector Naval Kishore Ram said on Thursday.

There is no room for complacency now and the government’s lockdown order has to be strictly followed, he added.

“While 90% of the population has responded well to the lockdown order, reducing traffic density and movement on the roads, the remaining are on the roads in the morning and evening. The police are taking action, but it is imperative for citizens to follow the order or face action,” he said.

He turned down a demand from IT companies to open shops where they can rent or buy laptops. There will be enough flow of vegetables, fruits, medical and other essentials and people should not panic, he added.

Diesel should be given for those ferrying essential goods, he said.

Title: Miles to go before they sleep
Content:
Ghaziabad: A group of migrant workers walk to their villages amid the nationwide complete lockdown, on the NH2... Read More

After the Prime Minister announced the 21-day lockdown on Tuesday evening, Raj Kumar’s employer in Gurugram told him to get back home and stay there. But home was 1,050km away in Bihar’s Chapra. With just Rs 1,000 in hand, and not sure when his next pay would come, staying on in Gurugram made no sense to him.

With all public transport off the roads because of the lockdown, Raj Kumar and his family — his wife, their three-month-old toddler and his 58-year-old mother — set out on foot early on Wednesday, joining a stream of thousands of workers heading out of the city, all on foot, in hope of finding a way to reach home. By evening, many from Haryana had reached UP, having walked more than 50km, across Delhi. Some local residents offered packets of food along the way. They were thankful for that, but kept walking, hoping someone, somewhere would offer a ride.

This exodus of a huge work force that finds employment in the gigantic commercial sector of Delhi-NCR, which includes one of India’s largest automobile hubs in Manesar, began earlier this week and turned into a steady, endless flow down the presently car-free expressways that go deep into Haryana and UP after it became clear that the lockdown wouldn’t end on March 31. The people leaving are factory workers, construction labourers and daily wagers, whose earnings have dried up because of the total shutdown of the commercial sector.

The migration out of Delhi-NCR, which has more than 60 cases of people testing positive for the novel coronavirus infection, will also be of concern for governments because of the bridge it builds between urban and rural India, which is what the lockdown aims to stop.

“How do I pay my room rent if I don’t have any money? I had no option but to head back home. I’ll return only when things get back to normal and my employer gives me a call,” Raj said on Wednesday evening. He and his family had reached Ghaziabad by then. But Chapra was still hundreds of kilometres away.

Manoj Thakur (26), who worked with a factory in Vaishali, had reached Dadri after 10 hours of walking from the empty Anand Vihar bus terminal. “I stay in a rented room near my factory in Vaishali. I started walking around 3pm and reached Dadri at 1am. I have got food, but there is no water. None of the shops are open on the highway,” he said. Manoj still had to travel 160km to reach home in Etah district.
