Manorama (30), also from Etah, had her 11-year-old daughter for company. “People like me need daily wage to survive. We don’t have enough savings to stay at a rented home for a month. Those who take decisions should have thought about us before shutting down public transport overnight,” she said. Manorama expected to reach home earliest by Friday. She had no idea where she would spend the night with her daughter.

It is the suddenness of the lockdown decision and the uncertainty about wages that have rendered the workers helpless. Many workers said though their employers had given them some cash, it wasn’t enough to sustain them for 21 days.

“I was given only Rs 1,000 before being told to stay at home. How can we stay here or pay our room rent with this money, at a time when essentials are overpriced?” asked Omkar. He is among six workers from Agra sent on long leave by a prominent sweet shop in Noida.

For Mohan Singh, the hope of earning a livelihood in a city had shattered too soon. He had come to Manesar just 10 days ago. “I have no money left. My family has been without proper food for three days now,” said Mohan, who is from Badaun. With his family of 10, Mohan has now started walking towards his home, 266km away.

It was more difficult for Om Prakash Kushwaha, who was carrying his seven-month-old daughter in his arms. Om Prakash was headed for Ajmer, which might take almost a week if he doesn’t get a transport on the way.

On Thursday morning, the Delhi-Jaipur highway had many such groups of people walking home — some with luggage on their heads, others with kids ticked between their arms. Most of them had a question for the government: “Why didn’t they inform us about the lockdown in advance? We wouldn’t have to walk like this,” said Patap Gupta, who was on his way to Amethi from Faridabad — a distance of 550km.

Meanwhile, a group of activists distributed packaged food, bananas and biscuits among a few labourers on the Yamuna Expressway in Greater Noida. Noida police said the only way they could help the labourers was by allowing them to pass. Rajesh Kumar Singh, DCP (zone 3), said, “We are not stopping them, but keeping a watch on their movement. We are helpless as commercial vehicles are not supposed to be on the road.”

Late on Thursday, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath announced special arrangements for the migrant workers, directing police to arrange food, water and security for them. The CM has also requested Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar to take necessary measures to ensure the safety of those coming from Gurgaon and Faridabad. “Those who are going to Bihar will also be taken care of, the administration will ensure required health measures for them along with food and water,” said a UP government statement.

Title: Man tests positive for Covid-19, fourth case with no foreign travel history
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 40-year-old critically-ill man from Sahakarnagar, a known patient of chronic liver disease, tested positive for the Covid-19 infection on Thursday.

With this, four cases have been found in the city within a week where the source of infection is not linked to international travel or a traceable contact to infected person.

The man was admitted to a private hospital after he complained of breathlessness. His throat swab sample when sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) was found positive for Covid19, pushing Pune’s positive case tally to 32 so far.

Of the total Pune cases, the health condition of 20 is being monitored by Pune Municipal Corporation health officials. Fifteen of them are currently undergoing treatment at designated government and private isolation hospitals and five of them have been discharged after successful recovery. Another 12 infected persons are undergoing treatment at identified facilities in Pimpri Chinchwad.

“As per preliminary reports, the man has not travelled abroad recently nor has he come in close contact with infected persons or their known close contacts. We are investigating the case. The man’s close contacts are being traced,” a civic health official said.

An official from the private hospital where the man is undergoing treatment said, “His condition is critical. He is put on ventilator support in the hospital’s isolation ICU.”

A state health official said, “Of the four Covid-19 patients with no apparent history of foreign travel, condition of three is critical and they are on the ventilator support.”

In Mumbai, a 53-year-old physician and two of his family members have tested positive for Covid-19. The trio are undergoing treatment at a private hospital and are said to be stable.

Mumbai civic body officials didn’t officially confirm the case, but told TOI that apart from practising in his own clinic, he also consulted in two hospitals nearby. The civic body has started an elaborate contact tracing exercise.

His 43-year-old wife and 20-year-old daughter also tested positive. His son’s report was negative.

(With inputs from Richa Pinto & Sumitra Deb Roy)

Title: Fuel for vehicles on essential services duty only in Pune: Administration
Content:
An attempt to curb movement of people under Section 144

PUNE: Pumps would only refuel vehicles involved in providing essential services in the district for now.

The district administration iterated on Thursday that petrol and diesel would be dispensed only to vehicles providing essential services in Pune even after a flurry of notifications issued by the Union and state governments on making essential services available to all citizens.

An official from the district administration on Thursday clarified that the district authorities could enforce certain restrictions to hinder the movement of people under Section 144 imposed in the district. “The decision to restrict the petrol and diesel supply to all, except essential service providers, has been taken to restrict unnecessary movement of people to curb the spread of Covid-19,” the official said.

He added that all those involved in providing essential services, including vehicles for transport of agriculture commodities and equipment, as well as other essential services, would be refilled with petrol and diesel if they provided proof of being involved in providing such services.

The revised lockdown orders issued by the state government on Wednesday had said steps should be taken to ensure there was no disruption in the supply of essential commodities to citizens. Also, a recent order released by the ministry of petroleum and natural gas had said in view of the recent outbreak of Covid-19, state governments had imposed restrictions on various activities, including restrictions on movement of vehicles and individuals.

It stated, “In all states/UTs, following activities must be permitted without any hindrance: Operation of petrol pump/retail outlets, LPG and oil agencies, including their back-end activities.”

Title: Rural Visakha more aware of lockdown
Content:
Village heads have requested residents not to step outside the house if it’s not necessary

Visakhapatnam: People in rural areas are showing more awareness than those in cities who seem apathetic about maintaining social distance and observing lockdown.

In Visakhapatnam, police are still struggling to enforce lockdown as people are coming out in large numbers on the pretext of buying essentials. Besides, not only are crowding a common sight outside shops, people continue to ride pillion despite orders.

However, the picture in the rural areas is quite the opposite. People have blocked village borders with farm equipments and tractor tyres. Village heads have requested residents not to step outside the house if it’s not necessary.

People of Gottipalli village in Anandapuram mandal have decided not to allow anyone into their village. Similarly, people in Yarada village, close to the industrial area in Vizag, Simhadri NTPC colony, Parawada, Pendurthi, Kapulupada, Bheemili rural areas, Padmanabham, Rajayyapeta, Pedateenarla villages in Nakkapalli and few villages in Atchyutapuram have taken strict measures to break the chain of transmission.

“We have been requesting all the village elders to take precautions through our local police. City people should also cooperation just like those in villages,” rural SP Babujee Attada said.

People in Visakha agency have imposed restrictions as well by not allowing other anyone to enter their village.

Title: 335 beds set up in Surat hospitals in record time
Content:
One of the wards for treatment of COVID-19 patients in SMIMER hospital of Surat

SURAT: Over 300 additional beds have been created at the city’s two hospitals on an emergency basis for treatment of COVID-19 patients. About 225 beds have been created at New Civil Hospital (NCH) and 100 at Surat Municipal Corporation-run SMIMER hospital. About 28 more beds can be added to the new facility at NCH for the treatment of coronavirus patients.

The facilities for COVID-19 patients have been developed in the existing two hospital buildings. The state government had announced this on Saturday last and made the project ready for operations on Wednesday.

NCH already had 375-bed facility, including isolation wards, said Mahendra Patel, commissioner of municipalities, Gandhinagar. Patel, former district collector of Surat, was assigned the task of coordination with regard to creation of additional beds in the city hospitals.

“The 100-bed facility has been created at SMIMER over and above its existing infrastructure of 100 beds. We developed the 325-bed facility within three days,” Patel added.

The new facility at NCH has been developed at the under construction building for stem cell hospital. First three floors of the building have been utilized. “They were almost complete with partitions and electrification. Installation of medical and electrical equipment was required and that we have completed,” said Jayesh Brahmbhatt, dean, Government Medical College (GMC).

There are 12 beds in ICU unit equipped with ventilator, multipara monitor, pulse oximeter, crash cart of medicines and other equipment. NCH officials claimed they have enough personal protection equipment kit for doctors and medical staff.

Title: PMPML to increase number of buses plying on road
Content:
The transport utility has been providing free-of-charge bus services for government employees engaged in emerg... Read More

PUNE: The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) will increase the number of buses on road following requests by private hospitals and pathology laboratories.

The transport utility has been providing free-of-charge bus services for government employees engaged in emergency services as of now, PMPML’s joint managing director Ajay Charthankar said. PMPML runs 110 buses in the morning and evening hours currently.

“We have been getting requests from different private hospitals and pathology centres for providing their staff with buses. While a plan is being chalked out, we need between 10 to 12 commuters in a bus preferably from one area in order to make our jobs easier. If someone working in a private hospital takes our bus and shows their identity card verifying that s/he is on emergency duty, they are being allowed to board. The number of buses will be increased as per the demand of the civic body, government hospitals and private parties, if it suits us. We might be looking at adding 50 buses in the future,” said a PMPML official.

The official added that passengers travelling in the buses were being checked. “We have requested them to wear masks and carry hand sanitizers. The identity cards are being checked. The service starts at 5am and goes on till 11am, resumes at 5pm and goes on till the late evening hours as there are many people working night shifts. Discussions are on with private hospitals on ways to provide them buses,” he said.

PMP Pravasi Manch activist Sanjay Shitole hailed the move. “The PMPML is a public service and it must be used to provide transportation under these difficult circumstances. On normal days, many people don’t want to travel in the buses but they are doing a good job presently,” he said.

Title: Won’t tolerate attacks on cops, health workers: Ajit Pawar
Content: PUNE: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar on Thursday said the government won’t tolerate attacks on police and health workers, who were working day and night to check the Covid-19 spread.“Doctors and police are doing their duty in the fight against Covid-19 outbreak. We will not tolerate attacks on doctors and police personnel. Those who are found heckling or attacking doctors and police personnel will be dealt with strict actions under the law,” Pawar said in a statement.Pawar’s statement followed reports of people hitch-hiking in milk vans, a policeman suffering serious injuries after a motorcyclist drove straight into him to avoid being stopped in Vasai (Palghar), among others.The deputy CM also urged people to avoid unnecessary crowding in public places. “Don’t let the time come for us to use the military,” Pawar said, adding, “Despite the lockdown, we are still continuing the essential services like milk, groceries, vegetables, gas, medicine, and fruits etc. The public and police must cooperate with each other during this time.”Pawar also welcomed the finance minister’s announcement of Rs 1.70 lakh crore relief package.Pawar assured that there were sufficient stocks of milk, fruits, vegetables, medicines, foodgrains, fuel and all other essential items of daily life. “However, the crowds are still witnessed in the markets, which is a matter of serious concern. I have instructed the officials to take steps to provide essentials to the people at their doorsteps or at their society gates to prevent them from going out. This has been implemented successfully in Baramati and Wai towns,” Pawar said in the statementHe called upon social organisations, NGOs and volunteers to come forward and take care of senior citizens, students, slum dwellers and the homeless poor in their localities by providing them with food and other requirements on humanitarian grounds.Besides, Pawar also permitted thousands of truckers stranded all over the state to proceed to their destinations. He even allowed community kitchens to cater to their food needs.

Title: Crime rate dips amid coronavirus scare in Bhopal
Content:
Caption

Bhopal: The number of serious offences reported in the state capital has come down drastically during the ongoing lockdown amid the coronavirus scare. Not a single case of loot, murder, attempt to murder, rape and other serious crimes were reported in the past four days. House break-ins and vehicle thefts have also been negligible. Senior city cops maintained that the fall in crime rate was a result of continuous monitoring and checking done by police personnel.

Earlier, around 8-10 cases of serious offences were reported at various police stations in the city on an average daily. Every day, on an average around half a dozen vehicle theft cases were also reported. On an average, two molestation and a rape case were also reported daily before the lockdown.

Ever since the lockdown was enforced from Sunday, only three vehicle theft cases and two house break-ins were reported. A considerable fall was also registered in crimes against women and only one molestation case has been reported during the last four days.

More than 30 cases were registered in the city against people violating the lockdown order including one against a Covid-19 suspect, who had returned from Dubai three days back and was found roaming on his scooter at Board Office Square police check point. Ten cases against lockdown violators were registered on Thursday. Although, a few assault cases were reported across the city.

ASP (crime branch) Nishchal Jharia said that enhanced police movement and curfew has led to a steep fall in the crime rate. “Even the miscreants are worried about their health and it seems and they are not venturing out”, he said.

ASP Zone-1 Rajat Saklecha said that cops have been maintaining constant vigil at every nook and corner of the city to enforce the lockdown. Security check points have been set up at all roads on the city outskirts to check movements. Also, 17 internal check points have been set up across the city to keep a check on people venturing out without any valid reason.

Apart from them, 27 fixed picket points have been set up under the jurisdiction of various city police station areas. As many as 19 check points have been set up by traffic police at major city crossings. Senior officers were regularly patrolling the areas and monitoring security.

SP (Police Headquarters) Dharamveer Singh Yadav said that apart from setting up check points, two police patrol vehicles at each police station level were directed to patrol in their respective areas and spread awareness on precautions to be taken to avoid the spread of coronavirus. Violators of prohibitory orders are being booked under relevant sections of the IPC and Motor Vehicles Act.

Title: Delhi lockdown: Food kitchens so that no one goes hungry
Content: NEW DELHI: With the objective that nobody sleeps hungry during the 21-day lockdown, Delhi government has decided to rope in charitable and religious organisations, civil society and not-for-profit organisations to provide cooked food to the city’s poor.Delhi Disaster Management Authority has started a hunger helpline where people can call up for food. District magistrates have been asked to ensure that packed food is delivered at their doorstep.The helpline, officials said, would be open between 11am to 3pm and 6pm to 9pm and manned by DUSIB officials. It will direct people to the nearest night shelter or pass on the information to the DM for delivery of packed food if the need arises.A nine-member advisory panel under deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia has also been formed for coordination and effective implementation of measures taken by the government for providing food. Apart from two bureaucrats, the government has roped in civil society members and experts in the fields of urban planning, homeless and disaster management.Following PM Narendra Modi’s call for a day-long ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal had last week announced a slew of measures, including enhancement of ration by 1.5 times to 72 lakh public distribution system beneficiaries and free lunch and dinner at night shelters for the needy.With a complete lockdown till April 14, a large number of daily wagers, causal workers and those working in shops, offices and factories may face problems to arrange for food.Apart from the 220 night shelters in Delhi, where anyone can go and eat lunch and dinner, the government has also decided to open feeding centres at least two school buildings in each municipal ward and provide meals to 500 people each.“The district magistrates have been asked to identify pockets where poor people may need food. By opening feeding centres in schools, we will be able to decongest night shelters and also maintain the norms of social distancing,” DUSIB member-expert Bipin Rai said.On Wednesday evening, about 18,500 people had food at night shelters and officials said the number was likely to increase in the coming days. Officials said their target is to provide free food to at least 1-1.5 lakh people every day.

Title: Police to issue travel passes for extreme emergencies
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Immigrants stranded in AP amidst the lockdown can visit their local police station in case they need to travel within or outside the state in case there is an emergency. Police officials will decide upon providing a travel permit upon request, depending upon their judgement of the emergency.

“Such passes are given only for extreme emergencies and are valid of inter-state travel as well. But the reason to obtain them must be convincing enough,” a district official said adding that those holding interstate travel passes must be careful and travel only through those routes that fall en route destinations mentioned on the passes.

“Only reasons as severe as deaths or health issues of elderly parents or close family members will be considered. Applicants should bring documents to support their claims,” added the official.

There are There are large numbers of immigrants from Telangana, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, West Bengal and Maharashtra who are either employed or have businesses in Visakhapatnam.

An official of the Srikakulam district administration said the system also applies to people from AP who have migrated to other states. “If they can bring in a permit from the local police station of their place of work, we will allow them to enter the state,” the official said.

Title: Many volunteer initiatives in capital hit a roadblock
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Though Covid-19 cases were reported from the capital, there was collaborative effort not to create panic among public and to support the affected. After an initial stage of shock, a set of Good Samaritans came out offering support for those who are undergoing home isolation. However, after the announcement of the three-week lockdown, police have given a strict instruction not to engage in such services.Most volunteer initiatives to provide food and essentials to people on home quarantine and senior citizens have come to a halt after the lockdown. A section of volunteers are providing services in their localities.Mathew Jacob, one of the first persons to launch a volunteer initiative to support people in home quarantine, said that they were denied permission to deliver the materials. “Though police obstructed us, we are still getting calls from people in need. It will be difficult for volunteers to deliver materials without police permission,” he said.When contacted, DCP R Karuppasamy said that they are only allowing volunteers who are working in co-ordination with the health department. “Volunteers who are providing service with the support of health department can continue. However, we cannot allow others because various organizations and clubs will start doing this. It will defeat the purpose of the lockdown. However, when there is need we will contact such volunteers. So, we are keeping a database of people who contacted us with the demand,” he said.Though the health team, police and corporation are making arrangements to provide support to people on home quarantine, it is facing some initial hiccups. Those persons who returned from foreign countries and are undergoing home quarantine are facing difficulties in getting essential items following the lockdown. Unlike others, they were not able to stock enough supplies.Senior citizens too are facing difficulties at the time of lockdown as domestic helps could not reach their houses. Many have started looking for maids who could stay with them.Youth volunteers Vivek Vijayakumar, Akhil M, Manu A K and Ivan John are engaged in volunteer services in and around Sasthamangalam area. “We provide home-cooked food to elderly and people who are stranded. Understanding the purpose of the lockdown, we are providing services only in our locality. We feel that if a youngster in a locality is willing, he could take care of the needs of 10 families there,” said Vivek.The police have made it mandatory for all to carry IDs and self-declaration statements while going out for necessary purposes.

Title: Won’t tolerate attacks on cops, health workers: Ajit Pawar
Content: PUNE: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar on Thursday said the government won’t tolerate attacks on police and health workers, who were working day and night to check the Covid-19 spread.“Doctors and police are doing their duty in the fight against Covid-19 outbreak. We will not tolerate attacks on doctors and police personnel. Those who are found heckling or attacking doctors and police personnel will be dealt with strict actions under the law,” Pawar said in a statement.Pawar’s statement followed reports of people hitch-hiking in milk vans, a policeman suffering serious injuries after a motorcyclist drove straight into him to avoid being stopped in Vasai (Palghar), among others.The deputy CM also urged people to avoid unnecessary crowding in public places. “Don’t let the time come for us to use the military,” Pawar said, adding, “Despite the lockdown, we are still continuing the essential services like milk, groceries, vegetables, gas, medicine, and fruits etc. The public and police must cooperate with each other during this time.”Pawar also welcomed the finance minister’s announcement of Rs 1.70 lakh crore relief package.Pawar assured that there were sufficient stocks of milk, fruits, vegetables, medicines, foodgrains, fuel and all other essential items of daily life. “However, the crowds are still witnessed in the markets, which is a matter of serious concern. I have instructed the officials to take steps to provide essentials to the people at their doorsteps or at their society gates to prevent them from going out. This has been implemented successfully in Baramati and Wai towns,” Pawar said in the statementHe called upon social organisations, NGOs and volunteers to come forward and take care of senior citizens, students, slum dwellers and the homeless poor in their localities by providing them with food and other requirements on humanitarian grounds.Besides, Pawar also permitted thousands of truckers stranded all over the state to proceed to their destinations. He even allowed community kitchens to cater to their food needs.

Title: Garbage generation goes down due to lockdown
Content:
Pune: The garbage generation in the city dropped by 400 tonnes per day following the lockdown to tame the spread of coronavirus.

The solid waste management department attributed the plunge in trash generation to the closure of food joints and commercial establishments like shopping malls following the lockdown. The shutdown of restaurants has reduced the wet garbage, while the dry garbage generation has gone down because the offices are closed.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) figures reveal that on an average the city generates around 2,100 tonnes of garbage. It has come down to 1,600 tonnes following the lockdown. Nearly 180 tonnes of wet garbage have gone out of the collection system, while 240 tonnes of dry garbage and 80 tonnes of reject items have reduced.

Dnyaneshwar Molak, the head of the PMC’s solid waste management department, said, “A sizeable reduction in trash generation has been seen off late. Both dry and wet garbage generation has gone down. Even the garbage reject has reduced.”

After the imposition of the lockdown, many waste-pickers could not pick up garbage because of police restrictions on the movement of residents. Also, many housing societies are not cooperating with the waste-pickers, affecting the garbage collection.

“Police have not allowed waste-pickers to leave their houses and go for door-to-door collection. It has adversely impacted the collection of garbage,” said Laxmi Narayanan of Solid Waste Collection and Handling (SWaCH) Collective.

Narayanan said the PMC commissioner and the city police commissioner had appealed to policemen to allow the conservancy staffers to do their job but not all policemen acted upon it. Many policemen were still preventing the conservancy staffers from venturing out, she said.

She said apart from the non-cooperation from the policemen, other issues, including non-availability of transport services, inability to use two-wheelers and lack of communication facilities, had also caused obstacles for the SWaCH workers.

Molak said, “Now the problem is as good as resolved. We have spoken to police officers. They are now allowing these workers to travel and perform their duties.”

Pinky Sonawane, who works in Aundh, said, “A few housing societies and residents also told us not to collect waste till March 31, fearing infection. A few others told us to come only once in a few days.”

Some waste-pickers were afraid of collecting garbage from areas where people had been home quarantined, said a source.

HL: DISPOSAL OF SAFETY GEARS

All masks, gloves and other safety items used by citizens should be wrapped carefully in a newspaper and marked with a big RED DOT, before handing them over to waste-pickers

It will ensure that waste-pickers do not open/touch such items

RESIDENTS’ ROLE

Citizens should segregate wet, dry and sanitary waste

All citizens must try to compost their waste at source and reduce the growing pressure on the system

INCOME HIT

Waste-pickers are not paid employees of the Pune Municipal Corporation or SWaCH

They depend on monthly user fees from citizens and daily sale of recyclable material

Their income will take a hit because scrap markets are currently closed

Title: 500 vehicles seized, 6,000 cases filed so far in Visakhapatnam
Content:
Representative Image

VISAKHAPATNAM: City traffic police have registered cases against 6,000 vehicles and impounded 500 for violating the lockdown since it came into force on March 24. They also collected Rs 14 lakh in fine.

Speaking to TOI, additional DCP (traffic) Ch Adinarayana said on March 24 they registered 2,885 cases and seized 187 vehicles besides collecting a fine of Rs 6.4 lakh for violating the MV Act and lockdown. “On Thursday, we registered only 1,400 cases till 4pm and seized around 50 vehicles. People seem to have realised the seriousness of the situation,” Adinarayana said.

The state road transport authority (RTA) also conducted checks in the city outskirts to monitor vehicle movement. RTA Vizag deputy transport commissioner GC Raja Ratnam said, “We started impounding vehicles on Thursday.We seized nine vehicles, including autos, and imposed a fine of Rs 2,000 each.”

Title: Tatya Tope stadium’s academies shut till Apr 30
Content:
Bhopal: The state sports department has extended the leaves of athletes associated with Tatya Tope stadium academies from March 31 to April 30 in view of lockdown.

All sports activities at the state’s multi-purposed stadium will also remain suspended till April 30.

According to the circular issued by the sports department, boarding and day boarding athletes of all state sports academies will have a holiday till April 30.

“Precaution has been taken to prevent the possible risk of the Covid-19 virus infection,” stated director of sports VK Singh in the circular.

Also, no sports activities will be organised by the sports department during this period, the circular added.

Title: Fumigation at Bhopal’s ‘corona epicentre’
Content: Bhopal: After two Covid-19 positive cases were reported from the same colony in the last four days, the district administration has started making public announcements in the locality.The authorities have also started daily fumigation near the house where the cases were detected.Bhopal’s ‘Patient Zero’ is a resident of the colony. Her father was also tested positive on Wednesday.After the colony became the epicentre of corona outbreak in Bhopal , a mobile van could be seen making announcements. “Aap ki colony mein corona ka positive case paya gaya hai, savdhan rahe, ghar se bahar na nikle” (positive cases of coronavirus have been found in this colony. Be careful and don’t venture out), the announcement said.Rajaram Sharma, a resident of the colony, said, “This is need of the hour. The administration should be proactive in the colony. A lot of cleansing operations are required frequently not only around the house of the family where the positive case was found, but elsewhere too.”But, this doesn’t seem to be happening. Once a day fumigation operations are not enough, that too near the house of the family where the positive case was found, the residents said. They want the administration to add more parts of the colony, at least within the 200-metre vicinity of ground zero.

Title: Pune: Sex workers struggle for basic rations, welfare organisation extends help
Content:
By: Padmashree.Pande

PUNE: Around 1,500 sex workers living in Budhwar Peth have barely enough rations to last a fortnight as they struggle to make ends meet in the wake of the curbs imposed due to Covid-19.

The police are keeping a strict vigil to ensure social distancing in these areas. “Even though we are doing our best to help these women, it is not enough.” Tejaswi Sevekari, executive director of Saheli Sangh, a sex-workers’ collective operating in the area said.

Saheli started educating the women of the situation since February-end . They were told about covering their faces while coughing or sneezing, washing their hands with soap and save money and ration for the tough days.

“Most women have come together and are helping each other by sharing ration, LPG and other goods. We have told them to store at least 5kg grain, but the packages given by our regular donors is not enough,” Sevekari said. Given the small dwellings these women inhabit, storing grain is a big problem.

The women have also been advised to stop sending money home and to first sustain themselves. Their landlords have told them not to pay rent for a month or two.

“They must get at least two meals a day. With all other activities on hold, we have appealed to local political leaders, families and friends to pitch in wherever they can. We are worried about the older women and the critical group which comprises HIV patients,” Sevekari said.

Several of them come from outside Maharashtra. Some from Karnataka had tried to find a state transport bus to take them back home before Sunday’s janata curfew, but they returned disappointed.

“Around 40 of us live together. There are no customers and we are not earning. Saheli is helping us out but we cannot go on like this,” 30-year-old Rani said.

Local corporator Datta Sagare has been helping Saheli. His son Anand, and Veer Hanuman Mitra Mandal, along with Sachin Damge of Vande Mataram Sanghatana have distributed food grain packets to the women.

Title: Delhi Police step in to feed those left jobless due to lockdown
Content: NEW DELHI: Since the announcement of the lockdown, most slum dwellers are out of job and several of them have been dialling the police helpline number requesting for food. On Thursday, Delhi Police got food packets and ration delivered at many of these slums.The Delhi Police commissioner has also directed the district deputy commissioners of police to identify areas where people are going hungry. The cops are in touch with NGOs and local good Samaritans to arrange necessary supplies.The helpline, 011- 23469526, has received 1,700 calls in the past 24 hours. A senior officer said, “At least 26 calls were for ration, food and money.”The district DCPs are trying to reach out to as many as possible. At Dwarka district, the station house officers have made WhatsApp groups with residents welfare associations (RWAs) to take help of those willing to volunteer. Pradhan Dev Choudhary, RWA president of Om Vihar, said, “Volunteers are making announcements about food and ration distribution at slums. To avoid crowding, we are keeping the packets at their doorstep. We are trying to arrange a cook as some people are homeless.”Dwarka DCP Anto Alphonse said, “Police teams, along with local NGOs, are distributing food packets and water bottles to poor people, and at slums and JJ clusters at Sector 3, Dwarka Mod, Najafgarh, Mohan Gardern and other areas.” NGOs have been given curfew passes for the work.In south and northwest Delhi, beat officers have been visiting senior citizens living alone to ensure they don’t have to step out at all. “Some of them required groceries, some other essentials,” said Atul Kumar Thakur, DCP (South).Ravi Shankar, a painter living at a south Delhi slum, said they had no money as there was no work. “Today police, along with some others, gave us cooked food. We hope this comes every day.”At Dwarka Sector 3, Gurpreet Singh, a businessman, are helping labourers along with two friends. “As the demand has grown, we are now preparing langar at a gurdwara and distributing meals thrice a day. The gurdwara is helping us with some ration too.” They are also feeding strays.At Majnu ka Tila in north Delhi, cops distributed rice and dal. Two youths, both migrant labourers from Bihar and Uttar Pradesh, were fed at the Inderlok police post when they made a PCR call saying they had not eaten anything for the past four days.

Title: Pune: Gram panchayat, local traders bring essential items at village doorstep
Content:
PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Residents of Manchar village in Pune district’s Ambegaon taluka have been getting free home delivery of essential items, thanks to the initiative of the gram panchayat and local traders.

Manchar village is one of the largest villages in Ambegaon taluka with a population of around 60,000.

“There was a rush to purchase essential commodities like milk, groceries and other goods after the lockdown was suddenly announced and social distancing was quickly forgotten. So, we decided to start the free home delivery facility,” sarpanch Datta Kenjale said.

He said the gram panchayat prepared category-wise list of traders selling various items like milk, meat, vegetables and other goods and sent it to residents via social media platforms. “Now, people contact the traders as per their needs and get home delivery of goods. We have also instructed them to observe social distancing in their shops and while delivering the commodities at home,” he said.

Dinesh Khude, a grocer, said, “People call us and send a list of goods needed either through SMS or WhatsApp. We deliver the goods in three-four hours. We have found that people cancel their orders if there is a delay in delivery of goods. So, we intimate customers about the approximate time needed to deliver the goods. There has been a good response from customers for this service.”

The Renuka women’s self-help group has also benefited from the home delivery service. President, Aruna Dheke, said, “Ours is a group of 10 women farmers and is a part of the home delivery service in the village. The vegetables grown on our farms are supplied to customers after getting orders on phone. We carry additional stock with us as people residing nearby too come to purchase vegetables. We maintain social distancing while selling vegetables. On Tuesday, we sold 100kg of peas and as many kg of chillies.”

Title: Disruptions in supply of raw material for hand sanitisers to be eased
Content:
Hyderabad: To ensure uninterrupted supply of hand sanitisers, the Telangana government has sought the intervention of the Department of Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade, Union ministry of commerce and industry, for removal of bottlenecks in supply of iso-propyl alcohol, a key ingredient used in the manufacture of hand sanitisers, to companies making hand sanitisers in the state.

The supply of IPA, which comes from Gujarat, was disrupted over the past three days after the lockdown brought inter-state movement of goods to a grinding halt. Jayesh Ranjan, IT secretary, said, “Hand sanitiser manufacturers are trying to get the bottlenecks removed.” TNN

Title: Sassoon’s flu unit to study Covid-19 community spread
Content: PUNE: A dedicated unit to diagnose and treat patients complaining of flu-like symptoms, including cold, cough and fever, started at Sassoon General Hospital will decode the community spread of the novel coronavirus in Pune Only patients who have not travelled abroad in the past one month but have unrelenting flu symptoms will be examined at this unit. Experts at the hospitals will carry out random sampling of some patients to understand the presence of the virus in the community.“So far, we have screened 326 citizens with flu-like symptoms who have no history of international travel or proximity to known Covid-19 infected persons or their close contacts. Of these, we advised 32 persons to remain in home quarantined for 14 days. They are individuals who are mobile and have got exposed to maids, cab drivers and food delivery persons. Others are family members, friends and close contacts of such individuals,” the hospital’s forensic science expert Harish Tatiya told TOI.“We took throat swabs of 10 individuals to rule out Covid-19 infection. Of the 10, five have tested negative for the contagion so far and the reports of another five are awaited. Besides, we have also taken samples of some admitted patients and their reports are awaited. So far, we have not seen a single case which is indicative of the presence of the virus in the community,” he said.Covid-19 and the seasonal flu are similar in many ways. Both are respiratory diseases that spread through the droplets of fluid from the mouth and nose of someone who is infected. Both are contagious, produce similar symptoms and may cause severe symptoms in some.“There has been a sudden rise in cases of viral illnesses following the drop in temperature and the wide fluctuation in mercury levels. We have been seeing many patients complaining of cough, cold and fever. Many often ask if they have Covid-19 infection. We clear their misconceptions and treat those people who have no recent history of international travel or proximity to known positive patients and their close contacts,” senior family physician Prakash Mahajan said.The doctors said Covid-19 and seasonal influenza viruses ‘have a similar disease presentation’. Both viruses are transmitted by contact, droplets and fomites. As a result, the same public health measures, such as hand hygiene and good respiratory etiquette like coughing into your elbow or into a tissue and immediately disposing it of prevent infection.

Title: Doctors, counsellors go online to keep a tab on patients
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Doctors and therapists are going online to offer consultations, both free and chargeable, in the times of social distancing made necessary due to Covid-19 spread.

ENT surgeon Kavita Choudhari said Baner Balewadi Medicos’ Association had started an online consultation for minor ailments so that patients do not crowd the clinics. “Prescriptions could not be provided via phone earlier. However, due to Covid-19, the Medical Council of India has issued a guideline stating that doctors can do online consultation for minor ailments,” she said.

Choudhari said cases of cough, sore throat and fever were on the rise, leaving many people scared in the wake of coronavirus spread, which also presents flu-like symptoms. “However, when such people talk to doctors, they realise that it is just a seasonal flu. Even in cases where a physical examination is needed, we keep a gap of 15 minutes between two patients so that proper sanitisation can be done,” she said.

Health psychologist Kinjal Goyal is offering free therapy to medical professionals working tirelessly in the prevailing situation. “Doctors are humans too and feel anxiety, fear and apprehension just like their patients. We need to safeguard their emotional well-being now to be able to minimize post-traumatic stress disorder on the other side of the pandemic. That’s why I am holding online therapy sessions for medical professionals,” Goyal said.

Anand Gangwal, a physiotherapist, has temporarily shut down his clinic and is following up with his patients online. “My patients video call me and I advise them accordingly.”

Title: PCMC’s first 3 +ve cases await -ve tag
Content:
Pune: Swab samples of the first three Covid-19 patients from Pimpri Chinchwad tested negative as they successfully completed their 14-day quarantine on Thursday.

Municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar said they would be discharged only after the second test, the results of which were expected on Friday, was also negative.

Additional commissioner Santosh Patil said, “There has been no rise in the Covid-19 positive cases in Pimpri Chinchwad for the sixth consecutive day. The condition of all the 12 positive patients is stable.”

The corporation has placed 1,306 patients in home quarantine due to their history of travel abroad or possible contact with either of the 12 positive patients. As many as 27 people’s swab samples were sent for tests on Thursday and the results would be out on Friday.

Officials said the civic body has completed its door-to-door survey covering 4.47 lakh citizens to check on their health and travel history.

Title: Bhopal: All waiting & no play for state athletes
Content:
Long jumper Ankit Sharma spending time at his home by watching his own past

Bhopal: Coronavirus has proved to be a barrier in the practice routine for national and international athletes. Several of them were undergoing hard trainings for the Olympics before the pandemic shut down their active lives.

Ankit Sharma, a long jumper from Morena who had qualified for the 2016 Rio Olympics, was preparing for the Olympics 2020, until it was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. “Everything is blank now for me. I don’t know what will happen now. I have locked myself completely, which will end up in me losing endurance. This is a very frustrating situation for an athlete like me who had been working hard for the past four year,” said Ankit from Chennai.

Talking about his routine life after the lockdown, Ankit replied, “Eating, sleeping and watching TV.” He used to practice for 6-7 hours daily during normal times.

In 2015, Ankit had recorded a jump of 8.04 metres at the National Games in Thiruvananthapuram and became the fifth Indian to go past the 8-metre mark. He had won the gold medal at the 2016 South Asian Games , breaking a 27-year Games record.

It is a similar situation for snooker world championship bronze medallist, cueist Kamal Chawla , who is from Bhopal. “Instead of practising on the table, I am spending my days by playing cards.I am seriously worried about my game. You can’t practise solo. As for improving skills, you need an opponent, which is not available now,” said Chawla. He had to leave a tournament mid-way after it was called off in Hyderabad a few days ago.

Players like Indian hockey team member Vivek Prasad from Itarsi, shooter Manisha Keer from Bhopal and others are also facing the sasimilar problems.

Title: RTO to start providing approval certificates to transport vehicles carrying essentials
Content:
Pune: The Regional Transport Office (RTO) has started providing certificates to ensure hassle-free movement of vehicles carrying essential items.

“We are giving the certificates to ensure that vehicles carrying essential items, such as milk, vegetables and medicines, are not stopped. An officer will be at the RTO for the job,” an RTO official said.

The driver and the owner of the vehicle need to register personal details in an application, provide all necessary documents and mention the nature of the services. “The official at the RTO will scrutinize the details and issue the certificate,” the official said. Those who cannot visit RTO can mail an application to rto.12-mh@gov.in.

The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited has announced helpline numbers, 020-24545454, 020-24503211 and 020-24503223, for thoe providing essential services.

The “dial an autorickshaw” service (98591-98591) received 2,876 calls on Thursday. However, vehicles could be provided to only 198 callers.

Title: Corp ensures home for over 200 destitute people
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Corporation has ensured a home for the homeless to ensure that they too stay at home during lockdown to fight Covid-19 situation. A large makeshift tent, erected at Putharikandam ground at East Fort for a cultural programme held recently, was converted into a home to shelter the destitute and 208 were brought here on Thursday.Corporation’s care for the destitute did not end by bringing them under a roof. It conducted a medical camp by Nemom taluk Hospital superintendent Dr BP Premkumar and Fort taluk Hospital superintendent Dr Stanley.The camp was opened on Wednesday. Corporation officials said that most inmates were brought here on Thursday by squads of the corporation while others were brought by the police. By Thursday evening, a few more waked in.Officials have divided the camp into two for men and women. Wooden planks were laid on the floor over which carpets were spread. The inmates were given mats to sleep.Police too have initiated a programme to deliver food to the persons living in destitute homes and also on the streets. Through the programme, police will deliver food to the destitute thrice a day. The programme began with food distribution to inmates of the camp at Putharikandam ground on Thursday noon. Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran inaugurated the programme.

Title: MLA Misal raises pitch for uninterrupted water supply
Content:
Pune: The residents of Sinhagad Road and Satara Road have demanded more water due to rise in consumption amid the lockdown.

Raising their issue with civic authorities, MLA Madhuri Misal sent a letter to PMC on March 26 demanding uninterrupted water supply in the affected areas, including Dattawadi, Bibvewadi, Hingane Khurd, Panmala and Parvati, among others. “Alternate day water supply is causing problems and residents have raised complaints about non-availability of water. Regular supply should be started,” MLA Madhuri Misal said.

PMC commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad said the civic body had not demanded additional water from irrigation department as consumption for commercial purposes had gone down.

“With specific reference to Sinhagad Road, the problem is peculiar to that area. It will be sorted out o nce the 24x7 water supply scheme is completed. We will look at the demand made by the residents and take appropriate action to resolve this issue,” he said.

Title: Power cuts hit work and sleep in Vimannagar
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Vimannagar residents were a vexed lot on Wednesday and Thursday after frequent power outages disrupted their office and domestic work.

With most people now working from home, no power meant laptops and mobile phones ran out of charge eventually, impacting their routine.

Many families spent sleepless nights as there was no power till 5am in many parts. Kitchen appliances too didn’t work properly for the same reason, homemakers said.

Working professional Kiran Thapa said there was no power in Oakwood society from 9pm on Wednesday to 5am next the day. “Yes, I am working from home and due to the power cut, I was unable to access my laptop,” she said.

“There was no electricity till 3am (on Thursday),” Richa Das, a resident of the Clover Acropolis society, said. “There was a power cut sometime later and was not restored till the morning. The weather is very hot and without fans, it becomes very tough. I am a clinical hypnotherapist, so all my work is through phone calls,” Das added.

At Lunkad Greenland II, there was no power from 9pm to 2am. “There was power for 30 minutes and an outage again for 40 minutes. After that, it fluctuated till 10.30am today. I have three kids in the house and they couldn’t sleep. Laptops and phones had run out of charge, while my husband and brother-in-law couldn’t work,” Farida, a resident, said.

“In NIBM area, there was no power since 3am to 7am day on Wednesday, and power fluctuations since then, even today. We basically have electricity for an hour and then it’s out. It is getting difficult to manage,” Raheela Shaikh said./

In a statement on Thursday, Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL)’s public relations officer Nishikant Raut said the post-midnight rain on Tuesday and showers on Wednesday disrupted the supply in several parts of the city. “The engineers have been working hard since the Wednesday morning to restore power. Inclement weather disrupted nearly 35-40 power lines across Pune city,” Raut stated.

Title: Enough stocks at Ghazipur mandi, says east Delhi DM
Content: NEW DELHI: Following rumours of scarcity of vegetables and overcharging by retailers, east Delhi district magistrate Arun Kumar Mishra said the buffer stock of kitchen staples, potato and onion, was available for at least a month at Ghazipur mandi Mishra claimed that green vegetables were arriving from the neighbouring state of Uttar Pradesh in enough quantity and without any obstruction. “Consumers will continue to get the supply without any hassle throughout the lockdown period,” he said.The DM said that regular meetings were being held with shopkeepers and wholesalers dealing in essential commodities to ensure there is no shortage of milk, food items and medicines. “We had separate meetings with chemist association and wholesalers at Kondli. They’ve been told to mark their vehicles that are carrying essential items to ensure smooth passage,” Mishra added.The East DM also said that directions had been issued to police and district officials to not stop anyone carrying essential commodities. “Even if they don’t have the passes being issued by government, we are not stopping them. But we also tell them to get the passes made,” he said. On Thursday, East district had made around 2,800 such passes.

Title: Ahmedabad: No retail sale at Kalupur, Jamalpur
Content: AHMEDABAD: Overcrowding at Kalupur and Jamalpur markets has forced the Ahmedabad municipal commissioner and city police commissioner to ban retail sale of vegetables there, though bulk purchases can be made by traders.From early morning on Thursday, people from different corners of the city made a rush for these markets to avoid the scalding prices being charged by their local vegetable traders. But this led to a chaotic situation, overcrowding, and loss of all social distancing, thus defeating the purpose of the lockdown and heightening the risks of the spread of Covid-19.Municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra went to the Kalupur market after reports of large crowds of consumers crammed in the narrow lanes of the market came in. He talked with the vegetable dealers and then with city police commissioner Ashish Bhatia.“We had a detailed discussion and decided to permit only wholesale purchases from Kalupur market. The police commissioner has decided on heavy bandobust to prevent individual retail customers making purchases,” Nehra said.Nehra added that only wholesalers are permitted inside the Jamalpur main market, and the retailers who used to sit outside have already been shifted to Riverfront Sunday market, where there was little chance of overcrowding.A trader at Jamalpur market said there was a rush of retail customers in the wholesale market from Thursday morning. “The individual purchasers who came were willing to buy in bulk as retailers in their areas were overcharging. He said potato, which was priced at Rs 10-14 per kg was being sold at Rs 30-35 per kg in many areas. So families are pooling requirements for collective buying in bulk.”The trader added that the state government should fix retail rates for vegetables which may be 1.5 to 2 times of wholesale rates. He said at Jamalpur main market they usually did not sell less than 5kg to anyone, but on Thursday they also sold lesser amounts at a higher price.

Title: Many students face challenges amid national lockdown
Content:
Pune: Students in the city preparing for competitive exams have been facing multiple challenges in the wake of the national lockdown.

They want the district and municipal administration to facilitate transport for them to return home.

Pune municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad said, “Our top priority is to provide basic facilities and health services to all sections of the society. It will be difficult for us to make transport arrangements.”

Laxman Waghmare, an MPSC aspirant from Jalgaon district, said, “As per the previous schedule, the prelim exam was going to be on April 8. Had the government taken the decision to postpone it earlier, we would have gone to our villages,” he said.

Some students said they do not have gas to cook food. “We used to have food at the mess. We don’t have a gas cylinder either,” Parikshet Saner, a student from Nashik, said.

“Some have their own vehicles and are ready to travel to their native places. The administration should make passes for us so the police will not stop us,” Mauli Naiknavare from Pandharpur in Solapur district said.

A senior district official said, “We cannot make alternative arrangements for them. Neither can we issue a pass , otherwise many people could have similar requests.” Most of these students live in Peth areas of the city, where limited shops are open. Some said they didn’t get grocery and food items in nearby shops.

Santosh Rathod, another aspirant from Nanded district, said, “I get around Rs2,500 per month from home for my expenses and I paid the mess and room rent from that. Now, I don’t know how to survive with less than Rs500 in with me for the next three days.”

Title: 5 shops sealed for gutka sales
Content: Pimpri Chinchwad: The Food and Drugs Administration sealed five shops for breaking the lockdown to sell gutka and paan masala. Three of the shops were in Mhalunge Padal village. One shop each was shut down in Hinjewadi and Maan. Banned goods worth Rs 1,100 were seized from a person in Mhalunge Padal. TNN

Title: Coronavirus adds to misery of Delhi riot victims
Content: NEW DELHI: A month after Mohammad Akhtar’s house was set ablaze in Shiv Vihar during the Delhi riots, the 52-year-old returned to his neighbourhood this week. Coming back to the charred remains of his home was the only option available to him as the tent that served as his temporary shelter was dismantled. Akhtar had been living at the Eidgah relief camp in Mustafabad which housed at least 600 riot-displaced victims.“We weren’t forced to leave. But the camp was running out of ration supply. The caterer had already packed up. There was nothing left there,” said Akhtar, who once reared buffaloes to eke out a living. He has no source of earning now, and is apprehensive about the future.Fear over Covid-19 has forced the administration to look for alternative shelters for those displaced by the riots. Delhi Waqf Board, which was managing the site, confirmed that at least five tents have been dismantled. It claimed that the residents are being shifted to rented properties in the neighbourhood. But many of these families claimed that they have nowhere to go and little to eat.“We prepared our last meal at Eidgah today. The authorities have asked us to leave. For the last two days, we were struggling to prepare food because essentials like oil and milk were hard to come by in bulk,” said Aqueel Ahmad, the caterer who was in-charge of the kitchen at Eidgah.Fear of the contagious disease has also led a few people to leave on their own.Akhtar was among the two petitioners who had moved Delhi high court on March 20 asking the government to set up a medical camp to screen people for Covid-19 by thermal scanners. The high court passed an order on March 23, asking the government to set up the camp within 48 hours. But even before the deadline for compliance ended, the Waqf board began to dismantle camps.“This is a clear violation of the court’s order. The government can be held accountable for contempt of court if it’s making people leave without screening them,” said a lawyer who had represented Akhtar at the high court.Wasim was among those who left because of coronavirus fear. “We left two days ago because people started saying it wasn’t safe to live with so many people as the disease could spread,” he said. The 30-year-old has taken up a rented house, but there's no work for him. “Some volunteers gave us money for three months rent, but we don’t know how we will eat now,” he added.Even as the displaced stare at a bleak future, all they pray for is peace. “We hope that this does not happen with anyone. Our lives changed overnight because of the riots. And then it changed again when we had to leave the camp at such a short notice. We don't have a plan for survival, but we know we have to try,” said Akhtar.“If we had money or sources of regular income, we could have fed at least 10 more people in these times of fear. But right now, we don’t even have the clarity about what we will be eating next,” he added.

Title: Many come forward to distribute food among the needy in Jaipur
Content: JAIPUR: As the lockdown has affected jobs of thousands of labourers in the unorganised sector, they are finding it difficult to arrange for two square meals a day. To solve this crisis, people from all sections of the society are coming forward to donate ration and food to the people in need.Kho Nagoriyan, situated in the city’s outskirts, has major population of labourers, most of whom are out of business since the lockdown. Hence, a few economically secure residents of the area have decided to distribute food items to the needy.Jakir Haji, a resident of Kho Nagoriyan said, “We are seeing that every day people are sleeping hungry which prompted us to start distributing food. Some shopkeeper supplied paneer, tomatoes, potato, cooking oil bottle or achaar (pickle). It is a collaboration by many people. Every day, we distribute food to 300 people, but I know that is not enough so I am trying to get in touch with some NGO to get help.”While the battle against coronavirus is underway in full swing, hunger has come to haunt many due to the economic crisis that has followed. However, people are visiting various colonies and slums for serving food to the needy. Rashmi Jain, along with three others has been running ‘Feeding Hands’, an NGO that serves free food to people.Everyday they serve 400 people and have been going around the city for this. “The times are so hard that we are teary-eyed looking at the situation of the poor . There are places where people haven’t eaten for three consecutive days. Everyday, police control rooms receive calls from people where food is needed as soon as possible and they later inform us. We serve daal and four kulchas daily prepared at home by our workers. This NGO has been working with the help of people who are coming forward to contribute items like buns, potatoes, puri or other food items,” said Rashmi.Some citizen have been going door to door distributing food packets with the help of donors. Giriraj Khandelwal, one such person in Jaipur, has been receiving help from the people in distributing the food packets. “Jain Samaj, Arya Samaj and various other organizations have been calling me. I pick up my vehicle every day, collect the food material provided and distribute the food like masala puri or achaar or dry ration like – wheat, pulses, rice along with pouches of masalas (spices). This is a time of crisis, wherein everyone should come forward to help,” said Khandelwal.The government has recently announced that people will be given ration without papers, which is although appreciable, yet the People’s Union for Civil Liberties (PUCL) says that a blueprint hasn’t been created for it. The PUCL has been supplying cooked food packets to 1,000 people daily. “We have been distributing food packets everywhere. Government has taken a good initiative but it should also speed up the implementation of it. A helpline is needed for rural areas where people can register their complaints or else the problem will not be solved,” said Kavita Srivastav, president, PUCL.

Title: Bizman, who returned from Delhi, is city’s 5th Covid-19 +ve case
Content:
Nagpur: While the first Covid-19 patient of Central India recovered and was discharged from IGGMCH on Thursday, a city-based businessman tested positive and was admitted in the isolation ward of the same hospital.

The new case is the fifth positive patient in Nagpur city and eighth in Vidarbha so far. The businessman has no travel history to foreign country, neither was he in close contact with any positive patients, or travelled by flight. The person had travelled to New Delhi and returned by train recently.

Government authorities remained tight-lipped and refused to comment if this could be a case of local transmission. But the way NMC sprang into action and started survey of the entire locality of the patient shows that the administration has taken this case very seriously. Moreover, the patient has diabetes and high blood pressure, which increases his risk.

NMC zonal medical officer Dr Sunil Kamble claimed that the case came out due to NMC’s door-to-door containment drive. “Our door-to-door survey team visited the house of this person on Monday, and learnt he had high fever. Our team asked him to go to IGGMCH and get himself tested. This prompted the person to go for a check-up,” he said.

The patient runs a famous shoe shop adjacent to the residence of a former minister at Khamla. He and his manager, both from the same community, went to New Delhi by Tamil Nadu Express on March 16. They reached Delhi the next morning, and freshened at the station itself.

They went to Karol Bagh in Delhi and purchased materials for their shop. They did not stay in Delhi, and started back the same day by the Telangana Express, and reached the city on March 18.

One of the patient’s relatives, a former corporator, told TOI, “He and his manager had no health problems on March 18. The person has diabetes and high blood pressure. He and his manager went to their shop as usual till March 21,” he said.

The shop was closed for janata curfew on March 22, and the same day the patient started experiencing health problems. Since then, he did not go to the shop and the manager along with two more staffers managed the shop. He visited a nearby doctor and took treatment.

“After NMC staffers told him to visit IGGMCH, he called me in panic on March 25. I asked him to go with his entire family to Mayo Hospital and get checked so that he has no confusion or fear. He along with his mother, wife, son and daughter went to Mayo Hospital. After taking samples, he was asked to stay there while the others returned home. Today, doctors said he was positive for Covid-19,” the senior corporator said.

Immediately after the person tested positive, a team of health department with police reached his home and cordoned off the entire lane. Total 10 persons, including four family members of the patient and six family members of the manager, were also taken to IGGMCH by the NMC team for check up.

This sent ripples among residents of Khamla, which is a crowded market area of South-West Nagpur. Also, members of the businessman’s community are known to mingle a lot, with many meeting and visiting houses of each other daily.

Mayor Sandip Joshi has directed NMC officials to conduct door-to-door containment drive in the vicinity of the house of the shopkeeper and the activity has already kicked-off.

Till now, all five positive patients in Nagpur have been from south-west part of the city.

Title: Residents claim JMC spraying disinfectants in VIP areas only
Content: Jaipur: Jaipur Municipal Corporation ( JMC ) has been accused of spraying disinfectants only in the VIP areas as residents living in slums have complained that no vehicle reached their areas .Officials of JMC claimed that they had been spraying disinfectants in all the areas for more than two weeks. “It is a densely populated area where people mainly from the labour class reside. No vehicle has ever come here for spraying and we are worried about our safety. We have called up JMC helpline but they just give us assurances,” said Zakir Haji, a resident of Kho Nagoriyan.Similarly people of Jaisinghpura Khor which is spread over several kilometres claimed no JMC vehicle had ever come. Gyarsilal Mali, a resident of the area, said JMC was just completing a formality by spraying on the main roads.“Forget about spraying disinfectants, JMC officials have never visited this area for fogging at the time when dengue was at its peak. They come with machines of fogging and after spraying in a few lanes give excuse that they have to refill it. A few days ago, a bike came to spray disinfectants but that was limited to only roads not the lanes,” said Gyarsilal.JMC has claimed to have deployed 17 fire tenders, 2 vehicles and 120 teams in the entire city to carry out spraying disinfectants.In a meeting held on Thursday, JMC commissioner V.P.Singh has asked his officers to focus on slum areas and densely populated areas. Officials at JMC however said it would take some time to cover the entire city and they have been doing work day and night. Officials claim that it is difficult to get into congested lanes which consume time in old city but they are working towards spraying with portable machines in those areas.In Vaishali Nagar, where recently one person was found positive of coronavirus , the slums have been ignored by the JMC. Prempura village near Vaishali Nagar hasn’t seen any spraying of disinfectants.

Title: Sree Chitra doc discharged, hospital back to normalcy
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The functioning of Sree Chitra Institute of Medical Sciences and Technology is getting back to normalcy as the doctor, who had earlier tested positive for Covid-19 , was tested negative and discharged. All the primary contacts were also discharged as they completed the mandatory quarantine period.After the doctor was tested positive on March 15, as many as179 employees of the institute, including doctors, were detected as primary contacts of which 55 were categorized as high-risk contacts and 124 as low-risk contacts.Apart from this, additional five staff members, including colleagues who shared office, and two family members were also put under home quarantine.“All primary contacts and their family members (secondary contacts) were also given strict instructions to follow all the home quarantine norms,” said Dr Asha Kishore, director of the institute.Until now, nine of the contacts developed mild symptoms and were tested at the Medical College facility and the results were negative (four among the low-risk and five among the high-risk primary contacts).After the RT-PCR laboratory started functioning on March 24 at the institute, 47 of the primary contacts were tested. Except the last batch of 12, all remaining samples have been tested negative. At present, all primary contacts and secondary contacts of the institute are asymptomatic and have completed 15 days under observation since their last contact with the index case, said the director.In addition to the primary contact, 44 staff and students who had no contact history with the index case had developed symptoms of respiratory infection after the index case was diagnosed. They were also referred to the state Covid-19 cell for assessment. Of these, 13 were screened by the Medical College laboratory and all results were negative.“The index case treated in the Medical College isolation ward has been declared cured and discharged. Thus the containment of the spread of the disease among primary and secondary contacts, which was performed by the state and supported by the institute has been successful,” said Dr Asha Kishore.Meanwhile, the institute has opened a second testing facility on its technology campus and will be ready for accepting samples from the state in a few days as soon as the preparations are over.The institute is accepting emergency cases and will start telemedicine consultations for cardiology and neurology specialty clinics for review patients from March 27. Contact numbers are 0471-2524621 and 0471-2524533.

Title: Goa: Online petition to keep lockdown in force grows
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: While chief minister Pramod Sawant, responding to public demand, announced the opening of provisional stores from Friday, there was an angry reaction from several quarters who say that it would invite trouble for the state in a big way.

A letter petition is also being circulated on social media for citizens to sign in favour of continuing with the complete 21-day lockdown.

Noted singer Hema Sardesai and former Indian Medical Association (IMA) president Dr Shekhar Salkar who are among those in the forefront demanding reversal of the decision, said that the government cannot take a risk considering that three people have tested positive for Covid-19 in the state. They have appealed to the chief minister to reconsider his decision in the interest of the health of the citizens of Goa.

“The medical fraternity will be with you on this. There must be 100% lockdown and people will support this,” Salkar said on Thursday.

Title: Karnataka seeks to import 1 lakh Covid-19 rapid testing kits from China
Content:
Shipping a major hurdle

25k random tests in next 10 days

BENGALURU: If all goes according to plan, Karnataka will soon start testing more samples. The state is in talks with a Chinese manufacturer to procure rapid testing kits.Dr CN Manjunath , director, Sri Jayadeva Institute of Cardiovascular Sciences and Research, and nodal officer for Covid-19 lab testing in the newly-formed task force, said the government is in touch with a Beijing-based manufacturer for the supply of 1 lakh kits.“The idea is to test more persons. What we are currently doing is the polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) test. There is acute shortage of kits even at the ICMR level. What we are buying from China is the rapid testing kit called ‘SARS-CoV-2 Antibody Test Strip’, which will use the blood sample. It is validated and the accuracy is almost 96-97%,” he said.Currently, the government is spending Rs 2,600 per test per person. Once the kits are available, the cost can come down to Rs 600-700.The rapid immune-based testing kit is used to detect Covid-19 coronavirus antigen. It was widely used in China to detect both immunoglobulin IgM and IgG antibodies, said Dr Manjuanth. In this technique, when the antigen and antibody combine, they leave a visible colour spot or band which confirms presence of the infection.“The rapid testing mechanism is to avoid the Covid-19 infection from spreading further. Thursday’s positive case of a Mysuru man who had no travel history and no contact with patients has raised questions on the virus behaviour. It’s showing signs of slipping into the community and has to be looked into immediately,” said a top-level official.With flights to and from China having been suspended, procuring the kits will be a major problem. “We have discussed this with the director general of civil aviation and the home ministry. The only option is to send a chartered flight to China and procure 1 lakh testing kits. We also want to buy Personal Protection Equipment and masks in large numbers,” said Dr Manjunath.The government will start 31 fever clinics in Bengaluru on Friday to screen persons with Covid-19 symptoms. It will scale up tests to 25,000 in the next 10 days, in keeping with the ICMR mandate to conduct random testing. Medical education minister K Sudhakar said: “This is being done to ensure that if people with travel history develop Covid-19 symptoms, they should come to the fever clinics. This way, we can reduce the risk of community spread.” He said only 1,500 tests have been conducted so far. “We want to follow the example of South Korea,” he added. Random testing has started in Kalaburagi.

Title: Traders demand uninterrupted flow of essential supplies
Content: Madurai: Trader bodies and consumer organisations have written to chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and DGP J K Tripathy to ensure that supply of essential commodities and services is not interrupted during the 21-day lockdown. They noted that there were hindrances on Wednesday and Thursday.Following the death of a 54-year-old man from the city from Covid-19 on Wednesday, traders are facing difficulties in bringing their stock to the city and taking it to retailers, Tamil Nadu Foodgrains Merchants Association Limited president S P Jeyapragasam said. “But for Madurai, there is no trouble in transporting the commodities to the rest of Tamil Nadu,” he said.“Madurai is the hub for good grains and essential commodities catering to six districts – Madurai, Theni, Dindigul Virudhunagar , Sivaganga and Ramanathapuram – and partly to four other southern districts. Traders and retailers from the south buy essential commodities such as rice, wheat, dal, flour, spices and oil from wholesalers in Madurai,” he said.According to him, hindrances in despatching these commodities from here will result in acute shortage in the neighbouring districts. Following their representation to the CM, chief secretary and top government officials, city police officials have started talks with wholesalers to fix a specific time when goods could be allowed into the city, loading and unloading.Tuticorin based consumer rights organisation Empower has written to the CM and DGP to issue passes to people and vehicles involved in essential services. “This will help them perform their duties without any hindrance as they will carry passes issued by the police and district administration,” Empower executive director A Sankar said.He added that the passes could also be issued to employees of cold storage and warehousing services, employees from essential commodities manufacturing units, transportation of essential goods and private security guards.

Title: 10-year-old girl mauled todeath by leopard in Kheri
Content:
Bareilly: A 10-year-old girl was killed by a leopard in Isanagar area of Lakhimpur Kheri district late on Wednesday.

The girl was a resident of Chakdaha village. She went missing in the evening. After an intense search, villagers recovered the girl’s body from a wheat field.

Police and forest department was immediately informed about the incident. Since it was late at night, forest department carried out their investigation on Thursday morning and recovered the pug marks of a leopard. Chakdaha village is adjacent to Dhaurahra range of forests which is the buffer zone of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve and movement of wild animals is common in the village’s exterior areas.

Divisional forest officer Anil Patel told TOI, “A girl named Mohini was mauled to death by a leopard near Dhaurahra range. Our team is monitoring the movement of the leopard. A cage would be placed at the spot after seeking permission from senior officials, to capture the animal as it may attack others in the area. We have spoken to SDM Sunandu Sudhakaran and the aggrieved family will be granted a compensation of Rs 5 lakh under relief scheme.”

Title: All hands on deck: Three big private hospitals join coronavirus fight in Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: The city’s fight against Covid-19 got a shot in the arm on Thursday with three top private hospitals — Indraprastha Apollo, Max and BLK — announcing isolation and treatment facility for people suffering from the disease.Till date, only public hospitals like Safdarjung, Ram Manohar Lohia (RML), Lok Nayak, Rajiv Gandhi Super Specialty, Guru Tegh Bahadur (GTB), Deen Dayal Upadhyay and Baba Saheb Ambedkar hospital had this facility. Fortis group is also likely to announce the creation of isolation facility on Friday, sources said.While Apollo hospital has reserved 50 beds for Covid-19 patients, Max group has reserved 20 beds each at its Saket and Patparganj centres and BLK 10 beds for isolation and treatment. All three hospital groups said they were prepared to scale up the infrastructure significantly, depending on the need, on a short notice.Apollo has also received licence for Covid-19 testing. Sangita Reddy, joint managing director of the group, said most centres have been cleared for testing.“Full-scale testing is likely to start by the end of March. We will have the provision for home collection of samples as well as drive-through testing. In-hospital testing will be discouraged, except for in-patients. Dedicated fever clinics are being set up to screen people.
