People who qualify under the criteria for tests will enter via the drive-through, make payment as per government recommendations and then be tested,” Reddy said.Reddy added more than 50% Covid-19 positive cases need only isolation and symptomatic management. “Isolation is not possible in many Indian homes where 6-7 people share common accommodation and toilet. Soon, we will be launching “Project Stay I” to create medical rooms in hotels/hostels with light medical supervision for quarantine and creating a barrier before people come into the hospitals,” she said.The medical rooms will be rolled out in Chennai, Mumbai, Hyderabad, Kolkata, Bengaluru and Delhi, starting with approximately 50 in each city. They will go up by 50 rooms every three days, to reach an eventual target of 5,000 across the country, said Reddy.Preetha Reddy, vice-chairperson of Apollo, said preparations are on for the next stage of community transmission of the virus. “There will be over 250 beds, which can be enhanced to 500 beds, to treat the critically ill. We expect to give advanced care to over 2,000 patients a month.”Max Healthcare will begin admission of Covid-19 patients from Friday. The treatment will be available in specially designated isolation wards — east block of Max Super Speciality Hospital, Saket and Patparganj, said Dr Sandeep Budhiraja, group medical director, Max Healthcare. Max Labs will also begin testing for Covid-19 from samples collected from four units across Delhi-NCR, he added.“We will keep adding bed/wards in case there is a surge in the number of patients,” Dr Sanjay Mehta, unit head and vice-president of BLK said.Delhi has reported 39 cases of Covid-19 as on Thursday. Of this, state authorities said, 31 are admitted in various hospitals. “The total number of patients admitted till date is 156. Some of them were allowed to go home once the tests results came negative. Five people found positive have fully recovered,” said an official.

Title: 108 ambulance workers seek special benefits
Content:
Madurai: Ambulance workers, who play an integral role in the healthcare system, said they are yet to get any special benefits although the state government had recently announced one month special pay for doctors, nurses and sanitary workers for their efforts to prevent Covid-19 spread and treatment of patients.

“We are working tirelessly to help those in need. We are also facing so many difficulties with the lockdown and risking our lives to carry out our work during these difficult times. We are just as much as eligible like health workers and doctors to get special pay and benefits which would enhance our livelihoods,” president of 108 Ambulance Employees’ Welfare Association, M Irulandi said.

The association added that more than 2,000 ambulance workers from across Tamil Nadu had called the Amma Call Centre toll free number 1100 to register complaint demanding special pay.

Meanwhile, 108 ambulance authorities said that they are holding talks with the government regarding benefits for workers. “As of now, considering the lockdown situation, we are providing an additional payment of Rs 150 per day for all workers to buy food and groceries,” said an official.

Some workers claimed that they were not getting enough masks and protective wear. “We are only using whatever we were already given. They are telling us they will get us more masks and protective gear but keep on delaying. Superiors told us masks are in short supply so we need to wait,” said one of the workers.

However, authorities denied that there was any shortage in supply. “Stock availability is not an issue and we have already ordered for additional supplies too. We are facing few logistical issues since couriers stopped functioning so there could be delays. All workers mandatorily get masks and gloves. The workers of special ambulances designated for Covid-19 are also getting proper personal protective equipment kits,” the official said.

Title: Panic buying dips, ropes used to check overcrowding
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The common man has begun rewiring his daily routine to the rigours of the nation-wide lockdown. People seemed less nervy and tried to make regular purchases, picking up vegetables for daily use, unlike the previous two days.

Most residents in areas such as Maharanipeta and MVP did not purchase vegetables which could be stocked and instead focused on buying limited amounts of perishable vegetables.

P Govinda Rao, a vendor at the wholesale market, said: “This is probably because people have already stocked their pantries and fridges. However, by and large, the stockpiling has been limited to a few with a majority focusing on sensible purchasing.”

While social distancing was practiced across the city, wary shopkeepers came up with new ideas to keep anxious buyers out. Much like Wednesday, some shopkeepers drew boxes or circles outside the shop for buyers stand at a distance from one another. But on Thursday many shops were seen with ropes tied across their door frames to prevent buyers stepping inside the shop. Besides it also helped maintain the necessary distance.

The authorities too have done their bit to ensure that there was free flow of vegetables, indicating better coordination between revenue and law and order authorities.

L Shiva Shankar, joint collector, said that vendors and farmers were allowed to bring in vegetables.

Title: GJEPC contributes Rs 50cr for industry workers’ welfare
Content:
Surat: The Gem and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) has contributed Rs50 crore from its reserves to help industry workers impacted by the outbreak of COVID-19.

GJEPC chairman Pramod Kumar Agarwal said, “The GJEPC has decided to contribute Rs50 crore for the welfare of workers of the industry. The industry contributes 7% to India’s GDP and employs more than five million workforce.”

Agarwal added, “It becomes important to take adequate care of our employees and support them wholeheartedly at such a distressing time. We have braved many turmoils and it will be no different this time.”

GJEPC has appealed to all its members to take care of their employees during the lockdown period and demonstrate a united and humane approach towards them.

Sources said the fund allocated by GJEPC will be utilized to aid daily wage workers employed in gems and jewellery Industry whose livelihood is directly impacted by COVID-19 outbreak.

The contributed fund will also be used for funding specific initiatives undertaken by the government for the public at large in India to fight COVID- 19, such as creation of medical facility etc.

The GJEPC has formed a task force to decide on the modalities for utilization of Rs50 crores donated by it by identifying the industry needs and initiatives of the government.

GJEPC has urged all sections of the industry, trade bodies, organizations associated with gems and jewellery sector to come forward and replicate its efforts by generously donating to support the workers and the government in tackling the COVID-19 crisis.

GJEPC vice-chairman Colin Shah said, “We at GJEPC will leave no stone unturned in taking care of the industry workers.”

Title: Docs take up consultation via social media, ensure social distancing
Content:
Madurai: Doctors are finding ways to communicate with their patients using technology and social media during this period of social distancing, thereby ensuring that people are not unwontedly exposed to harm. They are monitoring patients, following up and also calming them down through video calls and chats.

Geriatrician Dr N Raja has started consulting his patients through video on WhatsApp . “I shut my clinic for consultation four days back after the Prime Minister ordered the country to go into lockdown. Soon after, I started anxious calls from my patients,” he said.

One of his patients who is undergoing treatment for rheumatoid arthritis wanted to know if it was safe to continue with his medication as he had read that it has side effects. “This is because the patient was overloaded with information on quinone, a name that has been making rounds since the (Covid-19) crisis started,” he said.

Another patients of his had read that the drugs he was taking for hypertension could make him susceptible to the deadly virus. “This is when I ask them to come on a video call and reassure them to take the drug for another month,” he said, adding that he and many other private practitioners do not want to expose patients to any unwanted infection, and hence suggested those on long term medication to continue for another month.

Gynaecologist Dr Revathy Janakiram said she was using social media to provide free consultation to keep them comfortable. “I have a staff nurse and an office assistant in my clinic in case there is an emergency delivery, otherwise I speak to them over WhatsApp, prescribe necessary medicines and follow up after six hours to know how they are doing,” she said. For now, her relief is that most of the deliveries of her patients are scheduled for the first week of April.

K M G Vivekanandham, 66, a patient, said consulting over the phone was a relief. “Being connected with your doctor at times like this is a boon as telephone consulting is the only solution here,” he said.

Dr Raja adds, “Most of my patients have ailments like diabetes and hypertension and many are equipped with devices to know their blood sugar levels and pressure. Hence, counselling them to continue with medication is not a problem. It is only people who do not have monitors that is a matter of concern.” Many private practitioners are also working round-the-clock, like the counterparts in government service, over the phone. “We cannot afford to ignore the calls, so have to answer them,” the doctors said.

Title: Bengaluru: Coronavirus victim was made to change three hospitals for ventilator
Content: BENGALURU: The death of a 70-year-old Covid-19 infected woman has raised questions about the city's preparedness, especially with regard to ventilators.In less than 48 hours, she was shifted to three different hospitals: the district hospital in Chikkaballapur Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases in Bengaluru and then to Bowring & Lady Curzon hospital, all for a ventilator. She died Tuesday midnight and three medical staff at Bowring hospital who treated her are now in home isolation. It’s the first Covid-19 death in Bengaluru.Sources privy to the case said, “There are not enough ventilators in the city, and the health community is worried. There is no clarity about what led to her death. Was it late diagnosis or shortage of ventilators? She developed acute respiratory distress. The woman’s son, who has also been quarantined, expressed his helplessness at having to take her from one hospital to another,” sources said.K Sudhakar, medical education minister and in-charge of Covid-19 matters, said she was shifted from RGICD as all beds there were occupied.Currently, there are not more than 2000 ventilators in the state and half are in Bengaluru. RGICD director Dr C Nagaraja was unavailable for comment about ventilators.

Title: MLA hits road to spray disinfectants in Jaipur
Content: JAIPUR: Congress chief whip Mahesh Joshi, who has the status of a cabinet minister, was seen spraying disinfectants in his constituency areas of the city on Thursday.The gesture was hailed by locals who saw their leader among the frontline people battling the spread of Covid-19.Joshi and his son reached Shubash Chowk area with portable spray machines. Pictures of Joshi were also pasted on the spraying machines, which his supporters were hanging on their shoulders. However , the move was criticised by many officials as residents have to maintain social distancing.A JMC official said, “Though supporters of the leaders were wearing masks, but many people gathered, which is wrong. The JMC staff was also deployed in the area on the directions of the leader.”Taking an initiative to disinfect public areas, transport minister Pratap Singh also inspected the areas and monitored the drive where sodium hypochlorite was sprayed. The state has deployed 17 fire tenders and 2 vehicle mounted machines to disinfect the public areas. A total of 120 teams have been constituted to carry out the driveOfficial source said calls to JMC for disinfectant spraying have multiplied from various localities as the number of coronavirus positive cases was on the rise. In fact, gated societies which would routinely refuse inspections by JMC teams earlier are allowing uninhibited access now for spraying, sources said.The teams in the city have begun spraying localities where there is a possibility of Covid-19 spread including Walled City areas.

Title: Two Thai preachers test negative
Content:
Two preachers from Thailand who had been in contact with the man from Anna Nagar in Madurai , who tested positive for Covid-19 and died on Wednesday, continue to be in the isolation ward at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH). However, the first samples of the two preachers tested negative for Covid-19.

This has raised another question as to how the man from Madurai, who was in contact with them tested positive, when the preachers have tested negative. Sources said that there are chances that some people who had been in the group went to other parts of the state.

Meanwhile, the total number of people in the isolation ward in the GRH was seven on Thursday.

According to Madurai district collector Dr TG Vinay, the increase in number was because the authorities have identified people who had been in contact with the victim. Earlier only people who had travelled to the seven notified countries were taken into account. But now everybody who had travelled overseas between March 1 and March 23 are being quarantined as a precaution. Among the quarantined cases are 1,350 from the rural area and 2,275 from urban limits taking the total to 3,625.

Meanwhile in Kanyakuamari , a 40-year-old man, who recently returned from Kuwait and was admitted to Kanyakumari Government Medical College Hospital with suspected symptoms of Covid-19, died on Thursday.

However, his samples had tested negative for Covid-19. “Samples taken from five people admitted to Kanyakumari MCH with suspected Covid-19 symptoms, including the Kuwait returnee, tested negative on Thursday,” said health officials.

In Tirunelveli district , the 43-year-old Covid-19 positive patient continues to undergo treatment at the isolation ward in Tirunelveli Medical College Hospital. A 72-year-old man has also been admitted to the isolation ward with suspected Covid-19 symptoms. Meanwhile, officials said that a total of 2,117 people were home quarantined in the district as of Thursday.

Title: Lockdown poses problem for pet owners in city
Content:
Pune: The coronavirus lockdown has posed a problem for those who have pets at home.

Many people said that they were unable to take their dogs out for walks or defecation, while others said finding food, essentials and veterinarian services was a huge problem.

The situation has remained unchanged despite the exemption granted to veterinarians and pet stores by the Union home ministry through a notification.

Purva Sankhla, a resident of Satara Road, said, “There is certainly a problem with regards to supply of dog essentials in the market. Pet stores in our area are closed. I even checked online, but e-commerce sites are only supplying essential commodities, which do not include dog food.”

Lyla Cama, an NIBM Road resident and a dog trainer, said, “Finding dog food has become a major challenge. All the pet stores in my area are closed and deliveries are not taking place. Delivery boys from a pet store in Aundh were beaten up by the police. I will have to drive all the way to Aundh on Friday to get food for my dog. I am planning to pick up over 15kg of dog food as many people from my area have been calling me for the same.”

Shilpi Hisariya Khemka, owner of a pet shop Hadapsar, said people indulged in bulk buying when the 21-day lockdown was announced. “We are selling whatever stock we have in hand, but new supplies are not coming in. My customers call me in advance, and I give them the time when they can visit to make purchases. I open the store for only 30-45 minutes daily,” she said.

Prathamesh Gaikar, another pet shop owner in Baner, said that he has been getting orders for at least 30 deliveries daily as many shops are shut. My shop has run out of stuff, but I am getting stock picked up from warehouses. Some dog food brands have depots in Pune but are facing difficulty with logistics. While stock is available for one to two months in Pune, it is not reaching shops and customers due to staff crunch and other logistical issues,” he said.

He further added that he is delivering only pet food and some essentials like medicated shampoos. “We have told people that we will not deliver toys and treats as these are not essentials. We are also urging people to buy food that will last for a month. If people start hoarding, no stock will be left in the city,” he added.

Pet shop owners stated that maximum demand for pet food is from people who feed stray dogs and animals. Cama said, “Restaurants, shops and all other establishments are shut, and strays are not getting food and water. Dog food brands have provided stock to organisations to feed strays, but people are not allowed to get out. Something needs to be done to ensure that even stray animals are fed well.”

Graphic:

Pet care during lockdown

- If society is big, walk dogs only on society premises. If outdoors, walk only a short distance so that dogs can pee or poop

- Make sure to clean the poop

- Clean paws of dogs with a sanitizer after walks

- Do not visit pet shops or veterinarians unless there is an emergency

- If dogs can’t be taken outdoors, find games to play with them indoors

- Play sniffing and mentally demanding games with dogs - 15 minutes of cognitive or sniffing activity is equivalent to an hour of physical activity

(Source Veterinarian Milind Mhatre and dog trainer Lyla Cama)

Title: Push cart vendors in Vizianagaram to carry IDs, banners
Content:
The Vizianagaram administration has decided to allow sale of vegetables and essentials through push carts and ... Read More

VIZIANAGARAM: The Vizianagaram administration has decided to allow sale of vegetables and essentials through push carts and mobile vans. The decision was taken during a meet at the collectorate here on Thursday.

The administration has also decided to relocate three rythu bazaars to Ayodhya Maidan, Rajiv Gandhi Stadium and Bonkula Dibba, which are open grounds.

Talking to TOI, district collector M Jawahar Lal said: “We are taking this option mainly because vegetables have to be sold quickly, the farmers and vendors cannot take back their stock. However, we are doing this within the confines of the lockdown rules.”

Vizianagaram Marketing additional director, Shyam Kumar, said: “In many rythu bazaars we cannot accommodate all the customers and vendors at once. Moreover, in most of the bazaars vendors share shop space, in such a scenario we need to control the customer flow and practise social distancing.”

GC Kishore Kumar , Vizianagaram district joint collector, said: “During the meet it has been decided to relocate and rehabilitate small vendors by allowing them to set up shop in colonies, where no major markets are available and allow sale of essentials and vegetables by push carts and vans in colonies. We are relocating many of the small vendors from the fort area to new colonies. As for the push carts and vendors, they will have to carry a banner and ID papers to ensure that they are properly identified.”

Title: HC asks TN to consider plea on creating posts in med college hosps
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has directed the state government to consider a representation on a plea moved by seven people to finalize the proposal regarding creation of emergency care technician posts’ in government medical college hospitals in the state.

The petitioners have completed certificate course for the post of emergency care technicians from 2005 onwards. According to the petitioners, they are well trained in handling both surgical and medical emergencies such as handling high-end mechanical ventilators, dialysis machine, multipara monitor, ECG, nebulization machine, plasmapheresis . The petitioners are continuously requesting the state government to create such posts as it would create employment opportunity to people like them.

Based on the request of the petitioners, the secretary to the government of health and family welfare department in his proceedings on January 30, 2019 had forwarded a proposal to the director of medical education to ascertain the need for creation of such posts in all medical colleges.

In response to the same, the director of medical education has issued a proceedings seeking for a proposal regarding creation of such posts.

Though the petitioners have sent a representation to the authorities seeking to finalize the proposal for creation of the posts, no steps were taken. Hence, the petitioners moved the high court Madurai bench.

Hearing the plea, justice J Nisha Banu observed that by considering the limited prayer sought for in this petition, the state government is directed to dispose of the representation submitted by the petitioners by taking note of the proceedings of the director of medical education.

Title: Cops thrash health worker; vandalize 2 grocery shops
Content:
Pilibhit: A private health worker, Rajiv Kumar, 35, of Behta village under Bilsanda police station was allegedly beaten up by a group of constables out to enforce the lockdown on Thursday. The man was on his way to his clinic for work.

A group of policemen from the same station also allegedly vandalized two grocery shops for being open at 9.30 am. All grocery shops across the district have been allowed to be open between 7 am and 10 am every day so that residents can purchase essential items. However, the police team ignored the order to the effect by DM Vaibhav Shrivastav.

According to Kumar, a compounder employed at the clinic of Dr Manmeet Gupta, he was on way to work when he was stopped by a police team at around 10 am when people are allowed to go out to purchase essentials. He claimed he was stopped by a woman constable, Chanchal Bhatia, and was allegedly beaten up for “breaking lockdown rule”.

“I told the constable the name of the clinic and asked her to verify the same by calling up the clinic but she beat me up,” claimed Kumar. He did not have any document to prove his claim. He allegedly sustained a minor fracture due to the beating.

Two grocery shop owners also accused police of “tyranny” in the name of the lockdown. Both shop owners, Mukesh Gupta and Neelesh Gupta, alleged that group of policemen barged into their shops and vandalized it. They were abused, the owners claimed.

When asked, Abhishek Dixit, superintendent of police, said he would order an inquiry into the matter and take appropriate action if the complaints were found to be true.

Title: 400 more vehicles to supply vegetables
Content:
Ahmedabad: The civic body will put 400 more vehicles into distribution of food and provisions in residential societies and slums alike from Friday onwards.

After an encouraging response to the vegetables vans, Ahmedabad municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra said that 250 extra autorickshaws including loading rickshaws have been pressed into service. Nearly 48 medium-sized commercial vehicles including trucks will be hired for Amul milk distribution, mainly milk tetra packs. There will also be five large trucks that will take vegetables to slum areas and will provided vegetables for free. “Beginning Friday 20,000 food packets will be distributed to the homeless via 96 autorickshaws. The volume of food and distribution of provisions will be scaled up further in the coming days as and when more vehicles are pressed into service,” Nehra said.

Title: Select shops to deliver groceries at doorstep
Content:
Madurai: The best thing that the district administrations can do to prevent people from crowding in shops is to ensure door delivery of goods, and they are taking steps to ensure the same.

A shopkeeper at Anna Nagar in Madurai said that they were finding it difficult to supply goods owing to the panic buying, as people used to buy essential commodities in large quantities. Now, the corporation has enlisted shops, which could deliver goods, and also roped in volunteers to deliver goods.

Sugumar of K K Nagar said that he thought of doing something useful for the society in the crisis and approached shops to deliver goods. It is only if they have an ID and a local address. This was made mandatory because only people having ID’s given by the corporation authorities could deliver goods. Kumar, a shopkeeper, says that they may approach more volunteers if the situation demands.

A few customers are asking for bulk orders for apartments, and in that case auto rickshaws are being roped in for home delivery. The customer would have to pay the auto charge in addition to the price of the goods. All these operations are expected to begin on Friday, according to corporation sources. But, all delivery personnel will have to wear masks and gloves. Vehicles used for delivery would have to be disinfected.

Dindigul district collector M Vijayalakshmi has said that four markets would be set up at Palani Road Lorry Terminal, Mettupati ground, Nagal Nagar Bharathipuram Market and SMPM School near the Round Road for the convenience of people. These markets would start functioning from March 27. People from villages can also make use of these markets.

The district administration has also put out a list of whatsapp numbers, which will help public get their grocery delivered at their doorsteps to ensure that they did not crowd in the shops. Shops have been identified to be common for many wards of the Dindigul Corporation. For example the Kannan Departmental Store with the whatsapp number 8489943093, could be useful to the people living in ward numbers 1 to 5, 36 to 40, villages under Settiyanayakkampatti panchayat and N S Nagar.

Such arrangements have been made for all the 48 wards in the Dindigul Corporation. She has said that all the vehicles to be used for home delivery would be disinfected and the delivery personnel equipped with protective gear.

Tuticorin and Tirunelveli district administrations have also made similar arrangements. In Tirunelveli, people can order from Pothy’s Super Market, Big Bazaar and Reliance Shop, between 9am and 4pm. Rs 25 would be added as delivery charge to each delivery, Tirunelveli corporation has said.

Title: Taskforce to map and scout for tech, solutions
Content: Bengaluru: The department of science and technology (DST) is coordinating efforts to upscale appropriate technologies and manufacturing in India to address a plethora of issues related to the outbreak. It is also scouting for new and developing solutions more relevant to India to help prepare for exigencies arising from the pandemic.“DST has set up a Covid-19 taskforce which will map technologies from R&D labs, academic institutions, startups, and MSMEs to fund nearly market-ready solutions in the area of diagnostics, testing, healthcare delivery solutions, equipment supplies,” DST said.Some of these solutions, besides others, include masks and other protective gear, sanitisers, affordable kits for screening, ventilators and oxygenators, data analytics to track, monitor and control the spread of outbreak through AI and IOT based solutions.DST said the taskforce will identify the most promising startups that are close to scale up and chip in with financial or other help or connections to rapidly scale up. It said nodal officers of concerned ministries and departments have been requested to personally expedite the process to obtain information on such startups and other entities.Towards this end, DST has already invited two separate sets of proposals -- one each under Science & Engineering Research Board (SERB) and Technology Development Board (TDB) -- to support scientific solutions and commercial manufacturing of both new and existing solutions.The capacity mapping group includes representatives from DST, department of biotechnology, Indian Council for Medical Research, ministry of electronics and information technology, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Atal Innovation Mission, ministry of micro, small and medium enterprises, Startup India and All India Council for Technical Education.

Title: Corona threat: No ICU, ventilator at Rampur district hospital
Content:
Rampur: At a time when covid-19 threat looming large over the country and as many as 40 people have been tested positive for the deadly virus in UP, Rampur district hospital doesn’t have even an intensive care unit (ICU) and a ventilator to tackle an emergency case.

Moreover, the posts of physicians and cardiologists have been lying vacant at the hospital since long. The hospital also needs protective kits for the doctors and nurses working at the isolation ward, where suspected and confirmed cases are quarantined.

Covid-19 virus targets lungs and causes acute respiratory distress in the patient, who immediately needs ventilator for his survival. However, no positive case has so far been reported in the district.

Speaking with TOI, Rampur district magistrate Aunjaneya Kumar Singh said, “We have sent a request to the state government in this regard. We need 3,000 protective kits. A general kit costs around Rs 1,000, while special kits for the ICU cost Rs 5,000 each.”

According to the DM, they have the required funds with them to buy kits, but under the prevailing circumstances, the demands for the kits are very high and there is a shortage in the market. “However, the district hospital will get some kits soon.”

Chief medical officer (CMO ), Rampur district hospital, Dr Subodh Sharma said, "At present, the district has only three ventilators functioning at a private hospital in Bilaspur thesil, while we don't have an ICI and the ventilator facility available at the district hospital.”

The CMO also confirmed that the hospital did not have a physician and a cardiologist, at present. "In case of emergency, we will hire private doctors,” said Dr Sharma.

Meanwhile, Social Service Council chairman and former OSD of the Uttar Pardesh Minority Commission Shahab Malik said, "It’s a matter of grave concern. Rampur district has a sizeable population of more than 23 lakh (according to the 2011 census), but the district hospital doesn’t have a ventilator and the ICU. Despite the outbreak of coronavirus, the government hospital is not equipped to tackle any emergency situation. We are sending an email to Union health minister Harshvardhan, requesting him to provide ventilators and other essential medical equipment to the Rampur district hospital as early as possible."

Title: Confusion order of day as Goa citizens hunt for essentials
Content:
Curfew in Goa

MARGAO: Day two of the lockdown in the state was marked with pronounced confusion. While the authorities failed to make any arrangements to ensure availability of daily essentials, like milk and groceries, the few departmental stores and grocery shops that had made announcements of home delivery failed to honour their commitments as they couldn’t obtain curfew passes to make the necessary logistical arrangements.

Some adventurous vegetable vendors, who had kept their stalls open in the Gandhi market in Margao on Thursday morning did some brisk business before lathi-wielding cops descended on the market and thrashed the vendors, forcing people who had come to the market to beat a hasty retreat.

“As I had failed to stock on groceries, I found this morning that I had completely run out of rice. I rushed to the market, but found everything closed. I chanced upon an open grocery shop only to be told by the owner that he had opened it to take some groceries home and would sell none of it. On being told about my predicament, he was kind enough to oblige me,” Edgar Fernandes from Borda in Margao told TOI.

Those who opted to try out the home delivery offer by super stores and grocery shops were also left disappointed. “I tried their number several times, but nobody answered. Just when I was about to give up, somebody answered and told me that they were helpless in doing home delivery of goods as they were unable to get curfew passes for movement of vehicles,” a resident of Comba in Margao said.

At the milk booths, as people resorted to panic buying, the stock soon got over, leaving many to make do without milk for the day. Similar was the case with bread supplies at bakeries.

Title: Unseasonal showers drench parts of Ahmedabad
Content: Ahmedabad: Heavy showers accompanied by thunder hit many areas in the city from Ashram Road to Bopal, Ghuma, and Shela on Thursday night. The IMD Ahmedabad on Thursday evening predicted unseasonal weather conditions for the next four days in various regions of Gujarat.On Friday, light to moderate rain or thundershower is likely at a few places in the districts of Ahmedabad, Gandhinagar, Banaskantha, Sabarkantha, Kheda, Dahod, Mahisagar, Aravalli, Surat, Vadodara and Anand. Similar weather is expected in Jamnagar, Botad, Morbi, Surendranagar, Bhavnagar, Amreli, Gir-Somnath, Junagadh, and Kutch districts.On Saturday, light to moderate rain is likely at isolated places in Chhota Udepur, Narmada, and Dahod. On Sunday, similar weather is likely in districts such as Surat, Panchmahal, Dahod, Anand and Kheda and in Saurashtra in districts such as Dwarka, Porbandar, Bhavnagar, Amreli, Gir-Somnath and Kutch. On Monday, light to moderate rain is expected at isolated places in Banaskantha, Sabarkantha, Mehsana, and Patan.

Title: Lekhpal suspended, booked for refusing to join duty in lockdown
Content:
Rampur: A Milak thesil lekhpal has been suspended and booked after he allegedly refused to join his duty during the covid-19 pandemic, which has been declared as a disaster by the UP government.

Following a complaint lodged by tehsildar Bimal Kumar Shukl, Milak police registered an FIR against Sumit Saxena under relevant sections of the Disaster Management Act.

Meanwhile, Rampur district magistrate Aunjaneya Kumar Singh warned, “Stringent action will be taken against those government officials who refused to work during the lockdown.”

Title: Convoy system for essential goods
Content: Hyderabad: To ensure uninterrupted supply of essential goods like edible oil, which is not produced in the state, the Telangana government is working with authorities of other states like Andhra Pradesh and companies to implement a convoy system, industries principal secretary Jayesh Ranjan told TOI. TNN

Title: 350 inmates of Burail jail may get parole
Content: CHANDIGARH: In the wake of pandemic outbreak of coronavirus , nearly 30-35% prisoners, or close to 350 inmates, of the Burail Model Jail here are likely to be given the benefit of parole to decongest the jails.A high-powered committee headed by executive chairman of the District Legal Services Authority (DLSA) Justice Jaswant Singh, and comprising principal secretary, home department Arun Kumar Gupta, and prisons IG Om Veer Singh, has decided that in line with the Supreme Court’s directive, convicts could be given the benefit of parole and the undertrials, interim bails.It has also been decided that a special jail Lok Adalat would be held within a week, after which the undertrials, who have already spent a considerable time behind bars, and those serving jail terms for petty crimes, would be released. The entire process is set to be executed within a week. Also, at the time of issuing parole and while readmitting the convicts in jail, their medical test would be conducted.Under normal circumstances, parole period is of 45 days, but under the current special circumstances, the period has been extended to 60 days. If need arises, it could be extended further.The capacity of Burail jail 1,120 and the current number of prisoners there is also to its strength. Out of these, 420 are convicts, 583 undertrials and four children.The high-powered committee has decided that out of the 420 convicts, around 261 convicts have never availed parole and it is expected that 40-50% or 100 to 120 of them, would be given parole benefit. Similarly, 80-85% of the 146 convicts, who have already availed parole earlier and their report is positive, would also be given the benefit. However, seven 7 convicts, who have a history of jumping parole, would not get this benefit. Also, 6 foreign nationals would also not get the parole benefit, while the duration of 14 convicts, who are already out on parole, would be extended.There are 583 undertrials in Burail jail, out of whom 146 are identified as ones who could be given interim bail. Their counsels would file applications in the court, which the duty magistrate would decide via videoconferencing. For the rest of undertrails, who have already undergone their jail terms and those with petty crimes, could be released after the jail Lok Adalat is held.DLSA executive chairman justice Jaswant Singh said, “As per the direction of Supreme Court, benefit of parole is to be given to the convicts. The purpose is to decongest jails so that social distancing could be implemented there. If need arises, the parole period could be extended as well.”As far as the process of release on parole is concerned, DLSA member secretary Ashok Kumar Mann said the district magistrate after getting report from the jail superintendent and the SSP would issue release orders.

Title: Yes! I am back: First positive patient returns home after defeating Covid-19
Content:
Nagpur: The software professional who was discharged from the isolation ward of Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) said that the last 14 days were tough, but he rediscovered himself during this period.

“Yes! I am back,” said the 45-year-old, who happens to be the first patient in Central India to test positive for Covid-19, and eventually the first who recovered.

“We need tonnes and tonnes of positivity at this point of time. Bombard it. Ours is a great nation,” he exclaimed when asked about his first reaction after homecoming. He also expects that his wife, who is recovering from Covid-19 at GMCH, will return home by Saturday.

While it was an important development for Vidarbha, authorities kept it low-key, respecting the privacy of the patient and his family. An ambulance of IGGMC drove him to his house. His mother welcomed him in a traditional manner with aarti and applied tilak on his forehead as he stepped into the house.

His 14-year-old daughter had drawn a beautiful ‘rangoli’ at the main entrance door of the house. The rangoli showed a pair of boxing gloves fighting against the invisible coronavirus. She wrote two words — Fighter and Champion in praise of her father. “I am overwhelmed, short of words,” he said after seeing the rangoli.

The patient, as he earlier told TOI, kept himself busy in reading and thinking positive. As he is a believer in god, he used to read Shrimad Bhagwad Gita regularly. He has done a lot of spiritual thinking and now plans to write a book to inspire others to fight Covid-19.

“I will share exactly what I learnt during my experience in the 14-day isolation with Corona. I realized that there is a hierarchy of power. Body or physical strength comes at the lowest level of this hierarchy,” he said. According to his thinking, body, mind, intellect, soul and finally god are the right hierarchy of power.

“For body, you need to keep your temperature in control, which is quite easy. For mind, you have to resolve that you are going to fight. For intellect, you need to trust doctors’ knowledge. For soul, you must keep telling yourself that you are beyond all these sufferings. And finally, the super power is god, for which you must believe that god is with me all the time,” he said.

As common people are also observing the 21-day home quarantine-like situation due to lockdown, this man has a message for all of them. “If I can stay calm and composed in one room of the hospital for 14 days, you all are in your own houses, with your loved ones around you. What is the problem? Just be with your family, pray for all, and take care of yourself,” he quipped.

Title: Amid corona crisis, central railway exceeds revenue target
Content:
Nagpur: With closure of passenger train operations due to coronavirus, there has been a spurt in freight train movement and the Central Railway is working 24X7 to ensure uninterrupted supply of essential commodities, with coal loading of 190 rakes in the last four days.

Nagpur Division of Central Railway alone loaded 137 coal rakes from March 21-25, supplying 5,08,712.20 tonnes coal and generating a revenue of Rs46.45 crore. Besides, 12 container rakes were also loaded, earning Rs1.52 crore.

Freight movement has been quick, though number of rakes that have been moving are as usual between 28 and 32 per day. Even railway minister Piyush Goyal has lauded Nagpur division for speedy coal supplies to power plants despite lockdown.

Despite Central Railway releasing a refund of over Rs10.27 crore to over 1.69 lakh passengers due to cancellation of trains between March 1 and 21, the achievement of revenue target has come as a silver lining.

A delighted Somesh Kumar, DRM, Central Railway, has thanked SrDCM Krishnath Patil and SrDOM Ashutosh Shrivastava and other branch heads for dedicated efforts to boost loadings.

“A 4pm on Thursday, we crossed last financial year’s earnings of Rs3,076.73 crore with five days left for current financial year to end. Nagpur has earned Rs3,078.73 crore this financial year (2019-20). In the next 5 days we expect to earn Rs60 crore,” said railway spokesperson & ACM (Goods) SG Rao.

“We are making all out efforts to ensure availability of essential commodities through its uninterrupted freight services. During the situation of lockdown in various states, Central Railway deployed staff at various goods sheds, stations and control offices, and is working to ensure that supply of essential items for the nation does not get affected,” said chief public relations officer (CPRO) Shivaji Sutar.

Sutar said the total tonnage of all the freight during the four days (March 22-25) is approximately 5.66 lakh tonnes. In terms of wagons, it is 9,837 wagons. Coal was the bulk one which was loaded for power plants at Parli, Nashik, Paras, Koradi and Mouda in Maharashtra, and Sarani and Singaji in MP.

Sutar says petrol , oil and lubricants (POL) and LPG was carried in 17 rakes for supply to various destinations like Gaigaon, Khapri, Tadali etc. Bhusawal alone carried 13 rakes. It also operated one full rake of onions.

Out of 57 rakes of container traffic, Mumbai alone accounted for 46 rakes. All the 6 rakes of fertilizer originated from Mumbai Division dispatched to northern and southern parts of India. Freight movement is being closely monitored by officials at very senior level. “Central Railway understands its crucial role during this difficult time and requests all the stakeholders to fully support in this endeavour,” he added.

Railway trackmen get masks, sanitizers

Even as coronavirus scare continues, trackmen have geared up for zero missing fittings, immediate rail replacements at Butibori, Bharatwada and Borkhedi yard. They have been counselled on safety precautions and onus of maintaining tracks following goods traffic. Hand-wash , mask and sanitizers were issued on Thursday. These gangmen were scanned with thermal gun. Social distancing while working in gang during work and lunch time is being ensured. “Gang staff is staggered to facilitate personal safety and safety of train running,” said ACM Rao.

Title: Visakhapatnam: Lockdown Disrupts Supply Of Essentials
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: Although the government has exempted essential goods and their delivery through e-commerce from the lockdown, shopkeepers are still finding it difficult to acquire stock. When TOI visited a few supermarkets and department stores, it was learnt that pulses, cereals and other essential commodities were out of stock.“The scarcity is due to two reasons: shortage of staff and restrictions on traffic movement. Although we have enough stock at our warehouse, there are neither people at the backend nor there are staff to load the stock. Hence, most of the commodities like rava, oil, pulses, cereals, biscuits and dairy products were out of stock on Thursday,” a senior store manager of MORE supermarket said adding that it has become difficult to procure vegetables and fruits from other cities due to traffic restrictions.The same is plight of e-commerce platforms. Since crowded areas are to be avoided, many opted to place orders online through various applications like Bigbasket, Amazon and Flipkart. But most of the e-commerce portals have stopped delivery.P Asha, a homemaker, said, “I need wheat flour. Although I ordered online, my order was cancelled. Moreover, when I went to check at the supermarket, they said it is out of stock and could not say when stocks would arrive. My father’s medicines that I ordered online have also not arrived yet.”However, the picture is slightly different with local e-commerce portals like Do Ghante, Farm 19, etc. D Srinivas, director of Do Ghante, said, “We are getting many orders, but due to time contraints and travel restrictions, we are unable to reach out to the people. There are many people who are old and scared to visit markets. Hence, we approached the district administration to allow home delivery of essential commodities.”Speaking to TOI, Ranga Reddy, DCP (law and order), said, “We have taken this matter to the district administration and discussed it with the police officials. People who wish to home deliver essential commodities need to make an ID card with their name, registered e-commerce portal and mention home delivery in the card. This card needs to be submitted to the police and a list will be prepared. Only then they will be allowed to home deliver. If the ID card is genuine, deliveries can be done from 6 am to 6 pm.”

Title: Get essentials, medicines at your doorstep in Jaipur
Content: JAIPUR: Many departmental stores, pharmacies , retailers and online grocery stores in coordination with the district administration will deliver essential items and medicines to every household in the city, while some having begun delivering on Thursday.The collector held a meeting with representatives of D-Mart, Reliance, Metro Mas, Swiggy, PharmEasy, Kirana King and Big Bazaar. Representatives of the firms said the services would be smooth after labour passes are issued by the police stations. D-Mart has launched a mobile app and created a WhatsApp group. Reliance Fresh has also started a WhatsApp group and will go door-to-door to deliver the items. A public address system will be installed on vehicles of the stores and they will use it to make announcements and ask people if they need essential items. Collector Joga Ram said, “We held meetings with a few companies which are engaged in online home deliveries. Some of them have already agreed.”“If a family or any person orders essential items through the D-Mart app, the items will be delivered to their houses. Reliance Fresh has also started door-to-door delivery of items,” said SDM Jaipur Yugantar Sharma. “We instructed them that they should fix standard rates for the items and if there is any disruption with regard to supply of items, we assured them of easing out the supply through coordination,” he added.Many trade unions and retailers pledged that will not let the supply reduce. They also urged traders to supply items at a low cost. A WhatsApp group of service providers have been made to keep the supply line open and to resolve any problem. Teams have been formed for speedy action on plaints of overcharging. On the collector's recommendation, wheat up to 10 metric tons will be made available to the traders at Rs 23 by the Food Corporation of India. The collector visited Ajmer Road, Tonk Road, Sanganer, SMS Medical College, JLN Marg, Khasa Koti bus stand, Jhotwara, Gandhi Path, Mansarovar Metro Station and Jharkhand Mod on Thursday to check if the food items and dry ration were provided to migrant labourers and the poor in the city.

Title: Beijing blocks UNSC meet on coronavirus
Content: NEW DELHI: China blocked a discussion in the UN Security Council on the coronavirus pandemic sweeping the world, sought earlier this week by Estonia, in a sign that reflects the limitations of the apex body of global governance to debate the burning issues of the day.Estonia, which is a nonpermanent member, had asked for a meeting on the pandemic last week. The document stressed the “growing concern about the unprecedented extent of the Covid-19 outbreak in the world, which may constitute a threat to international peace and security.”The proposal, however, did not go far, with both China and Russia nixing the idea. Sources said it did not appear as if the P-5 were overly keen to hold a meeting on a subject that is devastating countries and the global economy, virtually without any early end in sight.Some reports said the Estonian proposal called for “transparency” which China was reportedly unwilling to address. Beijing has been facing a volley of alle gations that it hid the incidence of the highly infectious coronavirus for over a month before reporting cases of unexplained pneumonia in Wuhan in late 2019. While the UN stonewalled a discussion when the G-20 leaders sat down on Thursday for a unique virtual summit, there was no questioning for transparency or origin of the virus.Official sources said the conversation was collaborative and cooperative, which means the US and China may have put their mutual acrimony behind for the moment. In 2015, the Security Council did hold a similar meeting when the Ebola virus was a looming threat, particularly to UN missions in Africa But this time it’s different. Not only is China the source of the pandemic, the US-China rivalry is playing out in the background as well with President Donald Trump insisting on referring to the disease as ‘China virus’. According to recent reports, the UN Security Council has not met since March 12. Calls for virtual UNSC meetings in the era of social distancing and lockdowns have also found no merit with either China or Russia.

Title: Day 2 a bit better but more complaints in Chandigarh
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: On the second day of the national lockdown, door-to-door delivery of milk, vegetables, grocery and medicines saw an improvement in the city, but residents complained of high prices of vegetables and limited stock with grocers.

The Chandigarh administration has not planned any kind of relaxation and will stick to door-to-door delivery of essential items. About the arrangements, UT administrator VP Singh Badnore said quarantining was more important than essential items. He said he would daily make rounds of different areas of the city and the residents need to show some patience as the system would be 100% in place in a day or two.

Badnore, who flagged off CTU buses from Sector 26 mandi to different areas of the city for door-to-door delivery of vegetables, said he and his team of officers have assessed the issues that need to be resolved. “By Friday, most of the issues will be sorted out by the UT administration,” he assured.

UT adviser Manoj Parida, who also took rounds of different sectors, said, “Is it fair to expect normalcy in abnormal times? Residents must show some patience. We are constantly trying to improve efficiency of the door-to-door delivery system in the city.”

However, the residents complained of high prices of vegetables delivered door-to-door by vendors in CTU buses. Raju, a resident of Sector 44-C, said the vendor sold peas at Rs 100 per kg and tomato and cucumber at Rs 60 per kg, which were available between Rs 30 and Rs 40 per kg last week. No public announcement was made by vendors and officials. There was a huge rush of residents, which defeated the purpose of social distancing, he added.

Echoing a similar view, Pooja of Sector 45-C said there was around half-a-kilometre queue in front of the CTU bus to buy vegetables. She did not buy any as she did not want to put her and her family’s life at risk by going into the rush. People were not maintaining proper distance and some were even without masks, she added.

Milk and newspaper supply also witnessed an improvement. But the residents complained of switched off numbers of grocery stores. A grocer said he had received around 500 calls since morning and his stock was finished within three hours. As there was no stock left, he preferred to switch off his phone.

“The administration should improve the wholesale supply of grocery items as only then we will be able to sell those to customers in retail. We have limited staff to provide home delivery,” he added.

Medicine supply improves

The UT administration released numbers of chemists in various sectors for home delivery of medicines. However, the residents demanded that more chemist shops be given permission. Harjeet Singh Sandhu , State Transport Authority (STA) secretary who is the nodal officer for supplying medicines, said they were planning to open more chemist shops in the coming days.

UT creates corona fund

The UT administrator announced the creation of “Chandigarh Fights Corona Fund” and contributed Rs 1 lakh. The fund will be used to fight Covid-19 in Chandigarh. Any person who intends to contribute can deposit the money either through cheque or through online banking with the Indian Red Cross Society , UT, Chandigarh bank account. Bank details are as follows:

Name: Indian Red Cross Society , UT, Chandigarh; bank: Central Bank of India , Sector 17-B, Chandigarh; address SCO 68-69, Bank Square, Sector-17 B, Chandigarh; account number: 3578152035; IFSC code CBIN0280412; MICR code 160016002

Admn to set up SRTs

UT has decided to set up sector response teams (SRTs) consisting of officials, who will address the grievances of people in their areas. People will be able to consult them and the SRTs will coordinate between them and the administration, besides the control rooms in the municipal commissioner’s office/deputy commissioner’s office, among others, and ensure that the supply chain is maintained. The names and contact information of the nodal officers of the SRTs has been uploaded on the website of the Chandigarh administration.

Ration in mobile vans

UT adviser Manoj Parida said talks were on with Markfed and Hafed to operate mobile vans in the city to provide ration at reasonable rates. He appealed to the residents to avail facility of three mobile ATMs arranged for the city.

Title: Milk powder, baby food off shelves in Jaipur
Content: JAIPUR: Milk powder and baby food were off the shelves of most kirana (grocery) stores in and around the city. Shopkeepers say most of the people have hoarded cartons of milk powder and baby food fearing that pasteurized milk will not be available in the market following the lockdown. They also say there are no labourers and transport to deliver the essential items like milk powder, baby food and tetra packs of various kinds of milkThey say, while liquid milk/saras milk packets are available in the market, due to disruption in supply by the distributors, milk powder is not available."Milk powder is not available in the market for the past five days. There is no supply at all. People have hoarded packets and packets of milk powder over the last few days. We are hoping the crisis will get over in a day or two as the supply chain restores. Wheat (atta) and rice were also not available, but we have got these items today," said a shopkeeper of Kushal grocery store in Raja Park.A shopkeeper at Bees Dukan in Adarsh Nagar said, “You will not find milk powder anywhere across the city. Fearing that pasteurized milk or saras milk will not be available following lockdown, people have stocked huge amount of milk powder packets. But, see, there is no shortage of pasteurized milk in the market.”Another shopkeeper at Ashoka Store said, "The milk powder used for feeding the kids is available but not the ones used for making tea and coffee. There are no laborers and transport to deliver the essential items to the retailers. It is expected that the supply of these items will resume soon.”Meanwhile, collector Joga Ram, said, “We received complaints from a few retailers about interruption in the supply of various items. We had a meeting with the wholesalers, associations for the distribution of various essential items and sabzi mandi associations. They have been directed to ensure there is no disruption in the supply of essentials.”

Title: Man detained for alleged murder of daughters
Content:
Madurai: Police have detained a 36-year-old man who allegedly murdered both his daughters by throwing them into a well at Kovilpatti in Tuticorin district on Thursday.

According to police sources, Devikumar, a resident of Iluppaiurani near Kovilpatti was married to Mahalakshmi, 32. The couple had two daughters Shaini Jayasathya, 11 and Jesika Rani, 9, who were studying Class V and Class III respectively.

Devikumar was working as a broker and used to get driving licences for people. He had borrowed money from several people and was allegedly facing problems as they started demanding the money back. Frustrated by this, Devikumar reportedly took his daughters to a well situated at Sattur road and threw them inside on Thursday morning. The girls, who did not know swimming died after drowning inside the water. Police officials who rushed to the spot conducted investigations. The fire and rescue services personnel recovered the bodies after nearly four hours.The police who have detained Devikumar are conducting further investigations with him. TNN

Title: Private ambulance driver rues ‘mistreatment’ by cops, seeks clarification
Content:
Bareilly: A driver of a private ambulance, which was carrying a patient, narrated his difficulties in a video message in which he claimed that policemen stopped him from going from Ekata colony to Double Fatak in Moradabad on Thursday.

The driver further said that cops strictly warned him of dire consequences if he was seen driving on the road again.

“There should be a clarification on whether we should drive our ambulance or not. We are ready to cooperate with the police. People, like me, are here only for emergency work but the way we are being treated is disappointing,” he said, adding that the patient belonged to Civil Lines area.

“I showed them [the police] the patient’s medical documents. However, the police officer on duty asked me not to drive on this road again. Now, please make it clear, whether I should continue my emergency work or not,” he further said.

Responding to the video, additional superintendent of police (city) Amit Kumar Anand said that all emergency services are allowed to function.

“This is the first time we are experiencing such a lockdown and nobody was fully prepared for it. Even some policemen are not quite sure while differentiating between lockdown and curfew. In curfew, it is clear that all movement would be stopped but in a situation like this, there are some restrictions and some relaxations,” the police officer said.

Title: UP cops aid pregnant woman, ensure hubby is by her side after baby’s birth
Content:
Bareilly: At a time when police are busy enforcing the lockdown due to coronavirus, they came to the aid of a nine-month pregnant woman who was alone at her house here in Bareilly as her husband was stuck in Noida. They admitted her to hospital, where she delivered a healthy baby, her first. They also got in touch with their counterparts in Noida and arranged a taxi to ferry her husband to Bareilly.

The woman has expressed her gratitude on Twitter, thanking UP Police, specially SSP, Bareilly, Shailesh Pandey, and additional DCP, Noida, Kumar Ranvijay Singh for their help. The woman said local police acted like her guardian angles coming to her aid when she thought that she going to die alone as she went into labour. Not only did they take her to hospital but soon after delivering her baby, her joy knew no bounds on seeing her husband by her side.

The woman, Tamanna, is a 25-year-old a resident of Izzatnagar area of Bareilly district, was expecting her first baby when her husband, Anees Khan, who works in Noida, got stuck there due to the lockdown. As the time for her delivery drew nearer, Tamanna, who lives alone, was frightened without his support.

With no one to help her, she sent a video message to police, seeking their help. To her surprise, police promptly responded and ensured that Tamanna was admitted to hospital and made arrangements to bring Anees home.

Shailesh Pandey, SSP Bareilly, said, “UP Police is trying to make sure that assistance is provided to everyone in need of support. This woman was. We are happy that we managed to bring smile on the face of a family during this challenging time.”

Title: Lockdown good, but we need to develop medicine: AIIMS director
Content:
Bhopal: Lockdown is a measure to suppress and stop the transmission of Covid-19. However, by itself, it will not ward off the epidemic, said AIIMS, Bhopal director Dr Sarman Singh, here on Thursday.

“Buying time (through lockdown) will not help the epidemic die down on its own until the young population is allowed to get infected as is being done in the United Kingdom. However, it will help to experiment or develop medicine and vaccine,” he said. Every country can frame strategies to mitigate trans-border spread of the infection, as India intends to by lockdown, he added.

Dr Singh echoed World Health Organisation (WHO)’s Director-General, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus’s warning .“Last thing any country needs is to reopen schools and businesses only to be forced to close them again because of resurgence,” Ghebreyesus had said on Wednesday.

“We failed to learn from Covid-19 (experiences) beyond our borders. We should have not seen this day, and I foresee even worst of it. Still, the epidemic can be controlled, by hand hygiene, social distancing and isolation…..isolation,” said Dr Singh.

Little over eight years since AIIMS Bhopal began, the institute is faced with its greatest challenge yet. “We are trying to mitigate limitations,” Dr Singh explained. “Except for scarcity of Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) we have workable stock of other accessories,” he added.

As of now, AIIMS has around 80 isolation beds, six ICU beds and four of these are with negative pressure. These are needed when the patient is critical and excreting a large quantity of virus, said Dr Singh. To control or even slow down the epidemic in India, we all must adhere to the advisory of lockdown as suggested by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Dr Singh said.

“Even the highly educated have failed to understand the need for 24-hour Janata curfew,” he said.

Title: Helpline for supply of essential items set up
Content: Gandhinagar:A control room and helpline to facilitate the supply of essential items such as milk, fruits and vegetables has been made functional in Gandhinagar. A helpline has been also been set up where where people can call and seek information about the availability of essential commodities.Secretary to the chief minister, Ashwini Kumar, said, “The control room will be operational 24x7 and people can seek assistance about availing of essential commodities by dialing1070 and 079-23251900.”Kumar said 59,000 quintals of vegetables arrived at various markets on Thursday morning. “13,655 quintals of potatoes, 4,350 quintals of onions, 6,900 quintals of tomatoes, and 34,000 quintals of green vegetables have been made available,” a government statement said. There are around 68 vegetable markets in the state. In addition to vegetables, 610 quintals of bananas, 670 quintals of apples and 1,100 quintals of other fruits have been made available on Thursday.The government added that 55 lakh litres of milk is being sold every day.

Title: Kerala scales up Covid-19 testing
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala, which has recorded 138 Covid cases so far, is going by the words of World Health Organization WHO ) chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus as it has accelerated testing process considerably, especially in the past two weeks. At NIV Alappuzha , the number of samples being handled a day has increased by four times in the past one week. Along with three other states, Kerala has the highest number of government approved laboratories — eight.In the first 10 days of March, the state tested 691 samples and in the next 14 days, the testing spiked to 3,723 samples. As cases began to turn positive, the number of people who were brought under surveillance rose from 3,313 to 1.02 lakh in just two weeks, preventing exposure of a large section of society to symptomatic persons as well as those under observation.Speedy results from multiple facilities have so far enabled three crucial steps in containment; identifying primary contacts, tracking possibilities of infection followed by isolation and monitoring.“Only if we do tests, we would know the sources of infection which could enable us to initiate steps for containment. The faster you do it, the better, especially considering that exposure of immuno-suppressed persons to infected persons could lead to an uncontrollable spread. Early testing helps us in quicker isolation steps,” a health official saidEquipped with eight testing facilities across the state, and awaiting one more, and having to deal with samples from 13 Covid-affected districts, the health department has prepared a sample distribution channel (SDC) to facilitate sample collection and arrival at testing facilities in minimum time across a larger network. When Covid cases were confirmed in Pathanamthitta after a brief silent period of the first series of outbreak, health authorities realized that speed in detecting positive cases mattered in containing the spread.Earlier, samples from all districts were pooled in at Ernakulam and then transported to Kalamassery Medical college from where it airlifted to Pune. On February 2, the testing began at NIV, Alappuzha. As case load surged, testing was initiated at Medical colleges in Kozhikode, Thiruvananthapuram and Thrissur. In the meantime, the authorities pushed proposals for Covid testing facilities at Rajiv Gandhi Center for Biotechnology, Thiruvanathapuram, Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute of Medical Sciences, Thiruvanathapuram, State Public Health Laboratory, Thiruvanathapuram and Interuniversity, Kottayam.The health department has also put in place a system for self-manufacture of viral transport medium (VTM) which is crucial in the process of transportation of samples. In addition, the government is set to procure PCR machines for medical colleges in Ernakulam, Kottayam, Pariyaram, and Parippally and once the machines are installed, proposal would be sent to ICMR for starting Covid testing facility in these places as well.NIV Alappuzha has consistently handled around 150 samples a day for the past one week. The machine can load 96 samples at a time and the initial RNA isolation process takes 1.5 hours for around 24 samples.

Title: Sibling fights? Here is how you can manage fighting kids this lockdown
Content: With the world under coronavirus induced lockdown, families have been forced to be stuck at home with each other. Being under one roof 24X7, especially during such stressful times can cause fights among family members. Family members might start feeling irritated and grumpy. This is true especially if you have children. Siblings tend to fight a lot on a normal day. With the added tension of the pandemic and the struggle of sharing a living space with your sibling for a long time, they might end up fighting even more.This might get to the parents’ nerves and force them to react harshly. Instead of cooling the situation down, this might just add to the tension in the household. Here are a few ways that can help you manage your kids if they are fighting or irritated.It is true that kids do tend to mirror their parent’s behaviour. Therefore, many times if parents are fighting, kids might too. The tension in the household might be coming from you and you might not even know it. Which is why it is important to keep a check on how you feel as well. It does not mean that you only need to keep yourself physically fit but also emotionally fit. To keep your kids from festering any negative feelings, make sure that you do not ooze of anxiety yourself.The most likely answer to your child being irritated and angry is that they are stressed. Children do not have the same inner resources to handle stress as adults do. It is important that you initiate a conversation with them as they might be reluctant to do so. They might be scared of the way you would react to their feelings. They often anticipate that their parents would react harshly in situations like these. It is your responsibility to build an environment where your kids can talk about how they feel. Be honest about the seriousness of the pandemic but also give them a sense of hope and calm.Even if your children do fight every now and then, it is important that they make up and not leave the tension looming in the air. Here is how you, as parents, help them reconcile.– You need to take time out of your routine, even if you are working from home, to help your children when they need you. Sometimes, having the undivided attention of a parent helps them cope with their own stress. You can take this time to understand why your children are fighting and find a solution.– Ensure that your kids reconcile properly if they have a fight. Make them use statements like “I did not like you taking this out of my cupboard” rather than “You did so and so”. This will teach them a healthier way to resolve conflict.– In times like these, it is important for everyone to have patience. Make sure that your kids do not fight over something that happened a few days or weeks ago. It creates unnecessary feelings of negativity which at detrimental to their health, especially during such trying times.

Title: Sale of petrol, diesel down
Content:
Surat: The South Gujarat Petrol Pump Dealers Association (SGPPDA) office-bearers stated that the sale of petrol and diesel has gone down by 85% as residents are staying indoors due to lockdown.

President of SGPPDA, Suresh Desai told TOI, “All the petrol pump owners in Surat and south Gujarat are operating their pumps from 7 am to 7pm, but we are getting less numbers of customers due to the lockdown. Majority of our customers are government vehicles on duty.”

According to Desai, there are 60 petrol pumps in Surat city about 700 pumps across the South Gujarat region. TNN

Title: I thought my life will end, says 4th Covid-19 patient
Content: Nagpur: The fourth Covid-19 positive patient is hoping to reunite with his family in the next two to three days after all his tests turned out to be negative. However, the world came crashing down for this professional working with an IT he was detected with the virus.He was so upset that he thought it would be the end of his life after reading reports of deaths in China and European countries. He even called on his close friend and disclosed all investments he had made. After being in the isolation ward for 12 days, he now says his perspective towards life has changed completely. In an exclusive tête-à-tête with TOI, he shared his experience from being traumatic initially to a change that he termed as “second life”.Excerpts:How it all began?I was part of the team from same IT company that went to the US. We were four of which two fell sick. When our first colleague tested positive, second one, who was sick, pushed me to check my swab samples. In fact, the second one’s test came out to be negative. I went there very casually as I was completely fit with no cold, cough or fever. But when my test came out positive, it was the biggest shock of my life since corona’s name is synonymous with death.What was your reaction?I was completely shattered and didn’t know what to do. I sat with my head down for half an hour thinking was it the end of my world? I then called up a close friend and told him to open an excel file on my laptop where I had all the files of my investments. I told him the password and advised him to pass it on to my parents in case something drastic happens. I wasn’t able to sleep properly for the first couple of days due to tension.How you are spending time in isolation?Initially, it was bit difficult, but later I adjusted my schedule and made a timetable. I keep myself busy on phone and talking to my sister along with my parents, friends and relatives. I keep watching inspirational videos on YouTube and talking to some of the monks of Ram Krishna Math, who also kept my spirits high.What has changed in the last 12 days?Truly speaking, it was roller coaster ride for me in this short span. This stay at isolation has changed my entire perspective towards life. Before coming here, I was content with my career growth like normal humans. It included high profile job in an IT company and career growth that I thought were the milestones. But, now I realized that these are not objectives of the life. I came back from the 2% of people from the world who were infected with the deadly virus which opened my eyes in a real sense. Now, I want to contribute towards betterment of the society in whatever way I can.How are the facilities and doctors at GMCH?Usually, we tend to blame the government for poor facilities, but now only its manpower is working while taking all the risks to treat patients like us. They’re in fact lifesavers and I want to express my gratitude to them, including Dr Gosavi and his team of doctors and nurses. Even the staff here deserves appreciation, as they clean and disinfect our rooms thrice. I would rather say that they’re no less than soldiers, who guard our borders. I will carry this experience throughout my life.Any bitter experience?After the list of quarantine patients was leaked, me and my family faced numerous problems as it contained my name. Me and my family received numerous calls and I had to literally tell them a lie that I was under isolation due to fear of social stigma. It was a very painful experience. It was kind of hypocrisy of the people who on one hand avoid helping out with the positive patients and families, but on other hand blindly forward such lists without thinking of implications on the persons named there.

Title: Lockdown violations rampant in slums, cops to counsel people
Content:
Nagpur: The movement of citizens on the roads, with or without vehicles, has left many disappointed in the backdrop of the national lockdown over coronavirus, even as the city witnessed its fifth positive case getting registered on Thursday.

District guardian minister Nitin Raut, who inspected Mayo Hospital and Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), said preparations are being expedited to put in place special facilities. “We are soon going to have a special 250-bed special ward for Covid-19, and another 1,200-1,300-bedded facility at GMCH, which will have 50% reserved for intensive care units,” he said.

Raut, who expressed dismay at the fifth positive patient in the city, said the health team had done well to send one earlier patient home fit and fine. “I have already sanctioned Rs25 crore to set up infrastructure to fight Covid-19 in the district, in addition to Rs7 crore for the rural areas,” said the guardian minister.

Raut expressed satisfaction with the existing facilities of treating Covid-19 patients and suspects at government hospitals but said there is scope for improvement, which too would be a reality soon.

Raut also said people had started queuing up at grocery shops and such other outlets of essential commodities after the announcement by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, but their fears have been allayed now. “We are stressing on social distancing now, especially at shops and other places,” he said.

With slums left grossly unattended by authorities, including police, the fear of community infection spreading there seems to be high among the more aware citizens, since the unaware lot are venturing out and mingling, violating all orders.

At slums like Naik Talao, Pandhrabodi, Futala Nayi Vasti and such places, people were spotted socializing and gathering. There are also reports of liquor being available at such places at higher rates.

Mamta Sharma, a teacher from Hiwre Layout, said the streets are occupied by loitering people, cyclists and bikers despite prohibitory orders, which is causing distress to people like her who are aware about the dangerous situation. “Twice I had to call police and again NMC control room. They just come for temporary rounds,” she said, demanding permanent deployment at Wathoda Road and Quetta Colony.

Sandesh Singalkar, Congress spokesperson, too said the lack of awareness is causing problems in East Nagpur , where public seems to be taking the Covid-19 threat casually. “Public is coming out, gathering at different places, socializing and remaining out of their homes causing much fear of infection spread,” he said. Singalkar wanted the government to pronounce it’s policies in more clear terms to remove all confusion.

East Nagpur MLA Krishna Khopde said daily wagers are coming onto the streets and can be found more in slums and areas where the economically weaker community reside. “With the Central government under PM Modi having detailed sops for daily wagers, they are likely to remain inside homes now. I am constantly communicating with my supporters and party office-bearers, and accordingly sharing feedback and alerting authorities regarding issues cropping up,” said Khopde.

“People need to understand and cooperate as a pandemic like Covid-19 will not go away unless they join us in our fight,” said Khopde.

City police, on Thursday, detained 76 persons, registered three offences against violators, and slapped penalties at nakabandis against 171 persons. Around 4,732 passes were also distributed to citizens at different police stations for emergency movement.

City police chief BK Upadhyay said the police would now try to create awareness among citizens in slums. “We will make announcements through our public address systems in the slums and interior lanes,” he said.

Title: ‘Policemen told not to use force against citizens’
Content: Overall, what role is the police set to play in the coming days to enforce section 144?We are focusing on two aspects, which is restriction of movement and ensuring availability of essential services. People should not come on the road unnecessarily and cooperate with police and administration as it is a period of grave concern due to the pandemic Covid-19. Police are just trying to ensure that maximum people stay at home and do not come on the streets with or without vehicles.Still many people can be seen on the roads despite police presence?People are coming on the roads only to avail essential and emergency services. Almost 99.9% people are inside homes and not stepping out. Essential commodities and emergency services also have their chains, where substantial people are engaged, whom we cannot stop or else the network would be broken and availability will be affected. There are a number of employees or workers behind each service, and chains that need to be on the roads to help these networks remain functional.
